name: Martina WERNER
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Please allow me to make a brief comment in advance. I would have liked to have welcomed the Commissioner responsible, Mrs Bie-kowska, or Vice-President Katainen. Nevertheless, I hope that they will take our demand very seriously for an industry on which several hundred thousand jobs in Europe depend. And now to the actual topic. China is practicing thought games to develop a train link under the Bering Strait to the US, While Google is sending self-driving cars through the desert. And it takes Europe two years to organise the Shift to Rail research programme. I know that I am provosting a little. Nevertheless, a structural problem for the European railway industry is becoming clear here. On the one hand, Asian companies – primarily the Chinese rail technology giant CRRC – are benefiting from huge economies of scale and a tough industrial policy strategy in China that is geared toward expansion. On the other hand, other areas of mobility, such as aviation and the automotive sector, are pushing ahead and innovating much faster than the railways. It is against this background that this initiative, which we are discussing today, must be seen. Please do not misunderstand me: the European rail industry is strong – the world market share is 46%, the sector employs 400 000 people across Europe, and it is looking forward to market growth of an average of 2.8% by 2019. However, a strong and innovative railway industry is not only in the interests of European employees and companies – COP21 demands and requires an ambitious climate policy. For this purpose, the change to the rail is essential. Low-emission e-mobility has long been a reality there. And for this change, it is fundamentally irrelevant whether the technology comes from Europe or not. The first tram with fuel cell drive may not come from Salzgitter, but from Changchun. Many rail operators are quite unemotional about this. I can't do that. Railway technology has been developed in my constituency in north and east Hesse for 150 years. In the West Midlands in the UK, Valenciennes in France, Olomouc in the Czech Republic, Pistoia in Italy and many other locations, this sector is similarly developed. During factory visits, I spoke to many employees who drive fantastic innovations. For them, we need to ensure that the industry thrives from the big system integrators to the numerous suppliers. That is why it is my position to set the right course from the position of strength in order to be able to carry out the shift to rail with a strong European rail industry behind us. In the steel industry, the right framework conditions were not set in good time. It is now in an existential crisis. It is essential that we avoid this mistake in the rail industry. It must not become steel industry 2.0. The resolution specifically looks at improving the market environment for the railway industry in order to enable industrial growth and new jobs. The content now in a nutshell: First, we want the rapid implementation of Shift to Rail. At the same time, it would also be important to allow research funding explicitly for railway technology outside the joint venture. Secondly, SMEs often depend on a dominant provider. They need more support to internationalise. Thirdly, for small businesses in particular, the fragmentation of the European rail market is an obstacle. The completion of the Gotthard Base Tunnel last week is of great symbolic importance. Rail transport must be thought of across borders. Fourthly, a hugely important point is that, unfortunately, investment is not available in many places. Projects to purchase trains in Italy and build infrastructure in Spain have proven that the EFSI can be helpful – more of them! In addition, the Member States must finally make full use of all the resources available for railway projects through the CEF and the Structural Funds. Fifthly, we want the EU procurement pact to be implemented quickly, with a focus on life-cycle costs. One final demand, ladies and gentlemen, is particularly close to my heart, and I would ask you, Commissioner: please pass this on to Mrs Bie kowska: present an EU industrial strategy! The horizontal approach that you are promoting makes sense, but we still need a communication that sets out coherently how you intend to achieve the 20% target and what role strategically important sectors such as the railway industry play in this. Love Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I hope you will support the railway industry!

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am here today on behalf of my dear colleague Commissioner Bieńkowska to talk about one of the industries that best represents the pioneering spirit of the Europeans: the railway sector, and in particular the manufacturers of trains. The improvement of EU industrial competitiveness is a major objective of our policy. This applies in particular to the rail supply industry, where the European Union is a world leader. Let me address your specific questions.  Firstly, on the Shift 2 Rail (S2R) joint technology initiative, the set-up of the Shift 2 Rail joint undertaking has been rather fast compared to previous joint undertakings. It launched its first call for proposals in December 2015. Fifty-six project proposals were received. The grants for the selected projects will be signed this autumn at the latest. The Commission is particularly attentive to SME participation. We are satisfied that one quarter of the more than 450 applicants to the first call for proposals are SMEs. The Commission will ensure the internal coordination of the different EU funding instruments. We will investigate in particular the possible use of European Structural and Investment funds and the European Fund for Strategic Investments for future Shift 2 Rail deployment activities.  Secondly, on SMEs, the areas identified as most important in the consultation on the Small Business Act in 2014 are in fact covered by the Commission’s main initiatives. For this reason, rather than presenting a separate SME policy initiative, we concentrate on ensuring that the SME policy is mainstreamed in all relevant Commission policies, notably the Better Regulation Agenda, the Capital Market Union, the Trade for All strategy and the Single Market Strategy.  Several actions have been taken by the Commission in the priority initiatives mentioned above: the Start-up Initiative, reduction of administrative burden, access to finance and access to the markets. Through the European Semester the Commission pushes for structural reforms in Member States to improve the business environment. Last but not least, the Commission promotes entrepreneurship through the COSME programme and through the European Structural and Investment Funds.  Thirdly, on rail equipment, the efficient and quick implementation of the Fourth Railway Package will be of great value for the rail industry. The package will help European rail manufacturers thrive globally by improving the authorisation process in the EU and by removing the remaining barriers that hamper market access. These will help bring new investments and innovation into the sector and thus contribute to its competitiveness.  The ambitious public-private partnership Shift 2 Rail will be the suitable instrument to provide the rail sector with better attractiveness and competitiveness. Among others, Shift 2 Rail will contribute to: cutting the life-cycle cost of railway transport by as much as 50%; doubling railway capacity; increasing reliability and punctuality by as much as 50%.  Fourthly, on the international dimension of the industry, China has become an exporter of railway equipment in particular to the developing world. The Commission is in continuous dialogue with the Chinese authorities. We are requesting the inclusion of state-owned enterprises operating in the utilities sector in China’s offer in the context of the WTO negotiations. The accession of China to the Agreement on Government Procurement will be an important step to ensure the application of transparent and non-discriminatory rules in procurement procedures. China is reluctant to include important state-owned enterprises, as it claims that its internal reform has first to be accomplished.  Progress in the area of rail procurement is one of the Commission’s key priorities in the Free Trade Agreement negotiations with Japan. Public procurement discussions with the United States continue without clear progress. Strategic partnership and alliances to improve competitiveness, as promoted in the question, are not as such prohibited under EU competition law. The Commission has published extensive guidance documents for companies to set up cooperation agreements that are in full compliance with competition rules.  Fifthly, on industrial policy – the Connecting Europe Facility, maintaining the technological advanced position of Europe is key to retaining its huge competitive position, production and jobs in Europe. In addition to the already mentioned programmes, through the Trans-European Networks (Transport) and the Connecting Europe Facility funding mechanisms we inject EUR 24 billion in EU transport infrastructure. The vast majority of Connecting Europe Facility funding will be for major cross-border projects and projects addressing main bottlenecks on the 9 TEN-T multimodal Core Network Corridors. It will also be a key funding instrument to help deploy the European Railway Traffic Management System throughout Europe. 75% of the Connecting Europe Facility funding goes to rail projects. We want the European rail supply industry to remain an important contributor to EU employment and the economy. European companies have the know-how and the competitiveness capabilities to remain leaders in the world market. On our side we will continue to provide the framework conditions to preserve and improve their competitive position.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, first of all, let me be offended to see that the Commissioner for Industry is not on the bench of the European Commissioners this morning, for a debate which is absolutely essential because it deals with the strategic area for the European Union that constitutes the railway industry. Nearly 400,000 jobs are affected, 1,200,000 jobs indirectly, in this absolutely strategic industry and the Commissioner is not there... She had already indicated her absence on 22 April in Warsaw, where she was also not present, despite the fact that it was her country, at a strategic meeting also, which brought together the friends of the industry in Warsaw in the presence of the ministers in charge of this sector. Commissioner, I have obviously listened very carefully to you. The groups here , and I welcome the work done by Martina Werner as rapporteur on this subject, have worked together a lot and reached compromise agreements. We are asking you an oral question, and I thought you were extremely light on the unfair competition our rail industry faces with respect to China. Today, in China, the railway industry is totally infused with public money. When China manufactures 200 TGVs annually, in France, at Alstom, we manufacture 13. Therefore, it is clear that china is now easily entering the European market, but we are having a hard time having the same competition, and unfair competition today is a big issue for the Railway industry in the European Union.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Werner has explained very well the key points of our question and also the reasons why we sounded the alarm to the Commission. So I say to you quite frankly, Commissioner, that over and above the individual answers, all of which are valid, what we are asking for and what is lacking – but the interlocutor would be another Commissioner or a Vice-President – is an industrial strategy, a strategy of mobility, a strategy of environmental sustainability that, around all the manufacture of the railway sector, hypocrites what vision Europe has and what it wants to do. It is a sector that reaches almost 50 % of the world's railway industry today, it is also a leader in some places for innovation – Martina pointed them out – but if Europe does not implement a strategy, we will see either the gradual decline of this important sector or the presence of other international operators from outside Europe who will certainly see our European record lost. So, when I say a strategy, I mean an action that brings all these aspects together, because the sector is the mechanical engineering sector, there is a lot of engineering, there is telecommunications, there are all the possible digital applications. There is a whole aspect of connection with SMEs, as well as with large companies. And if this sector is not strategic, I wonder which others, for the European industry that we would like to relaunch. But we have the impression that the Commission is not clear about this objective of reviving European industry. I will mention just two important aspects: shitf to rail, which I promoted together with other Members in the last parliamentary term but which goes too slowly, and investment, the ESFI, which you mentioned.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: on the ecr group. – Madam President, Commissioner, we see that our traditional industry, which employs many people, is facing problems, which is why I like the title of the report, it describes exactly what we are talking about. Competitors are pushing us out in the world and now they are coming to Europe. This must be reflected, in particular, in the context of the debate on granting market economy status to China. If our industry is to remain competitive, we need to improve the environment, make better use of the financial instruments at our disposal. We have an important Shift2Rail programme from Horizon 2020 and I am glad that great emphasis is placed on small and medium-sized enterprises in particular. Finally, we have taken the first step towards stimulating demand directly in Europe: mainly thanks to the trans-European networks and the CEF programme, but of course our rail network needs further investment. If we look at the map, I think we should also pay more attention to the potential of high-speed lines for Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, with 46% of the innovation market at the forefront, it has been said, Europe is still the world leader at the moment, but for how long? The challenges we face are known: - stagnation or even recoil of rail in the face of other modes of transport - and I think that unfortunately the political pillar of the fourth rail package is not going to make things better; - weak public order;  - difficulties in accessing research funding for SMEs; - the rise of third countries - Mrs Morano reiterated how much China was in a situation of concern.  It is therefore necessary, in this context, to make every effort to revitalise this sector through investment, for example - but not exclusively - through the Juncker plan. It is also desirable to create a regulatory environment favourable to these investments: defragmentation of the internal market, concrete implementation of the agreement reached at COP 21 and, perhaps also, revision of the rules governing the procurement of public contracts. There is also a need to boost the participation of SMEs in the European research programme; my colleagues have previously mentioned the difficulties of Shift 2 Rail. Commissioner, I congratulate you on the start-up of Shift 2 Rail. It took a year to make the first call for projects, which is purely outrageous, and we are now, in fact, more than eighteen months behind schedule. Finally, the principle of reciprocity with respect to third countries must be ensured to be absolutely respected. Of course, Japan, China, Korea and the United States are still in a situation where their markets are closed to us, while they are making great efforts to penetrate ours. Together, the companies involved must take their full part in this global struggle. I personally support the Airbus of rail, the restructuring of the industry and the major European manufacturers and, as such, the commission's permission to authorise the emergence of great European champions against the world champions by reducing its competition law.

name: João FERREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, suddenly everyone is talking about the need to reindustrialise Europe. Today there is talk of the railway equipment industry. But there is one thing that always seems forgotten by some of the speakers in this debate: it is that if we are talking about reindustrialising today, it is because there has been a deindustrialisation before.  And let's start here! This deindustrialization had causes and had responsible. It would be, at the very least, unintelligent to try so-called reindustrialisation with the same policies and guidelines that led to deindustrialisation. In fact, it is the liberalisation and privatisation strategies that are at the root of the sector's decline in several Member States that have led to the dismantling of many production units in europe outside, which have promoted monopolistic concentration and led to the dismissal of thousands of workers.  Remember this when you regret the lack of skilled workers in the sector. It's just that they already existed. Now they want a European policy tailored to the major European groups in the sector, to colonise what remains of national markets, to which successive railway packages and European public procurement rules contribute and making life easier for these European colossi in international competition to colonise other markets around the world.  This is not our way and we have made it clear in the amendments we have tabled to this resolution. The defence of the European railway industry requires a strong public role and investment. I will end, Madam President, a regulatory framework that prevents the race to the bottom in the work of wages and workers' rights and fosters the exploitation of the potential of each country (the speaker is removed)

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to begin by thanking Mrs Werner as rapporteur and all my fellow Members for their good cooperation. It is not difficult to understand why this is an important issue. It is not just a question of many jobs – as has already been pointed out – but of an industry that must be a necessary partner for the indispensable transformation of our economies in a green direction. Indeed, as Mrs Werner said, we need our own European industrial strategy in response to the tough industrial policy that others are making. China's tough industrial policy, for example, is reflected in the widespread unfair restrictions on access for European competitors. I am astonished at the fact that the Commissioner for Industry, Mrs Bie-kowska, is missing here. It does not have many opportunities to shine. Why does it not take the opportunity to make it clear that the Commission is taking the matter seriously? The previous Commission was already further ahead in industrial policy than the Juncker Commission is. The industrial strategy must become a priority. But industrial policy does not mean "more and more access to more and more public pots." Industrial policy means changing competition law, correcting merger control in Europe that is too narrow, but also making greater eye-catching the world market. For example, our competition watchdogs simply did not look at the merger to form a Chinese rail giant. That cannot remain the case! I hope that the House will decide accordingly.

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating a crucial sector of our industry that employs so many European citizens. The European railway industry accounts for 46 % of the world market and we cannot risk losing this market and hundreds of jobs as a result of unfair competition. On the contrary, this sector, through technological innovation and digitalisation, must become a driving force for the creation of new jobs. In order for this to happen, however, it is necessary to have clear priorities at european industrial policy level and we must first of all work well within ourselves, where the rules must be respected and there is clearly a need for greater transparency and an exchange of ex ante information on public procurement. If the number one danger, in this sector as in so many others, is called China, we cannot let China build the Budapest-Belgrade high-speed railway, without transparency. Of course, in this area too, the possible recognition of the ES MES to China would have a very serious impact. We have the technologies and we have the know-how. We must demand and ensure that the principle of reciprocity and symmetrical access to third markets is respected. In the coming years, railway infrastructure in America, Africa and Asia will be strengthened. The European Commission must design a strong and coordinated industrial policy that will enable European companies to be protagonists in these markets. The rapporteur, Mrs Werner, has done an excellent job. The European Parliament has drawn attention to a crucial sector of European manufacturing industry, but now action is needed, coordinated political decisions and concrete action by the European Commission are needed quickly.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Mr Werner's report deals with a key sector of industry in our countries, France and Europe, namely rail.   This sector, which is particularly essential for employment, is in difficulty because of the destruction of a public monopoly present in our countries. You want to open up our public sectors to all the winds of globalization in free and undistorted competition. However, Canada, South Korea and tomorrow China, which have kept their public service, will win contracts on our continent in the name of that competition. Competition distorted by these sovereign countries which already use all the weapons in their possession to deny us access to their market.  Moreover, your policy of unilateral sanctions against Russia calls into question rail projects that could benefit European companies. Finally, the promotion of the organization "Shift 2 Rail" in this motion goes against the European railway, because in this group of so-called European industrialists, we find Bombardier, a Canadian industrialist, which is the first competitor of our European champions Siemens and Alstom on the world markets. Who are we kidding?  Only a synergy between rail equipment manufacturers and European national operators will offer future customers competitive rail projects and you are destroying this synergy.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).)

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: blue-card question. – You just mentioned Bombardier and called it a Canadian consortium. But as far as I know, Bombardier is providing a very high number of good European jobs in the rail sector. So are you advocating that we now turn different European rail companies against each other instead of combining efforts?

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: "blue card" answer. "No, sir, there is no question of competing with European companies. It is simply a question of promoting and favouring European companies such as Alstom and Siemens. That's all. That is the only point I made in my speech.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The European rail supply sector spans a broad industrial spectrum, as in addition to the production of locomotives and wagons, it includes all track infrastructure, electricity supply, signalling and safety equipment. It has a major role to play, as it has a Community role and indirectly one million jobs are linked to the entire rail sector. We really need to maintain the competitiveness of this sector, but when we talk about global competition, we are thinking primarily about how it will be possible outside the EUROPEAN Union market, on the global market. In fact, the task is much more serious because the EU market is part of the global market and this is where opportunities should be preserved. Because while the Union is largely open to competitors from third countries, they have imposed restrictive measures and, moreover, chinese competitors are able to grant unsencumbed State aid in the first place.  Hungary also signed a contract with a Chinese investor for the Budapest-Belgrade railway line for Hungary worth EUR 1.5 billion. This is indeed a large amount, and it is understandable that it is not financed by the budget, but hungarian and EU supplies have not been published, and analysts say that, in fact, China will support its own industry with this loan. In this situation, it's not such a rosy decision anymore.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Commissioner, i would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur The rail industry in Europe is now a gold medalist and is the world leader. But we know that one thing in sport is to reach the top, the other is to hold positions, because all the time there are new competitors who train and want to beat the leader. Our rail sector, which currently employs around four hundred thousand people across Europe, is indeed a world leader compared to all the other economies, but we are experiencing a great deal of competition, especially now, on the Chinese side, and that is why we have serious questions about state aid. We know that these issues are, and that is a challenge for us. Now what can we do to strengthen this sector? What are its drawbacks? One of the disadvantages is that this sector, although strong, is still slightly s split across the various Member States. So, Commissioner, I would call on the Commission to do three things, namely to set up a high-level coordination group that would identify best practices in the rail sector, to improve standardisation and to promote partnership so that we become even stronger. This is our leader, we are champions. We need to keep this position in coordination.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, yesterday the balance sheet of the first year of implementation of the European Strategic Investment Fund was discussed in this House. A disappointing balance sheet, not only by insufficient mobilisation of funds, but above all by the inability to generate a boost for the European Union to take the lead in the industries of the future, in energy, digital and smart grids. The railway-associated industry is an excellent example of a sector that can and must be supported to adopt a new innovation agenda in industry 4.0. The resolution we are enjoying has a holistic and integrated vision to apply and inspire this strategy. I would like to welcome the excellent coordination work of your rapporteur, Martina Werner.  This resolution poses a clear challenge to the European institutions - increasing political support for the sector, including it in the negotiating priorities of international trade treaties, encouraging investment and creating a collaborative context, using this case as an aggregator for the publication of a Communication on europe's reindustrialisation in the framework of the digital revolution and energy transition - and also poses a challenge to national governments , regional and local authorities, businesses, knowledge centres and citizens.  We need a new innovation agenda as a key pillar for a new growth and jobs agenda for the European Union. A future-mobilizing agenda that, Commissioner, is needed now.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to join in expressing my regret at Commissioner Bieńkowska's absence. The manufacturers of rolling stock are very often one of the best business cards of the economies of the Member States, and this is certainly the case with Bydgoszcz Pesa – a company from my city. The success of this company includes many jobs, increasing rye and development expenditure and an opportunity for many small and medium-sized companies gathered around it. When planning to reindustrialise the European economy, we cannot ignore the potential of the rail supply industry. Rail transport is an excellent response to the need to find an economical and energy-efficient means of transporting goods, passengers, including intercontinental. In addition to increasing investment in the European Union, we must also ensure that our producers are treated equally on non-European markets and that unfair competition for our products is combated more effectively. Only such a balanced approach will provide a stable outlook for the European rail industry in the coming years.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, first of all the competitiveness of the supply industry is about the competitiveness of the rail sector and better services for customers and passengers. I think that there are positive signs. We have progressed with the railway package. I have personally addressed the question of accessibility of the rolling stock. We have ERTMS, we have certain funds, but we need to further deploy ERTMS. We need to get away from the bottlenecks that exist. We need to dismantle barriers. We need to implement all that.  The problem, of course, that we are facing is whether European industries have the means to fit in the competitive environment: I mean accessibility of SMEs to funding, the unfair competition elsewhere. The key issue for me, though, is not that Ms Bieńkowska is not present, it is the absence of industrial policy. We do have legislative and financial instruments – ERTMS, EFSI, the Fourth Railway Package and so on, but we need to link those. We need to link those to have an industrial policy strategy and implement it.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: – Madam President, railways and related industries are an important sector of European Union industry. Perhaps in no other transport sector does the European Union take such an important position in the world.  At the end of the 20th century, there were a number of changes in the European rail supply industry that were not always positive. A number of businesses in the Czech Republic have been sold several times and some of them have been cancelled. Maintaining the eu industry's leadership in the world is an important task for the current European Commission, the European Parliament and national governments. How businesses in the sector will meet the demands of digitisation, automation and interoperability is crucial for the future.  In the short term, we probably can not do without the use of space technologies and the widest possible standardization. The right step in this direction is to deploy RTMS. Especially in recent years, we have seen a rapid onset of infrastructure development, without which the railway would lose competitiveness. Stimulating demand for industrial products is a necessary part of the European Union's reindustrialisation project.  I recommend the report, the conclusions of which I strongly support, as an incentive for further action by all those involved in rail transport. Only then can we ensure a decent place in this sector of green transport among the community-wide development plans and gain new quality jobs.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In Europe, too, environmentally friendly rail is discriminated against. Each locomotive has to pay tolls on each kilometre of the route. On the road, it is a voluntary matter for the Member States, it is usually only on motorways and a few other roads and not on all lorries. 100 per cent of the rail network is tolled, but only one per cent of the road network. In this way, the railways will have no chance in the future. Let us look at the railway network. We have wanted to bring Europe together for 30 years. But it is a patchwork, and the gaps are exactly where the borders are, because in Europe it is not the integration that is a priority, but the major projects, which may be half finished in 30 or 40 years' time. All this must change. And because mrs Werner mentioned the Gotthard Tunnel: in 1996, 20 years ago, the Lugano Treaty was concluded. Switzerland has completed the tunnel, but neither Germany nor Italy has built the access routes. This is a scandal because we are not setting priorities! This should have been a top priority for the Rotterdam-Genoa corridor, which is the most important in Europe. If we carry on like this, the railways will have no chance – either within Europe or globally.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, there are elements today which mirror last night’s debate in so far as the distorting actions of China are concerned. China is not a market economy; to propose giving it market economy status is like something out of Alice in Wonderland. Indeed the UK rail supply industry contributes over GBP 9 billion a year to the British economy; it employs over 200 000 people. But whereas the UK rail supply industry has taken a market approach, it has had a battering as others have not taken that same approach. It is estimated that just 10% of UK revenue in this sector comes from exports, compared with 20% in France and 50% in Germany. I would also say that we need to develop a more skilled workforce in the UK, where we need to do better in terms of technology, in terms of research and development, as we move towards the future. Indeed, just 1 in 6 people working in this sector at present have level 4 qualifications in a relevant area. So it is estimated that thousands of highly-skilled jobs are needed, and do you know what? This is something that is a perfect example of why we need proper skilled immigration through a points-based system, as opposed to a free-for-all.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, railway equipment is an essential sector of the industry in France and Europe. This sector is in difficulty because of the destruction of a public monopoly present in our countries. The European Union wants to open up the public sector to all the winds of globalisation in the name of supposedly free and undistorted competition. The result is that Canada, China and South Korea will take the opportunity to come and win markets on our continent while denying our companies access to their markets. Our European champions Siemens and Alstom will therefore be penalised.  If we want to develop our railway industries, we must adopt a proactive policy and not rely solely on the market. In contrast to the ultra-liberal laissez-faire of the Union, it is necessary to create a synergy between european railway equipment manufacturers and national operators in order to offer our future customers competitive rail projects. Hundreds of thousands of jobs are at stake. There is an urgent need to open our eyes if we want to save them, but I know that the Union will not be able to do so.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: First of all, I would like to thank the colleagues of ITRE and Mrs Werner in particular for putting this item on the agenda of the plenary today. We are indeed talking about one of the most innovative sectors of European industry 4.0.  But we have to note that just blaming China does not help. Europe is too slow. Everything the Commissioner has said is true, but the world of competition is much tougher than the European Commission seems to realise. He mentioned Shift2Rail and the tenders in December 2015. Before that, we had to wait two years for new management at Shift2Rail, which is too long.  Another point is the trade treaties. It's not just about China, it's about Japan. These negotiations are taking too long to keep the European rail sector in the picture. You know that the Chinese competition opened an office in Budapest last week. We all know what's going to happen next. So the central message is: European Commission, be faster and more accurate.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: Madam President, the European rail industry is a world leader. It accounts for 46% of the market and 400,000 direct jobs in Europe. But while we are talking about rail and rolling stock, it must be said, the time has come to sound the alarm. Our position is under threat. To be convinced, one only has to look at the Chinese giants CRRC for rolling stock and CRCC for rail infrastructure. This penetration already affects European lines such as Belgrade-Budapest, whose conditions for awarding public contracts have been more than opaque. Martina Werner's work is therefore timely to shake the coconut tree and put on the table a series of tracks that, put end to end, draw a real sectoral industrial policy. An industrial policy which, by the way, has been absent for this sector as for others long absent from the European radar, for example in terms of research and development, concerning the joint venture Shift 2 Rail, standardisation, competition policy, etc.  But these ideas, the Commission still needs to grasp them, encourage an industrial policy, defend it and defend a sector that is crucial for our economy and our jobs. In fact, where is the Commissioner defending this vital sector for our economy?

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Europe is a world leader in railway technology, a vital means of transport to achieve the objectives of the White Paper in critical aspects such as the efficient combination of modes of transport, supply integration and decarbonisation. It is also a source of employment and a quarry of innovators, and our external competitors here take advantage of the absence of a single rail space and we are increasingly having difficulty in accessing our industries to external markets. States are obliged to implement the fourth rail package with determination and without veto and to end fragmentation. And the Union, to insist on support for innovation in the sector through initiatives such as the Shift2Rail Joint Undertaking, in which Basque CAF participates, which demonstrates, on the basis of innovation, the European capacity to compete around the world. Digitization needs to be improved to increase yields and reduce energy efficiency costs and provide more attractive services for businesses and travelers. A single rail space adds value to Europe and is vital for re-industrialization and competitiveness. Commissioner, this is the challenge.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, preserving industrial employment is a minimum requirement to rebuild a productive model broken by neoliberal reforms. And more in sectors such as rail equipment, with high added value, export strength and at the heart of the transition to a more sustainable economy. Without a doubt, R&D support must be maintained and increased and its technological adaptation to the new European standards ensured. We must also continue to bet that the railway is the centre of an intermodal transport agenda, reinforcing European freight corridors and the train of medium-distance and commuter travellers. But the main threats to the sector come from neoliberal policies that many groups, which today show concern, have been supporting. The first is the liberalisation of the railway, which considerably limits the possibility of using public procurement to preserve the railway industry. Second, trade opening up to countries that practice social and environmental dumping, unfair competition that will severely harm this sector and our entire industry.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The railway industry is a strategic industry. Strong rail suppliers set global standards and are an export hit. With the CEF, we promote investment in the railways. Yes, and there is also progress in the rail package. But, all this takes far too long, and I say that to our own address. Here in Parliament, we are having technical discussions up to the age of self-indulgentness, while at the same time taking far too much account of the assets of the Member States. The Commission, too, must speed up. Keyword China: Chinese investors are buying in the Member States against the rules of competition law. Why is the Commission watching here? The anti-dumping procedures also take far too long. Many medium-sized companies simply can't stand it anymore. However, if market criteria do not play a role in China, then the Commission must also act and not run any egg egg. It must act quickly as long as we still have good rail industry in Europe.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, it was with real pride that I attended the opening of Hitachi Rail Europe’s new train production plant at Newton Aycliffe last summer in my constituency. A real success story of what we should be promoting in the North-East of England in terms of inward investment and local job creation. All credit to the local community, our local unions, County Durham’s investment team, and the local MP Phil Wilson, who worked together to attract rail production back to the very place that the very first passenger trains were built – in the world, I should stress. On Monday this week, the chairman of Hitachi made it clear that, while respecting the democratic rights of UK citizens, Brexit would force Hitachi and similar companies to re-think, because they still have a European vision and would be disadvantaged in pursuing it from the UK, meaning less investment in my region and fewer good local jobs. We urgently need a modern industrial policy and we urgently need a European Commissioner who gets it. For the European rail supply industry, today’s report sets out clearly the challenges for the sector, and I congratulate my colleague, Martina, on the report. But for British rail production and its workforce of thousands, nothing is as urgent as ensuring that we remain in the EU on 23 June.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have acquired that the railway supply industry is strategic because it is the sum of important competences. So the question is how to defend it, and that is why I congratulate the rapporteurs on this important dossier. The first issue is that the railway industry defends itself if there is rail investment. The CEF is better than EFSI in this regard, because the CEF supports long-remuneration investments better than EFSI, for which leverage is too tight. So don't take money away from the CEF.  Secondly, as far as businesses are concerned, those who are in the market must win. The market is not a strange, hyper-liberal thing at all costs. The market is a nice thing, where the state sets minimum standards and companies respect them. Those who don't meet those standards are out of the market. China is out of the market. Let us not go down in history with this Commission for forgetting about our industries, but defending them as we know how to do.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I am very happy with this resolution, and I am also happy that the rail supply industry has been explicitly recognised in the recent Joint Warsaw Declaration of the Friends of Industry as a strategic manufacturing sector for the development of Europe. Whilst I welcome the Commission’s Fourth Rail Package, we also need to ensure that the Third Rail Package is fully and properly implemented. Furthermore, I am happy to say that studies have shown that rail markets will continue to grow on all continents, and there are therefore great business opportunities to seize for European rail suppliers. However, at the same time, we see that European rail supply companies face a critical challenge to their global market leadership with industrial competition from Asia, and especially China, becoming increasingly fierce and problematically unfair. We need to be aware of this and avert the risk of job losses. Finally, I want to say that mitigation of climate change and shifting toward sustainable, energy-efficient and clean technological development of the industry will be essential for its growth. I welcome the resolution, greatly highlighting these aspects in line with COP 21.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Sincere thanks to Martini Werner for the report. Last year at the end of the year, we spent together in China, and we made sure of what the Chinese rail market looks like. In three years, they've built 180,000 miles of high-speed railways, more than 100 kilometres a week! Their plan ahead is how they will connect Shanghai and Rotterdam with the high-speed railway, because their industry has nothing to build in China anymore. I come from Slovenia, where for a decade we have been talking about how we will build 20 km of second track between Kopro and Divača, where we would open our port. And in this case, we see this huge difference, where, on the one hand, we have a national interventionist policy and, on the other, complicated European processes. I would therefore like to emphasise two things in the context of this procedure: simplify the processes, bring European industry together so that this is our Silicon Valley, and on the other hand, let the Commission look at... anti-dumping legislation stops non-market economy on European soil.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all the colleagues who support this initiative. It may seem strange, but I am glad that there is another Commissioner here, because I believe that every Commissioner speaks in his or her own language and does not connect with the projects. Commissioner, you can argue before Mr Juncker that we need reindustrialisation, that we need a strategy and that, for all the projects that the Commission generates, there must be a connection between them. The Strategic Investment Fund must be connected for railway equipment, for investment, for the railway industry. We cannot work separately and not connect these programs. Yesterday we talked late about economic diplomacy. That's what this is all about! Make, through economic diplomacy, an industrialisation strategy so that European industry can withstand globally the unfair competition created by state-subsidised industries!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, first came the railway package, which strengthens the process of privatising this vital sector in European transport, and now some are afraid of competition from Chinese and other non-European companies and are proposing measures to leave these players off the market. By this logic, the next railway legislation could be written by one, two French and German companies, which will only be allowed to control Europe's rail networks. What the European Union is trying to do is to implement a neo-mercantile policy on the railways as well. After the whole European region has been transformed into a large debt colony, then it will also be forced to have a compulsory monopoly on Franco-German companies. Thus in Greece, which has become a guinea pig of the troika, THEPED at the behest of the lenders proceeds to the privatisation of TRAINOSE and THE EUSTY. That's what the colonialists did in Africa a hundred years ago. They are trying to impose the same on Greece. But that's not going to happen. The Greek people will react.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam Chairman, I will not talk about the classic benefits and importance of rail and rail transport in the European Union and the problems we face when we talk about Chinese presence within the European railway area, but I want to highlight two problems. I want to highlight the problem of cross-border rail connectivity in the European rail area and highlight one concrete example. And a concrete example is the Istrian arm of Croatian railways that ends in Slovenia, which is a general problem.  For 25 years, no one cares about these railways, and the potential for passenger transport and for the transportation of goods is fantastic. Another example is the problem of traffic intermodality, which of course is extremely important in order for cargo when it reaches a port to cross to the railway and go further. The port of Rijeka will never be competitive until we solve the problem of railways between Rijeka and Zagreb, but also Rijeka and Pivka, which is, of course, a problem of cooperation between Croatia and Slovenia.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The rail supply industry is undoubtedly a strategically important industry in Europe. However, it is an industry that is business to business and therefore not so visible to the public. All the more reason why the rapporteur is to be thanked for this oral answer to the question, because this industry needs more public attention. European companies are now the world market leader with 46 percent of the world market share and a turnover of 47 billion euros, but China is very much on Europe's heels. Today, a Chinese company, CRCC, generates almost 30 billion euros in sales, which means that more than half of Europe's turnover in China alone goes to one company. China, of course, also has financing opportunities for such large companies that Europe does not have. That is why it is necessary for Europe to focus, for Shift to Rail, a very good initiative funded by Horizon 2020, to be implemented as quickly as possible, for the Connecting Europe Facility to be implemented, for the EFSI Fund to become more and more effective. We need more competitiveness and support for the European rail supply industry.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, the Communist Party is voting against the resolution because it further promotes the privatisation of the railways at the expense of the workers themselves and passengers. But we underline the enormous political audacity of parties here in the European Parliament that are shamelessly mocking. We refer to SYRIZA, which its government in Greece, in the dirtiest role of the system useful to the Left, on the one hand crushes the people and on the other hand hands over all public property for 99 years to the lenders, privatizing everything and the railways. It is therefore a huge challenge for SYRIZA MEPs on the one side to sign in here an amendment denouncing the privatisation of the railways and then to return to order and not to sign a subsequent amendment calling on governments to reject privatisation, that is to say their own government. That's SYRIZA and his mockery! This is the GUE group and the party of the European Left, the so-called left-wing crutch of urban political barbarism, the political roof of the parties to the memorandums! We leave them to the judgment of the people.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support In January, the itre committee's resolution on this subject summarised very well the challenges and solutions that could contribute to the further development of the European rail supply industry and to maintaining its share of the world market. However, if we do not want to lose our position in the near future, it is important to take clear steps that are not only relevant to the current market situation, but also to future prospects and challenges. To do this, we must not put more emphasis on research and education.  Furthermore, the fact that many small and medium-sized enterprises in the rail supply industry operate in an unfavourable business environment, which needs to be repaired and can be achieved using the European Small Business Act and EPSI, is also not negligible, but the Commission's assistance is necessary. We need to simplify procedures and reduce the financial and administrative burden on SMEs so that they can finally focus on production.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: Madam President, in Spain the railway equipment industry is made up of about six hundred companies , 75% of which are SMEs and occupy 145 000 people. It is an industry of great strategic importance for growth, employment, investment and, crucially, to facilitate the transition to sustainable mobility. While the European Union maintains a high degree of openness to competition from third countries, our companies face numerous obstacles and unfair competition. Some third-country competitors, such as China, carry out an aggressive policy of expansion with strong political support. Today we are suffering the consequences of having acted late in the steel sector. Let's not make the same mistakes. Europe needs a modern industrial policy that defends industry on fair and balanced rules of the game. Only by facilitating suppliers' access to international markets, facilitating innovation and the commitment to investment, can we achieve this.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to your comments, your exchanges and, of course, your criticism. I would like to thank you for your contribution to this important debate at a very crucial time. As the Commission, we follow closely the developments in the rail supply industries in order to be in a position to provide the appropriate policy and, of course, to ensure that the EU rail supply industry remains a leader in world markets. Thank you for your attention, thank you for your remarks and your contributions in this very difficult position about the rail industry in Europe as a leader worldwide.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Madam President, I will not need half a minute. I just wanted to ask, as a point of procedure, whether such a lackadaisical answer from the Commission stands in this House?

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The European rail equipment sector is a generator for industrial growth and innovation in Europe, while contributing to job creation. Rail transport is the mode of transport with the lowest carbon dioxide emissions. The creation of modern railways and equipment and accessories can provide Europe with a head start in technology and innovation. Investment in research and innovation is indispensable for preserving the international competitiveness of the European rail sector. Both national and EU governments must support and encourage innovation, in line with the EU 2020 strategy. Without adequate funding, the objective of an integrated rail network cannot be achieved. Particular attention should be paid to the effective implementation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments as a tool for mobilising private capital for the railway sector. In view of the reduction in public expenditure in this area, substantial private investment in railway projects is required for a long-term European development strategy. In addition, it is necessary to modernise existing rail equipment and replace used equipment by Member States with modern and long-term products. An effective rail infrastructure capable of serving the general interest of European society in the long term is therefore needed.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The privatization processes of EMEF, Empresa de Manutenção de Equipamento Ferroviário, S.A. and CP Carga, Logística e Transportes Ferroviários de Mercadorias, S.A., are an integral part of the liquidation process of the national railway sector and are also part of the privatization process that the Government is launching in the terminal phase of its mandate. The true origin of this process dates back to successive railway packages and successive attempts to impose the liberalisation of the railway sector on the States and peoples of the European Union. These decisions are in front of the Portuguese Constitution itself and are part of a process that affronts this Constitution in broader terms. It is recalled that the Constitution points, as fundamental economic tasks, to the 'Coexistence of the public sector, the private sector and the cooperative and social sector owned by the means of production' and to 'Public ownership of natural resources and means of production, in accordance with the collective interest'. It is once again confirmed that the European Union is involved in a process of effective destruction of the public sector in order to favour the large private interests.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy for bringing this issue here today. The European Shift2Rail initiative aims to contribute to the implementation of a single European railway area. This programme will develop, through research and development, the market launch of major technological advances. The fact that it is a public-private initiative also highlights the sector's commitment to the unification of the European market. The largest companies in the European railway sector have been financially involved together with the Commission and the Member States. Shift2Rail will reduce infrastructure construction and operability costs, increase rail capacity and increase industry reliability. This is a great European objective that brings together institutions, governments, businesses and citizens. The initiative is aimed at playing a key role in the innovation of the railway sector. The evolution of the initiative and the involvement that SMEs may have in this project remains to be glimpsed, and that is why I think the oral question presented is appropriate.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The controversial law regulating non-governmental organisations in Cambodia, LANGO, has long been at the centre of human rights criticism. It was foreseeable that the use of LANGO would invite unjustified action against human rights defenders in their own country. It shows a kind of pattern to complicate public protest and criticism of government action. There are increasing sums of statements by official bodies criminalising the work of human rights NGOs and independent trade unions and even trying to portray them as attempts at overthrow. On 2 May, four senior staff members of the established and respected human rights organisation ADHOC were arrested: Ny Sokha, Nay Vanda, Yi Soksan and Lim Mony, as well as Ny Chakrya of the National Election Committee. Peaceful demonstrations for their release were crushed by the police, and there were again arrests of activists. We call on the Cambodian Government to release human rights defenders without delay and to respect and protect the right to freedom of expression and assembly. These events, of course, can also be seen in the context of the 2017 and 2018 elections. In this regard, the European Union must pay close attention to technical assistance, such as the registration of voters. It should also be possible for migrants to have the right to vote and to be able to vote in this election. We are also dealing with the attacks on the opposition in this resolution. Here, too, we call on the Cambodian Government to refrain from doing so. Whether it is the leaders of the opposition, but also all the supporters, are constantly threatened here, or representatives of the opposition, if they want to enter parliament, are violently attacked.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, when we talk about Cambodia, we are talking about the third resolution in less than a year. We made one in July last year, talking specifically about the repression of non-governmental organizations, we made another one in November, talking about how this country was in total sell-off against multinationals, and today again to reiterate that the Hun Sen government is a government that brutally represses not only freedom of expression , not only freedom of association, but also any form of defence of human rights. Now, assuming that we are Cambodia's main partner, we give it EUR 410 million in the period 2014-2020, perhaps the time has come to review our development aid, given that it is not possible to convey it through democratic instruments, especially in view of the next elections in 2017. If we have tools, let's try to use them, if not we find ourselves every six months talking about the same things all the time.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I apologise for this confusion. It is astonishing that we deal with the events in Cambodia at a certain frequency and that this is always related to human rights. It is regrettable that we have to do this and we have to do it again and again. Cambodia has a tragic history: there has been a genocide of the Khmer Rouge that has gone down in history, and against this background it is actually astonishing that this country has developed positively, that there has been positive economic development, that there have also been positive political developments. The prospects would be good, and this country could indeed develop if it followed the path of the rule of law and democracy. Unfortunately, there is a risk that Cambodia will fall back into corruption and arbitrariness. The country has overcome a constitutional crisis and an electoral commission has been agreed. The European Union supports this Electoral Commission. But the closer the elections get, the more nervous the government becomes. Opposition is systematically eliminated, The NGO margins are restricted, the trade unions are taken to the fore, and a climate of fear has spread throughout the country. This resolution is an urgent appeal to the Cambodian Government to abandon this path, to release all those arrested, and I am very pleased that we are also happy to remind the Cambodian Government that the not inconsiderable resources that Europe is providing also depend on it and on continuing this democratic development.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Madam President, this resolution is an urgent appeal to the Cambodian Government to really change the current situation in Cambodia, because, as my forebodings have already said, the situation there is really getting worse every month. The European Union is one of cambodia's largest partners in development aid and cannot tolerate the current situation in the country. It not only suppresses the opposition, but also suppresses all activities of the non-profit sector. On the contrary, the European Union must put sufficient pressure on the Cambodian Government to recognise the activities of non-profit organisations and to give civil society, trade unions and, above all, the opposition the opportunity to act legitimately. In particular, in the context of presidential and municipal elections in the next two years, fairness of elections and election campaigns is to be ensured. That is why I say for my faction that we will monitor the whole situation in Cambodia very strongly and we will want to participate in the democratic elections there.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, this is, indeed, the third resolution on Cambodia in less than a year. The country has been in a political crisis since July 2013 and the repression is worsening, including now against trade union organisations. But if there is one fundamental issue in Cambodia, it is land grabbing and related crimes, which are now the subject of a complaint to the International Criminal Court. More than 800,000 victims since 2000 and at least 60,000 more in the first half of 2015 alone. On this issue, our resolution is very weak and does not at all call into question the primary responsibility of multinationals, including European ones, in the textile and sugar sector, where working conditions, especially for women and children, are particularly alarming. If we want to improve the human rights situation in this country, this is where we must act and demand that the victims be compensated, but also that the agreement "Everything but arms" be revised so that the European Union and its Member States no longer import products from the exploitation and expropriation of Cambodian peasants. The United Nations is currently working on corporate responsibility. Commissioner, please, I am speaking to you - it is good when you have a representative of the Commission, but it is even better when he listens to us. Thank you, Commissioner. The United Nations is currently working on corporate responsibility, with the establishment of a legal instrument. It is time for the European Union and its Member States to get involved on this issue. I am waiting for your response on this, please.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Madam President, two months ago I took part in the Subcommittee on Human Rights mission to Cambodia. It was a highly alarming and eye—opening exposure to the country’s deteriorating political reality. Just recently, Sam Rainsy, leader of the main opposition party, who aimed to establish a real culture of dialogue, was issued with a politically motivated arrest warrant. He and many other political and human rights activists have been convicted for what was a legitimate and peaceful exercise of their freedom of expression.  I urge the Cambodian authorities to revoke the arrest warrant and drop all the charges against Sam Rainsy and other opposition politicians and human rights activists. I call on them to immediately guarantee the freedom of expression and all democratic freedoms for Cambodians. I stress the need for further and strong involvement of the European Union in Cambodian issues.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I am going after the authors who have sufficiently justified the need for this resolution, I fully support it for our faction. The situation is all the more recent at the moment, with a trial to be held in Cambodia in July this year against chief foreman Sam Rainsy in a fabricated trial in his absence. So perhaps it is appropriate at the moment to demand that the Cambodian government, led by Hun Sen, refrain from this political attack against the leader of the opposition. Colleagues here have described in detail how the rights of opposition leaders, political activists, civil activists and journalists are more or less being suppressed in Cambodia, there is no point in repeating this. Future elections must be guarded, but it must also be made clear that, at a time when Cambodia is to receive EUR 400 million – and if it behaves in this way in relation to democracy and opposition leaders – the Commission should reconsider whether to use the money more for migration than giving it to Cambodia.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as has already been said, human rights activists in Cambodia, including a UNITED Nations employee, have been accused of corruption and are at risk of five to ten years in prison. These accusations are politically motivated and represent an alarming increase in respect for civil society and those working to defend human rights in the country, making it clear that the government's ultimate objective is to silence dissent in the run-up to the next elections. This is an improper use of the criminal justice system that intends and uses state institutions as tools to intimidate, criminalise and punish the legitimate activities of human rights defenders and civil society. We have only one task, and it is simple, and I say this to the Commissioner: we must change our relationship with Cambodia and put it under clear conditions, namely that human rights issues are actually addressed.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we are going to call things by name. Cambodia has a corrupt oligarchy, a kleptocracy that rules since the time when former Khmer Rouge Hun Sen seized power and maintained it, first under the Vietnamese umbrella and then under his own dictatorship based on his armed groups, on his weapons. We are before pure and hard gangsters. Cambodia, in addition to the systematic violation of human rights, is known to some as a sexual paradise (I would say a sexual hell) that I know; I've been there, I know what I'm talking about. Where girls are sold to any bidder who has enough dollars to pay for it and the government does absolutely nothing because it is part of that same system. We cannot continue to give aid to this Government, maintaining the current situation in Cambodia, and the European Union's aid must necessarily be linked to a radical improvement in human rights in Cambodia.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, I do not know the Cambodian language, but I do know how hypocritical I think there are some who are supposedly concerned and interested in democracy and human rights in Cambodia. The report, like so many reports on countries close to or thousands of kilometres away, calls on us to condemn the lack of democracy, oppression, political persecution, repression and violation of human rights. Hypocrisy, if not populism! The imprisonment of a leader and opposition MPs took place not only in Cambodia but also in Greece. Political persecution of opposition parties also occurs in the Europe of the rule of law against the nationalist parties of the Front National, Lega Nord, Jobbik, the NPD. You don't want different opinions to be heard.  And before anyone rushes to call me racist or inhuman, to respond, I would rather denounce the behaviour of members of the Commission, who deal with human rights violations, who in my calls to discuss a case of violation of them did not bother to respond, even negatively. Even the President of the Commission himself! Only one replied, saying that for the next 5 months it does not have a time of 20 minutes. If this is not undemocratic behaviour, hypocrisy, ridiculousness and racism, then I challenge anyone to give me a wiser definition.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The political situation in Cambodia is undoubtedly worrying and requires the international community to take decisive action. The arrests and persecution of representatives of the opposition, as well as human rights activists or members of NGOs, are unacceptable actions that must be stopped immediately. I would also like to draw attention to cambodia's exceptionally low score in the Rule of Law Index published last year, in which Cambodia ranks third from the end. The people of Cambodia do not believe in the activities of their courts. They point to them as the most unbelievable and corrupt institution in the country.  At the same time, the Union is the largest donor of development aid to Cambodia. I therefore believe that if the Cambodian authorities, despite calls from European partners, do not decide to return to a peaceful and constructive dialogue with the opposition, as well as to strengthen democracy and the rule of law, then the development aid provided should be made conditional on progress on this issue.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister Hun Sen has now been in power for 30 years. While these years have moved Cambodia away from the nightmare of the killing fields, we can say that the road to full democracy is far from complete.  We have seen some positive steps; steps that have led to the opening of different European missions in Cambodia, including from the Czech Republic. But Prime Minister Hun Sen must understand that the greatest proof that Cambodia is now a modern nation state would be to accept truly free and fair elections, to allow a fully independent press and free speech, and to ensure a government that works for all its citizens, including those who are not supporters of the current government. Repression by the government and attacks against the opposition do not serve the strategic goals of Cambodia or its people. There is a quote attributed to the late Cambodian King during his exile in China which reads: ‘I renounce my throne to show the masses that there is no such thing as a divine right, that no-one descends from the heavens to rule the people’. I think this statement is just as true for all prime ministers and all presidents.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Cambodia is a country that has relatively recently begun to transform and open up to the world. If the Government of Cambodia has the ambition to transform this country and improve the economic and social situation of its citizens, it needs, above all, to create an open society respecting fundamental civil and human freedoms and rights. In such a case, the persecution of civil activists or the physical attacks and criminalisation of political opponents that we have seen recently cannot be tolerated. Our Parliament should send out a clear signal and support activists and the growth of civil society in Cambodia. This country has the potential to dynamic develop and deal with the trauma of the past. However, one premise is that its citizens will not be traumatised again by their own government.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, trade can be one of two things when it comes to helping developing countries. When done properly, when done sensitively, when done fairly, trade can develop a country’s economy. It can create jobs and it can develop exports and help that nation to be able to import the things it cannot produce. But, when done badly, as I fear is the case in Cambodia, it becomes a cynical exploitation of that country’s natural resources. In this situation, in particular, we see serious concerns over the land grabbing which has taken place in recent years, and indeed is picking up apace. Then there are the human rights abuses: there are the political prisoners, the lack of democracy and massive abuse. What I would say simply, in terms of development aid in such situations, is that it is vital that we are incredibly careful that development aid is not going directly to the Cambodian Government.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, It is not very often that I agree with virtually all my pre-speaker, so I would no longer water down the debate. I condemn human rights violations in Cambodia. However, I believe that our condemnation of human rights violations should then have real implications for the performance of European Union policies. And I must agree with my pre-ers that the instruments of our diplomacy, which consist in providing development aid, should also be used. I think we should respond if one state consistently does not respect fundamental human rights. I do not think that the whole catalogue of human rights that we profess in the European Union is universal, but fundamental human rights are truly universal and universal. Their violations in Cambodia must be reflected in our contribution to this country, because otherwise we do not have real tools to force this state to make a certain u-turn.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it was only in November that we held a similar debate here on the political situation in Cambodia. Now again, as described in detail by previous speakers, actions against members of the opposition and civil society are cause for serious concern. Specifically, we have seen what appears to be a continuing campaign of harassment against opposition leader Kem Sokha, regardless of his parliamentary immunity. This has also led to the arrest of four officials and one former official of the human rights NGO ADHOC. These actions are particularly worrying in the context of preparations for commune council elections in 2017 and national elections in 2018. They leave us with the perception of new restrictions on civil society.  The European Union has not been silent during this tense period. The visit of a delegation of the Subcommittee on Human Rights in early April was very timely. A few weeks later, at the beginning of May, the EU-Cambodia Joint Committee meeting was held in Phnom Penh. This is a biannual 3-day event which includes meetings on cooperation, on trade and on governance and human rights. In the margins, the EU also held bilateral meetings with the Minister of the Interior, with the Minister of Foreign Affairs, with civil society organisations and, of course, with the opposition. Throughout all these meetings, the EU very clearly spelled out its serious concerns about the arrests and about the decreasing space for civil society and for the opposition. It explicitly called for the release of the NGO officials. This call was reflected in the joint statement and in the press afterwards.  Following the Joint Committee, the EU Ambassador continued to approach the government in Phnom Penh, together with like-minded and EU Ambassadors. In Brussels the Cambodian Ambassador was called in. Last week the EU Heads of Missions in Phnom Penh issued a local statement calling on the authorities to stop the judicial harassment and urging them to resume a constructive dialogue with the opposition. They stressed that this is a condition for the legitimacy of the forthcoming elections.  It is our strong view that the Government of Cambodia has a duty to create and sustain an environment in which all political parties can go about their work without fear of violence or harassment. An environment in which robust and frank policy discussion is encouraged, and in which the law is applied impartially.  Also, the European Union has earmarked EUR 10 million to support the electoral reform, and works closely with the bi-partisan National Election Committee on the best ways to provide assistance for the preparation of the next elections. It is indeed important that we support an election reform process with solid guarantees for a real democratic electoral competition.  The elections are still some way away: commune level in June 2017 and parliamentary in July 2018. We are monitoring and assessing the situation on a regular basis. We will consider in due course whether it would be appropriate to observe one of the upcoming elections. In any case, the EU will continue to support reform in Cambodia and to encourage the respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Today we are focusing on the difficult political situation in Cambodia and the persecution and problems affecting members of the opposition and human rights defenders. The problem is undoubtedly pressing and important, but the text, which is intended to treat different aspects of the situation in the country, lacked one very important subject – children. Around 30% of the country's citizens live in poverty, and a large proportion of this number are the youngest. 10% of children do not go to school at all and only 20% of girls attend the equivalent of a lower secondary school or high school. Despite the government's regulations, it is calculated that around 45% of children aged 5 to 14 are actually forced to work, and working conditions often break basic standards.
