Around 23% of young girls in Cambodia are married when they are under the age of 18. These statistics are very alarming and I believe that we should not forget the situation of the youngest in this country. I therefore call on the External Action Service to pay more attention to this subject – not only in Cambodia, but in all the countries that we are discussing in the human rights debates.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – There is peace where there is justice, rights and political pluralism. All of this is being violated in Cambodia. Political pluralism is virtually absent. The constitution includes the principles of a multi-party democracy, but in reality the political opposition is strangled. The government is pushing for the prosecution of Kem Sokha, the interim leader of the opposition. An arrest warrant has been issued for Sam Rainsy - the current opposition leader. Freedom of speech is violated. A 2010 law criminalises defamation or written criticism of senior civil servants. Last month's anti-government protests resulted in the arrest of human rights activists at ADHOC. Corruption, land grabbing by influential politicians, illegal extraction of resources, nepotism, counterfeiting and buying votes are the order of the day. Environmentalist Chut Wutty was killed in 2012 while investigating illegal logging. I call for the release of all political prisoners and the adoption of clear criteria for the 2017 elections that ensure fair and free elections.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: author. – Mr President, Tajikistan is the poorest of the five central Asian countries and we have to continue to support social and economic developments in this country; but we also have to remind the country about the obligation on the grounds of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement that our cooperation must be based on shared values.  Just yesterday, to my knowledge, the human rights dialogue between Tajikistan and the EU was held. The Parliament already wanted to send a strong message to this human rights dialogue. We can conclude that the human rights situation has steadily deteriorated. Some very repressive laws have been put in place, notably the law on public associations, which poses the risk of serious sanctions on NGOs, and the law on the bar and the practice of law, which has been recently adopted and which threatens the independence of the legal profession in the country, and so on. What we also see is that political prisoners are convicted on obviously political grounds, and we have to call for a full release of these people. We also should not accept that the fight against terrorism, which of course is a real issue, is conducted by opposing and repressing the rights of democratic opposition parties. So we have to support the rights of peaceful opposition parties and civil society to continue to act.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have had the opportunity to see for myself what is going on in Tajikistan, having participated in the election mission that took place last year. It is clear that we are talking about a country that has a fairly pronounced totalitarian tendency, where there is repression of opposition political parties, where there is no possibility of associating and criticising and where media control is also quite clear. Furthermore, we must specify that we have had a partnership agreement with Tajikistan since 2009 which had set itself the objective of achieving certain results. The years have passed, the objectives have been achieved practically for nothing. On the contrary, with the constitutional referendum that was held a few days ago, on 22 May, President Rahmon did nothing more than remove the mandate limit and lower the threshold, practically paving the way for a presidential election of his son. I believe that we must take action, especially with regard to prisoners of conscience, and raise our voices a little, because we have privileged trade relations with that country.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, like many post-Soviet states Tajikistan experienced a traumatic and deadly birth as a country. The civil war between Islamists and secularists is estimated to have cost the lives of 100 000 people before the peace accords of 1997. Since then, President Rahmon has ensconced himself in office and many of the divisions we see today are a continuation of those seen during the civil war. As Rahmon enjoys his fourth term now as president, and he has acquired the right to stand again without limits, the fruits of his leadership are not those that we would have hoped for in a more democratic society. Arrests and detentions of political opposition figures, disappearances in collusion with Moscow, clampdowns on journalists and civil society – the list is not an enviable one. We also see, at the geopolitical level, Tajikistan falling more closely back into the orbit of Russia.  As a member of the Eurasian Union which is stagnating economically right now, and economically so reliant on the remittances sent back home from workers living and working in Russia, we see little hope of Tajikistan moving in a western direction in terms of democratic, political and economic norms.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a year ago, the European Parliament denounced the partisan scenario in which elections were held for the renewal of the Tajik Parliament. In May of this year, a referendum amended the Constitution, removing the limit on the number of mandates and allowing President Rahmon, who has been in office since 1992, to run for president again. Today, it is not only the difficult political context that attracts criticism, but also the recent serious legal cases. With this resolution, the European Parliament is calling for the conditions of legality and freedom to be restored. As far as we are concerned, we are re-puttinging trade agreements, which must strictly include clear conditions, freedom of expression and the protection of human rights defenders. That is the task we have today in our relationship with this country.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, six years ago the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) concluded between the EU and Tajikistan came into force. This is not only about trade and economic cooperation. Article 2 stresses the respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights which should underpin their external as well as internal policies. Today, there are most worrying signals about the increased harassment and suppression of the opposition, culminating in last week’s sentencing of two opposition leaders to life imprisonment. We are concerned about the systematic harassment and arrest of lawyers, especially those who defend people accused by the state power. The third reason for concern is news about many cases of the use of torture. While understanding the importance of the political and economic relationship, this must be deeply linked with respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. Therefore I call on the EEAS to closely monitor proper implementation of the law, especially the right of association and forming political parties.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Author. – Mr President, the fact that the European Union has geostrategic interests in a region must not, under any circumstances, justify unconditional support for its rulers, because this unconditional support tends to become a condemnation for the people. This is the case in Tajikistan, where, on the pretext of counter-terrorism, the Government has suppressed the opposition and there is evidence of systematic human rights violations. We must base relations between the European Union and Tajikistan on the lines set out in the sustainable development goals: gender equality, women's empowerment and the will of organised civil society. Let us never lose sight of the inclusion of social inclusion and redistributive policies and social cohesion are essential to ending violent extremism and all forms of violence. Without justice there will be no end to violence. With the SDGs in hand, it is clear that we have a responsibility to change the role that the European Union plays in the world. To be consistent and consistent, we must not regard Tajikistan as a piece on a game board, we must not let the geostrategic interests of the European Union condition our entire foreign policy.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: Author. – The development of political and economic relations with Tajikistan is of exceptional interest to the European Union. The country is an important partner in the context of the Union's Central Asia Strategy, which aims to strengthen trade and energy links between Europe and the region. It is also important to note tajikistan's role as an important ally in the fight against terrorism and fundamentalism.  Although the country has been seeking its democratic identity for 26 years, the human rights situation is deteriorating. The authorities in Tajikistan are putting serious pressure on free-thinking people, the political opposition and the independent media. There is also a serious crackdown on civil society, in particular NGOs that protect human rights. Political accusations are being brought against critics of the government, and prominent lawyers, journalists and human rights defenders have been detained in prison.  I call on the authorities in Tajikistan to immediately release all political prisoners in the country, respect international human rights laws and guarantee the fundamental freedoms of the citizens of the country.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, when the civil war ended in Tajikistan in 1992, some 30 000 war orphans were left behind. I remember it well, because I was making a film documentary about them in Dushanbe in the late 1990s. Today, all these children are adults. I wish they could live in a country where they can breathe freely. But their country is in a bad place with freedom. Pluralism, a free and open political environment, meanwhile, are alien to the concepts of this beautiful country. This is also evidenced by the politically motivated indictments and imprisonments of Abu Bakr Al-Zaydiya, Zayd Saeed, Maksoud Ibrahim and others. The EU-Republic of Tajikistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement states that respect for democratic principles and human rights is an essential element of the agreement. It must therefore be used to the maximum possible use of its framework to provide concrete support for the unjustly imprisoned and prosecuted.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to express my sincere in/ 20 – It is sad to say that Tajikistan, which is indeed one of the poorest post-communist countries, has increasingly fallen back into a complete totalitarian atmosphere over the past year. The European Union has reached out to Tajik, but we cannot turn a blind eye to the fact that the whole rule of law has stopped. Independent law enforcement is a very important guarantee of the rule of law. The fact that law enforcement people in Tajik, who could be expected to guarantee basic human rights to the political opposition, have also been victims of political repression is a particularly high sign of danger.  Our resolution is very important in this sense that it also stresses that, while we understand that any fight against terror, violent extremism, understanding internationally, it does not mean that it can be any excuse that such human rights and tyrannical methods can be applied against political opposition and against independent law enforcement. So we very much hope that the representatives of the European Union in their dialogue with Tajik will follow the rule of law very strictly in this country.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Tajikistan is still the poorest country in Central Asia dependent on economic relations with Russia and China. The partnership agreement that Europe has offered is a fair one. Only EUR 251 million of structural support is planned for 2020. The EU is already Tajikistan's third largest trading partner. And there is much more to it if both sides accept the rules. Developments in Tajikistan are all the more irritating in the ECR. We must call the grievances by their name: banning parties, locking their leaders in prison, muzzled critics of the system, restricting religious freedom, confiscing places of worship – that is not the fair deal with Europe. I am thinking of the situation of the German, mostly Christian, minority. We cannot accept the looting of their cemeteries, the slow erasure of their history and culture. I say: Europe is at your side. But cooperation with Europe can and will only take place if democracy and human rights are permanently based in Tajikistan.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, is dóigh liom gur thug na húdair cur síos an-mhaith ar cad atá ag tarlú sa Táidsíceastáin faoi láthair agus le blianta beaga anuas, go háirithe faoi réim an uachtaráin atá ann anois – b’fhéidir go ró-fhada.  Ba cheart gan dabht comhoibriú leo, ach ag an am gcéanna is ceart freisin brú a chur orthu chun leasuithe a dhéanamh go háirithe maidir leis an tslí a bhfuil siad á n-iompar féin maidir leis an lucht freasúra. Tuigimid gur ceart troid i gcoinne na sceimhlitheoireachta agus na caimiléireachta, ach tá siad ag úsáid an troid seo chun teacht anuas ar an lucht freasúra. Táthar á gcur i bpríosún agus tá na dlíodóirí a chosain iad curtha i bpríosún.  Tá rialacha nua á dtabhairt isteach chun cosc a chur ar shaoirse an phreasa agus ar shaoirse na saoránach i gcoitinne. Dá bhrí sin, ba chóir dúinn, agus is ceart dúinn, a iarraidh orthu leasuithe a dhéanamh maidir leis sin agus go háirithe na príosúnaigh pholaitiúla agus na dlíodóirí a ligean saor.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I believe we have a strong interest in stepping up political and economic security cooperation, as well as sustainable development and peace cooperation, with the Central Asian region. However, political and economic relations with Tajikistan are deeply linked with sharing values on respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. Therefore, I strongly support the call for the release of everyone imprisoned on politically motivated charges. We cannot turn a blind eye to the increase in the number of detentions and arrests of people allegedly on criminal charges, when in fact they are political prisoners – human rights lawyers, for example, or political opposition members and their relatives – or to restrictions on media freedom, internet and mobile communications and to limitations of religious expression. These politicians, activists and human rights defenders must be allowed to work freely without fear of arrest or persecution. Commissioner, the EU has to intervene on this matter by all available means.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, we hear disturbing evidence about a substantial number of opposition leaders and lawyers detained in Tajikistan. These individuals, singled out in our resolution, must be released. The EU has invested in a human rights dialogue with Tajikistan and part of this dialogue should result in launching reforms. This especially applies to an independent judiciary with a functional system of checks and balances. Lawyers must be able to represent their clients freely in front of the courts. If – and only if – charged with credible offences, all Tajik citizens must be guaranteed the right to a fair trial and transparent court proceedings. I appreciate the work of the Ombudsman’s office, the group dedicated to monitoring human rights in the country, but a lot of work and improvement is still needed.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Tajikistan is a particularly poor state, but where there is systematic repression of the democratic rights of its citizens. The media, civil society organisations are in the crosshairs of the authorities. There is also oppression of the Christian populations that are in this country. The European Union must put pressure on Tajikistan to restore democracy, the rule of law, the rights of the opposition, multi-partyism and freedom of expression. The European Union must closely monitor the practical application of the right of association and the right to form political parties. We must finally put an end to the repression of human rights in this country and I think that the European Union has the means, it has the means and the ability, really, to exert its pressure on Tajikistan.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, what are the basic features of the Tajik State at this time? Arrests and disappearances of people, general poverty, even torture, muzzle media, oligarch rule, religious beliefs that are not equal to state power. These are all labels that show what the current face of Tajikistan is like. I recognise that the European Union has agreed with this State on a commitment of some strategic importance, but I ask whether recognising this commitment to the strategic importance of this country can completely negate fundamental human rights, whether we can resign to the protection of human rights because of the strategic importance of Tajikistan. I do not think that this is the case and that we should send a clear message on this matter.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I naturally support all the comments made by colleagues here. We must support Tajikistan on its road to democracy, even if it is not always easy for a country that has a thousand kilometres of border with Afghanistan and into which many things are spilling over from Afghanistan. However, I would like to raise a rather procedural question here: if I read this resolution, I see nothing that would be urgent there. All cases raised are months, some years old. I have been a member of the Central Asia delegation for seven years, I am President of the Tajikistan Friendship Group in the House, I have also met the President myself, and yet there was no way that I could have been involved in drafting this resolution. I think we in this House should think about this: what is really important, and where should we involve the relevant delegations, so that a better resolution comes out and people and colleagues who really know the country are also involved? I would urge that. I think that if the delegations are to have any meaning here, they must also be involved in such cases.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, alas Tajikistan is in one of those situations that we see to be quite frequent in the former Soviet republics. There is a main confrontation, almost a civil war, between the current ruling Communist Party and the Islamists. Unfortunately, in this dangerous combination of authoritarianism, poverty, threats to internal security and threats from Afghanistan, the stability of the country is seriously compromised. In particular, the current government of Emomali Rahmon has been guilty of a great deal of persecution of opponents, particularly of human rights lawyers. It is to them that I address myself, as a lawyer, as someone who has been trained in the field of law. We cannot allow, in addition to the unjust persecution of the Islamic Revival party, which has seen life sentences, still sentences for all forms of support for democracy, there should also be the persecution of those who legitimately defend the rights to have a right to a fair trial and a right to a defence. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address all of you: we must ask for more within the framework of the partnership agreement that already exists with Tajikistan. Human rights clauses must stop being rivers of ink and must become a reality.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are currently witnessing what is clearly a very challenging period for human rights in Tajikistan. While there have been some positive developments during the past year – for instance, we welcome the activities of the Human Rights Ombudsman – we continue to have very serious concerns with regard to a number of issues. Our most prominent concerns are about political participation and political prisoners. On 29 September 2015, the Islamic Renaissance Party of Tajikistan (IRPT) was outlawed as a terrorist organisation and its leadership arrested. At the time, the European Union issued a statement calling for restraint. We also reminded the Tajik Government of the importance of upholding fundamental rights, including the right to a fair trial, even in the pursuit of security operations. Last week, the Tajik Supreme Court issued harsh prison sentences for the 13 leaders of the IRPT arrested, in two cases life imprisonment unfortunately. Again, we made a critical public statement saying that the court proceedings were not transparent and violated the rights of the accused to a fair trial, which is not in line with Tajikistan’s commitments under international law. We also reminded the Tajik Government that clear evidence must be presented justifying the criminal charges brought against the defendants in connection with all the sentences issued.  An open and inclusive law-making process is most likely to prevent radicalisation and political extremism. We stressed these points in several high-level meetings recently: when President Rahmon visited Brussels in December 2015; in Astana at a ministerial meeting also in late 2015; and on numerous occasions – most recently, today on the occasion of the EU-Tajikistan human rights dialogue held in Dushanbe.  In my view, the actions of the Tajik Government clearly have the potential to damage the overall legitimacy of the Tajik political system. This is emphatically not in our interests. Our policy seeks political stability and economic prosperity. As the European Union, we remain a key provider of development cooperation assistance to both Tajikistan and to Central Asia, and we will continue to put human rights and the rights of prisoners of conscience firmly on our agenda. The European Union stands ready to work together with Tajikistan in addressing these important issues.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. On 17 September 2009, the European Parliament gave a positive opinion on the conclusion of a partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and the Republic of Tajikistan. The agreement obviously makes respect for democratic principles and human rights a prerequisite. Unfortunately, the situation in Tajikistan is still dramatic. Freedom of the press is practically non-existent, given the climate of restriction and censorship created by the government to counter independent information. The use of torture and the continued detentions of political opponents continue, unfortunately, to be on the agenda, despite the efforts requested of the government in August 2013, regarding compliance with the agreed anti-torture plans. In view of these considerations, I believe it is of the utmost importance that the EU acts to put an end to the continuing violations of human rights.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – The EU is one of the largest donors of financial assistance to central Asian countries, including Tajikistan, as governed by the 2010 Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. In recent years, we have been following the political landscape with great concern. However, the situation is not improving – it is getting worse. But while most colleagues are calling for the immediate release of all political prisoners, I want to emphasise something else - foreign fighters. Today, most of them come from Asian countries, including Tajikistan. Although the only opposition party, let's not forget that the Islamic Revival Party is above all an Islamist party, although there is no direct evidence of its link to Islamic State. In this regard, I would like to call for a halt to the crackdown on the opposition, as they can encourage those at risk of joining extremist groups. Instead, I believe that ensuring a fair and objective process, complying with international human rights laws and the ability for lawyers to perform their duties freely and without fear of reprisal is the right path for the country to develop.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in November last year, that is, about six months ago, we found ourselves talking about Vietnam, before the free trade agreement was approved. Many concerns about the maintenance of human rights were reiterated in this House, not least because three years earlier, in 2012, the human rights situation had not improved at all with the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. Six months have now passed since the FTA was approved and the human rights situation in Vietnam continues to deteriorate systematically: the killing of bloggers, arrests by the government of opposition figures and there continues to be violent repression. I believe that we really should learn to put the maintenance of human rights at the same level as economic interests sometimes because, in order to do a favour to our multinationals that are going to exploit the resources in Vietnam, we are still not credible in terms of human rights.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – Vietnam has two faces, that of the dynamic young country that enthusiastically joins the world, and that of the rigid one-party state.  The control of the Communist Party is absolute. The regime reacts paranoidly to anything that resembles critical or anti-state activities: bloggers, peaceful protesters, religious minorities. It is clear that Vietnam is not inferior to big brother China. We have indeed expressed these concerns before, but the human rights situation is not improving. Contrary! Priest Nguyen Van Ly may have been released, but many of his fellow citizens remain behind. I specifically mention Thich Quang Do, monk, head of the United Buddhist Church of Vietnam. Thirty years he's been living under some form of detention. Commissioner, we expect the European Union to keep up the pressure. With the free trade agreement concluded in 2015, we have an important instrument in our hands for this.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the When we voted on the framework agreement with Vietnam in December, we were already discussing the very serious human rights situation in the country, the strategy for judicial reform and repression against non-governmental organisations. Our emergency resolution today was triggered by the violent suppression of peaceful protests in connection with a massive environmental disaster. As a result, there were peaceful demonstrations in many cities, to which the state responded with arrests and violence against demonstrators. The Vietnamese Government has announced that it will have the causes of this environmental disaster investigated independently, and that is a good thing. It is equally important to hold those responsible to account and to compensate those affected appropriately. Above all, however, the Vietnamese Government is called upon to release immediately the arrested demonstrators who have merely exercised their fundamental right to freedom of assembly and expression. Since the beginning of the year, we have been concerned about an increase in intimidation, attacks on and arrests of human rights defenders such as Nguyen Van Dai, who was arrested provocatively just one day after the EU-Vietnam Human Rights Dialogue and has been in prison ever since for propaganda against the state. I believe that the EU delegation on the ground must continue to fight for this release.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Vietnamese regime has decided to respond violently to legitimate voices protesting against the failed institutional response to the ecological disaster that has seriously damaged the fish stocks of the coastal provinces. Not even the recent visit of US President Obama stopped the repression and six other activists were arrested.  This is just the latest example of a wide-ranging campaign of intimidation of political opponents and defenders of fundamental freedoms. There are at least eighty prisoners among journalists and activists currently in detention, guilty only of peacefully expressing their disagreement. In the country, which ranks last in the world rankings for press freedom, the government maintains strict control over the media and has recently introduced new laws that further exacerbate censorship. We therefore call on the Vietnamese authorities to put an end to the systematic violation of freedom of expression, as well as to all forms of persecution of activists.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Author. – Vietnam is an important partner for the EU in a crucial region. We welcomed the partnership and cooperation agreement here by a large majority a few months ago.  The negotiations for the Free Trade Agreement have been concluded and we made a very constructive visit to Vietnam with the ASEAN delegation a while ago. So eu-Vietnam relations are intensive and a proper discussion of fundamental freedoms in Vietnam should be a crucial part of those relations.  I am referring in particular to a number of issues that are rightly endorsed in this resolution which we are voting on today: the suppression, intimidation and persecution of bloggers activists, the suppression of religious minorities and the lack of freedom of the press and freedom of expression. It is up to the EU, the European External Action Service, and the delegation in Hanoi – which is already doing a very good job in this area – to make use of all the opportunities we have in the framework of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and the Free Trade Agreement, to force positive change in Vietnam.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Author. Mr President, protests are continuing in Vietnam, following the environmental scandal that effectively set fire to the powder in April. Our resolution, of course, denounces the brutal repression that has been organized by the authorities ever since, and President Obama's visit last May served as an alibi, again, for the authorities to make further totally arbitrary arrests. Every day, journalists, bloggers, human rights activists and religious leaders are arrested. Vietnam, not surprisingly, is one of the red lanterns in the world press freedom rankings. We continue to condemn these continuing violations and call for the release of all those who have been thrown behind bars, such as Thich Quang Dô, the leader and symbol of the Vietnamese Buddhist movement, who has been deprived of his liberty almost continuously for almost 34 years now - he is 88 years old, Mr President, he is under house arrest in Saigon , without cause, without charge, and his health deteriorated sharply. We call on Mrs Mogherini to put all the weight of the Council and the Commission in securing her and all the others' release.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Vietnam is now an essential partner of Europe and that is precisely why we insist that it respect human rights.  Freedom of association and the press, but also religious freedom, cannot be compromised. The case of the persecution of Catholics in Vietnam is of great concern: they are still seen as the enemies of the state. The Bill on Beliefs and Religions currently being negotiated in parliament is a threat not only to Catholics, but also to all other religions in Vietnam. This law, by not recognizing the legal existence of a religious organization, is in direct contradiction with the freedom of belief enshrined in the Vietnamese Constitution.  The authorities therefore do not respect the fundamental law and I ask Mr Mélenchon, who is a friend of all communists, to make a phone call to Vietnam to tell them that they do not respect the Constitution. This is very serious, Mr Mélenchon, and I know you agree with me. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).)

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: "blue card" question. I will always agree with you, dear colleague, to defend freedom and, especially, freedom of conscience including, of course, freedom of religion, since this idea was born in my homeland and is called secularism. Now, sir, it is my turn to ask you whether you would say the same thing about freedom of religion in Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain or other countries that we never hear about here, when it is enough for a country to have a single communist or left-wing minister for us to hear, for hours, protests of all kinds. , which are sometimes well founded, it must be admitted, and sometimes are not at all, if not through propaganda efforts.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: "blue card" answer. I am glad to hear Mr Mélenchon on respect for religious freedom and I would just like to tell him that we have also spoken very often about the cases he has cited, but since he spends too much time on the streets of Paris and elsewhere, he has not had the opportunity to follow our debates.  Therefore, Mr Mélenchon, be nice, come here more frequently because it's your job!

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the promotion and respect for human rights does not pose a threat to the stability of a country, but, on the contrary, contributes to its strengthening. In Vietnam fundamental rights, including freedom of expression, the right to opinion, association are restricted. The press and religious freedom do not have a better situation. Human rights activists and dissident bloggers face constant harassment and intimidation, including physical assault and imprisonment. I strongly condemn continued human rights violations, including political intimidation, harassment, arbitrary arrests and unfair trials against political activists, dissident journalists and human rights defenders. It is essential that the authorities in Vietnam combat discrimination against women by introducing legislation against trafficking in human beings and effective measures to combat the phenomenon of domestic violence. The European Union delegation must use all the tools to help the Vietnamese authorities make progress in the field of human rights.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The resolution on Vietnam calls on the authorities in paragraph 10 to put an end to religious persecution. I wholeheartedly support this appeal. Religious persecution in Vietnam is mainly the christian side, especially ethnic minorities in the central highlands and in the north. Dissemination of bibles and Christian reading in their language is forbidden, as is the holding of worship services. What is darker is the fate of dozens of Christians from these ethnic minorities, who face years in prison under harsh conditions on highly dubious charges. Downright sinister forms takes on religious persecution in Vietnam in the event of staged accidents. That happened to the Vietnamese predecessor Nam last month with three fellow Christians. The 56-year-old Nam was scooped up by an army truck and died at the scene. Commission, the seriousness of religious persecution in Vietnam is evident. Let your intervention with the Vietnamese authorities be just as obvious and urgent!

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the English have an idiomatic proverb that says ‘You cannot have your cake and eat it’, which is used to illustrate trade-offs. This aptly summarises the situation of the EU relationship with Vietnam, which is a dysfunctional one. In February 2016, the European Union signed a free trade agreement with Vietnam on the usual expectation that Vietnam would do something about its human rights, and that the human rights situation would improve. Well, clearly it has not done so, and the recent Obama visit proved exactly that. The message to the European Union therefore is: dispense with your expectations; stop using trade as a lever; recognise that the world is changing and the era of using trade to influence human rights is long gone, and, finally, that European Union imperialist pretensions are not only not working but, indeed, are counterproductive in the sphere of human rights.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, everyone here is alarmed by the massive abuses of basic human rights in Vietnam.  We must not forget that Vietnam is, politically, a communist regime. Communism has killed more than 100 million people worldwide over the past century. Many European political parties and other intellectuals supported the Viet Minh in its time. As you prepare to vote for the transatlantic treaty, part of the international trade matrix desired by the United States, you are de facto accepting the Trans-Pacific Partnership, of which Washington has made the Vietnamese regime one of the main pillars. Thus, the Vietnamese communist regime, legitimized by its economic partnerships with the European Union and the United States, can continue to exercise its multiple human rights violations.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, Vietnam’s proposed 5th Draft Law on Belief and Religion is directly in violation of international human rights law, to which Vietnam is a party. If passed, the provisions of the draft law would act as a powerful instrument of control, placing overly-broad limitations on the practice of religion or belief within the country. The EU must urge Vietnam to come up with a new draft that conforms to Vietnam’s obligations under Article 18 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, one that ensures that the practice of any religion or belief in Vietnam is not conditional upon a process of state recognition, registration and approval. Such a process would result in discrimination or other violations of the human rights of ethnic and religious minorities, and in favouritism towards recognised, state-controlled or state-friendly groups. Above all, the fundamental freedom of religion or belief needs to become a reality in Vietnam.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, as this resolution indicates, Vietnam is one of our main trading partners in Asia and it must be recognised that in some areas it has made progress towards a more open and tolerant society, of which the legalisation of same-sex marriage is a very recent example. Unfortunately, we must also point out that, despite the calls and recommendations of various international entities, there are still too many situations in which Vietnam's single party regime continues to incur serious abuses of power and human rights violations, which cannot and should not be ignored. The repression of the rights of demonstration and assembly, as well as the persecution of human rights activists, the outrage of religious freedom, the shivering of international laws and the recommendations of the UN envoys, must be harshly criticized, whether in Vietnam or anywhere else in the world where these same events occur.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Mr President, I appreciate the concerns expressed in the joint resolution. It fairly reflects the views on the latest developments in Vietnam shared by my colleagues, at least within the European Parliament. While a strong message of condemnation can be sent, the resolution is particularly critical in some areas. I would have appreciated a more carefully calibrated message that makes the Vietnamese feel that they can be part of the solution, rather than the problem itself. Comprehensive domestic reform should always be encouraged, but our top-down approach may not yield the results that we are looking to ultimately achieve. Let us be as pragmatic as possible because when we punish the Vietnamese Government we punish their people, including the most unfortunate, whether we like it or not.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I am prepared to support the draft resolution, even though I am from the Czech Republic, where there is a very important and large community of Vietnamese citizens who are, I would say, a very strong link between the Czech Republic and Vietnam. Nevertheless, I believe that the trade link itself, which is here and which is very important, cannot be a reason not to criticise the suppression of human rights in Vietnam. To me, the proposal seems balanced, there are both critical points concerning, for example, the form of vague provisions of the Criminal Code, which is then used to suppress civil and political activists, and the points where we praise Vietnam, perhaps for its access to sexual minorities. I will therefore support this resolution and think that it can be a good contribution to future cooperation and dialogue with Vietnam on human rights.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are still serious concerns about human rights violations in Vietnam. Twenty-four independent organisations, some international, have released a report drawing attention to human rights violations in Vietnam. The document includes abuses of freedom of religion and belief. In Vietnam, independent political parties, trade unions and human rights organisations are banned and official authorisation is required for public gatherings. They are concerned about the ban on free demonstrations and the arrests of certain political activists. The Commission must demand compliance with the commitments made in the agreement and also push itself to take unilateral measures in the event that Vietnam continues to disrespect fundamental freedoms. We must ensure that relations with Vietnam, however intense, are subordinate to the improvement of human rights in the country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, independent political parties, trade unions and human rights organisations are still banned in Vietnam, and a new law was adopted in April 2016 restricting freedom of expression and enhancing censorship. At the same time, there was a violent crackdown on demonstrations in May. At the same time, under the free trade agreement signed as early as 2015, the European Union and Vietnam are supposed to have launched a dialogue on the protection of human rights. However, this agreement is far from protecting citizens' rights. What it achieves is to boost the speculation of large enterprises at the expense of small and medium-sized enterprises as well as citizens. In the face of these violations in Vietnam, the European Union should take immediate measures to stop all forms of repression against persons exercising the rights of freedom of expression and to ensure that the Vietnamese Government complies with the recommendations of the UN and the Commission on Human Rights, repealing any legislation that runs counter to citizens' freedoms.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, last year we celebrated the 25th anniversary of EU-Vietnam relations. In Vietnam, a one-party system since 1975, the communist party rules over 90 million souls, allowing no challenge to its leadership and having control over the National Assembly and the courts. In Vietnam, civil liberties, freedom of speech and human rights are concepts that are not taken seriously and violations of the most fundamental human rights happen on a daily basis. Mr Thích Quảng Độ, a Buddhist monk and 2016 Nobel Prize nominee and a prisoner of conscience adopted by Amnesty International, has spent 30 years in jail for his peaceful opposition to the communist regime. He said, and I quote, ‘civilised society should never allow any government, whatsoever its ideology or political creed, to derogate from universal human rights and isolate its people behind an iron curtain on the pretext of non-interference into the nation’s internal affairs’.  Colleagues, until when will we allow the EU to be complacent with dictatorial regimes like the ones in Venezuela or Vietnam? They both start with a ‘V’ but it is not a ‘V for victory’, it is ‘V for villainy’.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when the PARTNERSHIP Agreement was signed in 2015 between the EU and Vietnam, we all hoped that it would be the dawn of a new day, the dawn of greater respect for human rights. That was not the case. Alas, Vietnam, despite having signed important pacts such as the international covenant on civil and political rights or the United Nations Convention against Torture, unfortunately never takes these commitments seriously and does not actually implement those legal reforms that would be essential to make them operational. Instead, we are seeing an increase in the repression of freedom of movement, an increase in the death penalty, strict limits on freedom of expression and the press and numerous prisoners of conscience, independent activists who are attacked, intimidated, confined to their homes and tortured, prisoners harassed in abominable and unacceptable conditions in prisons. We cannot allow people like Nguyèn Văn Đài or Lê Thu Hà to be prosecuted for defending human rights as if they had campaigned against the state. A state that denies human rights is not a state that can defend itself by crushing the people who support them. If we do not bring to life those clauses for geopolitical and economic interests of the treaties that we sign, then we are more hypocritical than we would like our citizens to believe.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – There are grave human rights violations in Vietnam, as the Communist Party of Vietnam there has absolute control over the country and has not been willing to reash its power since 1975. It is therefore very important to establish a multi-party system in Vietnam. The Vietnam resolution calls on the Vietnamese Government to immediately stop harassing, intimidating and prosecuting human rights activists. Political intimidation, harassment, assaults, severe imprisonment and unjust judicial proceedings targeting political activists, journalists, bloggers and human rights defenders must also be condemned. The Communist Party of Vietnam also fully controls the media and thus freedom of speech, imposing harsh penalties on those who dare to criticise the government. Therefore, the European Union delegation has an important role to play in monitoring the Vietnamese Government and thus in protecting human rights defenders. The resolution also carries an important message and demand that Vietnam combat discrimination against women by introducing anti-smuggling legislation and taking concrete measures to reduce violence and families. In short, more needs to be done by the European Union for human rights in Vietnam.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I think in some respects it is disappointing that we have to have this resolution. We do have to have it because, any place where there is violation of human rights, then it is only right that the European Union should express its advice and its opposition to that type of development. The reason I say it is disappointing is because I was part of the European delegation to Vietnam last November. It is a lovely country; we were treated very well; they obviously have a high regard for cooperation with the European Union. Subsequently we signed the free trade agreement with them. Indeed you would think, from observing people as they go around on their little motorbikes, that everything is lovely and happy. They are making great progress, but obviously in the area of human rights a lot more needs to be done.  Yesterday, we had an ASEAN delegation meeting here, where there were representative from Vietnam and the other nine countries involved, and human rights was discussed. It is by continuously raising this issue and maybe having it as a quid pro quo for future cooperation that they will gradually move to do the right thing with regard to respecting human rights, religious leaders, etc.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we take good note of Parliament’s concerns regarding the human rights situation in Vietnam. This debate is definitely timely and highly relevant. When we discuss the situation in Vietnam today, we must take account of where the country came from. Then we see clear evidence of progress, notably in the socio-economic domain. However, governance structures, and in particular respect for human rights, remain areas of concern. The frequent use of controversial national security provisions in the penal code to repress dissent is very worrying. This does not mean that we do not recognise important positive developments. I would highlight the ratification of the UN Convention Against Torture and other Degrading or Inhumane Treatment (UNCAT) in 2015. Vietnam is also a frontrunner in the region regarding LGTBI rights. We also see increasing – and often critical – public debate in social media. In other key areas, however, Vietnam is found wanting: freedom of expression and assembly, of religion or belief, and application of the death penalty. We note frequent cases of harassment and arrest of human rights activists. We also note the conviction of independent journalists, bloggers and victims of land confiscation to harsh prison sentences for peacefully expressing their opinions. We systematically discuss these issues with the authorities, including at the highest level, calling on the Government to end persecution and harassment and to release all peaceful human-rights advocates in the country. These issues are also addressed through our annual enhanced Human Rights Dialogue. Beyond that, we provide specific support to promote and strengthen respect for human rights and the rule of law. As stated in the joint press statement of last December, the EU offers support to Vietnam’s institutional reforms, bringing them into line with the recommendations it accepted in the United Nations Universal Periodic Review. We also stand ready to support the drafting of the Law on Belief and Religion, to ensure its compliance with international commitments, and to support the implementation of UNCAT. The EU wants a strong and prosperous Vietnam: a Vietnam that respects the rule of law and human rights, and honours its international commitments. Let me be clear: the European Union and Vietnam enjoy a close and deepening mutually beneficial partnership, which is based on the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and the Free Trade Agreement. But – as in any relationship – we have our differences, and first and foremost in the critical area of human rights. We are addressing those differences with all the instruments at our disposal. Our objective is to achieve tangible results. I have confidence that, over time, we will contribute to strengthening human rights in Vietnam as a fundamental element of our partnership.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: I would like to mention the four Israelis killed yesterday in a cowardly attack. We do not care about the nationality of those who killed them, we are only interested in seeing innocent blood on the ground once again. So it is right that Parliament should remember the four Israelis killed yesterday and gather around their families.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I support this report, which concerns the necessary modernisation of the system and which will greatly facilitate citizens of the Member States of the European Union. There are still too many administrative burdens and formalities when it comes to exchanging certain public documents in Europe. It is our duty and responsibility to simplify procedures and reduce the high costs paid for the transfer and translation of certain public documents, such as birth certificate, death certificate, marriage certificate. I support the introduction of standard European multilingual forms, based on the example of social security e-forms. They will significantly reduce translation costs without imposing obligations to recognise the content itself. I reiterate my support for this report and congratulate the rapporteur on the work done.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I also supported this proposal. I am generally sceptical about the adoption of new and new European legislation, but if legislation makes life easier for the citizens of the European Union – and in this case, for example, we remove administrative barriers and obstacles – then I believe that such European legislation makes sense. That is why I voted in favour of the document and why I say publicly that such legislation is good and I am happy to support it. These proposals will lead to better mutual recognition of public documents, clear uniform criteria for certain public documents, uniform forms shall be established. It is perhaps a pity that the project is not so ambitious and that, for example, diplomas or certificates of vocational training or certificates of disability have not been mutually recognised. Even so, as I said, it's a step in the right direction.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. The free movement of citizens of the European Union is, at least within the Schengen area, one of the most significant progress made by the Community and the aim of this regulation is to facilitate the free movement of citizens and to simplify the formal functioning of certain public documents within the territory of the European Union. It is important to note that the Regulation does not provide for the recognition of the content of public documents for such purposes. Today, millions of Europeans regularly move between Member States to study, do business, simply travel, etc., and so far the two primary accepted documents were a passport and an ID card. Following the final adoption of the Regulation, it will also be possible to extend this list. And, of course, I unequivocally support the adoption of this legislation that has long been adopted. I would like to stress the importance of balancing citizens' rights and their implementation in practice with maintaining security standards.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Available data show that internal migration within the European Union is still low. This means a huge untapped potential. That is why I voted with all conviction today with the European Parliament's report on a regulation allowing the promotion of free movement through simplification in the adoption of public documents. The Regulation covers all civil status documents and certain other documents which, for example, concern residence, nationality or a certificate of non-criminal record. It provides for the abolition of the verification requirement and measures to facilitate the acceptance of copies of certified documents and certified translations.  The most important element, however, is the introduction of standard and multilingual forms for most of the public documents covered by the Regulation. Parliament also sought to include similar regulations on school diplomas and certificates, as well as other documents relevant to the employer, m.in. confirming qualifications. However, this has not been achieved in the framework of the regulation we are discussing today – and it is a pity, as this would significantly improve the movement of workers within the single market.  It is to be hoped that the positive experience gained from the functioning of the Regulation will in the near future lead Member State governments to accept facilitations in the field of diplomas and school certificates. In conclusion, there is significant progress and facilitation of the procedures to be completed by European citizens travelling between Member States, but there are still not enough.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report on simplification for the presentation of public documents, because the mobility of EU citizens is now a reality that we must defend at all levels. Some twelve million Europeans study, work or live in a Member State of which they are not citizens. EU citizens and businesses already exercise their right to free movement or the freedoms of the internal market – it is the greatest success of a united Europe – but unfortunately they can still encounter administrative complications when they have to submit public documents to the authorities of another Member State. We are talking, for example, about making life easier for students who relate to different administrative systems, tourists who need the health system when they are travelling, and in any case European citizens who do not know but are subject to different tax systems. The free movement of citizens and businesses does not stop at the abolition of visas or border controls. It is precisely administrative practices that affect daily life, and this is, above all, what needs to be simplified.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – I support the Council’s position and have voted against this amendment, which is a proposal not to support the legislation. I disagree with that as this is a good piece of legislation, which aims to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents, for example, by abolishing the costly and burdensome apostille requirement. It is important to note that it does not affect recognition of the content of public documents in order to preserve the sovereignty of Member States, particularly with regard to family law matters, etc. The regulation covers all civil status documents, and certain other documents that are often required by members of the public concerning, for example, residence, nationality and absence of a criminal record. Like my colleague Mr Pospíšil, I am slightly disappointed that diplomas, etc. were not included, and hopefully that can be rectified in due course, but I do welcome multilingual standard forms.   Tá sé sin fíor go háirithe do mo theanga dhúchais féin, an Ghaolainn.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, the authentication and translation of original documents are problems faced by many European citizens, including many Romanian citizens living, working in other EU states. Once this regulation has entered into force, the legalisation and translation of documents very important to citizens, such as birth, death, marriage, divorce certificates, documents certifying the adoption or custody of a child, the criminal record or nationality will be translated and certified very quickly. Secondly, it should be noted that this regulation does not apply to the content of documents, but only to the efficiency, speed of certification and translation.  Three, I support the proposal for the establishment of multilingual forms for these documents, obviously, including in the Romanian language.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I am professing the principle of a certain moderation in European law, i.e. that it should be an essential part of European law and an expression of the principle of subsidiarity. However, in this case, I have come to know that this is an arrangement which is advantageous for European citizens. It simplifies the circulation of documents in terms of their form requirements. I think that my pre-ers have said here a number of advantages that this new arrangement offers, and I could support it. I am a little sorry that the regulation was perhaps not more ambitious, that we did not touch not only the form, but also the content, which is a substantial part of legalisation. However, this is, I think, a task for the future period, and I firmly believe that, even in this part, the EU institutions will be able to make life easier for citizens, as they have done at least in that form.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Acceptance of certain public documents between Member States may facilitate the free movement of citizens and businesses. The contents of the documents are not touched, leaving national family law regulations intact. The text is a good starting point for reducing bureaucracy for citizens and administrations. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote the free movement of citizens, simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The text does not deal with the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular in order to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. The Regulation covers documents relating to marital status, as well as other documents often requested by citizens, relating, for example, to residence, nationality and criminal records.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This new public documents regulation is a key measure that benefits citizens exercising their rights to live anywhere within the European Union. It allows official certificates of birth, death, nationality and some other similarly important documents to be accepted more readily by relevant authorities throughout the EU without the need to pay for expensive administration or translation procedures. The regulation allows for user-friendly multilingual standard forms. It does not encroach upon the rights of Member States to issue official certificates and it respects their jurisdiction to conclude bilateral international agreements with third countries on such matters. The new regulation also supports public authorities making proper enquiries of their counterparts in other EU countries through innovative information technology coordination and systems to help ensure that free movement for people operates smoothly.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation. Our group would have liked to go further, namely to broaden the scope of this text and to abolish these red tape even further. But it is clear that Member States are still too attached to their national procedures and continue to be wary of each other. We hope, however, that this regulation will help restore trust between Member States, in order to further reduce the administrative burden on European citizens.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the amendment to a recommendation at second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents to the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1024/2012, because it is legislation that will greatly benefit the daily lives of European citizens.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Documents are often recognised by the authorities or courts of another State only if their authenticity or probative value has been established in a special procedure. Two administrative procedures are used to confirm the authenticity of a foreign public document, the so-called Hague Apostille and legalisation. The aim of this proposal is to exempt the confirmation of the authenticity of a foreign public document from legalisation and apostille in order to facilitate adoption and promote the free movement of citizens. The proposal also aims to simplify certification and translation processes and introduce the multilingualism of standard documents. This would affect 12 million citizens working, studying or residing in another Member State. Especially in border regions, this regulation will simplify people's lives, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted against the proposal and therefore for the amendment to reject this report: given the applicable conventions already in force, it is difficult to find the real interest of this text and what would help to combat existing fraud. This is yet another gimmick that will add to the burden on our already overburdened administrations, on which, for some Member States, austerity prevails.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy, I would like to confirm I voted in favour of this proposal to reject the Council´s position on this matter. The EU wants to promote free movement by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents. This would mean the UK is forced to recognise civil documents produced as part of the right to freedom of movement. This will lead to an enforced lowering of the guard on checking the veracity of the contents and the genuine nature of the document itself. This is a criminal and forger´s dream and is a threat to the security of our country, and it will curtail the UK´s ability to properly check documentation. The case for the need for this legislation has not been made out. The claimed keystone of this regulation is the creation of multilingual standard forms for most public documents concerned. This is clearly the precursor to an EU-wide and EU-controlled system of civil documentation. Finally, as a matter of principle, I disagree with the unelected EU civil servants enforcing legislation on the British people.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to introduce new European rules to facilitate the free movement of citizens by making it easier to prove the authenticity of documents, such as a birth or marriage certificate, in another Eu Member State.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which seeks to facilitate the recognition of birth or marriage certificates. The new rules will simplify the presentation of certain public documents, such as birth or marriage certificates, to institutions in other EU countries. For example, they will no longer need to be legalised and to provide a translation into another language. The Regulation provides that certain documents or criminal records of civil status may be accompanied by a multilingual standard form. It will allow individuals wishing to submit these documents to the authorities of other EU countries to avoid the obligation to present them together.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal streamlines the procedures currently used between Member States to verify the authenticity of individual authentic documents while complementing the eu sectoral legislation in force by abolishing the requirement of verification and simplifying the use of copies and translations. It draws on existing eu sectoral law and relevant international law sources, while strengthening confidence in authentic documents issued in other Member States. However, the proposal does not amend but complements existing EU sectoral law, which contains provisions on over-certification or other formalities or administrative cooperation. It also provides for the simplification of other formalities relating to the adoption of authentic documents in other Member States, namely certified copies and certified translations. The ENF Group recommended that the European Parliament reject the Council's position at first reading. I do not consider the rejection to be justified, as this regulation will result in significant relief and cost reductions in everyday life for Hungarians who work or study abroad. The rejection is a resolution against the principle of free movement within the Union, which would be in the interest of the large number of Hungarians who, hopefully temporarily, are seeking prosperity in the West. The proposal also provides for facilitation in legal proceedings, as it will make it easier and more cost-effective for Hungarian citizens to pursue their interests in the field of private international law. Accordingly, I voted against the rejection.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves a draft regulation aimed at promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the Union. For civil registration documents, the regulation provides for the exemption from legalization and apostille. Easier acceptance measures are also provided for certified compliant copies.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. With these new rules, we are moving towards a true European common area, a true political union and not just economic one. In short, towards achieving more and better Europe. The ratification of the new rules facilitates free movement within the EU, as it involves simplifying procedures for demonstrating the authenticity of official documents such as birth or marriage certificates issued in another Member State. To avoid the need for translations, a new multilingual form will be attached to the documents in some cases. Simplification will also apply to documents that citizens living in another EU country must submit if they wish to vote or run as candidates in the European or municipal elections of their country of residence.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the pillars of the integration process is freedom of movement within the territory of the Union, a principle which is a reality confirmed by the existence of more than twelve million citizens studying, working and living in a Member State other than that of which they are citizens. In order to further facilitate cross-border mobility, a proposal for a new regulation has been presented which simplifies the requirements for the submission of certain public documents such as criminal records, civil status documents and residence documents. The Delvaux report, which I supported, endorses the Council's proposal which, in addition to providing for exemption from certain administrative formalities, also establishes standard multilingual forms for most of the public documents concerned. The failure to include diplomas and other types of business-related documents is a negative factor that will have to be addressed in the future.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this amendment, which is the proposal for Parliament to reject the Council's position, since what the report presented intends to adopt is the compromise between the Council and Parliament for the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The aim of the rapporteur's report is to promote the free movement of Union citizens between countries, simplifying the acceptance of public documents. It is a technical report that will benefit the citizens of the European Union. That is why I am in favour, and I am voting against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. More than twelve million Union citizens temporarily reside in non-national States. This regulation will help them overcome the heavy administrative burdens of mutual non-recognition of many certifications that are requested in the country of destination and issued by the country of origin. The standard multilingual form is a breakthrough, but it is incomprehensible that we have not managed to make it work on its own and must be accompanied by the original. At least citizens are freed from having to prove the authenticity of certificates, work that is transferred to administrations.  Let us hope that the review clauses will improve this and other deficiencies quickly.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The legislation covered by this recommendation at second reading aims to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. It does not concern the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular in order to preserve the sovereignty of Member States in relation to family law. Several documents are affected by this proposal, but it is mentioned in a recital that this regulation should not apply to passports and identity cards. In view of the applicable conventions already in force, I wonder about the real interest of this text and how it would help to combat existing fraud. Rather, it is yet another gimmick that will add to the burden on our already overburdened administrations, on which, for some Member States, austerity prevails. I therefore voted in favour of the rejection amendment proposed by our ENF group.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With my vote I intended to support the request to reject this measure.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I supported this recommendation with my vote, in order to continue to promote the freedom of movement of European citizens. To this end, this Regulation simplifies procedures for the acceptance of certain official Union documents, such as all those related to marital status, certificates of residence, nationality or absence of criminal records, which are documents highly requested by citizens for day-to-day formalities.  Simplification measures will also apply to certified copies or translations, and standardized multilingual forms are envisaged to facilitate further such procedures.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses Parliament its position on a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the European Union.  The aim of this legislation is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the recognition of certain public documents in the European Union. The legislation does not regulate the recognition of the content of public documents as it seeks to preserve the independence of the Member States in the field of family law. The mobility of Union citizens is a reality: around 12 million people are in the eu-25. citizens study, work or reside in a Member State other than their nationality. Although Union citizens and businesses currently enjoy the right to freedom of movement or the freedoms of the internal market, they may face administrative difficulties when they have to submit public documents to the authorities of another Member State, for example upon arrival in another Member State. Following the interinstitutional negotiations, the co-legislators and the Commission agreed on a compromise text. Thus, this Regulation applies to civil status documents and some other documents frequently requested by citizens and relating, for example, to residence, nationality and criminal record. The Regulation provides that these public documents do not require legalisation and apostille, two administrative formalities normally applicable to public documents issued by another Member State.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote is a step towards implementing new legislation to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses, facilitating the recognition and acceptance of certain public documents within the Union. In addition to being one of the Union's greatest achievements, internal mobility within the EU is a reality that affects more and more citizens and businesses, thus making it necessary to reduce the bureaucratic difficulties and the burden of administrative burdens that they often face. The text adopted today facilitates, in particular, the recognition of certain documents, such as those relating to civil status, residence, and criminal records. However, the simplification and reduction of administrative formalities need to be extended further and extended to other types of documents, such as diplomas, other qualifications and disability certifications. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to present a new proposal for the acceptance and recognition of public documents that remain outside the scope of this legislation.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this Report on promoting free movement by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. With this Regulation, trust between Member States would be strengthened with a view to strengthening regulation in the future, and reducing more bureaucratic burdens on European citizens.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Given the existing conventions, it is difficult to find the real interest of this text and what would help to combat existing fraud. This is yet another gimmick that will add to the burden on our already overburdened administrations, on which, for some Member States, austerity prevails. I therefore voted in favour of the rejection amendment tabled by my group, the ENF Group.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with the simplification of acceptance of certain public documents. By simplifying the procedure, this will facilitate procedures for Irish citizens moving between Member States. The main ways acceptance is simplified are the exemption from legislation, apostille or similar formalities for a set list of public documents including birth, death, name, marriage, divorce, registered partnership, parenthood, adoption, domicile, nationality, and absence of a criminal record. In theory, persons producing these documents will not have to go through expensive and lengthy procedures legalising or translating these documents any more. For now diplomas, certificates of disabilities and documents related to established businesses have been excluded. As this will not affect national family or administrative law, there are no sovereignty issues and so therefore I voted in favour of this report.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Free movement within the EU is one of the fundamental principles on which the process of European integration is based, as well as one of the pillars of Union citizenship, introduced by the Maastricht Treaty of 1992. With this in mind, the new regulation on simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents (such as civil status documents, residence certificates, citizenship and criminal records) is an important step forward in simplifying the acceptance of these types of documents by the competent public authorities of other Member States.  This draft regulation will further encourage mobility within the Union, simplifying the lives of European citizens and reducing the monetary and non-monetary costs of such bureaucratic practices. Despite the many positive points contained in the proposal, which I whole much support, we must nevertheless stress a certain regret at the non-inclusion in the legislative draft of other types of documents such as diplomas, training certificates or certificates of disability.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The aim of this legislation is to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents within the European Union. The regulation provides for the provision of legalisation and apostilles of public documents of nationals of Member States within the European Union, such as birth and death certificates, as well as the creation of multilingual forms. This text is in fact devoid of major interest in view of the existing conventions, which exempt almost all EU Member States from apostille and legalisation procedures. That is why I voted in favour of an amendment to reject the text presented by my Europe of Nations and Freedoms group.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this regulation because it represents an important step towards eliminating the bureaucratic burden of submitting public documents to the authorities of another Member State.
