The mobility of EU citizens is constantly increasing. At present, some twelve million Europeans study, work or live in a Member State of which they are not citizens. The removal of legalisation and post-mail from cross-border public documents, the acceptance of certified copies and translations, and the creation of standard multilingual forms for most of the public documents concerned are all important innovations. Once the national administrations have acquired the new way of working, the scope of administrative simplifications will have to be further expanded. In order to facilitate the labour market, diplomas and training certificates and all documents relevant to enterprises should be included among the documents eligible for simplification. It will also be necessary to give autonomy to the planned multilingual standard forms so as not to have to attach the national documents in question to them, and special attention must be paid to disability certificates.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ There was only one amendment to this file, which was an amendment to reject. I voted against that amendment, thus endorsing the agreed text. The file concerns the simplification of acceptance of certain public documents. By this, the file is not about the harmonisation, nor standardisation of these public documents, nor does it oblige Member States to accept the content of these public documents.  The main way acceptance is simplified is the exemption from legislation, apostille or similar formalities for a set list of public documents including birth, death, name, marriage, divorce, registered partnership, parenthood, adoption, domicile, nationality, and absence of a criminal record. In theory, persons producing these documents will not have to go through expensive and lengthy procedures legalising or translating these documents any more.  As this will get rid of a lot of unnecessary bureaucracy for EU citizens, but will not affect national family or administrative law (or raise sovereignty issues), I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the measures which are outlined in it will make the lives of the citizens of the European Union much easier by simplifying a number of procedures related to the use of certain public documents. Taking the mobility of European Union citizens into account, removing the administrative process associated with certain public documents promotes effective communication and businesses.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 There are around twelve million European citizens studying, working or living in a Member State of the Union other than their own. Although freedom of movement and all economic freedoms inherent in the internal market are firmly entrenched, European citizens in another European state face administrative complications on a daily basis when they have to submit public documents to national authorities. In view of this need, the proposed regulation will considerably reduce bureaucratic difficulties. Civil status documents and certain other documents, such as residence, nationality and criminal records, will be exempt from legalisation and apostilla, administrative formalities traditionally provided for public documents when they are to be submitted in another Member State. Facilitated acceptance measures are also provided for authenticated copies and certified translations. The adoption of standard multilingual forms, which is provided for most public documents, will have the effect of simplifying the administrative process and facilitating citizens and businesses operating in a European country other than their country of origin. The regulation is another piece for the construction of the single market, for greater cooperation between Member States and strengthens the free movement which is a fundamental value of European integration. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the report as it contains several negative elements.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the rejection of the recommendation to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents to the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999 on the common organisation of the market in beef and field 1024/2012 has been an attempt to reverse and cancel the joint position of this House to date. As I believe that simplifying requirements on public documents is an opportunity to reduce red tape for the benefit of citizens, I voted against the rejection proposal.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The mobility of EU citizens is an issue close to my heart. In 2016 more than 10 million people study or work abroad and this figure, in my view, is very encouraging. These numbers are, in fact, very significant because they show that we are achieving a European Union that allows children to acquire different academic and professional skills. This phenomenon is very important now and I am convinced that it must be encouraged and simplified as much as possible. The aim of this project is to create standard multilingual forms for as many public documents as possible in order to facilitate the bureaucratic process of the European mobile citizen. For these reasons, which I consider to be of fundamental importance, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this legislation, whose aim is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents, for example by abolishing the costly and burdensome apostille requirement. It does not affect recognition of the content of public documents in order to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States, in particular with regards to family law matters.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The Union is often accused of dealing with small things, of its decisions having a distant impact on the lives of Europeans. This is the example of a complex instrument, tiny, but whose impact on citizens is quite considerable. With increasing European mobility, and which is also intended to be stimulated, it is clear that certain acts are important. This is particularly clear with the recognition of public documents, which required somewhat lengthy processes. However, with that regulation, formalities are removed from that procedure for certain public documents, for example relating to marital status or criminal record. In the EPP we fought to cover other documents, such as academic diplomas, which the Council ultimately did not allow. Nevertheless, it was possible to introduce a clause for revision of this instrument after this first phase of implementation. I therefore support this report.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because it will make it a real relief for our citizens and also for businesses if they want to reap the benefits of the internal market. The introduction of simplified standard uniform forms and the abolition of double procedures will make it easier for documents and other important documents to circulate. Although I would have liked the regulation to be applied further, it is nevertheless a major relief for the mobility of our citizens.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted today in favour of rejecting the Delvaux Report on Promoting free movement by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents. Enforcing a regime under which Member States are, effectively, forced to recognise certain civil documents produced as part of the exercise of the right to freedom of movement will lead to an enforced lowering of the guard on checking the veracity of the contents and genuineness of the document itself.  This is a criminal and terrorist forger’s charter and is a threat to the security of the UK and our ability properly to check documentation. It affects only 2.4% of the population of the entire EU: the case for the need for this legislation has not been made out. The claimed keystone of the regulation is the creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the public documents concerned: this is no less than the precursor to an EU-wide and EU-controlled system of civil documentation. The rapporteur’s claimed concern to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States with regard to family law is thus bogus. Finally, as a matter of principle, we vote against EU legislation.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of making formalities easier for citizens who move across borders to alleviate problems with the cross-border application of tax law, social insurance law and others which deter many citizens from taking the plunge and moving to another Member State. To promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union it does not affect recognition of the content of public documents, particularly out of a concern to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States with regard to family law. I agree that we need to face administrative difficulties when presenting the necessary public documents to the authorities of another Member State, for example because they have moved across a border which require the creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the public documents concerned, something which is also catered for in the report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote the free movement of citizens, simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The text does not deal with the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular in order to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. The Regulation covers documents relating to marital status, as well as other documents often requested by citizens, relating, for example, to residence, nationality and criminal records.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution on the free movement of public documents in the European Union will simplify the administrative burden for citizens moving to another Member State. I voted in favour of this resolution because, by voting, I intend to support the debureaucratisation of administrative procedures, for example, for the recognition of the authenticity of certificates such as birth, marriage or criminal records. This legislation will simplify the lives of citizens and at the same time reduce any costs arising from administrative procedures, for example for official translations. It must now be the national and local administrations that make these new rules effective.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The mobility of Union citizens is a reality: around 12 million of them study, work or live in a Member State other than the one whose nationality they hold. Currently, when citizens and businesses of the European Union exercise their right to free movement or talk about the freedoms of the internal market, they face administrative difficulties. The report refers to civil status documents and several other documents frequently requested by citizens, which concern, for example, residence, nationality and criminal record. I voted to lift these obstacles to the mobility of citizens within the European Union.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 More than 10 million EU citizens take the opportunity to move freely. Staying in another Member State, whether shorter or longer, is still hampered by a number of administrative obstacles. Proof of marital status, a certificate of civil status or even a certificate of morality may be required abroad when working, starting studies or even using services. It is therefore a milestone that the EU institutions have managed to reach an agreement and Parliament supports the text in the Council on the simplified adoption of certain authentic documents. By simplifying administrative formalities, the Regulation will soon facilitate the cross-border adoption of public documents and other evidence of marital status, in particular.  The essential achievement of the Regulation is the establishment of multilingual forms. Multilingualism is an additional burden in administrative matters, and forms that can be issued in all EU official languages will change the situation. Multilingual forms do not affect content, but will still help case managers. What is exhibited in one Member State makes it easier for them to work in their own language in the country of destination. All we have to do is inform citizens about simplification in as many forums as possible.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The main objective of the Regulation is to abolish the requirement to legalise and obtain apostille for public documents which fall within its scope. A number of simplifications have been made regarding certified copies and certified translations. The compromise text provides that the Regulation should apply only to certain public documents, in particular those relating to marital status (m.in. declaration of birth, death, marriage, divorce, parenthood, adoption) and certain other documents that citizens often need, such as residence, nationality and criminal record. Nevertheless, due to the doubts surrounding the regulation, I have decided against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this regulation is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the EU. The regulation covers all civil status documents and certain other documents that are often required by members of the public, concerning for example residence, nationality and absence of a criminal record. Parliament had significantly strengthened the proposal at its first reading, while the Council took a very cautious approach. While it always make sense to abolish more formalities and cut bureaucratic burdens for European citizens, it is also important to see that all rules and safeguards are respected, hence I supported this balanced approach by voting against the proposal to reject the Council position.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 12 million European citizens study, work or live in a Member State other than the one where they were born, and every day more than five million Europeans cross the Internal Borders of the Union to work in another Member State. For this reason, hundreds of thousands of official documents enter the legalisation or certification circuit each year to be recognised in Member States other than the one in which they were issued. As such, I support the rapporteur's proposal to reduce additional cross-border formalities for the recognition of these documents as a measure aimed at facilitating the freedom of movement of citizens.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report deals with the adoption of a regulation to facilitate the free movement of citizens by simplifying the recognition of official documents, such as birth or marriage certificates, in eu Member States. The regulation covers civil registration documents and other documents often required by citizens such as residence, nationality and criminal record. Considering that more than 14 million European citizens live in a Member State different from their Home State, that they face tedious administrative procedures and that it is necessary to ease these administrative obstacles, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to facilitate the free movement of EU citizens by simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents. More and more citizens are exercising their right to free movement and going to another EU country to study or work. The same is true for businesses. It is therefore important to facilitate their administrative procedures.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The aim of this legislation is to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. This is not about recognising the content of public documents, in order to preserve the sovereignty of Member States in matters of family law. For these public documents, the regulation provides for the exemption of legalization and apostille, which are two red tapes provided for cross-border public documents. Given the applicable conventions already in force, it is difficult to identify the added value of this text in terms of combating existing fraud. This is yet another device that will affect the functioning of our already overburdened administrations. Being against this proposal, I voted in favour of the rejection amendment.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States must escape any anchorages that hold them back and improve the quality of life of their citizens by limiting unnecessary and economically damaging suffering to such procedural matters. However, the simplification of procedures must not result in the credibility and security of documents being detrimental.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against the proposal, so for the rejection amendment. Given the existing conventions already in force, it is difficult to find the real interest of this text and what would help to combat existing fraud.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 Simplifying the rules for the circulation of documents must certainly be encouraged as it helps to reduce the asphyxiating bureaucracy that harms citizens, administration and businesses. While appreciating the steps taken in this direction, it regrets that diplomas, training certificates, disability certificates and certain documents relevant to companies have not also been included in the list of documents that are recognisable for acceptance within the European Union. We hope that in future the scope of the regulation can also be broadened to include other documents.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report (second reading) aims at the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the EU. This legislation stems from the provisions of Article 21 TFEU; aims to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the EU. It is not a question of the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. The Regulation covers only documents relating to marital status, as well as some other documents often required of citizens, for example relating to residence, nationality and criminal record. It is proposed to create multilingual forms for most of the public documents concerned to facilitate the process. The Council is critical of not including diplomas and training certificates, certificates of disability and certain documents relevant to companies. Furthermore, multilingual forms cannot circulate independently, but must be attached to the national documents in question, which is a preventable complication. The aim of this legislation is to facilitate the movement of citizens within the EU area, which in many respects is blocked by unnecessary administrative issues and could be faster.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ Due to simplification of procedures that will benefit citizens, I decided to vote in favour.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States must escape any anchorages that hold them back and improve the quality of life of their citizens by limiting unnecessary and economically damaging suffering to such procedural matters. However, the simplification of procedures must not result in the credibility and security of documents being detrimental, which is why I am voting against the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents to the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1024/2012.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that this regulation is a step in the right direction. If adopted, substantial progress will be made for citizens and it will help to build bridges and trust in order to strengthen the regulation in the future and to reduce more bureaucratic burdens for European citizens. However, we could have gone further by, for example, enlarging the scope and abolishing more formalities, but it seems that Member States are currently too attached to their national procedures and still mistrust each other. I therefore welcome the fact that the regulation contains revision clauses with a view to extending the scope of the administrative simplifications in the future. I support a call for the Commission to present a proposal on the acceptance of the content of public documents, including registered partnerships.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to adopt this regulation on promoting the free movement of citizens as I think that the free movement of people is a hugely important aspect of the European project and I support this effort to address several complications and issues that plague it. I support the report in stating that we should make sure that we use a harmonised and simplified method of acceptance of public documents within the EU in order to promote and protect the free movement of people and business. Another positive aspect of these rules is that it reduces unnecessary, costly and burdensome bureaucracy.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the Delvaux report on the promotion of freedom of movement through the simplified recognition of certain public documents. This agreement deals only ostensibly with the issue of bureaucratic relief for millions of binational or foreign families. Indeed, it undermines the subsidiarity and sovereignty of EU Member States in central national competences. I consider this to be particularly dangerous in relation to the repeated recognition of child marriages that are contrary to human rights (also in Germany). Imposing these on all EU Member States would be completely against the EU's actual course of combating child marriage worldwide. This text is unbalanced, ill-considered, politically foolish.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. This legislation promotes the free movement of citizens and businesses. By abolishing the costly and costly requirements of apostille, it is possible to simplify the adoption of certain public documents.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which backs further simplifying procedures for British citizens to make full use of the single market to travel, conduct business and retire. At the same time, however, with some disappointment that the Council was not as progressive as was hoped – my S&D Group would have like to have seen an enlargement of the scope and a reduction in administrative burden.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this amendment, which is the proposal for Parliament to reject the Council's position, since what the report presented intends to adopt is the compromise between the Council and Parliament for the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The aim of the rapporteur's report is to promote the free movement of Union citizens between countries, simplifying the acceptance of public documents. It is a technical report that will benefit the citizens of the European Union. That is why I am in favour, and I am voting against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. We must support all proposals that promote the free movement of European citizens. This is precisely the purpose of this regulation, which will simplify red tape by removing the requirement of legalisation or apostille for documents relating to the status of persons and certificates of life, with documents to be submitted by non-nationals who wish to exercise their right to vote in their Member State of residence for elections to the European Parliament and municipal elections. , and documents relating to the absence of a criminal record. No more mandatory official translations for these documents, which will be accepted as is by all European administrations!  A proposal for the extension of this scheme should be put in place as soon as possible within 2 years to include documents relating to the status and representation of companies, diplomas, intellectual property rights, certificates recognising disability status, or documents relating to social insurance rights.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. Parliament would have liked to include within the scope of the regulation diplomas and education certificates, certificates of disability and certain documents relevant to businesses. Furthermore, multilingual standard forms cannot circulate autonomously but must be annexed to the appropriate national documents, which constitutes an avoidable complication.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this draft regulation as it aims to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. It also foresees simplification of other formalities related to the cross-border acceptance of public documents, namely of certified copies and certified translations. I do not believe that this regulation would benefit the citizens of the European Union due to the numerous concerns regarding safety and security.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The proposal for a regulation aims to ensure the free movement of certain public documents within the Union, thereby promoting the free movement of Eu citizens. Specifically, the Regulation provides for the abolition of formalities (apostille and legalisation) for public documents falling within its scope, various simplifications with regard to certified translations/copies and the introduction of multilingual EU forms. The aim is to avoid the problem of translation by issuing multilingual forms. In particular, I would like to point out that this proposal for a regulation does not in any way harmonise the substantive law of the Member States in the areas concerned. The main aim is to reduce additional cross-border formalities. The Regulation does not require a Member State to recognise the content of a document from another Member State. I agree with the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly salute this report for promoting free movement and simplifying bureaucracy within the European Union. This regulation should have been taken further and more formalities should have been excluded in order to reduce the burdens that fall on European citizens and businesses.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the reading of certain public documents in the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1999/2013. 1024/2012, as freedom of movement and the internal market are one of the KEY values of the EU.  However, the mobility of EU citizens encounters administrative barriers to the commission of public documents to the authorities of another Member State, and this problem needs to be addressed as soon as possible. Fees paid by individuals should be reduced and a reciprocal support system should be put in place to prevent fraud. Multilingual standard forms will also facilitate the free movement of people within the Union and raise the level of equality between those citizens residing in a Member State of which they are not nationals, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Given the existing conventions, it is difficult to find the real interest of this text and what would help to combat existing fraud. This is yet another gimmick that will add to the burden on our already overburdened administrations, on which, for some Member States, austerity prevails. With this in mind, I opposed the text and voted in favour of the ENF rejection amendment.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I and my colleagues voted today in favour of rejecting the Delvaux Report on Promoting free movement by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents. Enforcing a regime under which Member States are, effectively, forced to recognise certain civil documents produced as part of the exercise of the right to freedom of movement will lead to an enforced lowering of the guard on checking the veracity of the contents and genuineness of the document itself. This is a criminal and terrorist forger’s charter and is a threat to the security of the UK and our ability properly to check documentation. It affects only 2.4% of the population of the entire EU: the case for the need for this legislation has not been made out. The claimed keystone of the regulation is the creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the public documents concerned: this is no less than the precursor to an EU-wide and EU-controlled system of civil documentation. The rapporteur’s claimed concern to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States with regard to family law is thus bogus. Finally, as a matter of principle, we vote against EU legislation.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal concerns the simplification of mutual recognition of civil documents between EU countries. Eu citizens moving to another EU country for work or family reasons should save time and money. I believe that free movement is one of the most important benefits of the EU as such. And facilitating the mobility of European citizens, even administratively, when they now have to re-verify documents such as a birth or marriage certificate or an extract from the criminal record, is certainly necessary, because it will facilitate and promote the free movement of persons. I was therefore happy to vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which will promote the freedom of movement of citizens between European countries, by facilitating the free movement of certain public documents between Member States.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report provides for a simplification of the recognition of certain public documents within the EU. In order to avoid administrative complications, a simplification of the recognition of certified copies and sworn translations is planned. I reject the Council's position because of the high risk of abuse in such sensitive areas and the conviction that in such cases the existing administrative procedures and administrative procedures are perfectly reasonable.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The proposal for a regulation aims to ensure the free movement of certain public documents within the Union, thereby promoting the free movement of Eu citizens. Specifically, the Regulation provides for the abolition of formalities (apostille and legalisation) for public documents falling within its scope, various simplifications with regard to certified translations/copies and the introduction of multilingual EU forms. The aim is to avoid the problem of translation by issuing multilingual forms. In particular, I would like to point out that this proposal for a regulation does not in any way harmonise the substantive law of the Member States in the areas concerned. The main aim is to reduce additional cross-border formalities. The Regulation does not require a Member State to recognise the content of a document from another Member State. I agree with the report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The report aims to promote the free movement of public documents. I voted in favour of the report but against the amendment tabled by the far-right group (ENF).

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to establish a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the production of public documents in the European Union. I find the proposal made by the European Commission to be extremely effective in terms of reducing the cost of administrative services for citizens, facilitating legalisation processes and endorsement of cross-border documents. The recognition of certificates supports one of the fundamental rights of European citizens – the free movement of persons across borders. I believe that any administrative obstacles disrupting the mobility of Europeans can be avoided by building a single European framework that includes clearly defined practical instruments of the Internal Market Information System and multilingual standard forms. Strategically, as a positive result, an increase in the professional qualification and competitiveness of European citizens can be expected, in line with an existing Single European Qualifications Framework, and a significant easing of training procedures abroad.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The aim of this legislation is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by seeking to simplify the admission of certain EU public documents. Specifically, it aims to maintain the sovereignty of the Member States in matters of family law. The free movement and freedom of the internal market of citizens and businesses of the Union is a very important element, even if, in certain circumstances, these may encounter administrative complications, such as the presentation of public documents to the authorities of another Member State. The basis of this regulation is therefore the creation of standard multilingual forms for public documents, in order to simplify procedures that are sometimes the cause of considerable delays. An important point concerns the translation of the public document, so that the citizen does not have to provide a translation of the administrative document, thus greatly facilitating the bureaucratic process of the European citizen moving in the different Member States. This is a very useful rule, which I strongly support.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the Council's position because its text is irrelevant. This rejection proposal, which was proposed by the ENL, was unfortunately rejected by Parliament.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. The need to make European citizenship more concrete was highlighted by the Stockholm programme in 2009. In order to strengthen confidence in the European area of justice, he advocates an action plan which specifically includes the abolition of the apostille. In this sense, the DELVAUX report entitled "Promoting free movement by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents" aims to reduce the administrative burden on European citizens while providing them with legal certainty and administrative simplification, since it abolishes the apostille for documents that are covered by this regulation. These are civil registration documents: marriage, partnership, birth, life certificate, death certificate, residence certificate, electoral rights and lack of criminal record. Finally, to mitigate the risk of fraud, the text provides for the use of an IMI platform, which is a system for the exchange of information directly between the various authorities. Thus, if an administration has doubts about the authenticity of a document, it can contact the relevant authority directly to verify the veracity of the document.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The report seeks to exempt EU member states (except Cyprus, Malta, Finland and the Czech Republic) from a number of legal steps to authenticate a French document. This proposal would apply to documents establishing birth, death, marriage, divorce, legal separation... However, passports and identity cards are not included in the text. Some public documents are concerned, such as those that allow the right to vote abroad. In addition, the text provides assistance in the translation of documents and a procedure allowing the foreign authority, if in doubt, to verify the authenticity of a document with the national reference authority. The report as a whole constitutes an increase in administrative burdens and echoes existing legislation. I therefore voted in favour of the rejection amendment tabled by our group.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote the free movement of citizens, simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The text does not deal with the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular in order to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. The Regulation covers documents relating to marital status, as well as other documents often requested by citizens, relating, for example, to residence, nationality and criminal records.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The aim of this legislation is to improve the free movement of citizens by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents within the union's borders.  To this end, one piece which I consider to be angular for this report has been the creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the public documents we are dealing with here.  This regulation covers, inter-view, documents relating to marital status as well as those relating to residence or nationality. This implies a reduction of economic and administrative burdens for the citizen, who from now on may request directly and electronically from the issuing authority, confirmation of the authenticity of the document.  I support this report, since I believe it facilitates the mobility of European citizens and in order to ensure that they carry out a correct exercise of their right to free movement.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The proposal for a regulation aims to ensure the free movement of certain public documents within the Union, thereby promoting the free movement of Eu citizens. Specifically, the Regulation provides for the abolition of formalities (apostille and legalisation) for public documents falling within its scope, various simplifications with regard to certified translations/copies and the introduction of multilingual EU forms. The aim is to avoid the problem of translation by issuing multilingual forms. In particular, I would like to point out that this proposal for a regulation does not in any way harmonise the substantive law of the Member States in the areas concerned. The main aim is to reduce additional cross-border formalities. The Regulation does not require a Member State to recognise the content of a document from another Member State. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion to reject, thereby supporting the proposal for a regulation itself. Normally, there is no second reading vote in the European Parliament, the proposal is automatically considered approved. A vote shall be made only if someone submits a motion to reject it. That's the kind of proposal I usually make here. I have made a commitment to the voters that I will oppose any proposals that restrict the freedom of man or the sovereignty of the Member States. This time, I did not file a motion to reject it, but it was submitted by another faction, and I voted against it. I consider the proposal to be beneficial. It does not force Member States to recognise public documents issued in another State, it merely facilitates their reading. A uniform form of birth, marriage or death certificate shall facilitate its reading by the authorities in another Member State which request it. This will save citizens paperwork and the need to have everything ed ed. I think this positive proposal is the perfect case for normal intergovernmental cooperation. We would not need the EU and an expensive European Parliament for these positive things.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The aim of this legislative act is to encourage the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal recognition of certain public documents in the European Union. It does not cover the recognition of the content of public documents in order to preserve member states' sovereignty in the field of family law. The mobility of Union citizens is a reality, but some of them still encounter administrative obstacles in the handing over public documents to the authorities of another Member State.  Following interinstitutional negotiations, the co-legislators and the Commission agreed on a compromise text. The Regulation thus covers civil status documents, documents relating to residence, nationality and criminal records. Measures are also envisaged to facilitate the recognition of certified copies and translations of court interpreters.  The most important component of the Regulation is the introduction of multilingual standard forms for most public documents. These multilingual standard forms are issued by national authorities and shall be attached to national documents where a public document is required in another Member State. This greatly facilitates mobility for European citizens, so I did not support the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 On 9 June, by an overwhelming majority at a parliamentary meeting, we adopted relaxed rules on the free movement of European citizens by simplifying the requirements for certain official documents. Following these rules, administrative formalities such as "legalization" and "apostille" of documents such as birth certificate, marriage certificate, death certificate, criminal record, etc. will be abolished. In order not to require translation of official documents, new multilingual options will be developed. Unfortunately, at this stage, such a text has not yet been adopted for documents relating to the legal status of undertakings, diplomas and documents proving invalidity. This could become a reality in 2 years, when the scope of the Regulation will be reviewed. I believe that citizens should have as few administrative setbacks as possible when moving within the EU.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – The present proposal for a regulation simplifies the measures and procedures for the handling of public documents on family status, residence, nationality and criminal record, which will be exempt from legalisation and applicability. The legalisation and authenticity of the documents shall be demonstrated directly by the institutions and bodies concerned. This will facilitate the mobility of persons in the Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents to the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1024/2012 for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 9/6/2016, and because this recommendation for second reading is complete and substantiated.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012. The aim of this regulation is to facilitate the free movement of citizens and businesses, by simplifying the acceptance of civil status documents and others, such as residence, citizenship and criminal records, by exempting legalisation and postmanship, without taking into account the content of public documents that remains in the sovereignty of the Member States in matters of family law. In this way, European citizens, who are increasingly moving to another Member State to study or work, will be able to exercise their right to free movement more easily.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. It is important that we are working on legislation to simplify the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union in order to facilitate formalities for citizens crossing borders. Promoting the free movement of citizens studying, working or living in a Member State of which they are not nationals is one of the foundations of the Union and we must ensure that there are no excessive bureaucratic hurdle in order to exercise that right. My support for this Parliament's draft, which makes it very clear that although everything we were trying to do at a time has not been advanced in this regard, there are significant improvements in the new legislation which will undoubtedly bring immediate benefits to our citizens.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 The free movement of European citizens has been the EU's main objective for many years and new measures are constantly being taken to improve and facilitate citizens in this area as much as possible. This report concerns the simplification of the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the EU.  It is remarkable that we have now achieved some 12 million European citizens living to study and work in a Member State other than their country of origin. The Regulation under consideration concerns the simplification of other identification documents relating to nationality, residence and criminal records. At the same time, it concerns facilitation in relation to documents requiring official translation with regard to their ratification. On the other hand, according to the Regulation there will be an insurance safeguard through the possibility for the authorities to certify directly from the editing authority the authenticity of the document through electronic communication. An interesting initiative in this respect is the introduction of multilingual standard forms with regard to these public documents. I would therefore like to vote in favour of this resolution in order to achieve easy and safe movement of European citizens within the Union.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Here, the EU is trying to attract more powers on the pretext of free movement. However, I see a certain risk of abuse on this point. I can therefore only agree with the ENF amendment.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This proposed regulation aims to simplify cross-border formalities in order to facilitate the freedom of movement of citizens and businesses. These provisions include the abolition of the apostille procedure, the simplification of the acceptance of certified or unstified copies and the recognition of birth or death certificates. The principle of mutual trust will thus be applied, while the introduction of multilingual model forms of the European Union will make life easier for citizens and businesses operating abroad. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Given the existing conventions, it is difficult to find the real interest of this text and what would help to combat existing fraud. This is yet another gimmick that will add to the burden on our already overburdened administrations, over which, for some states, austerity prevails. I therefore vote against the proposal and for the amendment to reject the ENF group.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation, as it seeks to simplify one of our fundamental freedoms. Free movement across the European Union is essential to economic development, tourism and strengthening the multi-layered connections between citizens of different Member States.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. More than 12 million European citizens live for various reasons in a Member State different from their home state. Many documents such as marriage, birth or other certificates have a cost to the citizen. This proposal, in line with free trade agreements aimed at facilitating the free movement of people through the formal acceptance of public documents - without of course prejudging the fund of these documents, which remains the responsibility of the Member States. This regulation is another step towards greater European integration. By reducing administrative barriers, it will facilitate the freedom of movement of citizens between European countries, strengthen the sense of belonging to Europe and further realise the concept of European citizenship. This simplification includes the exemption from legalization and apostille, which are provided for cross-border public documents. One regret is that it was not able to include diplomas, training certificates, disability certificates and other documents useful to businesses in the text. However, revision clauses, provided for in the text, will eventually allow this simplification to be extended further for the benefit of citizens and businesses.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Although citizens and businesses of the European Union exercise their rights of free movement or the freedoms of the internal market, they may be exposed to administrative difficulties when submitting authentic instruments to authorities of another Member State. The Regulation thus includes family documents as well as certain other documents often requested by citizens concerning, for example, residence, nationality and criminal record. The Regulation provides for exemption from legalisation and applicability, which are two administrative formalities traditionally required for cross-border authentic documents. Simplified reception measures are also provided for as regards certified copies and official translations. This simplification for the citizen is balanced by the possibility for the administrative authority that receives the document to contact the issuing administrative authority directly and electronically for confirmation of the authenticity of the document. The Regulation includes the creation of multilingual standard forms for most relevant authentic documents. Simplifying the adoption of certain authentic instruments in the Member States of the Union will strongly promote the free movement of citizens. This legislation does not concern the recognition of the content of authentic acts, for the sake of preserving the sovereignty of The Member States in the field of family law. In view of the above, I fully support the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation, which aims to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. It does not affect recognition of the content of public documents. The regulation covers all civil status documents and certain other documents that are often required by citizens, concerning for example residence, nationality and absence of a criminal record.  For these public documents, the regulation exempts from legalisation and apostille, which are two administrative formalities traditionally required for public documents issued by another country. Simplified acceptance measures are also laid down with regard to certified copies and certified translations. Last but not least, the regulation also provides for the creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the public documents concerned. That is why I have supported this regulation by voting against the proposal to reject the Council position.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2013, the Commission proposed to Parliament and the Council a regulation on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the presentation of certain authentic documents within the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012. The aim of the proposal is to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal adoption of certain authentic documents within the European Union. It does not apply to the recognition of the content of authentic documents, namely in order to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. In 2013, Parliament adopted its first reading position on the proposal. However, the Romanian Senate has tabled a reasoned opinion that the draft legislative act is incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. Following the interinstitutional negotiations, the co-legislators and the Commission agreed on a compromise text, reflecting the Council's position at first reading. The Second Reading Recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with the Council's position at first reading and declare that the legislative act has been adopted in accordance with the Council's position. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that one of the european Union's main objectives is to remove existing barriers to the free movement of persons, this proposal for a regulation is precisely to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. In this sense, some important measures are introduced, namely the dispensation of two of the formalities normally required for cross-border public documents - legalisation and handout - a greater ease in accepting certified copies and certified translations and the creation of multilingual forms, which exempts citizens from the charge of translation and speeding up procedures. However, it is regrettable that in the material scope of this Regulation documents such as certificates of disability/disability, training certificates and others do not fit. In this regard, I am voting in favour, because I believe that the adoption of these legislative measures is a decisive step in removing existing barriers to the free movement of citizens within the European Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Given the existing conventions, it is difficult to find the real interest of this text and what would help to combat existing fraud. This is yet another gimmick that will add to the burden on our already overburdened administrations, on which, for some Member States, austerity prevails. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against the amendment tabled by the ENF which aimed to reject the Council's position on this text, which concerns a draft regulation aimed at promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the conditions for the presentation of certain public documents in the European Union. This text aims to exempt European citizens from legalisation and apostille red tape, and to allow the administration receiving the document to ask the authority that issued it to verify its authenticity.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the draft resolution. It is important that we, as citizens of the European Union, experience EU citizenship as a reality as part of our daily lives. Think of the right of free movement. The mobility of EU citizens is a reality, with almost 12 million people studying, working and living in a Member State other than their nationality. When EU citizens and businesses exercise their rights of free movement or freedoms in the internal market, they may encounter administrative complications. Such completely realistic complications include the submission of authentic documents to the authorities of other Member States, the preparation of verification processes and certified translations. These situations are facilitated by the regulation which I support, as it foresees exemptions from over-authentication and apostille as regards authenticities, which are traditionally required for cross-border authentic documents. Finally, the main element of the Regulation is the creation of multilingual forms, which I also consider very important, for most of the authentic documents concerned. These multilingual forms shall be issued by the national authorities and attached to the national document when an authentic document is to be submitted in another Member State. This Annex contains the pre-translations of the authentic document in question, thereby exempting citizens from submitting translations of the administrative document. This will therefore greatly facilitate the daily lives of mobile, free and multilingual European citizens.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted this recommendation for a second reading that aims to promote free movement of people and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents within the European Union. This legislation covers all civil status documents and other documents concerning residence, nationality and criminal records.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report in my vote today because it supports the final form of negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council on the legislative act promoting the free movement of EU citizens by simplifying the formal acceptance of certain official documents between Member States. The submission of official documents requested by one Member State and issued by another is a bureaucratic problem for European citizens who wish to move to the territory of another Member State and involve very high costs for it. In this respect, simplifying procedures, waiving the need for legalisation and apostille, as well as authorised translation, will greatly ease the procedures that European citizens must go through. The introduction of multilingual forms for most official documents, although they will also need to be accompanied by the requested documents, will also help to avoid confusion and reduce settlement times.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 This is important legislation aimed at ensuring the free movement of public documents in the Union and thus promoting the free movement of Union citizens. It is a pity that, as a result of pressure from the Council, the scope of the Regulation was eventually limited to public documents certifying personal status (birth, death, marriage, divorce, parenthood, adoption, etc.), whereas the EP's wish was that the Regulation should also apply to diplomas and certificates of vocational training, certificates of disability, private documents relating to the legal status and representation of undertakings. A clear benefit is the introduction of multilingual standard forms, which eliminate the need for translations without leading to an obligation to recognise the content of forms, in particular in the area of family law.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with the simplification of acceptance of certain public documents. By simplifying the procedure, this will facilitate procedures for Irish citizens moving between Member States. The main ways acceptance is simplified are the exemption from legislation, apostille or similar formalities for a set list of public documents including birth, death, name, marriage, divorce, registered partnership, parenthood, adoption, domicile, nationality, and absence of a criminal record. In theory, persons producing these documents will not have to go through expensive and lengthy procedures legalising or translating these documents any more. For now diplomas, certificates of disabilities and documents related to established businesses have been excluded. As this will not affect national family or administrative law, there are no sovereignty issues and so therefore I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the report seeks to impose a simplified adoption of certain public documents within the European Union on the pretext of freedom of movement.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported a relevant legislative resolution on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents to the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1024/2012. As described in the text of that resolution, the mobility of Union citizens will be enhanced by this amendment, which provides for the exemption from the obligation to ratify and mark ('Hague stamp'), two administrative formalities normally required for public documents issued by another State. Measures to facilitate acceptance are also provided for certified photocopies and official translations.  These facilities for the citizen are compensated by the possibility for the authority receiving the document to request directly and electronically from the editing authority to verify the authenticity of the document.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted today in favour of rejecting the Delvaux Report on Promoting free movement by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents. Enforcing a regime under which Member States are, effectively, forced to recognise certain civil documents produced as part of the exercise of the right to freedom of movement will lead to an enforced lowering of the guard on checking the veracity of the contents and genuineness of the document itself.  This is a criminal and terrorist forger’s charter and is a threat to the security of the UK and our ability properly to check documentation. It affects only 2.4% of the population of the entire EU: the case for the need for this legislation has not been made out. The claimed keystone of the regulation is the creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the public documents concerned: this is no less than the precursor to an EU-wide and EU-controlled system of civil documentation. The rapporteur’s claimed concern to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States with regard to family law is thus bogus. Finally, as a matter of principle, we vote against EU legislation.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 While I broadly agree with my colleague's proposal and welcome the benefits of adopting simplified acceptance measures for the documentation required of European citizens on the move, I would consider it appropriate to vote against the amendment under discussion.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Many citizens of the Republic of Croatia have difficulty recognising the content of public documents and this is a big problem for them when considering that mobility within member states is increasing on a daily basis. Citizens often encounter administrative obstacles in the handing over public documents to the authorities of another country.  Since the aim and content of the proposed Regulation on promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the display of certain public documents in the European Union is to reduce the costs of individuals, as well as the associated administrative burden, including by providing multilingual standard forms, I consider the proposed Regulation to be a positive step in facilitating and encouraging the freer movement of citizens within the European Union. This Regulation thus covers civil status documents, as well as some other documents that citizens often need, relating, for example, to residence, nationality and criminal records.  For this reason, I supported its adoption. I would like to stress that I am disappointed that the scope of the regulation is limited mainly to civil status documents and not to documents on the legal status and representation of companies and many other types of undertakings. Nevertheless, it is good that we have relieved our citizens of unnecessary document validation in other Member States, as well as translation costs, and that this Regulation will also facilitate the detection of forged documents.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Given the existing conventions, it is difficult to find the real interest of this text and what would help to combat existing fraud. This is yet another gimmick that will add to the burden on our already overburdened administrations, on which the austerity imposed by the European Union prevails. I am voting against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this proposal for a regulation facilitating the free movement of citizens and businesses, simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. More could have been done if the Member States had not been so jealous of their competences, but considerable progress has been made. For civil status documents and documents concerning residence, citizenship and criminal records, legalisation and postmany will no longer be necessary. Simplified procedures are also provided for certified copies and translations.  From now on, it will be the receiving administration that will have the right to request directly, electronically, the issuing administration to confirm the authenticity of the document. The creation of standard multilingual forms that national authorities will issue, attached to public documents to be submitted abroad, is also very positive. All this will greatly simplify the bureaucratic process for millions of students and workers who study, work and live in a Member State of which they are not citizens. Businesses will also face fewer administrative complications within the single market. I would have preferred to see diplomas and certificates of training, disability and others included. I hope that the revision clauses will allow the scope of simplification to be broadened in the future.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Mobility of Union citizens is a reality. Around 12 million citizens study, work or live in Non-National Member States. Union citizens or businesses exercising their right to free movement or enjoyment of the freedoms of the internal market today may face administrative obstacles in presenting public documents to the authorities of another Member State, e.g. in cases of cross-border mobility. Thus, the aim of this legislative act is to encourage the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal recognition of certain public documents in the EU. It does not cover the recognition of the content of public documents, in the first place in order to preserve member states' sovereignty in the field of family law. The Regulation thus covers civil status documents, as well as some other documents that citizens often need, relating, for example, to residence, nationality and criminal records. Ultimately, the most important component of the Regulation is the introduction of multilingual standard forms for most public documents. These multilingual standard forms are issued by national authorities and shall be attached to national documents where a public document is required in another Member State. This annex contains the previously translated public documents in question and therefore relieves citizens of the obligation to present their translations. This greatly facilitates mobility procedures for European citizens.  I propose that the proposed text be approved.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. This is the recommendation for the adoption of the Regulation of Parliament and the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the European Union. It endorses the Council's position at first reading. This legislation aims to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The Regulation covers only documents relating to marital status, as well as some other documents often required of citizens, for example relating to residence, nationality and criminal record. It does not deal with the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. The Council is critical of not including diplomas and training certificates, certificates of disability and certain documents relevant to companies. Furthermore, multilingual forms cannot circulate independently, but must be attached to the national documents in question, which is a preventable complication. The aim of this legislation is to facilitate the movement of citizens within the european union, which in many respects is blocked by unnecessary administrative issues and could be faster. We voted for it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported Mp Delvaux's proposal, since a 65 per cent increase in the number of cases before the General Court between 2000 and 2010 requires a greater number of judges and I agree that a rotational system is the most acceptable solution that guarantees each member to alternately appoint two judges of the Court. I welcome the possibility of adapting the rules and practices relating to the allocation of cases in order to create thematic synergies in order to achieve consistency and quality of case law.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the greatest achievements of European integration, the single internal market, is based on four principles. It is a freedom of movement of goods, persons, services and capital. It is precisely because of its most optimal functioning that I have supported the simplification of the requirements for the presentation of certain public documents in other countries. Although we have shifted considerably in the degree of integration since the adoption of the relevant Single European Act of 1986 for the internal market, it remains a reality that submitting and approving documents abroad is often a very difficult process. I therefore approve that, in the case of public civil status documents and certain other documents that are often needed in the exercise of the right to mobility, an exception exempting citizens from the necessary legalisation of documents and the application for apocity should be applied. Although obsolete, this process is still in use and time-consuming and logistically challenging for citizens. Moreover, it entails unnecessary financial costs. The European Parliament has proposed from the outset that the fan of the documents to which this exception would apply should be wider. I completely do not understand the european council's negative attitude. I therefore find the outcome of the negotiations limited and have supported it with distaste and only because even such a limited position is better than being caught on the spot and accepting the unnecessary bureaucratic burdens that citizens face.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for this legislation, which will promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents, including the widespread implementation of standard multilingual forms for most public documents. Nevertheless, I would like to point out that this text does not concern the recognition of the content of public documents, in the interests of preserving the sovereignty of Member States, as in relation to family law, for example.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently, within the Community, some 12 million European citizens live, study, or work in a Member State other than their nationality. However, citizens and businesses in the Union face various administrative difficulties when submitting public documents required by the authorities of other Member States, which conditions the exercise of the right to free movement and the enjoyment of the possibilities of the internal market. In this regard, we believe that it is the duty of the legislator to simplify and improve the formalities concerning administrative procedures, as set out in Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012 (which assing the requirements for legalisation or handout, or certified translations and certified copies). The proposal to amend the Regulation at issue is aimed at simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents within the Territory of the Union: on the one hand, it introduces an innovative electronic mechanism, which makes it possible to confirm the authenticity of a document between issuer and receiver; on the other hand, it makes it possible to create multilingual forms. Taking into account the interests of the citizens of the Union, and sensitive to the added value that the homogeneity and simplification of bureaucratic procedures represent, I voted in favour.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This document, which I voted in favour of, concerns the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament of 9 June 2016 on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the European Union.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The mobility of European citizens is a reality: around 12 million people study, work or live in a Member State other than their nationality. Currently, if Union citizens and businesses exercise their right to free movement or the freedoms of the internal market they may face a number of administrative difficulties when submitting the necessary public documents to the authorities of another Member State, in particular when crossing a border. After interinstitutional negotiations, the co-legislators and the Commission agreed on a compromise text. The Regulation covers documents relating to marital status, residence, nationality and criminal record. Facilitated acceptance measures are also provided for in the field of certified copies and certified translations, as well as the creation of multilingual forms for most of the public documents concerned. Parliament would also like to have included diplomas and certificates of training and certificates of disability.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I supported this report with my vote, in order to continue to promote the freedom of movement of European citizens. To this end, the Regulation simplifies procedures for the acceptance of certain official Union documents, such as all those related to the civil situation, certificates of residence, nationality or absence of criminal records, which are documents highly requested by citizens for day-to-day formalities.  Simplification measures will also apply to certified copies or translations, and standardized multilingual forms are planned to facilitate, if possible, such procedures.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Today, more than 14 million European citizens live in a Member State other than their home Member State. Even if these citizens live in Europe, it must be acknowledged that they still have to deal with complex and tedious administrative procedures today. This includes getting married, declaring the birth of a child or presenting a clean criminal record.  That is why I welcome today's vote in the European Parliament. By adopting new European rules to facilitate the free movement of citizens, it will be easier for our citizens to have authentic civil registration documents recognised.  It should be noted that a revision clause has been introduced as certain documents such as university degrees have not been included in the scope of the legislative proposal.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislation under discussion will simplify the recognition of certain public documents in the European Union. About twelve million Citizens of the Union study, work or reside in a Member State other than their nationality. It is therefore clear that they may face many bureaucratic obstacles, in particular with regard to the recognition of documents issued in another country.  Importantly, the legislation does not regulate the recognition of the content of public documents. This preserves the independence of the Member States in the area of family law. More importantly, public documents will not require legalisation and apostille, two administrative formalities for documents issued by another Member State. These simplifications for citizens are offset by the possibility for the administrative body which received the document to request directly by electronic means the issuing body to authenticate that document.   It is also to be welcomed that the regulation creates multilingual standard forms for many of the necessary public documents. They will be issued by national authorities. This will greatly facilitate procedures for EU citizens who have arrived in another Member State. Unfortunately, the outcome of the negotiations with the Council has disappointed Parliament on some issues. The Council, for some reason, refused to include diplomas and certificates of completion of training courses, disability certificates and certain documents of interest to undertakings within the scope of the Regulation. It also prevented multilingual standard forms of documents from being submitted separately and must be attached to the relevant national documents, which is a avoidable difficulty.  However, this will not change the fact that significant progress has been made.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. We are dealing with a proposal for a recommendation from Parliament to implement the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union by amending Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012. The recognition of the content of public documents for the preservation of the sovereignty of The Member States in the field of family law is excluded from the proposal. In view of the current scenario of constant mobility of European citizens and the consequent right to free movement and the freedoms of the internal market, there are multiple administrative difficulties when submitting public documents requested by the authorities of another Member State. The agreement reached, which results from a compromise of several interinstitutional negotiations, will allow the change of Regulation No 1024/2012, without legalisation and handout various documents relating to marital status, as well as others relating to identification, residence, nationality and criminal record. There will also be a lower formality in the acceptance of certified copies and certified translations. I have always been in favour of administrative debureaucratisation and simplification and this is a report aimed at making life easier for citizens, from the outset by creating multilingual forms for most public documents, I naturally voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
