text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union.  This applies to civil registration documents, as well as certain other documents often required by citizens, such as residence, nationality and criminal record. Easier acceptance measures are also provided for certified compliant copies and sworn translations. Finally, the regulation provides for the creation of standard multilingual forms for most of the public documents concerned. I supported this text because it will make life easier for European citizens and allow for better cooperation between Member States.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Writing. \u2012 Ladies and gentlemen, cross-border mobility of Union citizens is a reality. Millions of Europeans studying, working or residing in a Member State other than that of their origin face administrative complications when submitting public documents to the host authorities. The proposed regulation mainly covers documents often requested by citizens concerning personal status (birth, marriage, death, etc.). It abolishes the obligation to validate and mark, while at the same time providing for measures to facilitate acceptance for certified photocopies and official translations. At the same time, multilingual standard forms are established for the majority of the relevant documents.  Ladies and gentlemen, recognising that these measures not only lead to a reduction in the costs borne by citizens, but at the same time facilitate a smooth transaction with public services and reduce red tape, I am in favour. However, I believe that it should be extended in the near future: A. to extend its scope, including diplomas, training certificates, certificates of invalidity and certain important documents for businesses, as originally planned, and B. provision should be made for the possibility of autonomous use of multilingual standard forms, which will now, after the adoption of the Regulation, be annexed to the relevant national documents. , which will lead to unnecessary and unjustified complications.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the majority of the parliamentary assembly, I voted against Amendment No 1 to the legislative resolution tabled by Mr Delvaux. By rejecting Amendment No 1, the Council's position on this issue was adopted. In this case, the Council's position is to simplify the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. I would like to remind you that one of the pillars on which this Union is founded is precisely the free movement of persons. That is why I am in favour of the Council's position.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this amendment, which is the proposal for Parliament to reject the Council's position, since what the report presented intends to adopt is the compromise between the Council and Parliament for the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The aim of the rapporteur's report is to promote the free movement of Union citizens between countries, simplifying the acceptance of public documents. It is a technical report that will benefit the citizens of the European Union. That is why I am in favour, and I am voting against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. \u2012 The purpose of this Regulation is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The regulation is not about which documents to accept, but acceptance can be speeded up, for example by obtaining public documents in several languages. I support the outcome of the negotiations and therefore vote against a proposal to withdraw the proposal for a regulation.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of 'promoting the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the adoption of certain public documents within the European Union', as this is a massive administrative facilitation for working and living within the European Union. The new decision exempts civil status documents, residence documents and criminal records from these regulations. At the same time, multilingual standard forms will be introduced in all Member States as replacements, which will then be recognised throughout Europe in connection with the original document.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, when someone wants to move from one State of the European Union to another, they still have to face unnecessary obstacles. One of these is the cross-border recognition of public documents on civil status, nationality or criminal record. I am therefore glad that this regulation will finally simplify their recognition. Nevertheless, I think that the list of these documents needs to be extended – I see no reason, for example, why the cards of persons with disabilities should not be recognised in this way. I therefore supported the report, but I hope that the cross-border recognition of other documents will soon be enforced.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The text does not deal with the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular in order to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. The Regulation covers documents relating to marital status as well as other documents often requested by citizens, relating, for example, to residence, nationality and criminal records.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 About twelve million people live, study or work in a Member State other than their own. Unfortunately, the mobility of European citizens often encounters administrative complications when presenting public documents to the authorities of another country. The new regulation will simplify the procedures for demonstrating the authenticity of certain certificates, such as those relating to residence, citizenship, civil status and the absence of criminal offences: standard multilingual forms will be introduced that will save citizens and businesses time and money, avoiding the need for certified translations. Convinced of the importance of facilitating the bureaucratic process for the free movement of persons within the European Union, I voted in favour of the agreement reached at second reading.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament has long sought to promote the right of free movement and residence of persons in the EU, which it considers to be a key principle of the European Union. Although this right was introduced by the Maastricht Treaty back in 1992, its practical implementation has not been in the past and is not so clear-up today. I am glad that today there is a directive on the right of EU citizens and their family members to move and reside freely within the territory of the Member States. Although Union citizens and businesses currently exercise their rights of free movement in accordance with the legislation in force or the freedom of the internal market, they are subject to many administrative obstacles to the cross-border use and adoption of authentic instruments when submitting authentic instruments to the authorities of another Member State. I supported the resolution on the current report because I believe that, on the basis of the measures taken, we will improve the free movement of citizens by facilitating the adoption of certain authentic instruments in the EU, which is aimed at fulfilling a very important task of facilitating formalities for citizens crossing borders. I believe that the proposed regulation will manage to reduce costs for individuals, as well as to reduce the often undesirable bureaucracy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP's report, which adopts the Council's position on the proposal for a regulation on simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the EU in the second reading. Documents certifying, for example, birth, marriage, permanent residence or criminal integrity will no longer have to be legalised or apocityed before being submitted to the authorities in another EU country. For most of the documents covered by the new Regulation, there is even no need to provide translation as uniform multilingual forms are put in place. The European Parliament originally proposed to go further and extend the regulation to includes evidence certifying education. It is a pity that the Member States were not willing to go that far, but even so, the proposal put forward is a great step forward and a good compromise.  The new rules will make life much easier for millions of citizens living, studying and working in another EU country. Unpleasant additional administration, time delays and, in some cases, financial burdens for formalities such as apostasy or official translation will be ed. It should be noted that the Regulation respects the sovereignty of the Member States and does not command them to recognise the content of the documents submitted – it is only a matter of reimproving the lives of the citizens who submit the documents. Any verification of documents by Member States will take place electronically between the authorities, so that this burden will not be passed on to the citizen. I consider this approach to be correct, which is why I supported the text.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Citizens of the European Union are quite mobile - around 12 million of them study, work or live in a foreign Member State of the European Union.  If citizens and businesses of the European Union today exercise their rights of free movement or the freedoms of the internal market, they may face administrative difficulties in submitting the necessary public documents to the authorities of another Member State, for example in the case of cross-border mobility.  The purpose of the legislative regulation is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by facilitating the adoption of certain public documents in the European Union. This is not about recognising the content of public documents, as it is important to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the area of family law. Unfortunately, certain regulations do not contain diplomas and professional certificates, certificates of disability and certain documents for companies. Moreover, multilingual standard forms cannot be provided independently, but must be attached to national documents, which is an unnecessary problem.  However, significant progress has been made, as the regulation also contains revision clauses which allow simplifications to be further extended in the administrative field in the future, when national administrations get used to the new way of working.  For the reasons set out above, I voted against the amendment in support of the report on the Council's position with a view to adopting a regulation on the promotion of the free movement of citizens.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The proposal for a regulation aims to ensure the free movement of certain public documents within the Union, thereby promoting the free movement of Eu citizens. Specifically, the Regulation provides for the abolition of formalities (apostille and legalisation) for public documents falling within its scope, various simplifications with regard to certified translations/copies and the introduction of multilingual EU forms. The aim is to avoid the problem of translation by issuing multilingual forms. In particular, I would like to point out that this proposal for a regulation does not in any way harmonise the substantive law of the Member States in the areas concerned. The main aim is to reduce additional cross-border formalities. The Regulation does not require a Member State to recognise the content of a document from another Member State. I agree with the report.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to support in plenary a regulation on the simplification of mutual recognition of official documents.  More than 14 million people live, study or work outside their home country in the EU. These citizens are subjected to unnecessary administrative burdens in various life situations in the form of the provision of judicial translations, notarial verifications and other time-consuming forms of validation and the provision of translations of personal documents. The adopted regulation aims to simplify the recognition of certain public documents in the EU. The Regulation applies to civil status documents as well as to certain other citizens frequently required documents relating to residence, nationality or criminal record.  The regulation provides for exemptions from legalisation and apocity, and also provides for simplified measures with regard to certified copies and certified translations. If necessary, the authorities will be able to request confirmation of the authenticity of the document from the issuing authority themselves. The regulation also includes multilingual forms, which are completed by an official in the citizen's home state and attach to the document.  Like many colleagues in the EP, I would like the regulation to apply to a wider range of charters, such as diplomas or certificates of disability, but I consider this compromise reached between the EP and the Member States to be a success. The text also contains a revision clause, which gives the possibility for future expansion of the spectrum of included documents.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. 'N-VA is in favour of the free movement of citizens within the EU and confirms the need to ensure the free movement of public documents. It therefore supports the objective of the Regulation to simplify the administrative rules for the production of public documents in another Member State. Unfortunately, the regulation is an unfortunate approach. For example, in practice, the use of multilingual forms will not be simple and there is a real risk of abuse. It is also not inconceivable that this could break the language rules of the Member States. N-VA therefore has some reservations about this legislative instrument and has abstained from voting in plenary.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. Around 12 million citizens study, work or live in Non-National Member States. Unfortunately, citizens, as well as EU companies, who today exercise their right to free movement or enjoy the freedom of the internal market often encounter administrative obstacles in presenting public documents to the authorities of another Member State, for example in cases of cross-border mobility. In order to promote the free movement of citizens, it is necessary to simplify the formal recognition of certain public debates in the European Union.  Furthermore, it is important that member states' sovereignty in the field of family law is preserved and therefore this legislative act does not include the recognition of the content of public documents. One of the more significant components of the Regulation is the introduction of multilingual standard forms for most public documents, which will greatly contribute to simplification. I believe that the scope of administrative simplifications needs to be expanded once the new way of working has risen in national administrations, and I therefore support the Council's proposal.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I agreed with the European Parliament's recommendation on the Council's first-reading position on the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents within the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012. The aim of this legislation is to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the adoption of certain public documents within the European Union. It does not concern the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular in order to safeguard the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. The aim of this legislative act is to encourage the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal recognition of certain public documents in the European Union. It does not cover the recognition of the content of public documents, in the first place in order to preserve member states' sovereignty in the field of family law. The resolution covers all civil status documents, as well as some other documents that citizens often need, relating, for example, to residence, nationality and criminal records. Measures are also envisaged to facilitate the recognition of certified copies and translations of court interpreters. The simplified procedure shall be compensated by the possibility for the authority receiving the document to request directly and electronically from the issuing authority to confirm its authenticity.  Ultimately, multilingual standard forms are introduced for most public documents. These multilingual standard forms are issued by national authorities and shall be attached to national documents where a public document is required in another Member State. I do not support the proposal for a recommendation for a second reading, as I consider the Council's position at first reading to be sufficiently clear and well-worded.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the European Union and amending the Regulation. I believe that the document is a good document, because by simplifying certain public documents, we will encourage the free movement of citizens and businesses. The right to free movement for citizens and businesses is an important asset for a united Europe, and this must therefore be promoted and the administrative difficulties faced by businesses in particular must be prevented. This legislation is a step in the right direction, which is why I voted against the amendment, in favour of the report.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a regulation aimed at substantially simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the EU due to cross-border mobility of citizens. At present, for public documents issued by another State, they are to be validated and flagged. By setting up a regulation, there will be an exemption from these administrative formalities with regard to registration documents, documents relating to residence, nationality and criminal record. These facilities are compensated by the ability of the authorities receiving the document to request a direct and electronic attestation of its authenticity from the issuing authority. There is no political problem with this proposal.  That is why we voted in favour.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States must escape any anchorages that hold them back and improve the quality of life of their citizens by limiting unnecessary and economically damaging suffering to such procedural matters. However, the simplification of procedures must not result in the credibility and security of documents being detrimental.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of this legislative act is to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal adoption of certain authentic acts within the European Union. It does not apply to the recognition of the content of authentic documents, namely in order to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. Following interinstitutional negotiations, the co-legislators and the Commission agreed on a compromise text. The Regulation thus covers public documents relating to marital status and certain other documents frequently requested by citizens, such as residence, nationality and criminal records. As regards these authentic documents, the Regulation foresees exemptions from over-authentication and apostille, which are traditionally required administrative formalities for cross-border authentic documents. It also foresees facilitated adoption measures in the field of certified copies and certified translations.  The current scope does not cover diplomas and certificates of professional qualifications, disability documents and some documents relevant to businesses, but the Regulation includes review clauses for the foreseeable future extension of the scope of administrative simplifications as soon as this new way of working becomes common practice in national authorities. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Freedom of movement for persons is one of the key rights of EU citizenship. Despite the fact that this right is firmly rooted in EU legislation, many EU citizens studying, living, working or doing business in another country face obstacles in their daily lives that make it difficult for them to exercise that right. Administrative formalities for authenticating public documents issued in another EU country in one Member State are among the most frequently mentioned problems. The Regulation indicates 13 categories of public documents, m.in. birth certificate, death certificate, marriage, divorce, lack of entry in the criminal register, which will be exempt from all forms of legalization. Copies certified as genuine will also be recognised in all Member States. Multilingual standard forms will also be introduced to facilitate the translation of documents. The EP-Council Regulation is an important step towards reducing costs, shortening the legalisation process, while maintaining legal certainty. This is to meet the expectations of Europeans that their daily lives and contacts with member states' offices become easier.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the principles underlying the European Union is the freedom of movement of citizens of the Member States. In this respect, an important component is the simplification of the acceptance of certain documents issued by those States. Unfortunately, there are still plenty of obstacles to the normalisation of this important process, which creates difficulties, especially for those who wish to study and work in another Member State, but also in the case of other public documents concerning marital status, residence, nationality and criminal record. The current proposal for a regulation envisages exemption from the obligation to legalise and apostille of those documents, traditional procedures in the case of cross-border official documents.  Simplifications are also provided for in respect of certified copies and authorised translations, in particular by creating standard multilingual forms and pre-translations annexed to national official documents. The regulation does not include diplomas and training certificates, disability certificates, business documents. However, the regulation is an important step forward and can be revised in the future, in line with developments in EU-wide conditions. That is why I believe that this is obvious progress and I support the adoption of this document.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the Delvaux report. The aim of this legislation is to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. It does not concern the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular in order to preserve the sovereignty of Member States in relation to family law. The mobility of EU citizens is a reality: some twelve million of them study, work or live in a Member State of which they are not nationals. At present, if EU citizens and businesses exercise their right to free movement or the freedoms of the internal market, they may face administrative complications when they have to submit public documents to the authorities of another Member State, for example as a result of cross-border mobility.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text on promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for presenting certain public documents in the European Union. The aim of this legislation is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. It does not affect recognition of the content of public documents, particularly out of a concern to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States with regard to family law.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal to reject the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012 was not supported. Citizens and businesses benefiting from the right to the free market face administrative difficulties in situations where they have to submit the necessary public documents to the authorities of the states. With regard to those public documents, the Regulation provides for an exemption from the legalisation and certification by stamp, which are among the administrative procedures normally required for authentic instruments from another State. Simplified procedures are provided for the accepting of certified copies and certified translations. The central part of the Regulation consists of multilingual standard forms for most of the public documents concerned.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this amendment, which is the proposal for Parliament to reject the Council's position, since what the report presented intends to adopt is the compromise between the Council and Parliament for the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The aim of the rapporteur's report is to promote the free movement of Union citizens between countries, simplifying the acceptance of public documents. It is a technical report that will benefit the citizens of the European Union. That is why I am in favour, and I am voting against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Given the existing conventions, it is difficult to find the real interest of this text and what would help to combat existing fraud. This is yet another gimmick that will add to the burden on our already overburdened administrations, on which, for some Member States, austerity prevails. So I voted for the rejection amendment.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support measures to facilitate travel for citizens of the European Union. Official procedures should be simplified. It is a pity that the agreement reached with the Council does not respond to all the problems. First of all, the liberalisation of m.in on diplomas and school certificates remains unexplained. I decided to vote against the recommendation.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of this legislative act is to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal adoption of certain authentic acts within the European Union. It does not apply to the recognition of the content of authentic documents, namely in order to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. The mobility of EU citizens is a reality: some 12 million of them study, work or live in a Member State other than their nationality. If EU citizens and businesses today exercise their right to free movement or their freedoms in the internal market, they may encounter administrative complications when submitting authentic documents to authorities in other Member States, for example as a result of cross-border mobility. I supported him.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this amendment, which is the proposal for Parliament to reject the Council's position, since what the report presented intends to adopt is the compromise between the Council and Parliament for the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. The aim of the rapporteur's report is to promote the free movement of Union citizens between countries, simplifying the acceptance of public documents. It is a technical report that will benefit the citizens of the European Union. That is why I am in favour, and I am voting against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. – I voted against the proposal to reject the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for presenting certain public documents in the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012. I am committed to the recommendation whose final goal is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. Furthermore, I believe that this regulation will put an end to the heavy and expensive bureaucracy currently in place.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The document aims to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying some public documents. We are talking about a report which is broadly compromised and which helps us to go one step further in free movement, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This legislation stems from the provisions of Article 21 TFEU. This legislation aims to promote the free movement of citizens by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. It is not a question of the recognition of the content of public documents, in particular to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of family law. The Regulation covers only documents relating to marital status, as well as some other documents often required of citizens, for example relating to residence, nationality and criminal record. It is proposed to create multilingual forms for most of the public documents concerned to facilitate the process. The Council is critical of not including diplomas and training certificates, certificates of disability and certain documents relevant to companies. Furthermore, multilingual forms cannot circulate independently, but must be attached to the national documents in question, which is a preventable complication.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report seeks, on the pretext of free movement, to enforce the simplified adoption of certain public documents within the EU. In order to save administrative complications, civil status certificates and a number of other documents relating to residence, nationality and criminal records are to be withdrawn from legalisation and apostille. I therefore believe that the ENF's amendment, which would put an end to this haunting, is worthy of support.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislation as it promotes the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. In other words, it aims at making the life of citizens easier by reducing the administrative burden to mobility inside the EU. The keystone of the regulation is the creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the public documents concerned. The forms are attached to the original version of the document, and are pre-translated, meaning the document holder is not required to get a certified/notarised copy of the translated document. This will therefore greatly facilitate procedures for European citizens moving between Member States.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Simplifying the requirements for verifying authentic documents and documents is of great importance for anyone applying for a job or wishes to settle in another EU Member State. Today, in such a case, it is necessary to officially verify a number of documents. The adopted proposal also helps students who go to European universities and need to submit public documents concerning birth, name, residence, citizenship and nationality, or the absence of a criminal record. All these documents shall be exempt from legalisation or similar formality. The authorities will also not be able to require simultaneous presentation of the original of the document and a certified copy thereof issued by the authorities of other Member States. In addition, they will also have to accept an unverified copy if the original document is presented together with such a copy, and also accept verifications issued in other Member States. This will certainly save not only students money and time in the completion of the necessary formalities. I therefore supported the proposal.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report as it is a step in the right direction towards the free movement of citizens by simplifying the formal adoption of certain public documents in the European Union. Around 12 million EU citizens study, work or live in a Member State of which they are not nationals. Although Union citizens exercise their right to free movement, they often face administrative complications. This measure largely eliminates these complications. Personally, I very much appreciate the creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the authentic instruments concerned.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 It has been found that the exchange of public documents between administrations in different Member States slows down and complicates the free movement of persons across the borders of the European Union, due to the costs and bureaucracy encountered by citizens. It is therefore necessary to provide a rapid and effective response, insisting on reducing bureaucratic difficulties and simplifying practices, accepting the creation of standard pre-translated forms available in the different languages of the Union, so as to avoid the translation costs borne by individuals and reduce the time taken to exchange documents, thus simplifying free movement within the EU.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the promotion of the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the European Union and amending the Regulation. The purpose of the legislative regulation is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by facilitating the adoption of certain public documents in the European Union. However, given the current security situation in the European Union, I believe that such a proposal is hasty, inundated and could jeopardise national security.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I abstained on this dossier because I am fundamentally opposed to the idea of increasing the number of judges. This is a fourth proposal in the form of a text on regulation and the outcome of the interinstitutional negotiations. The proposed reforms by the Court of Justice of the European Union, including the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal, are a long-delayed measure. However, the objective remains to transfer all staff to the Court of Justice and at the same time increase the number of judges to two for each Member State. Representative costs warn that this would cost around €20 million. There is insufficient evidence of the impact this increase in the number of judges will have.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I have finally supported this resolution, although I do not agree with the overall political reform of the Court of Justice, i.e. doubling the number of judges, but this text will lead to the transfer to the Court of Justice of the agenda pursued so far by the Civil Service Tribunal. I see this as a pragmatic little evil, having transferred part of the next agenda to at least such an increased number of judges – from 28 to 56 – and those judges will be able to do the extra work. That is why I finally voted in favour of this partial resolution.  Otherwise, I did not vote in support of the declaration on gender balance in court, personally I do not think that such political declarations do not belong to professional workplaces such as the courts. In the Czech Republic, we do not have an established gender balance of Czech courts, and at the same time 60% of judges and 40% of judges work in the Czech judiciary.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: " To the President! This is already the fourth stage of the Court's reform, and it is worth noting that it certainly went much easier than the previous one, with regard to increasing the number of judges. I believe that proper reform of the court, taking into account today's real ones and challenges, is important and necessary, but the Court is undoubtedly one of the most important institutions of the Union, so its effective functioning is a matter of overriding importance, so of course I welcome today's positive vote. It is also important to note that the Commission's proposal to regulate the referral of cases pending before the Civil Service Tribunal and, in turn, those pending before the Civil Service Tribunal will be referred to the procedural stage at the end of August this year as they will be at the stage of their entry into force on 31 August. I'm in for.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, I have actively contributed and support justice reform in Romania, neighbouring states and in all the European Union states and all over the world. The reform of the European Court of Justice, including through this transfer, will lead to an increase in efficiency, this is mandatory. And yes, justice needs good specialists, needs funding, needs research and clear laws. When the reform process is completed, each Member State will be able to appoint two judges and the maximum number of judges of the Court would reach fifty-six.  Now, I have a question: why do you have to double the number of judges? This will lead to an increase in expenditure of around EUR 20 million and this is justified and effective if the number of dossiers, for example, is also doubled. That is why I call on the Commission to present an impact study to tell us exactly why the number of judges needs to be doubled.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, the questions raised by my speaker, Mrs Macovei, are certainly relevant. However, on this point, I myself have considered very much whether to support the draft report, i finally voted in favour.  I did not support the report in the earlier vote, I do not consider the reform as such to be a success. However, on this sub-issue, having already been adopted and approved by the Parliament, there is essentially nothing left to support it, since parts of the Civil Service Tribunal's agenda are being transferred to the General Court, which means that the increased number of judges will have a greater share of responsibility, a greater share of the work. This is a pragmatic vote in this regard, I think that many of my colleagues, and for this reason I, too, supported this procedure, although I do not agree with the reform itself as a whole. However, the gender balance in the Court of Justice and the General Court does not cause me problems.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Civil Service Tribunal, set up by Decision 2004\752\EC, has jurisdiction to rule at first instance on disputes between the EU and its staff in the field of employment and social security relations. The Italian Presidency has begun a reform of the Court of Justice. The focal points were: an increase in the number of judges and the consequent abolition of the Court of First Instance. Thus, the increase in the number of general judges is matched by the disappearance of a court composed of specialised judges. I have therefore decided to vote against it, not only because I consider the reform to be a waste of money, but above all because I do not believe that it will benefit the citizens in any way.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This is the fourth time the EU Court is reformed. The last reform paved the way for double the number of judges. The consequence of this increase is the closure of the Court specialising in the European civil service and the transfer of its powers to the General Court.  I voted against this handover, because I do not think there is a need for an increase in judges and at the same time I am against the closure of the Court specialising in the European civil service.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice. I welcome the fact that in this text the European Parliament recalls in particular its commitment to gender balance among the judges of the courts of the European Union.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, which refers to this Regulation, which is the fourth in a row concerning the reform of the Court of Justice. The first Regulation made various changes to the compositions and procedure applicable to the Court of Justice and the General Court, while the second Regulation provided for the appointment of alternate judges to the Civil Service Tribunal.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The reform of the Court of Justice has been carried out, from the very beginning, in a scandalous manner, without any impact or cost analysis. The abolition of the TFP was proposed without consultation with its judges and officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its removal. We strongly oppose this costly, illegal and unnecessary reform at a time when austerity is sweeping our national jurisdictions. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This is part of the re-arrangement of the EU Court of Justice (ECJ) which includes doubling the number of judges in the court. As a matter of principle I oppose the very existence of the ECJ and its primacy over the Parliament and Courts of the United Kingdom. Previously I have voted against the report of Mady Delvaux on the transfer to the General Court of Jurisdiction at first instance in EU civil service cases.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This Regulation is the fourth related reform of the Court of Justice. The first regulation introduced various amendments concerning the composition and procedure of the Court of Justice and the General Court, while the second includes a provision on the temporary judges of the Civil Service Tribunal. The third part of the reform has been the subject of the most controversy, since it concerns an increase in the number of Judges of the General Court. The number of judges has been increased on the condition that the Tribunal is annulled and that public service disputes are referred back to the General Court. That regulation is therefore drawn up in the context of the third regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice. In the second stage of the increase in the number of Judges of the General Court from 40 to 47, the Civil Service Tribunal which had seven Judges must be annulled. The Court's proposal is therefore logical and consistent with what the co-legislators have asked for. I therefore support the proposal.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the transfer of jurisdiction to the Court of the European Union to rule, in the first instance, on disputes between the Union and its agents

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Delvaux report on the transfer to the Court of First Instance of jurisdiction to decide at first instance on the EU civil service. It is a text of a predominantly technical nature which leads to the dissolution of the Civil Service Tribunal and a consequent increase in the judges of the Court of First Instance from 40 to 47. According to the text, which also introduces some side amendments and transitional provisions, the powers of the dissolved Civil Service Tribunal are reallocated to the Court of First Instance. This is a functional proposal which meets the request to increase the number of judges to 56 in order to guarantee a number of two judges per Member State. The current reform does not provide for the amendment of the Rules of Procedure of the Court of First Instance and its internal organisation, on which action will have to be taken at a later date.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report, which is the fourth text relating to the reform of the COURT of Justice of the EU. At this stage of the process, it is proposed to increase the number of judges of the General Court of Justice. The consequence of this is the abolition of the Specialized Civil Service Tribunal, and the transfer of its powers to the General Court. I am opposed to the Draft Reform of the Court from the outset, so I am voting against this legislative resolution.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This draft regulation is the fourth relating to the controversial reform of the ECJ. This proposed transfer masks the reality of the outright abolition of the European Union Civil Service Tribunal. The seven-way increase in the number of Judges of the Tribunal on 1 September 2016 must be accompanied by the transfer of jurisdiction to the Tribunal to rule, at first instance, on disputes between the Union and its agents.  I had asked a written question to this effect and I consider that the reform of the Court of Justice was carried out, from its inception, in an scandalous manner, without any impact analysis or its cost. In addition, the abolition of the TFP was proposed without consultation with its judges and officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its removal. This costly and unequal reform is not, in my view, helpful, and I therefore voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The whole reform process that the Court of Justice has undergone in recent years has never totally convinced me. Although I fully support the measure being put to the vote, it retains passages that puzzle me and have led me to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The latest reform of the General Court envisaged an increase in the number of judges to 56 and the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal, with the consequent transfer of jurisdiction, in order to simplify and expedite the judicial system. This regulation therefore gives continuity to the reforms agreed, so that the General Court may decide at first instance all matters relating to the European civil service, and that is why I have cast my vote in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it expresses Parliament's position on the transmission of a regulation on jurisdiction to the General Court of the European Union as a first instance for disputes between the Union and its servants. This Regulation is the fourth relating to the reform of the Court of Justice. The first regulation introduced various amendments concerning the composition and procedure of the Court of Justice and the General Court, while the second includes a provision on the temporary judges of the Civil Service Tribunal. The third part of the reform has been the subject of the most controversy, since it concerns an increase in the number of Judges of the General Court. Initially, this figure was expected to increase from 28 to 40. At the council's insistence, the co-legislators finally decided to increase the number of Judges of the General Court to 56 so that each Member State could appoint two judges. The number of judges has been increased on the condition that the Tribunal is annulled and that public service disputes are referred back to the General Court. That regulation is therefore drawn up in the context of the third regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice. In the second stage of the increase in the number of Judges of the General Court from 40 to 47, the Civil Service Tribunal which had seven Judges must be annulled. The Court's proposal is therefore logical and consistent with what the co-legislators have asked for. It merely proposes the abolition of the provisions on the Civil Service Tribunal and a number of minor amendments and transitional provisions in this respect. Naturally, those amendments include the repeal of the second regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this report, which is only a continuation of the Court of Justice's reform. In parallel with the second step, i.e. increasing the number of judges at the General Court from 40 to 47, the civil service tribunal, which has seven judges, should be abolished.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The reform of the Court of Justice has been carried out, from the very beginning, in a scandalous manner, without any impact or cost analysis. The abolition of the European Union Civil Service Tribunal was proposed without consultation with its judges and officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its abolition. I strongly oppose this costly, illegal and unnecessary reform at a time when austerity is sweeping our national jurisdictions. I voted against it.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – The Civil Service Tribunal was put in place for disputes between EU personnel and the Institutions. This report seeks to merge the Civil Service Tribunal with the General Court, which will have a number of adverse consequences for applicants, including 1) much longer waiting times, 2) the loss of seven specialised judges, 3) the loss of one appellate stage. This reform seems to have no real substance as the Court was first set up in 2005 with the aim of relieving the burden of the General Court. It seems that this reform has been a long-laboured compromise due to disagreements over which countries should appoint judges and how the rotation should work. The result is a loss in interest in specialised courts and just an increase in judges to the General Court. There is no empirical research to show that this restructuring will improve efficiency or save money. Therefore I voted against this report.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The increase in the Judges of the Court of First Instance to 56 is consistent with the decision to allow each Member State of the Union to appoint two judges each. This increase was correctly made conditional on the dissolution of the Civil Service Tribunal and the referral of civil service disputes to the Court of First Instance. The proposal contains minor amendments, improving the functioning of the current institutions, consistent with what Parliament has already approved in the previous stages of the reform of the Court of Justice currently under way.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This is the fourth draft regulation on the completely questionable reform of the Court of Justice. It is part of a strategy to extend the powers of eu courts as litigation on European law intensifies. The aim of this regulation is first of all to provide the European Court with seven additional judges and to abolish the European Civil Service Tribunal. This reform, which was carried out without any consultation or impact study, aims to concentrate judicial powers in the hands of a judicial body. Rather than strengthening the resources of European judicial bodies, the lack of resources of the French judicial institution should be compensated. I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the transfer to the General Court of jurisdiction to rule at first instance on cases in the field of EU civil service, taking into account the need to regulate the existing legal framework. Judges will start their work on 1 October, which makes it all the more necessary to adopt this report. This regulation is the fourth stage of reforming the Court of Justice. With the increase in the number of judges of the General Court from 40 to 47, it was necessary to abolish the Civil Service Tribunal and to transfer disputes relating to the civil service to the General Court. I subscribe to this proposal, given that this is the solution that the co-legislators found to be the favourable one, but also that the amendments proposed by the General Court were prepared in close consultation with the Civil Service Tribunal and the Court of Justice.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of amendments to the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union. They represent not only an internal reorganisation of the Court of Justice of the European Union, but constitute a real reform of the institutional architecture of the European Union which will lose its current 'tripartite' structure by including the Civil Service Tribunal in the Court of The European Union.  Particular attention has been paid by the European Parliament to the issue of gender balance, which is considered to be of fundamental importance, with regard to the future appointment of judges of the Court of Justice of the European Union. At the end of the reform process, the Court of First Instance should be composed of two judges per Member State. I therefore call on the governments of the Member States, during the process of appointing candidates as judges to the Court of Justice of the European Union, to ensure gender equality. However, a number of aspects of the new structure remain to be clarified, for example with regard to the establishment, composition and functions of any specialised chambers within the Court of First Instance of the European Union. The definition of these aspects, as well as the practical way in which the court as a whole operates, will require a new revision of the Rules of Procedure of the Court of Justice, as well as that of the Court of Justice.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which concerned the closure of the specialised Civil Service Tribunal. This court had been the separate specialised court dealing with disputes between EU institutions/offices/agencies, and their employees, since 2005. The abolition, or merger of this court with the General Court will have a number of consequences for applicants, 1) much longer waiting times, 2) the loss of seven specialised judges, 3) the loss of one appellate stage for applicants. Furthermore, there has been no research or data to show that this restructuring will improve efficiency of save money.  For these reasons, I voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as part of the reform of the European Court of Justice. Among other matters, it proposes to increase the number of judges at the General Court to 56. To cope with the reform of the Court of Justice, I believe that allowing each Member State having two judges at the General Court promotes better legislation in the EU. I am especially content with the proposal of accordingly amendments that aim to build a more consistent judicial system.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The call for the abolition of the Special Civil Service Tribunal of the European Union is a consequence of the reform of the Court of Justice, which provides for an increase in the number of Judges from 28 to 40 and then 56 (with 2 appointments per Member State). In addition to doubts as to the usefulness of the increase in the number of judges (which also involves a considerable amount of public money), I find it a bad thing that a court composed of highly qualified judges specialising in a specific matter is being abolished, which would therefore be dealt with by necessarily less experienced judges in the future. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation we are debating today completes the process of reforming the Court of Justice by providing for the absorption of the Civil Service Tribunal as a result of the increase in the number of Judges of the Court of First Instance from 40 to 47, all with a view to increasing the number of Judges to 56 in the coming years, so as to guarantee each Member State the appointment of two judges. The reform, which is not particularly critical, is to be welcomed for its spirit of rationalisation. In addition, the transitional measures proposed to regulate the procedures for transferring cases pending before the Civil Service Tribunal to the Court of First Instance in the State in which they are located on 31 August 2016, in the interests of legal certainty, are to be welcomed. The need to restructure the institutional architecture of the Union, and in this case its bodies responsible for interpreting and implementing the law, is a positive sign of the growth and consolidation of the Union itself as a system of dynamic and flexible law to the needs of the citizens and the institutions that govern them. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report as we consider the technical amendments contained in it to be an improvement in legislation.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction in the first instance of disputes between the Union and its officials. This report concerns a rather technical issue, but with a great impact on many Union officials, as well as on the way in which its judicial mechanism works. I believe that the decision to abolish the special court for Union officials and transfer jurisdiction to the General Court is a step forward, as substantial steps should have been taken previously to ensure the independence of the Courts of the Union and their officers, so I voted against the report.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with this proposal as it simply represents the fourth regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice. The third regulation led to an increase in the number of Judges of the Court of First Instance from 28 to 56 so that each Member State could appoint two judges each. The purpose of the proposal, given the increase in the number of Judges, is to dissolve the Civil Service Tribunal, which is composed of seven Judges. I also agree with the rapporteur that the European Parliament and the Council should be able to dissolve the specialised courts, if necessary, which they themselves have created.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report to increase the number of judges at the General Court to 56, so as to allow each Member State to nominate two judges each. This increase was subject to the condition that the Civil Service Tribunal, which has seven judges, was to be abolished, and civil service disputes transferred back to the General Court. The present regulation is a follow-up to the third regulation reforming the Court of Justice.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Justice is undergoing a reform process. Among the various aspects of this reform is the reform of the General Court of the European Union. Given the considerable amount of work of this, which currently has 40 judges, Parliament and the Council agreed to increase this number to 56, i.e. two judges per Member State. In return, the elimination of the Civil Service Tribunal of the European Union, composed of seven judges, was also agreed. It serves that regulation to - consequently - transfer jurisdiction in disputes between the Union and its agents. I therefore support the adoption of the report.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the Report by Mady Delvaux on Transfer to the General Court of jurisdiction at first instance in EU civil service cases. UKIP is opposed in principle to the very existence of and primacy of the European Court of Justice and is opposed in principle to the right of the EU to make and pass legislation. For those reasons we voted against the proposed legislation.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the proposal is to implement the decision to transfer to the Court of Justice of the European Union the seven judges of the Civil Service Tribunal, a decision taken under the abovementioned Regulation, and also transferring the jurisdiction of the Civil Service Tribunal to the Court of First Instance. I voted in favour of the Court of Justice's proposal, which merely repeals the provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal and introduces side-changes and transitional provisions.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls for the repeal of the provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal, along with a small number of consequential amendments and transitional provisions. By amending provisions, it intends to make things clearer. I agree with the establishment of the office of Vice-President of the Court of Justice and the amendment of the rules relating to the composition and the way the Grand Chamber operates. I understand that the large Member States wanted them to be appointed on merit; however small Member States require a rotation system which ensures our countries, in turn, two judges at the Court to cope with increased workload. This should be kept in consideration in view of forthcoming developments.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This is the fourth time the EU Court is reformed. The last reform paved the way for double the number of judges. The consequence of this increase is the closure of the Court specialising in the European civil service and the transfer of its powers to the General Court.  I voted against this handover, because I do not think there is a need for an increase in judges and at the same time I am against the closure of the Court specialising in the European civil service.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Parliament's report on the draft regulation on the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of the power at first instance to resolve disputes between the Union and its employees. The report is one of the documents concerning the reform of the Luxembourg-based Court of Justice, which streamlines and improves the negotiating arrangements for cases in the 28 Member States, in this particular case disputes between the EU institutions and their staff.  The Regulation is the fourth act relating to the reform of the Court of Justice. The first made amendments to the composition and procedure of the Court of Justice and the General Court, and the second provided for substitute judges of the Civil Service Tribunal. The third relates to an increase in the number of judges of the General Court. Under the original proposal, the number of judges would have increased from 28 to 40. At the end of the process, a decision was taken which set the number of judges of the General Court at 56, allowing each Member State to nominate two judges. The Civil Service Tribunal shall cease to exist and the public service disputes shall be returned to the General Court. The proposal also covers the way in which proceedings pending before the Civil Service Tribunal are transferred to the General Court. Cases pending before the Civil Service Tribunal will be transferred on 31 August 2016 in accordance with their position at the time.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This Regulation is the fourth in a row concerning the reform of the Court of Justice, which is ultimately intended to increase the number of judges in the General Court to 56, so as to allow each Member State to nominate two judges each. The increase in the number of judges has been conditional on the dismantling of the Civil Service Court and the referral of public service disputes back to the General Court. The number of Judges of the General Court at this stage of the reform will be increased by 7 judges of the Civil Service Court and will eventually be 47. In his draft report, your rapporteur approves the proposal of the Court of Justice, proposing only a few minor technical amendments concerning: • the rules for the submission of court cases before the Civil Service Tribunal, • changes to the Court's rules of procedure and its internal organisation. I support the reform of the Court of Justice in order to increase the efficiency of the European judiciary, but not by doubling the number of judges. I therefore abstained.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with a regulation that is a mere follow-up to the third regulation reforming the Court of Justice. In parallel with the second step in the increase in the number of judges at the General Court, from 40 to 47, the Civil Service Tribunal, which has seven judges, is to be abolished. In this process the European Parliament took the opportunity to again highlight the importance which it attaches to gender balance amongst the judges at the courts of the European Union. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report focuses on the third and most controversial part of the Court of Justice's reform, which focuses on increasing the number of judges of the Tribunal. This increase is related to the abolition of the 7-judge Public Service Tribunal. The report presents several technical adjustments. Considering that the Court of the European Union must have the necessary tools and manpower to carry out its missions effectively, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the transfer of jurisdiction to the Court of the European Union to rule, in the first instance, on disputes between the Union and its agents. The increase in the number of judges in the Court of the European Union implies the abolition of the Public Service Tribunal of the European Union. Thus, the tribunal's judges will have jurisdiction to rule on public service litigation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This draft regulation is the fourth relating to the controversial reform of the Court of Justice. In particular, the text provides for the abolition of the 2004/752/EC decision establishing the Public Service Tribunal. The reform of the Court of Justice has been carried out, from the very beginning, without any impact or cost analysis. The abolition of the TFP was proposed without consultation with its judges and officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its removal. I was strongly opposed to this costly, irregular and unnecessary reform in a context of austerity that applies to our national courts.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Positive as a whole. There had already been doubts about the increase in the number of Judges of the General Court, which in the end was higher than what had been agreed. The reason, however, is that there will be representation from each Member State with two judges and the merger of the Civil Service Tribunal into the General Court. According to the specific reports, better functioning and adjudication of cases and better control will be achieved.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: the reform of the Court of Justice has been carried out, from the very beginning, in a scandalous manner, without any impact analysis or cost. The abolition of the TFP was proposed without consultation with its judges and officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its removal. We strongly oppose this costly, illegal and unnecessary reform at a time when austerity is sweeping our national jurisdictions.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal is, as you know, the direct consequence of the reform of the Court of Justice, which provides for a doubling of the number of Judges of the Court of First Instance. Our position on the reform is very negative because the advantages for the citizens of Europe, of this proliferation of seats, are all to be demonstrated. We fear that this reform, far from resolving the critical issues in the administration of justice within the European Union, could generate new waste without increasing the efficiency of the court. We also share the doubts raised by distinguished lawyers about the conformity of this reform with the Treaty. For all these reasons, we cannot vote in favour of this legislative motion for a resolution.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation is the fourth on the reform of the Court of Justice. The first regulation introduced several amendments to the formations and procedure of the Court of Justice and the General Court. The second part of the reform created provisions on the interim judges of the Civil Service Tribunal. The third part was controversial as it concerned an increase in the number of judges of the General Court. The initial increase predicted was 28 to 40 judges. At the end of the journey, the co-legislators agreed, under the impetus of the Council, on the increase to 56 of the number of judges of the General Court, in order to allow each Member State to appoint two judges. This increase was subject to the condition that the Civil Service Tribunal be abolished and civil service litigation transferred back to the General Court. We have opposed the extinction of the General Civil Service Tribunal and we see no use in increasing the number of judges, a situation that could be resolved with a turnover system. That is reason why we do not support this report either.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ The disappearance of such a specialised court is not needed and I do not see the need for the hiring of more judges. I voted against.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain because the whole reform of the Court of Justice has never completely convinced us.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction in the first instance of disputes between the Union and its officials, as there had already been disputes about the increase in the number of Judges of the General Court which in the end was more than had been agreed. The reason, however, is that there will be representation from each Member State, with two judges, as well as the merger of the Civil Service Tribunal into the General Court. According to the special reports, there will be better functioning and adjudication of cases and better control.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation is the fourth relating to the reform of the Court of Justice. The third reform concerned an increase in the number of judges at the General Court to 56. This increase was subject to the condition that the Civil Service Tribunal be abolished, with civil service disputes transferred back to the General Court. The present regulation is therefore a follow-up to the third regulation reforming the Court of Justice. In parallel with the second step on the increase in the number of judges at the General Court, from 40 to 47, the Civil Service Tribunal, which has seven judges, is to be abolished. The Court of Justice’s proposal merely proposes the repeal of the legal provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal, along with a small number of consequential amendments and transitional provisions concerning the transfer of ongoing cases.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the 'Report on the transfer of responsibility for the decision at first instance on EU civil service disputes to the Court of Justice of the European Union'. Although the report sets some useful accents, it, on the whole, in too many places, calls into question the sovereignty and subsidiarity of the Member States.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support the transfer to the Court of Justice of the European Union of jurisdiction for the decision at first instance on EU civil service disputes. This leads to the dissolution of the Civil Service Tribunal. The number of judges at the General Court of the European Union is to be increased to 56.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report, which is the fourth text relating to the reform of the COURT of Justice of the EU. At this stage of the process, it is proposed to increase the number of judges of the General Court of Justice. The consequence of this is the abolition of the Specialized Civil Service Tribunal, and the transfer of its powers to the General Court. I am opposed to the Draft Reform of the Court from the outset, so I am voting against this legislative resolution.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It meets the immediate efficiency and performance-related needs of the General Court. This will simplify the judicial structure of the European Union, enhance its overall efficiency and promote consistency in its case law.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the report, since its general approach has resulted (in the past) in the closure of the Special Court for Civil Servants and the transfer of its activities to the General Court of the European Union. We therefore do not see the need to hire more judges.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of the judicial cohesion of the European Court of Justice and of the general legal EU acquis, I supported this resolution. The amendments stemming from this resolution will facilitate appropriate transitional arrangements concerning the transfer to the General Court of the European Union civil service cases which will ease the burden of the ECJ’s caseload. This transfer of jurisdiction presupposes, in accordance with Article 256(1) TFEU, the dissolution of the European Union Civil Service Tribunal (‘Civil Service Tribunal’) which will also increase the coherency on the European legal system as EU civil servants will now have their cases heard at the General Court of the European Union.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it finishes necessary reforms to the ECJ.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The Delvaux report supports the fourth reform of the European Court of Justice (ECJ), which was long overdue due to the unreasonably long duration of the proceedings. In the case of the ECJ, ALFA can understand the increase in judges proposed by the Commission and welcomes the dissolution of the European Union Civil Service Tribunal (EUGöD) as part of the reform. This should not only remove previous confusions about the division of powers between the two courts, but also contribute to increased legal certainty in the EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I am strongly in favour of reforming the Court of Justice. This is a follow-up to the third regulation, which decides the increase of judges at the General Court since the Civil Service Tribunal is to be abolished.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft regulation of Parliament and the Council on the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction to decide in the first instance on disputes between the Union and its officials on the basis that I support the changes proposed by the fourth regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice.  I believe that it is necessary to reduce the number of pending cases and revise the structure of the Court for its greater efficiency and consistency, and in this context I support the adopted three-step approach. I also believe that this report contains some technical amendments that can improve legislation and I therefore support it.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The reform of the Court of Justice has been carried out, from the very beginning, in a scandalous manner, without any impact or cost analysis. The abolition of the TFP was proposed without consultation with its judges and officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its removal. We strongly oppose this costly, illegal and unnecessary reform at a time when austerity is sweeping our national jurisdictions. Naturally, I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the Report of Mady Delvaux on the Transfer to the General Court of jurisdiction at first instance in EU civil service cases. UKIP is opposed in principle to the very existence of and primacy of the European Court of Justice and is opposed in principle to the right of the EU to make and pass legislation. For those reasons we voted against the proposed legislation.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which, following the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal, transfers to the Court of the European Union the jurisdiction to rule, in the first instance, on disputes between the Union and its agents.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report deals with a necessary reform of the Court of Justice and an increase in the number of judges in order to meet the 65% increase in the volume of work in recent years. It is foreseen that each Member State may nominate two judges. In return, the Civil Service Tribunal is dissolved and pending disputes are transferred to the Court of Justice. This will allow for the increase from 28 to 56 judges and the transfer of the competences of the Specialitated Court to the Court of Justice, and legal proceedings pending from previous years may be settled in order to meet the increased volume of work. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The Delvaux report supports the fourth reform of the European Court of Justice (ECJ), which was long overdue due to the unreasonably long duration of the proceedings.
