In the case of the ECJ, ALFA can understand the increase in judges proposed by the Commission and welcomes the dissolution of the European Union Civil Service Tribunal (EUGöD) as part of the reform. This should not only remove previous confusions about the division of powers between the two courts, but also contribute to increased legal certainty in the EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the transfer of the case law of the Civil Service Tribunal to the EU General Court, I voted in favour of the proposal. At present, the length of legal proceedings before the General Court is disproportionately long. That is why solutions have been sought over the last few years to speed up management. The simplest solution is to increase the number of Judges of the General Court. However, for political reasons, it was impossible to increase the number of judges by judges only from certain States, so that some states were more represented in the General Court than others. Therefore, in the end, a solution was adopted under which the number of judges would be doubled, i.e. to 56, so that each Member State would be represented by two judges before the General Court. However, as this will increase the number of judges more than necessary, the Civil Service Tribunal, which currently has seven judges, will also be abolished. This will stabilise the number of judges to the necessary level when the General Court also takes over the public service tribunal's agenda. Judicial reform is already underway, but it was necessary to give the European Parliament's consent to the transfer of the jurisdiction of the Civil Service Tribunal to the General Court. At the same time as this proposal, the European Parliament has also promoted the gender balance of the Judges of the General Court. I agree with the proposal, as speeding up the Decision-making of the General Court is necessary in order to protect the rights of EU citizens. I also agree with the requirement of gender balance for judges.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the transfer of jurisdiction to the General Court at first instance is intended to apply technical and administrative improvements to the organisation of the General Court.  This is the fourth time such a report has been tabled in the European Parliament. Although each time the report tries to improve the internal organisation of the Court of Justice, this time an amendment finds me opposed. I do not agree with the amendment which aims to increase the number of Judges, because at the same time it will reduce the number of officials. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. This report, which is of a technical nature, analyses the proposal to repeal the provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal and to introduce certain amendments linked to the repeal of the second regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice. It calls for an increase in the number of Judges of the Court of First Instance so that each Member State can appoint two Judges each. The report also proposes other technical provisions aimed at remedying certain problems highlighted by practice. I am therefore voting in favour of the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it proposes to abolish the Public Service Tribunal without consulting its judges, and in defiance of Article 257 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which allows the creation of courts but not the removal of them. Moreover, this measure is a direct consequence of the scandalous decision to double the number of JUDGES in the Union from 28 to 56. However, I objected to this decision because it was unnecessary according to the testimony of the ECJ judges whom I had previously heard!

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The text put to the vote is the fourth version of the reform of the European Court of Justice. The latter proposal, submitted by the legal entity on 17 November 2015, provides for the main action to abolish the European Union's Civil Service Tribunal (PST). However, neither the judges nor the officials concerned were consulted. In addition, the Court of Justice expects to increase the number of judges from 40 to 47 from 1 September 2016, reaching the quota of two judges per Member State in 2019. This reform, which is cumbersome, costly and controversial, is unnecessary and inconsistent in view of the austerity that prevails over national courts. My vote is against it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This is the fourth time the EU Court is reformed. The last reform paved the way for double the number of judges. The consequence of this increase is the closure of the Court specialising in the European civil service and the transfer of its powers to the General Court.  I voted against this handover, because I do not think there is a need for an increase in judges and at the same time I am against the closure of the Court specialising in the European civil service.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This report is the fourth Regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice of the European Union, and is the next step in the European Union.  This report contains only a few technical amendments which the rapporteur considers to contribute to better legislation.  It is important to note that the section on specialized courts is completely repealed, as it will not be necessary until a specialized court is re-created. However, none of the amendments made affect the substance of the proposal. From the foregoing, and with the power afforded to us by the Treaty on European Union to co-legislators to institute specialised courts and to stress that even if it does not make implicit mention of the abolition of them, I consider, like the rapporteur, that it seems logical to infer that the treaty also permits it if circumstances so require.  I am voting in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The Delvaux report supports the fourth reform of the European Court of Justice (ECJ), which was long overdue due to the unreasonably long duration of the proceedings. In the case of the ECJ, ALFA can understand the increase in judges proposed by the Commission and welcomes the dissolution of the European Union Civil Service Tribunal (EUGöD) as part of the reform. This should not only remove previous confusions about the division of powers between the two courts, but also contribute to increased legal certainty in the EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. In my think, it doesn't matter what institution resolves labour disputes between the EU institutions and its staff. That's why I got late.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. This is the fourth regulation concerning the reform of the Court. The first regulation made various amendments to the composition and procedures of the Court of Justice and the General Court, and the second provides for the function of interim judges at the Civil Service Tribunal of the European Union. The third part of this reform included increases in the number of Judges of the General Court from 28 to 56, allowing each Member State to appoint 2 judges each.  This increase is conditional on the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal of the European Union, i.e. the transfer of disputes concerning the public service to the General Court. This report contains technical amendments that can improve legislation. The amending provisions are clearer and the section relating to specialised courts is being repealed al more fully.  The rapporteur agrees with the Commission's proposal and considers that in order to achieve consistency and quality of case law, more cases should be awarded to courts with a larger number of judges, where justified. In my view, this regulation aims to improve the General Court's action on cases in the field of the EU public service, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – The draft regulation concerns the reform of the Court of Justice, where the last reform increased the number of judges to 56, two for each Member State, on condition that the Civil Service Tribunal is abolished. This Regulation abolishes the Civil Service Tribunal and, at the same time, establishes the procedure for transferring the civil service disputes brought back to the General Court.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction in the first instance of disputes between the Union and its officials, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 9/6/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  This text follows the proposed regulation dated 17 November 2015 to transfer the powers of the European Civil Service Tribunal to the European Court. Introduced by the 2004/752/EC decision, it dealt specifically with disputes between European civil service officers. To accompany this transfer, the European Union Tribunal would see its staff gradually increased between 2016 and 2019. A transitional regime would be put in place for current cases as of August 31, 2016. We criticise both the principle and the method of abolishing the European Civil Service Tribunal outright without an impact assessment or in-depth legal analysis. This is an expensive reform, with a questionable legal basis. For this reason, we strongly oppose it.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the report on the draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the transfer to the Court of the European Union of jurisdiction to decide, at first instance, on disputes between the Union and its servants. This regulation is the fourth regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice and merely repeals the provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal and inserts a series of side amendments and transitional provisions including the repeal of the second regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the project report to transfer the jurisdiction to the General Court of the European Union to settle disputes between the European Union and its agents at first instance.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 Recent reforms by the General Court of the European Union have increased the number of judges from 28 to 56, so that there are two judges per Member State. This increase also requires the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal and the reintroduction of disputes between the Union and its officials at the General Court. I therefore consider it reasonable to introduce transitional arrangements in order to allow this adjustment by the General Court. This motion for a resolution on the transfer to the General Court of the EU of jurisdiction in the first instance of disputes between the Union and its officials (public administration disputes) contains both the necessary technical provisions, but also amendments which improve the legislation in force in this respect, highlighting the conditions for the transfer of powers and reforms to the internal organisation of the General Court to ensure coherence and effectiveness. For these reasons I would like to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This is about the reform of the Court of Justice. Subsequently, the issue is the increase in the number of judges from 28 to 56. This increase is a waste of resources if the specialised court is not closed. Since this is about the dissolution of the specialised court, I can unfortunately only agree here.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report includes a number of technical amendments which make the legislation clearer. The amending provisions have been clarified. The proposal includes the conditions for the referral of pending civil service tribunal cases to the General Court. Cases before the Civil Service Tribunal, which have not been heard before 31 August 2016, will be transferred to the stages of the proceedings as they will be on that date. In order to ensure legal certainty, these cases will be dealt with in accordance with the Rules of Procedure of the General Court

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This is the final step in reforming the European Court of Justice (ECJ).  It plans to abolish the European Civil Service Tribunal and transfer its powers and judges to the ECJ's district court.  But the bottleneck that justifies this reform is mainly the result of EU disputes against state aid and on recent developments in the Banking Union and the Common Security Foreign Policy. I therefore object to any increase in the weight of this court under these conditions. Moreover, while the Civil Service Tribunal has previously guaranteed quality treatment for European civil servants, there is concern about the fate of European officers in this Court in the event of a dispute with their employers. I am voting against this reform.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The reform of the Court of Justice has been carried out, from the very beginning, in a scandalous manner, without any impact analysis or its cost. The abolition of the TFP was proposed without consultation with its judges or officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its removal. We strongly oppose this costly, illegal and unnecessary reform at a time when austerity is punishing our national jurisdictions.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it addresses the need for reform within the Court of Justice. This report increases the functionality and fairness of the Court of Justice system, especially relating to the Civil Service Tribunal and the General Court.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. This report contains some so-called technical amendments that follow the court's latest reform of the increase in the number of judges. Specifically, this increase was conditional on the abolition of the seven-judge Public Service Tribunal. With regard to the whole reform of the Court, I have already spoken on this point. I do not think this reform was appropriate. Doubling the number of judges at a time when the backlog of courts is not only unnecessary but is a major flaw in all European institutions in times of crisis. With regard to the end of the Public Service Tribunal, I regret this decision. In addition to the fact that public service litigation is highly specialized, it is legitimate to question the appointment of 2 additional judges on March 22, who will be paid full-time when it is well known that all cases that have not been argued at the last meeting of the TFP on March 18, 2016 will be postponed to September 1, 2016!

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The regulation in question concerns the reform of the Court of Justice and builds on previous regulations. In parallel with the increase in the number of Judges of the General Court from 40 to 47, the Civil Service Tribunal, which has seven judges, must be annulled. The application deals with the method of transferring proceedings brought before the Civil Service Tribunal to the General Court. Proceedings before the Civil Service Tribunal, which will not be closed by 31 August 2016, shall be brought as they appear on that date. In the interests of legal certainty, the Rules of Procedure of the General Court shall apply to these proceedings. Not only the Rules of Procedure of the General Court, but also its internal organisation will have to be adapted. I believe that a higher number of things should be allocated to the wider colleges, if their importance so requires, in order to ensure the coherence and quality of case law. Consideration should also be given to adapting the rules and procedures governing the allocation of cases. I agree with the proposal on the table.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation which is the fourth relating to the reform of the Court of Justice. The third reform concerned an increase in the number of judges at the General Court to 56. This increase was subject to the condition that the Civil Service Tribunal be abolished, with civil service disputes transferred back to the General Court. The present regulation is therefore a follow-up to the third regulation reforming the Court of Justice. In parallel with the second step on the increase in the number of judges at the General Court, from 40 to 47, the Civil Service Tribunal, which has seven judges, is to be abolished. The Court of Justice’s proposal merely proposes the repeal of the legal provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal, along with a small number of consequential amendments and transitional provisions concerning the transfer of ongoing cases.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The General Court of the European Union has submitted an application to the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of a draft regulation on the transfer to the Court of Justice of the power at first instance to hear disputes between the Union and its servants. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the text proposed by the General Court with some technical amendments which do not affect the merits of the proposal. That's what I voted for.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Article 257 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union is the legal basis for the establishment of specialised courts. It was on the basis of this provision that the only specialised court set up to date was established in 2004: the specialised civil service tribunal. However, it has been found that the number of cases submitted to this fore instance is relatively small, so this proposal for a Regulation resolves this resource inefficiency by allocating human resources, in particular judges, from the specialised court to the General Court. Although the existence of a basis for that amendment has been called into question, the truth is that the legal basis results from the contrary interpretation of that treatise provision. In this regard, I am voting in favour of this proposal, since I believe that there must be efficient management of resources by the Institutions of the Union and that it should be based on the adequacy of the actually existing needs.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The reform of the Court of Justice has been carried out, from the very beginning, in a scandalous manner, without any impact or cost analysis. The abolition of the TFP was proposed without consultation with its judges and officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its removal. This reform is costly, illegal and unnecessary at a time when austerity is sweeping our national jurisdictions. I'm voting against this report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation on the transfer of jurisdiction to the Court of the European Union to rule, in the first instance, on disputes between the Union and its agents. This text endorses the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal, which compensates for the increase in the number of judges in the European Union Tribunal.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I think it is important that the General Court of the European Union has the necessary powers to resolve disputes between the European Union and its employees, and that the Court of Justice is constantly reformed and that technical amendments are made in order to ensure the impartiality, independence and transparency of the judiciary.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Court of Justice started to reform itself on 3 December 2015 with the aim to face an increasing workload and to ensure that legal redress in the EU is guaranteed within a reasonable time. I voted this report that is the fourth regulation relating to the reform of the Court of Justice.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report concerning the adoption of the Fourth Regulation on the Regulation of the Court of Justice and the General Court of the European Union. The personal opinion was favourable, as this new regulation will contribute to a simplification of the procedural and functional mechanisms of the Court of Justice and the General Court of the European Union. This amendment is absolutely necessary in view of the increase in the number of pending cases assigned to the General Court of the European Union. In order to facilitate this transfer, the European Parliament and the European Commission decided to increase the number of judges of the General Court in order to enable each Member State to appoint two judges from its jurisdiction. This increase in the number of judges was also necessary to ensure the consistency and quality of the case-law of the General Court. I welcome the reform initiative of the Court of Justice and the General Court, as, by making the transfer of disputes relating to the civil service more effective, the European Union is strengthening its legal mechanisms.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – The Civil Service Tribunal was put in place for disputes between EU personnel and the Institutions. This report seeks to merge the Civil Service Tribunal with the General Court, which will have a number of adverse consequences for applicants, including 1) much longer waiting times, 2) the loss of seven specialised judges, 3) the loss of one appellate stage. This reform seems to have no have no real substance as the Court was first set up in 2005 with the aim of relieving the burden of the General Court. It seems that this reform has been a long-laboured compromise due to disagreements over which countries should appoint judges and how the rotation should work. The result is a loss in interest in specialised courts and just an increase in judges to the General Court. There is no empirical research to show that this restructuring will improve efficiency or save money. Therefore I voted against this report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is in the context of the debate on the reform of the Court. The report is, in principle, about increasing the number of judges from 28 to 56; this would be a waste of resources, unless the specialised court is closed. However, this report deals with the transfer of powers by the specialised court and its dissolution, so that I can agree to that in these circumstances.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I could only support the proposed amended draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction to hear disputes between the Union and its officials at first instance. Following the earlier amendment of that regulation to extend and extend the powers of the General Court to the proceedings of Eu officials, the abolition of references to the previous court, namely the Civil Service Tribunal, is purely complementary.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Report of Mady Delvaux on the Transfer to the General Court of jurisdiction at first instance in EU civil service cases. UKIP is opposed in principle to the very existence of and primacy of the European Court of Justice and is opposed in principle to the right of the EU to make and pass legislation. For those reasons we voted against the proposed legislation.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with what has been discussed on several occasions about a change in the composition of the Court of Justice, in the sense of an increase in the number of Member Judges from the current 28 to 56, and the consequent dissolution of the Civil Service Tribunal and referral to the Court of First Instance of civil service litigation, I would welcome the amendments to the Rules of Procedure for readjustment to the new European legal reality. I would therefore vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the resolution on the draft regulation on transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction to decide in the first instance on disputes between the Union and its officials. The proposed regulation is the fourth regulation concerning the reform of the Court of Justice.  The first regulation made various amendments to the composition and procedures of the Court of Justice and the General Court, and the second provides for the function of interim judges at the Civil Service Tribunal of the European Union. The third part of this reform was about increasing the number of judges of the General Court. Initially, it envisioned an increase from 28 to 40 judges. However, at the initiative of the Council, the co-legislators agreed to increase the number of Judges of the General Court to 56, thus ingesting each Member State to appoint two judges. In parallel with the second step in the process of increasing the number of judges of the General Court from 40 to 47, the Civil Service Tribunal, which has seven judges, must be abolished. This fourth regulation, in line with the requirements proposed by the co-legislators (Parliament and Council), proposes the repeal of provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal, together with a smaller number of consequential amendments and transitional provisions. This will see Croatia have two judges, and the Court's work will be further improved. That is why I supported this legislative resolution.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The reform of the Court of Justice has been carried out, from the very beginning, in a scandalous manner, without any impact or cost analysis. The abolition of the TFP was proposed without consultation with its judges and officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its removal. This reform is costly, illegal and unnecessary at a time when austerity is sweeping our national jurisdictions. I'm voting against this report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which deals with the fourth phase of the reform process of the Court of Justice of the European Union. The regulation in question abolishes the Civil Service Tribunal and transfers jurisdiction to decide, at first instance, on disputes between the Union and its servants to the Court of Justice of the European Union. In the interests of legal certainty, the regulation covered by this report lays down the arrangements for the transfer of ongoing cases from the old to the new competent court. The abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal had already been made a condition for an increase in the number of judges of the Court of Justice of the European Union, from forty to forty-seven, and so this fourth stage is the logical and necessary continuation of a path that has already been undertaken and which I continue to support.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. Since the Van Gend en Loos ruling, the European Court of Justice has been and still is one of the main engines of EU integration. In Van Gend en Loos, the Court defined the legal order of the European Community as a new legal order that is different from international law, but also from the law of the Member States. Moreover, according to the Court of Justice, which is today indisputable, the legal position of Community law in the national legal entities of the Member States is no longer controlled by the constitutions of the Member States, but constitutes an integral part of their legal order by the fact of membership of the European Union.  Given the growing number of cases before the European Court of Justice, reforms are needed to continue the work of this respected Court of Justice. At the initiative of the Council, legislators agreed to increase the number of Judges of the General Court to 56, the way for each Member State to appoint two judges. This increase is conditional on the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal of the European Union, i.e. transfer of disputes concerning the public service to the General Court.  I welcome the decisions of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and support the transfer to the General Court of jurisdiction to decide in the first instance on cases in the field of the EU public service.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported Mp Delvaux's proposal, since a 65 per cent increase in the number of cases before the General Court between 2000 and 2010 requires a greater number of judges and I agree that a rotational system is the most acceptable solution that guarantees each member to alternately appoint two judges of the Court. I welcome the possibility of adapting the rules and practices relating to the allocation of cases in order to create thematic synergies in order to achieve consistency and quality of case law.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation is the fourth to focus on the reform of the Court of Justice. The third part of the reform, which relates to an increase in the number of Judges of the Court of First Instance, was complex. Initially, a change of 28 to 40 judges was planned. At the end of the procedure, 56 were set up to enable each Member State to appoint two judges each. This increase was made conditional on the dissolution of the Civil Service Tribunal and the referral of civil service disputes to the Court of First Instance. This Regulation is therefore a follow-up to the third Regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice. In conjunction with the second stage of the increase in the number of Judges of the Court of First Instance from 40 to 47, the Civil Service Tribunal, which has seven judges, should therefore be dissolved. I believe that this proposal by the Court of Justice is logical. It merely repeals the provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal and introduce certain side amendments and transitional provisions. These amendments naturally include the repeal of the second regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the transfer of jurisdiction to the Court of the European Union to rule, in the first instance, on disputes between the Union and its agents. This step is the fourth part of a major reform of the European Court of Justice, carried out since 2014 and which, with the aim of simplifying, endorses the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This regulation, which I voted in favour of, is already the fourth on the reform of the Court of Justice. The first Regulation introduced several amendments to the formations and proceedings of the Court of Justice and the General Court; the second established provisions on the interim judges of the Civil Service Tribunal; the third was the most controversial, as it concerned an increase in the number of judges of the General Court (from 28 to 56). This Regulation is a follow-up to the third.  With this report, the amending provisions are made clearer and the section on specialised courts is fully repealed, as it will not be necessary until a specialised court is re-established. This report also states that not only the Rules of Procedure of the General Court must be amended, but also its internal organisation, and that a greater number of cases should be entrusted to broader training, provided that this is justified on the basis of its importance in order to ensure the coherence and quality of case-law.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The latest reform of the General Court envisaged an increase in the number of judges to 56 and the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal, with the consequent transfer of jurisdiction, in order to simplify and expedite the judicial system. This regulation therefore gives continuity to the reforms agreed, so that the General Court may decide at first instance all matters relating to the European civil service, and that is why I have cast my vote in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of the legislative resolution on the draft regulation on the transfer to the Court of the European Union of jurisdiction to rule, in the first instance, on disputes between the Union and its agents. In other words, the Tribunal would be given jurisdiction to decide, at first instance, disputes between any institution, body or body, on the one hand, and their agents, on the other hand, for whom jurisdiction is assigned to the Court of Justice of the European Union. This transfer of jurisdiction will be accompanied by a seven-fold increase in the number of Tribunal judges as of September 1, 2016.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue in question is purely technical. I do not think that it is worth the long debate. It is true, at the same time, to stress that the transfer of new functions to the General Court of the EU may also require additional budgetary costs, which, unfortunately, the rapporteur makes no mention of.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We are dealing with the fourth regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice. After the controversial decision to increase the number of judges, which would involve the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal and the transfer of its litigation to the General Court, this regulation rightly proposes to repeal the provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal, together with a slight change in the transitional provisions and, of course, the repeal of the second regulation.  Moreover, it contains some markedly technical amendments, which will better target the legislation, making it clearer and without changing its substantive character. I agree with the proposed amendments and i agree overall with the considerations made by the rapporteur, so I voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the transfer of jurisdiction to the Court of the European Union to rule, in the first instance, on disputes between the Union and its agents. Indeed, such competence, in addition to being provided for by the treaties, is necessary for the proper functioning of the European institutions. It will speed up the action of the Court of the European Union in order to be effective towards European citizens.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report, which is the fourth text relating to the reform of the COURT of Justice of the EU. At this stage of the process, it is proposed to increase the number of judges of the General Court of Justice. The consequence of this is the abolition of the Specialized Civil Service Tribunal, and the transfer of its powers to the General Court. I am opposed to the Draft Reform of the Court from the outset, so I am voting against this legislative resolution.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. This regulation is a follow-up to the Third Court Regulation. This regulation moves the civil service law to the civil court. Follow-up is necessary to complete the final regulation of the Court of Justice. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'transfer of jurisdiction for the decision at first instance on disputes between the Union and its officials to the Court of Justice of the European Union', as the requests of the co-legislators have been taken into account by the Court of Justice accordingly.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This is the fourth time the EU Court is reformed. The last reform paved the way for double the number of judges. The consequence of this increase is the closure of the Court specialising in the European civil service and the transfer of its powers to the General Court.  I voted against this handover, because I do not think there is a need for an increase in judges and at the same time I am against the closure of the Court specialising in the European civil service.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation on the conferral of jurisdiction at first instance on disputes between the Union and its servants before the General Court of the EU is already fourth in line with the reform of the Court of Justice. I consider this proposal to be a necessary process for the continuation of the reform of the General Court decided by the Union legislature in order to resolve the problem of the increase in the number of cases heard before that court. I supported the resolution of this regulation because I believe that the amendments will contribute to better legislation and that all civil service cases transferred from the Civil Service Tribunal to the General Court will be heard as they are at that date and can be brought before the Court of Justice. I expect that the reform and the proposed measures will increase the flexibility of the General Court to discuss the contentious agenda, improve the quality and dignity of the justice carried out on behalf of European citizens. I believe that the Rules of Procedure of the General Court will also be rescheduling in the short term, which should take into account the specific rules currently laid down in the Rules of Procedure of the Civil Service Tribunal.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. This Regulation is the fourth in the context of the reform of the Court of Justice of the European Union and is building on its predecessor. In parallel with the increase in the number of Judges at the General Court from 40 to 47 Judges, the Civil Service Tribunal, which has seven Judges, must also be abolished. The application sets out how pending cases are to be 200 brought from the Civil Service Tribunal to the General Court, which will take place on 31 August 2016. For reasons of legal certainty, the Rules of Procedure of the General Court will apply to these matters. The report points out that the Rules of Procedure of the General Court should be amended in such a way as to take into account the specific rules laid down in the applicable Rules of Procedure of the Civil Service Tribunal in disputes in the field of civil servants. A number of cases should be referred to more numerous formations where their importance justifies them in order to ensure consistency and quality of case-law. Consideration should also be given to adapting the rules and practices for the allocation of cases in order to create thematic synergies. In conjunction with Article 257 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the report points out that it is logical to conclude that an article authorising the establishment of an institutional body implicitly permits the abolition of that body if the changed circumstances so require. The report corresponds to my opinion on the reform of the General Court of the European Union, which is why I supported it.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The Delvaux report supports the fourth reform of the European Court of Justice (ECJ), which was long overdue due to the unreasonably long duration of the proceedings. In the case of the ECJ, ALFA can understand the increase in judges proposed by the Commission and welcomes the dissolution of the European Union Civil Service Tribunal (EUGöD) as part of the reform. This should not only remove previous confusions about the division of powers between the two courts, but also contribute to increased legal certainty in the EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – It is important to clarify the relations between the different institutions and to clarify their activities.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. On 28 March 2011, the Court of Justice of the European Union submitted a proposal amending the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the basis of Article 254(1) and Article 281(2) of the EIA). treaty on the functioning of the European Union. After the Lisbon Treaty entered into force in 2009, such a proposal should be adopted for the first time in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure.  The legislative proposal submitted contains separate proposals for each of the three courts within the Court of Justice of the European Union, and as regards the Court of Justice, the proposals mainly relate to the establishment of the Office of the Vice-President of the Court and the amendment of the rules relating to the composition of the Grand Chamber and its course of action. The aim of this proposal is to implement the decision on the transfer of seven judges of the Civil Service Tribunal to the General Court by transferring the jurisdiction of the Civil Service Tribunal to the General Court. I support this report on the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction to decide at first instance on disputes between the Union and its officials.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal and the transfer of those seven judges to the Court of Justice as a cost-effective way to ensure justice is delivered faster. This transfer requires no additional funding and means that cases before the Court of Justice will be dealt with faster and more efficiently, making a big difference to British citizens and firms who need to have their rights enforced fairly and quickly.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's report on the draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the delegation of responsibility for the decision at first instance on disputes between the Union and its officials to the General Court of the European Union. The resolution points out that there must be a balance between women and men among the judges at the Court of Justice of the European Union. I am in favour of equality, not equality. Judges should be recruited according to qualifications, not gender.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ This is the fourth resolution concerning the reform of the Court. The first resolution made various amendments to the composition and procedures of the Court of Justice and the General Court, and the second foresees the function of interim judges at the Civil Service Tribunal of the European Union. The third part of this reform was the most controversial, as it concerned increasing the number of Judges of the General Court to 56 and thus allowed each Member State to appoint two judges.  This increase is conditional on the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal of the European Union, i.e. transfer of disputes concerning the public service to the General Court. The resolution proposes the repeal of provisions relating to the Civil Service Tribunal, together with fewer consequential amendments and transitional provisions. The amending provisions are clearer and the section relating to specialised courts is repealed in its entirety, as it is not necessary until a specialised court is reinstated.  I support the adoption of this resolution, as I consider it a logical continuation of the court's reforms undertaken so far. The aim of achieving consistency and quality case law is to assign as many cases as you can to courts with a larger number of judges, when justified by their importance.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the delegation of powers to the General Court of the European Union for the decision on disputes between the Union and its servants at first instance. This regulation builds on the previous three regulations, which provided, inter alia, for the number of Judges at the General Court to increase to 56 judges. This will give each Member State two judges to propose. With this report, which contains some technical changes, we will only improve the text and clear up some provisions that may have been somewhat vague.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's vote, I did not support this next part of the reform of the Court of Justice of the EU consisting in the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal, as I believe, above all, that the previous stage of the overall reform doubling the number of judges of the Court of Justice of the EU was not due to the de facto need for such a large increase in the number of judges, but to the unwillingness of Member States to agree on the selection (method of selection) of the originally proposed 12 judges to increase the status quo. , which was conditional precisely on the annulment of this specialised court. As regards the very annulment of the Civil Service Tribunal, the question arises, first of all, as to whether the current legislation makes it possible at all to annul that special court established within the Court of Justice of the EU. The question of gender balance is then, in my view, merely a political statement which is not binding and has nothing to do with the very essence of the reform to be the effective functioning of the Court of Justice.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 There had already been challenges to the increase in the number of Judges of the General Court, which in the end was greater than what had been agreed. The report mentions representation by each Member State with two judges and the merger of the Civil Service Tribunal into the General Court. According to the specific reports, better functioning and adjudication of cases and better control will be achieved.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – I supported this regulation, as it is just a follow-up to the third regulation reforming the Court of Justice, which concerns an increase in the number of judges at the General Court to 56. Under the reform here in question, the Civil Service Tribunal will be abolished on 1 September, so as to coincide with the increase in the number of judges at the General Court.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. This regulation is the fourth to deal with the reform of the Court of Justice. The first regulation made various changes to the training and procedures of the Court of Justice and the Tribunal, and the second created the function of acting judge at the Public Service Tribunal. The third part of this reform, the most controversial, was the increase in the number of judges of the Tribunal. The first draft increase envisaged the increase from 28 judges to 40. The co-legislators, at the initiative of the Council, finally decided to increase the number of judges of the Tribunal to 56, so that each Member State could appoint two judges. This increase was conditional on the abolition of the Public Service Tribunal and the return of public service litigation to the Tribunal's jurisdiction. This regulation therefore follows the third regulation on the reform of the Court of Justice. The second stage of the increase in the number of judges from 40 to 47 must be accompanied by the abolition of the seven-judge Public Service Tribunal. I voted in favour of the text.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text on the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction at first instance in disputes between the European Union and its servants. This text is the ‘formal’ second step of the ECJ reform already decided upon some time ago. The reform foresees the establishment of 28 additional posts for judges whereby, in a first step to create a certain number of posts in 2015, in a second step to merge the Civil Service Tribunal into the General Court (current proposal) and thirdly, to establish more additional posts in 2019.  Previously I was not in favour of doubling the number of judges just because the Member States could not agree who would not have one additional judge, notably as the court only asked initially for 12 additional judges. Unfortunately this position has not been supported by Parliament.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted abstained on this report. While I support increasing the efficiency of the Court, I do not consider that this can be achieved by simply increasing the number of judges, and therefore costs, without first analysing the impact and cost-effectiveness of such a move.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the delegation of powers to the General Court of the European Union to rule on disputes between the Union and its servants at first instance. The regulation foresees an increase in the number of Judges at the General Court from 40 to 47 and, at the same time, the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal, which is of 7 Judges. Pending judgments in the latter will be transferred to the General Court in the present state. For this reason, the Rules of Procedure of the General Court and its internal organisation should be amended. Changes are also necessary from the point of view of the internal organisation of the General Court.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report, which is the fourth text relating to the reform of the COURT of Justice of the EU. At this stage of the process, it is proposed to increase the number of judges of the General Court of Justice. The consequence of this is the abolition of the Specialized Civil Service Tribunal, and the transfer of its powers to the General Court. I am opposed to the Draft Reform of the Court from the outset, so I am voting against this legislative resolution.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This regulation provides for the removal of the 2004/752/EC decision establishing the Public Service Tribunal and adds two articles to the Statute of the Court providing for the jurisdiction of the Court of the Union at first instance to rule on disputes between the Union and its agents and the possibility of an amicable settlement of disputes.  There are also provisions governing the procedural handling of cases pending to August 31, 2016 before the PST and for a transitional regime for appeals under review. The reform of the Court of Justice has been carried out, from the very beginning, in a scandalous manner, without any impact analysis or its cost. The abolition of the TFP was proposed without consultation with its judges and officials and without a thorough analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as the legal basis for its removal. I strongly oppose this costly, illegal and unnecessary reform at a time when austerity is falling on national courts. So I'm voting against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In the Union in which the rule of law applies, it is necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always properly defined, developed and fulfilled. Citizens can expect a high level of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and responsiveness from the Union's institutions, bodies and offices. Citizens are also entitled to adequate information on the possibilities of taking further action in their case. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report, which is the fourth text relating to the reform of the COURT of Justice of the EU. At this stage of the process, it is proposed to increase the number of judges of the General Court of Justice. The consequence of this is the abolition of the Specialized Civil Service Tribunal, and the transfer of its powers to the General Court. I am opposed to the Draft Reform of the Court from the outset, so I am voting against this legislative resolution.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction at first instance in disputes between the Union and its servants. I voted in favour because I am of the view that this decision is based on the relevant legal basis.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This report advances the reform of the Court of Justice by abolishing the Civil Service Tribunal which once again has the jurisdiction of the court. Since judges will have to start their work on 1 October and the decision comes to answer a request made by the co-legislators, I consider it necessary to vote in their favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation is the fourth on the reform of the Court of Justice. The first Regulation introduced several amendments to the formations and procedure of the Court of Justice and the General Court, and the second created provisions on the interim judges of the Civil Service Tribunal. The third part of the reform concerned an increase in the number of judges of the General Court. The initial increase predicted was 28 to 40 judges. At the end of the journey, the co-legislators agreed, under the impetus of the Council, on the increase to 56 of the number of judges of the General Court, in order to allow each Member State to appoint two judges. This increase was subject to the condition that the Civil Service Tribunal be abolished and civil service litigation transferred back to the General Court. We oppose the extinction of the General Civil Service Tribunal and we see no use in increasing the number of judges, a situation that could be resolved with a turnover system.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This report is in the context of the debate on the reform of the Court. In principle, this involves an increase in the number of judges from 28 to 56, but this would be a waste of resources if the specialised court is not closed. However, since this report deals with the transfer of powers from the specialised court and its dissolution, I can agree with that in these circumstances.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal and the transfer of those seven judges to the Court of Justice as a cost-effective way to ensure justice is delivered faster. This transfer requires no additional funding, and means that cases before the Court of Justice will be dealt with faster and more efficiently, making a big difference to British citizens and firms who need to have their rights enforced fairly and quickly.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the delegation of powers to the General Court of the European Union for the decision on disputes between the Union and its servants at first instance. This is the fourth regulation, which concerns court reform and brings some technical changes and clearer provisions. The reforms so far have included increasing the number of Judges at the General Court to 56 Judges, allowing each Member State to propose two judges each. The Civil Service Tribunal is also abolished and the settlement of disputes between the European Union and its servants is transferred back to the General Court.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I supported the resolution as I believe that the European Commission has been repeatedly called upon to present legislation to ensure an open, effective and independent administration of the institutions in the European Union. I support the idea of such legislation because its existence will benefit both citizens and the institutions themselves, as it will contribute to reducing conflict-of-interest practices, for example. I look forward to seeing a proposal from the European Commission, and in particular whether it shares Parliament's point of view.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. It must be said that, in its resolution of 15 January 2013, Parliament already voted in favour of adopting a regulation on an open, sufficient, independent administration of the European Union, but for various reasons the Commission did not draw up a proposal, and so today the current vote was actually on the same issue. It is hoped that this time, however, the Commission will follow the results of Parliament's vote properly and develop this necessary legislative proposal. An open, efficient, independent union governance, both within the institutions and in inter-institutional terms, and in its relations with Member States or citizens, are fundamentally important issues for the quality functioning of the Community institutions and for its future development. The same is undoubtedly true for our Member States: the more effective the work of the Institutions of the European Union will be, the more potentially advanced the work of the development of the Member States and regions will also be.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar is dóigh liom go bhfuil sé an-tábhachtach dár saoránaigh. I think it is crucial that, when confronted with EU administrations, citizens have their procedural rights and obligations defined and respected. As was said, in January 2013 we were strongly encouraged that a solution would be found when we adopted a resolution calling for regulation on an open, efficient and independent European Union administration. Sadly, however, the Commission to date has not proposed anything. There is a great need for such legislation: it should be clear to citizens what their legal and administrative rights are, and I believe citizens have the right to expect a high level of efficiency, transparency and responsiveness from EU institutions, bodies and agencies. I think, moreover, that when we as parliamentarians recommend something to the Commission, while they have a right of initiative, they should take our proposal on board and respond as quickly as possible.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, as I did in January 2015 in another Parliament resolution in which we called for the adoption of a Regulation on an open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union, with inaction in response by the EC. In a Union based on the rule of law, it is necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always properly defined, developed and fulfilled. Citizens should be able to expect a high degree of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and responsiveness of the Union's institutions, bodies and bodies. Citizens also have the right to receive adequate information on the possibility of taking other actions.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this oral question, which followed the adoption in January 2013 of a regulation on an open, effective and independent European Union administration.  The question with an oral response was: Has the Commission analysed the suggestion of regulation to the point of being able to react to its content? What reasons prevented it from submitting a proposal similar to the suggested regulation? When can we wait for a proposal? I believe that it is necessary for the Union to have a clear body of rules of EU administrative law.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. This proposal is an important step towards ensuring better administration and greater transparency with regard to the institutions of the European Union, as well as greater legal certainty for European citizens. They are not fully aware of their rights vis-à-vis the Union's bodies and its administration. For most of them, the administration of the Union remains opaque and difficult to understand. There is an urgent need to bring the European administration closer to its citizens.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on an open, effective and independent administration of the European Union, as it is an important step towards ensuring better management and greater transparency in the functioning of the EU institutions as well as legal certainty for European citizens. Citizens are often not fully aware of their rights in their relations with the EU institutions. Creating a set of rules on administrative procedures will help address this issue and bring the EU closer to the citizens.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to ensure that the European Union has a clear body of eu administrative law rules. This does not prejudge our subsequent position on the merits of a possible legislative proposal by the European Commission.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it is a proposal for a regulation. The report sets out a step-by-step roadmap on the topic of ‘How to Administer’. If this proposed legislation were adopted the result would be a highly formalised administration structure which would be inflexible, overly-bureaucratic, hidebound by rules. It would lead to a veritably fertile field of play for every lawyer in the EU if some act of administration fails to be conducted exactly according to the rules.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 In its resolution of 15 January 2013, Parliament called on the Commission to adopt a regulation on an open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union, but the Commission's proposal did not take Into account Parliament's call, even though the resolution was adopted in plenary by a very large majority. I therefore support the calls for the Commission to submit a legislative proposal.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which approves a proposed regulation setting out the rules of procedure that govern the administrative tasks of the Union's institutions, with the aim of ensuring the right to good administration through open, efficient and independent administration. The regulation thus sets out the terms and conditions for the opening of an administrative procedure, its management, the duty of rigorous and impartial investigation, the right to be heard, to have access to its file, etc.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution for an open, effective and independent EU administration. This is an important text which renews the request made to the Commission in 2013 to adopt a regulation on this subject. Although it received almost unanimous support in Parliament, it was not accepted by the Commission, which ignored it at length. Parliament has therefore decided to adopt a new resolution attaching a proposal for a regulation. The aim is to stimulate the development of legislation that is equal to the challenges involved in relations between the Union administration and citizens. People are poorly aware of the rights reserved for them by the Treaties, which is why it is necessary to define a set of clear and transparent rules that will make it possible to strengthen the links between the EU and its citizens, providing them not only with greater guarantees but also with legal certainty in their relations with the administration.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Resolution as its purpose is to ask the Commission to carry out an action plan to propose to Parliament and the Council a regulation of the procedures of the European Union, as well as its administrative function. I am in favour of implementing such improvements in the administration and forcing the Commission to respond to Parliament's demands.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. Without wanting to seem too cynical, I would say that one can always dream. I voted in favour of this resolution for an effective administration of the European Union, although I fear - again - that the good intentions expressed in this resolution remain a dead letter. We can therefore always dream and support the stated will to write our texts from now on in a clear and clear language for all citizens. One can always dream and support the stated desire to put all the languages of the Union on an equal footing, even if, in our own assembly, so many texts are often only available in the language of Shakespeare alone. One can always dream and support the stated desire to work for true transparency and public access to all documents. Well done! It remains to implement these beautiful principles. This is not the first time they have been stated here. Will it still be a beautiful statement that will not be followed by effect?

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, because this should be one of the priorities of a Commission which, among other objectives, has been to reduce the administrative burdens on citizens and businesses and has appointed a specific Commissioner to defend the rule of law. On both issues, the adoption of a regulation that improves the efficiency and openness of the Community administration, ensures its independence and adequately protects the procedural rights of citizens should be a key part. Precisely in the corruption of these principles is the source of serious efficiency problems and other scourges affecting many European states. It is therefore essential to open the process for adopting a regulation in this area as soon as possible. The proposed text incorporates very appropriate bases for doing so.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In 2013, Parliament passed a resolution calling for a regulation on open, effective and independent administration for the European Union. This had not been followed up by the Commission.  The JURI Commission has therefore drafted such a document and this resolution invites the Commission to examine the draft and present it with a legislative proposal.  This text does not prejudge our future position and does not affect the substance, so I have decided to vote for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have always fought against the proliferation of eurocracy. I would like to support this resolution with my vote and strongly call for the introduction into existing legislation of a core of principles for good administration at European level. I believe it is essential that the European administration and its institutions move towards greater and clearer transparency in their work, in order to better protect the interests of our citizens.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The citizen must always be at the heart of all policies developed by the European Union. I have therefore supported this resolution containing a proposal for a Regulation strongly urging the Commission to guarantee the right to a good European administration that is open, efficient and independent. The Commission should take letters on this matter, and submit a legislative proposal regulating administrative procedures in the European institutions, with the aim of providing legal certainty and guarantees to citizens when interacting with them.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it reminds the Commission that, in its resolution of 15 January 2013, Parliament called for a regulation on an open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union, but the Commission's proposal did not take Into account Parliament's call, even though the resolution was adopted in plenary by a very large majority. Calls on the Commission to consider the attached proposal for a regulation and to submit a legislative proposal with a view to its inclusion in its work programme for 2017.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this issue to the Commission regarding the Regulation on open, effective and independent administration of the European Union. I believe this proposal represents an important step towards ensuring better governance and greater transparency of the EU institutions and the legal certainty of citizens. Creating a set of rules will help solve the problem of non-information of citizens, and will also bring them closer to the administration related to the institutions of the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. It is necessary for the European Union to have a clear body of EU administrative law rules. This does not prejudge my subsequent position on the merits of a possible legislative proposal by the European Commission. I voted for this resolution.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution which is a proposal for a legal act – a regulation on an open, efficient and independent European administration – which lays down the procedural rules that shall govern the administrative activities of the European Union’s administration. The objective of this regulation is to guarantee the right to good administration enshrined in Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union by means of an open, efficient and independent administration. The way to do this is by setting up an administrative procedure. The regulation enshrines rights to information, procedural rights against the institutions, duties of the administration to cooperate with requests, duties to state reasons for actions, remedies and notification of acts. This regulation is supposed to be an additional tool for citizens, who until now only have the Ombudsman for these matters of redress. I welcome the EU having a system for an administrative procedure, as this will improve the rights of citizens, bring coherence and should lead to more transparency.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union guarantees the right of European citizens to good administration, through open, effective and independent administration. In a context characterised overall by a gradual increase in the competences of the European institutions, the development of transparent and simple administration and bureaucratic practices must be promoted and promoted. With this in mind, I call on the Commission to examine carefully and quickly the proposal for a regulation tabled by my colleagues Heidi Hautala and Pavel Svoboda on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, adopted in plenary on 9 June 2016, which is an interesting starting point for improving the functioning of the bureaucratic practices and procedures of the European institutions. , as well as guaranteeing citizens' right to a fair, rapid and effective administration.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. On 15 January 2013, Parliament adopted a motion for a resolution to adopt a regulation establishing an open, effective and independent european Union administration. However, Parliament's motion for a resolution was never followed up by the Commission. That is why Parliament has come back to ask the Commission to put forward a proposal for a regulation on this matter. Because I am in favour of the Union adopting a clear body of EU administrative law rules without prejuding my subsequent position on the merits of a possible legislative proposal by the European Commission, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution before us.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important that at Union level there is and ensure a clear definition of rules and procedures that are correlated with their rights and obligations. A high degree of transparency, efficiency and rapid resolution of problems on the part of the institutions must be ensured. At the same time, we need to keep in mind that, although a number of sectoral administrative procedures have developed over time, they are not able to ensure the coherence of the system, thus making it difficult for citizens to understand their rights arising from European legislation. We voted in favour of this resolution because there is a need for a common set of administrative procedures to fill gaps in this system, which will certainly lead to greater legal certainty.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution today to remind the Commission that, in its resolution of 15 January 2013, Parliament called for the adoption of a regulation for an open, effective and independent EU administration. Although the resolution was adopted by an overwhelming majority (572 votes in favour, 16 against, 12 abstentions), Parliament's request was not followed by any action by the Commission. With the development of the European Union's competences, citizens are increasingly confronted directly with the institutions, bodies and bodies of the Union, but all too often they do not receive adequate answers. Over the years, the European Union has developed a large number of sectoral administrative procedures, in the form of binding and non-binding provisions, without necessarily taking into account the overall coherence of the system and the need for transparency, particularly with regard to European citizens. This complex set of different procedures leads to gaps and inconsistencies between the procedures themselves. With today's vote, in essence, we wanted to ask the Commission to propose, in the general interest, a regulation that would make the Administration of the Union more efficient and open. Citizens have the right to expect a high level of transparency, efficiency, speed of implementation and responsiveness from the Union's institutions, bodies and bodies.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which was a first reaction to the failure of the Commission to come forward with a proposal for transparency of the EU’s administration since Parliament called for same in 2013. The regulation enshrines rights to information, procedural rights against the institutions, duties of the administration to cooperate with requests, duties to state reasons for actions, remedies and notification of acts. This regulation is supposed to be an additional tool for citizens, who until now only have the Ombudsman for these matters of redress.  As I have long campaigned for more transparency within the EU institutions, I was glad to support this resolution.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because it is a very concrete regulation for the purpose of establishing an integrated European Union administration. In view of the frequent intercourse within the EU, people are exposed to the European Union’s agencies dealing with various issues. It is necessary to define obligations and rights clearly to avoid misunderstanding within the agencies. I believe that a good EU administration will deepen the relationship and positively affect the European economy through efficient collaboration among the institutions.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Good administration is the primary right of citizens of the Union, which is also enshrined in Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The report touches on the important points, starting with procedural rights, the obligation to examine matters thoroughly and impartially, and lays down criteria for the management of conflicts of interest, as well as for streamlining proceedings. These are among the primary objectives of the Movement, and, if achieved, they make it possible to really put the institutions at the service of the citizens. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline that EU citizens have the right to expect a high level of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and response from the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. They shall also have the right to be adequately informed if they can take further action on their matter.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the motion for a resolution on the regulation on open, effective and independent administration of the European Union. It is obvious that this effort is aimed at improving the functioning of the Union's administrative machinery. As such initiatives have positive effects on Europe and its citizens, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has significantly increased its competences over the years, and so European citizens are confronted with its institutions but do not always receive adequate protection of their procedural rights. This is because the Eu ropean Union lacks a coherent and well-organised set of administrative laws. I am convinced that citizens need an efficient administration of the European Union so that they can be aware of their administrative rights under European law. In addition, appropriate structures and precise administrative procedures favour an open, independent and efficient administration. That is why I am convinced that we must seek this cohesion in such a way as to guarantee all citizens the same rights and the same treatment by the institutions of the European Union. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for resolution for an open, efficient and independent European Union administration

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the previous resolution of the European Parliament, a Regulation on a European Law on Administrative Procedure was called for to guarantee the right to good administration through an open, effective and independent European administration. The Regulation voted on today responds to this desideratum. In a Union governed by the rule of law, it is pressing that procedural rights and obligations are always defined and safeguarded, and citizens should be able to expect a high level of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and responsiveness by the institutions, bodies and bodies of the Union, as well as appropriate information on the possibility of initiating proceedings in this area. I support this resolution on the basis that a Regulation on the Administrative Procedure for Union acts is vital, clearly setting out the rights and obligations to all administrative procedures of the Union, based on the principles of good administration and the rule of law and other values which are at the heart of the Union.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report which advocates a regulation on how to administer the European Union. The proposed legislation sets out a strict step-by-step, tick-box procedure as to how to administer any given item of administration that lies within the ambit of the proposed regulation. This will have the effect of creating an extraordinarily over-bureaucratic administration which will spend significant amounts of time checking to ensure the rules have been followed and the boxes ticked. If some step is missed, work will have to be re-done like some game of snakes and ladders.
