In addition it will create a significantly fertile field of opportunities for lawyers to attack administrative decisions on the basis of failure to follow the strict letter of the regulation. This proposal is a particularly absurd one. For those reasons and because UKIP always votes against proposals for legislation (as a matter of principle), UKIP voted against this report.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The fact that the Union does not have a coherent and comprehensive set of codified rules of administrative law makes it difficult for citizens to understand their administrative rights under Union law. I voted in favour of this proposal because the right to good administration requires that administrative acts be adopted by the EU administration in accordance with administrative procedures that guarantee impartiality, fairness and timeliness. The principle of legal certainty requires that UNION legislation be clear and precise, so that citizens can know with certainty their rights and obligations.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, as I did in January 2015 in another Parliament resolution in which we called for the adoption of a Regulation on an open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union, with inaction in response by the EC. In a Union based on the rule of law, it is necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always properly defined, developed and fulfilled. Citizens should be able to expect a high degree of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and responsiveness of the Union's institutions, bodies and bodies. Citizens also have the right to receive adequate information on the possibility of taking other actions.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2015, the Commission set up a working group on administrative law, with the aim of drawing up a proposal for a regulation on the EU administrative procedure. To date, the Commission has not followed up its promise, which is why it must be encouraged to present a legislative proposal as soon as possible to regulate the administrative procedures of the Union's institutions, to provide citizens with legal certainty and guarantees in their relations with the EU institutions. Today, the European Union has a cumbersome institutional mechanism, starting with the System of European Funds, the basis of which is a complicated system that is difficult for citizens and entrepreneurs to access, who are faced with excessive bureaucratic mechanisms, which limit activity. The situation must change. Good governance is not an option, but a right and a foundation for improving competitiveness. The institutions must be aware of the practical benefits of a more targeted approach to citizens' needs, based on principles of transparency, efficiency and independence.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The resolution refers to the European Parliament's view that the proposal should be presented by the Commission in 2017 in order to provide certainty on the interpretation of existing legislation for the benefit of citizens and businesses. Action would contribute to creating greater transparency and accessibility. This would result in a general administrative law for eu institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, intended for persons who deal with the EU institutions, and would cover conflict of interest aspects, so that the adoption of legal acts is clear, simple and understandable. Legislative, judicial and legislative procedures for the adoption of delegated and implementing acts and non-legislative acts would be excluded from this scope. As the Commission has not yet responded to Parliament's request and has not taken any action in this area, the resolution seeks concrete responses from the Commission on this idea. Without seeing the glaring points of contention of this resolution, I voted in favour of it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution is pushing for a legislative proposal regulating the administrative procedures of the EU in order to provide citizens with legal certainty and guarantees when dealing with the EU bodies. This proposal represents an important step towards ensuring better administration and greater transparency as regards the EU institutions, as well as legal certainty and predictability as regards citizens. People are many times not fully aware of their rights in their relations to the EU bodies and the process going on at the level of the EU administration remains opaque and difficult to understand. Because I believe that creating a set of rules for administrative procedures would help tackle this issue and bring the EU administration closer to people, I voted in favour of this resolution

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that this resolution will allow the Union to have a transparent, efficient and independent administration for the benefit of all European citizens.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament tabled a resolution in January 2013 calling for the adoption of a regulation for an open, efficient and independent EU administration. However, as a result of this resolution, Parliament's request was not heard by the Commission. The Committee on Legal Affairs has therefore drawn up a proposal for a regulation that can meet Parliament's expectations for democratisation and good administration. Considering that the Commission must take into account the views of the European citizens represented by the Members of Parliament, I supported this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I have supported this resolution on an open, effective and independent administration for the European Union. I strongly encourage the Commission to consider the draft regulation prepared and adopted by the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The open, effective and independent administration of the European Union is essential in the public interest and therefore particular attention should be paid to the drafting of corresponding regulations.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: it is necessary for the European Union to have a clear body of EU administrative law rules.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution calls on the European Commission to take action in the field of the EU administration. In January 2013, the European Parliament called for a regulation on an open, effective and independent EU administration in accordance with Article 298 TFEU. The European Commission has not taken any action to that end. The resolution calls on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal that should be included in its work programme for 2017. The resolution opens up a non-fully explicit possibility of codifying administrative law within the EU, in short, the publication of an EU Administrative Code. It refers to the explanaming memorandum: "The fact that the Union does not have a coherent and complete set of codified rules of administrative law makes it difficult for citizens to understand their administrative rights under Union law." We do not hide the fact that it is important that administrative regulations should be applied by implementing fundamental rules and principles with a view to respecting the principles of transparency, subsidiarity and proportionality. It should, however, be ensured that the applicability of such an internal instrument of the European Union does not extend to the Member States. This is the only way to respect the sovereignty of these States and the national framework of reference of their values.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to force the Commission to follow Parliament’s demands.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the regulation on open, effective and independent administration of the European Union, as I believe that special attention should be paid to the drafting of corresponding regulations.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe this proposal represents an important step towards ensuring better administration and greater transparency as regards the EU institutions, as well as legal certainty and predictability as regards citizens. People are many times not fully aware of their rights in their relations with the EU bodies and the process going on at the level of the EU administration remains opaque and difficult to understand. Creating a set of rules for administrative procedures would help tackle this issue and bring the EU administration closer to people. I therefore support the call on the Commission to come up with a legislative proposal regulating the administrative procedures of the EU institutions, in order to provide citizens with legal certainty and guarantees when dealing with the EU bodies. A regulation on the functioning of the EU bodies and their relation with citizens is absolutely necessary and should not be postponed any longer.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the rules for open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union. Such considerations are in the spirit of citizens, small and medium-sized enterprises and a better European Union close to the citizens.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The organisation of the European institutions, in terms of ensuring the effectiveness of action and management efficiency, is the subject of observation and evaluation by the governments of the Member States as well as by citizens and public opinion, especially when the EU, in its various forms, calls on the Member States to carry out structural reforms and improve the spending articulations of national budgets.  As long back as 2013, the European Parliament called, under Article 225 TFEI, for the adoption of a regulation on an open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union. However, although the motion for a resolution was adopted in this House by an overwhelming majority, Parliament's request was not followed by a Proposal from the Commission. With this question we want to ask why the request to draw up a draft regulation capable of providing greater clarity and consistency in the interpretation of existing rules, for the benefit of citizens and businesses as well as the administration and its officials, has not yet been followed up.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Resolution as its purpose is to ask the Commission to carry out an action plan to propose to Parliament and the Council a regulation of the procedures of the European Union, as well as its administrative function. I am in favour of implementing such improvements in the administration and forcing the Commission to respond to Parliament's demands.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Properly structured and consistent administrative procedures support both efficient administration and proper enforcement of the right to good administration guaranteed as a general principle of Union law and under Article 41 of the Charter. Therefore, an efficient Union administration is essential for the public interest. An excess, as well as a lack, of rules and procedures can lead to maladministration, which may also result from the existence of contradictory, inconsistent or unclear rules and procedures.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution concerns the strengthening of the citizen's right to transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and response by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, as it notes that the current range of procedures has gaps and inconsistencies in these procedures.  It also contains a regulation aimed at the proper functioning of the institutions and which they have reached on the recommendation of a group of lawyers.  It is essentially a continuation of the Berliningue report, which was voted on in 2013 and which we voted in favour of.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which follows on from the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon providing the Union with the legal basis for the adoption of an Administrative Procedure Regulation. This provides for the adoption of regulations to assure that, in carrying out their mission, the institutions, bodies, offices and agencies of the Union have the support of an open, efficient and independent European administration. Accordingly, I was happy that Parliament’s resolution stressed that an efficient Union administration is essential for the public interest. The resolution lays down the procedural rules that shall govern the activities of the Union’s administration. These rules aim to ensure both open, efficient and independent administration and proper enforcement of the right to good administration.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as I believe it creates a way of ensuring that every person receives their right to have their affairs handled in an impartial, fair, and timely manner by the institutions within the EU.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe this proposal is a crucial step to having better administration, less bureaucracy and transparency for EU institutions. Rights and regulations decided by the EU administration are very difficult for citizens to understand. The proposal works towards finding a solution to this issue.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the motion for a resolution submitted after the oral response question B8-0705/2016 in accordance with Article 128(5) of the EIA. Rules of Procedure on open, effective and independent administration of the European Union (2016/2610 (RSP)) as this calls on the Commission to consider the attached proposal for a regulation for an open, efficient and independent European Administration and to put forward its legislative proposal for a regulation. In its resolution of 15 January 2013, the EP called for a regulation on open, effective and independent administration of the European Union, but despite the fact that the proposal for a resolution was adopted by a huge majority (572 in order, 16 against and 12 abstentions), the Commission has not yet responded to Parliament's request by submitting its proposal.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. It is necessary for the European Union to have a clear body of EU administrative law rules. That is why I was in favour of this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report advocating a regulation on how to administer the European Union. The proposed legislation sets out a strict, step-by-step tick-box procedure for addressing any given item of administration within its ambit. This will have the effect of creating an extraordinarily over-bureaucratic administration that will spend significant amounts of time checking to ensure the rules have been followed and the boxes ticked. If a step is missed, work will have to be re-done, like some game of snakes and ladders. In addition, it will create a significantly fertile field of opportunities for lawyers to attack administrative decisions on the basis of failure to follow the strict letter of the regulation. This proposal is a particularly absurd one. For those reasons and because it always votes against proposals for legislation (as a matter of principle), UKIP voted against this report.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which refers to a legislative initiative report which in January 2013 made a request for regulation on the subject of a more open, effective and independent European administration, to which the European Commission never acted.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution calls for the establishment of common rules for administrative procedures at the level of the highest institutions, i.e. bodies, offices and agencies of the Union, in order to improve legal certainty, fill gaps in the legal system and contribute to the guarantee of the rule of law. The Commission is invited to address these issues in a timely manner. I agree with this motion for a resolution.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to establish a set of rules that the Union administration should respect in carrying out its administrative activities. These are aimed at ensuring proper, efficient and independent administration, but also at proper application of the right to good administration. The document approved today is applied to the administrative activities of EU institutions, bodies and bodies; it does not apply to the activities of the EU administration in the course of legislative procedures, judicial proceedings, and proceedings leading to the adoption of non-legislative acts that are based directly on treaties, delegated acts or implementing acts. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is necessary for the European Union to have a clear body of rules of administrative law, in the interests of the citizens, in order to combat the abuses of power of the many European administrations.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of this report. We are talking about the creation of an open, effective and independent European Union administration, the creation of which was approved by a majority parliamentary vote on 15 January 2013. It is necessary for the Union to have a clear body of EU administrative law rules. This does not prejudge our subsequent position on the substance of a possible legislative proposal by the European Commission, to come in 2017.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, as I did in January 2015 in another Parliament resolution in which we called for the adoption of a Regulation on an open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union, with inaction in response by the EC. In a Union based on the rule of law, it is necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always properly defined, developed and fulfilled. Citizens should be able to expect a high degree of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and responsiveness of the Union's institutions, bodies and bodies. Citizens also have the right to receive adequate information on the possibility of taking other actions.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal is a kind of administrative code for citizens' dealings with the Institutions of the Union. The purpose of this Regulation is to lay down a set of procedural rules to be followed by the Union in the implementation of its administrative activities. I don't think such a new order will help anything, but it won't hurt either. That's why I got late.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. Over the past years, the EU has created quite a number of administrative procedures without taking into account the coherence of the overall system. The fact that the Union does not have a single and comprehensive set of codified administrative law rules makes it difficult for citizens to understand their rights and administrative procedures. The adoption of this resolution should make it easier for citizens and businesses to effectively and quickly interact with the EU institutions and to achieve their rights more quickly, so I supported this resolution.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – With today's vote, we have called on the Commission to adopt a regulation laying down precise procedural rules for administration. It shall apply to Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, with the exception of activities in legislative procedures, legal proceedings and procedures leading to the adoption of non-legislative acts directly based on the Treaties, delegated acts or implementing acts. I support this proposal because it aims to establish transparent, comprehensible and unambiguous rules and procedures without increasing administrative burdens and burdens that are in line with good governance and strengthen the legal certainty of the parties concerned. This Regulation shall not apply to public administrations of the Member States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Motion for a Resolution on an open, effective and independent administration of the European Union, because it is well documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This resolution provides concrete details to the European Parliament resolution adopted by a large majority on 15 January 2013. This second resolution, which is the initiative of the Parliamentary Committee on Legal Affairs, presents concrete proposals for the establishment of a complete and coherent body of administrative law. If we support the principle, we reserve the right to assess the text drawn up by the Commission on the basis of this parliamentary resolution at a later date.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution, which calls on the Commission to include in its 2017 work programme a regulation on an open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union. Such a regulation would contribute to the transparency, efficiency of the work of the EU institutions, agencies and to ensure that the people who contact them are promptly received.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The purpose of this resolution is to establish a set of procedural rules that the administration of the European Union should respect in carrying out its activities. This would indeed bring more clarity and coherence to the interpretation of the current provisions, for the good of citizens and businesses as well as the administration and its agents. This resolution follows the Berlinguer report of 15 January 2013 which asked "the Commission to submit, on the basis of Article 298 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, a proposal for a regulation on a European law of administrative procedure, following the detailed recommendations contained in the appendix". The resolution notes that the Commission has not committed anything to this effect. I am asking the Commission for a proposal for a regulation on this. I am voting for this resolution.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It is necessary for the European Union to have a clear body of rules of administrative law. Of course, this does not prejudge our subsequent position on the merits of a possible legislative proposal by the European Commission. So I voted for this issue.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Citizens should be able to expect a high level of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and responsiveness from the European institutions. The existing rules and principles on good administration are scattered across a variety of sources of law, so it is necessary to clarify for reasons of certainty and legal certainty. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on an open, effective and independent Administration of the European Union.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion. The administration of the European Union must emphasise transparency and capability, avoiding unnecessary bureaucracy. This motion helps ensure a more productive and clear Union for citizens.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The Union does not have a single set of codified rules of administrative law and it is therefore difficult for citizens to understand the administrative rights that they derive from Union law. An excess, as well as a lack of rules and procedures, may lead to maladministration, which may also result from the existence of conflicting, incoherent or unclear rules and procedures. The aim is to establish a set of procedural rules to be followed by the Union administration when carrying out its administrative activities. These procedural rules are aimed at ensuring an open, efficient and independent administration, while at the same time properly enforcing the right to good administration. The right to good administration obliges the Union administration to state clearly the reasons on which its administrative acts are based. The recital should state the legal basis of the act, the general situation which led to its adoption and the general objectives to be achieved by it. The reasoning of the competent authority which adopted the act should be clearly and unambiguously disclosed so that the parties concerned can decide whether they wish to defend their rights through a request for judicial review. I am convinced that the establishment of a common set of rules for administrative procedure at the level of the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies will strengthen legal certainty, close loopholes in the Legal System of the Union and contribute to respect for the rule of law. I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which requests the Commission to submit, on the basis of Article 298 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, a proposal for a regulation on a European Law of Administrative Procedure. Such a regulation should aim to guarantee the right to good administration by means of an open, efficient and independent administration based on a European Law of Administrative Procedure applying to the Union’s institutions, bodies, offices and agencies (collectively ‘the Union’s administration ’) in their relations with the public. Its scope should therefore be limited to direct administration; it should codify the fundamental principles of good administration and should regulate the procedure to be followed by the Union’s administration when handling individual cases to which a natural or legal person is a party and other situations where an individual has direct or personal contact with the Union’s administration; and it should include a universal set of principles and lay down a procedure applicable as a de minimis rule where no lex specialis exists.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In its resolution of 15 January 2013, Parliament called for the adoption of a regulation on an open, effective and independent administration of the European Union. The resolution was adopted with 572 votes in favour, 16 against and 12 abstentions, but Parliament's request was not followed by a proposal from the Commission. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs has now proposed the text of such a regulation and is proposing to ask the Commission to examine this proposal and present a legislative proposal to be put forward in its work programme for 2017. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This resolution follows a vote by the European Parliament in January 2013 on the request for the adoption of a regulation on an administration of the European Union. However, there was no reaction from the European Commission.  Parliament therefore asked the Commission for an explanation and that the presentation of a legislative proposal be included in the 2017 work programme. We supported this resolution because it is necessary for the Union to have a clear body of administrative law. However, our position does not prejudge the position we will have on the substance of the legislative proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Article 298 TFEU, the institutions, bodies, bodies and agencies of the Union shall, in the performance of their tasks, support an open, effective and independent European administration and the European Union shall adopt the necessary provisions to that end. For its part, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union enshrines, in Article 41, the right of citizens to good administration. The European Union has been adopting a number of administrative procedures over the years in a wide range of sectors without, however, having met the overall coherence of the system. In this context, consistency of the Union's administrative activities and full respect for the right to good administration and interpretative compliance with procedural rules should be ensured. The right to good administration implies compliance with the duty of diligence, the principle of proportionality, the duty to act impartially, the obligation to state reasons for the acts, among others. In this regard, I am voting in favour of the adoption of a regulation on this matter, because I consider it essential that the administrative action of the Union be governed by an adequate and coherent structuring of administrative procedures, so that efficient, open and independent administration is ensured.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. It is necessary for the Union to have a clear body of eu administrative law rules. Without prejudging my position on the substance of a possible legislative proposal by the European Commission, I am voting for this text for the time being.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Commission to consider a report of legislative initiative adopted by a very large majority in the previous Parliament. This report made a request for a settlement on the subject of an open, effective and independent European Union administration, which the European Commission has never acted on. I voted for this resolution.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support the report. EU citizens are increasingly in direct contact with the institutions of the European Union, thus rightly expecting a high level of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and responsiveness from the Union's institutions, bodies and offices. Citizens are also entitled to adequate information on their case. Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union also provides for the right to good administration, according to which everyone has the right to conduct their affairs without bias, in a fair manner and within a reasonable time. At present, however, the EU does not have a comprehensive and unified set of codified administrative legal rules, which makes it difficult for EU citizens to understand their administrative rights under EU law. The exercise of the right to good administration would be greatly facilitated by the establishment and institutionalisation of an open, efficient and independent European administrative system.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s Committee on Legal Affairs set up a Working Group on Administrative Law in 2015, with the aim to come up with a proposal for a regulation on EU administrative procedures. I voted for this motion for a resolution that calls for a legislative proposal regulating the administrative procedures of the EU institutions.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 Effective Union administration is essential for the public interest. Excessive numbers of rules and procedures and lack thereof may lead to maladministration, which may also be caused by the existence of contradictory, inconsistent or unclear rules and procedures. The European Parliament calls on the Commission to adopt a regulation setting out the procedural rules governing the administrative activities of the Union administration. The objective of the Regulation is to guarantee the right to good administration enshrined in Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union through a transparent, effective and independent administration. The Regulation shall not apply to the administration of the Member States.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I support the approval of a Regulation on the Union’s administrative procedures, as the lack of it has often left European citizens’ procedural rights insufficiently protected in a context where growing EU competences have increased citizens’ administrative engagement with European institutions. The development of a significant number of sectorial procedures over the years has not always achieved the greatest coherence and consistence in the overall legal system, and thus the need for a comprehensive regulation seems clear. The Treaty of Lisbon provided grounds for the adoption of an Administrative Procedure Regulation, and in its Resolution of 15 January 2013 the European Parliament called for the adoption of a regulation on a European Law of Administrative Procedure.  Such a regulation, being promoted at present, aims at establishing a set of administrative norms the Union must comply with when carrying out its administrative procedures. This regulation shall not apply to Member States’ national administrations, but to the administrative activities of the Union’s institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. It shall apply neither to legislative or judicial procedures, nor to procedures leading to the adoption of non-legislative acts directly based on the Treaties, delegated acts or implementing acts.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the commission's initiative to come forward with a proposal for a regulation harmonising official procedures with the Union institutions, with the exception of judicial and legislative procedures. Clear and clearly defined rules on administrative procedures would provide more legal certainty for individuals who come into contact with the EU institutions, especially when they decide on their rights and obligations. Specific examples of harmonised legislation could be the right of access to their own file, the right to an effective legal protection, the obligation for institutions to take decisions within a reasonable time and the obligation to justify administrative acts.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, which is a proposal for a legal act – a regulation on an open, efficient and independent European administration – laying down the procedural rules that shall govern the activities of the Union’s administration. The objective of the regulation is to guarantee the right to good administration enshrined in Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union by means of an open, efficient and independent administration. The way to do this is by setting up an administrative procedure. The regulation enshrines rights to information, procedural rights vis-à-vis the institutions, the duties of the administration in terms of cooperating with requests, and duties to state reasons for actions, offer remedies and give notification of acts. This regulation is supposed to be an additional tool for citizens, who until now had only the Ombudsman for redress on such matters. I welcome the EU having a system for administrative procedure, as this will improve citizens’ rights and promote consistency and should lead to greater transparency.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I approve and welcome the adoption of this regulation which will bind and govern the action of the institutions and is the result of the Union's obligations, as they stem from the Treaty of Lisbon. European administrative procedural law has acquired its own written binding text which responds to the requirement for sound and effective administration. The right to be heard, the right to appeal to the administrative files and the strengthening of the right to an effective remedy against decisions of the Administration of the Union constitute, inter alia, rights granted to union administrators by that Regulation.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report advocating a regulation on how to administer the European Union. The proposed legislation sets out a strict, step-by-step tick-box procedure for addressing any given item of administration within its ambit. This will have the effect of creating an extraordinarily over-bureaucratic administration that will spend significant amounts of time checking to ensure the rules have been followed and the boxes ticked. If a step is missed, work will have to be re-done, like some game of snakes and ladders. In addition, it will create a significantly fertile field of opportunities for lawyers to attack administrative decisions on the basis of failure to follow the strict letter of the regulation. This proposal is a particularly absurd one. For those reasons and because it always votes against proposals for legislation (as a matter of principle), UKIP voted against this report.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On the proposal, I would like to vote in favour. European citizens have the right to demand greater openness, transparency and efficiency from the European institutions, and the institutions have a duty to meet this demand. In view, therefore, of the need for common rules, I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. All eu institutions, bodies, offices and agencies must be at the service of all its citizens, protecting their interests and acting in a completely transparent, impartial and efficient manner. The existing rules on the functioning of the Administration of the European Union are not unified in a single document, and their development has also led to mutual contradictions and illogicalities, and citizens face many difficulties in accessing information, understanding their rights and realising them, which undoubtedly need to be harmonised.  Already in 2013, the European Parliament has already called on the Commission to adopt a legislative act to ensure an open, effective and independent administration of the European Union, but this has not been achieved to date, so it is imperative that the Commission include the adoption of an appropriate regulation in the 2017 work programme. All citizens must be allowed to apply carefully worked-out and thoughtful law consistently, administrative procedures must be harmonised and administration swift and effective.  Citizens must understand their rights and obligations, which shows that the administrative acts of the European Union must be drafted simply and understandably in order not to prevent anyone from realising a guaranteed right. I supported this resolution on an open, effective and independent administration of the European Union, as I believe that the institutions of the European Union need to be in service and for the benefit of their citizens through more coordinated and effective action.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 As the European Union's competences develop, citizens are increasingly entering into direct contact with the Union's institutions. Procedural rights and obligations need to be clearly defined and the institutions must ensure the highest level of transparency, efficiency and speed of implementation, as set out in Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which recognises the right to good administration.  For this reason, I support the 'Proposal for a Regulation on an Open, Efficient and Independent European Administration', presented by the JURI Committee, which brought together a group of experts specialised in administrative law to draw up the text. The adoption of this text would go a long way to bringing European institutions and citizens closer together. The resolution sends out a strong political signal, given that a similar proposal had already been put forward in 2013, but was then dropped by the Commission. With today's vote, Parliament reiterates that it considers the application of the principle of good administration to be of fundamental importance, and the Commission cannot but take note of this.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. With the development of the competences of the European Union, citizens are increasingly coming into contact with the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, without their procedural rights always being adequately protected. The fact is that over the years the Union has worked out a large number of sectoral administrative procedures, both in the form of binding provisions and in the form of non-binding law, without necessarily taking into account the overall coherence of that system.  This complex variety of procedures has caused shortcomings and inconsistencies in these procedures. In order to facilitate the exercise of the right to an effective remedy, the Union administration should indicate in its administrative acts remedies available to the parties whose rights and interests those acts concern. In addition to the possibility of initiating legal proceedings or lodging an appeal with the European Ombudsman, the party should have the right to request an administrative review and should be informed of the procedure and the time limit for lodging such an application.  With a view to achieving the overall consistency of the actions of the Union administration, administrative acts of general application should comply with the principles of good governance set out in this Regulation, while in order to achieve overall consistency of action by the Union administration, administrative acts of general application should comply with the principles of good governance set out in this Regulation. I therefore support the text of the resolution and hope to apply it as soon as possible.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is to ask the Commission to submit a proposal for a Regulation on a European Law of Administrative Procedure. According to the rapporteur, in the face of a pressing problem in the European Union today - the lack of confidence of citizens, which can affect their legitimacy - the EU needs to give rapid, clear and visible answers to citizens in order to meet their wishes. This initiative is part of a process of increasing implementation of the federalization of administrative law, which continues, also part of a process of strengthening European capitalist integration which aims to harmonise national administrative rights. The report opens the door to the creation of a "communitarian" administrative right that would be another step in the construction of a European federation. We do not neglect the importance of administrative regulation by applying fundamental rules and principles, always with a view to respecting the principles of transparency, subsidiarity and proportionality. It should be ensured, however, that the applicability of such an internal instrument of the European Union does not extend to the Member States, in the context of respect for their sovereignty and the valorization of their national values, raising here the values of the state and para-state administration in its broadest sense. We abstained.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support svoboda's question, as it underlines that the EU administration should be effective, professional and independent primarily from political influences and that the principles of transparency and openness should be followed and every citizen exercised their rights. This issue recalls that bodies and institutions should act impartially, fairly and within a reasonable timeframe with the subject matter of any individual.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 The Administrative and Legislative Procedures of the European Union are difficult for the public to read. Citizens do not understand the rights that the European institutions and agencies give them, and this is partly the result of the current wave of Eurosceptics. That is why I supported the resolution on open, effective and independent governance of the European Union. I believe that such legislation, although the European Commission does not seem entirely in favour of it, can help to reduce the distance that citizens feel towards the institutions of the European Union. It is in the public interest for the European administration to operate effectively and to avoid both unnecessary production and a lack of rules. Both cases can become very dangerous. More specifically, this proposal is designed to ensure that any decision to start a new administrative procedure is accompanied by the provision of sufficient information to the relevant parties. It also includes highlighting the need to take administrative decisions within a reasonable time frame and avoiding excessive time-extending. What I see very positively is the provision on the right of citizens, who must be sure that they can contact the institutions and receive an answer to their questions in their own language at the optimal time. The institutions, agencies and authorities of the European Union are here for their citizens, who, on the other hand, should be clear that this is no different.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of adopting this regulation setting out the rules of procedure that govern the administrative tasks of the administration of the European Union. Indeed, the increase in EU-wide powers leads European citizens to be in contact with EUROPEAN institutions, bodies or bodies without the right protection of their procedural rights. Thus, the text sets out rules that will increase the level of transparency, efficiency or speed of execution and responsiveness of the European institutions.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 In a Union governed by the rule of law, it is necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always adequately defined, developed and respected. The rules and principles currently existing on good administration are scattered across a wide variety of sources such as primary law, secondary law, the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, non-binding legal measures and unilateral commitments of the Union institutions.  This regulation, which I voted in favour of, aims to guarantee the right to good administration supported by an open European administration that can improve the gaps and inconsistencies that the Union has developed over the years, through sectoral administrative procedures, in the form of binding provisions and non-binding measures, without necessarily looking at the overall coherence of the system. We must provide citizens with a high level of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and responsiveness by the institutions, bodies and agencies of the Union, as well as adequate information on the possibility of initiating proceedings in this area.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 On 15 January 2013, Parliament called for the adoption of a regulation on an open, effective and independent European Union administration pursuant to Article 298 TFEU, but despite the fact that the resolution was adopted by an overwhelming majority (572 votes in favour, 16 against and 12 abstentions), the request made by the European Parliament was not followed by any commission proposal. The EP now invites the Commission to consider this proposal for a regulation and to present a legislative proposal which it should include in its 2017 work programme.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The citizen must always be at the heart of all policies developed by the European Union. I have therefore supported this motion for a Resolution containing a proposal for a Regulation strongly urging the Commission to guarantee the right to a good European administration that is open, effective and independent. The Commission should take letters in this case and submit a legislative proposal regulating administrative procedures in the European institutions, with the aim of providing legal certainty and guarantees to citizens when interacting with them.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Administrative procedures are necessary for the proper functioning of our society. Nevertheless, it is essential for the Commission to also ensure a comprehensive coherence of the system.  This request by the European Parliament to the Commission to submit a proposal for a regulation "in favour of an open, effective and independent administration of the European Union" is not new, since such a request had already been made on 15 January 2013. Such a request is not, in my view, trivial, since it would fill the gaps in the Union's legal system and thus contribute to respect for the rule of law. The ball is now in the Commission's court.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I can hardly understand why the Commission is ignoring Parliament's proposal to draw up a regulation that would help define the openness, efficiency and independence of the EU administration. As we can see from colleagues' written question, the Commission does not provide any explanation of the reasons for its conduct at all. And this is already a worrying sign of arrogance.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to propose a regulation on the European Union's administrative procedure law. Such provisions would facilitate the relations of European citizens with the European administration. With the development of the Union's powers, citizens are increasingly directly confronted with the European administration. However, they do not always enjoy the corresponding procedural rights. At present, the Union does not have a coherent and comprehensive set of codified rules of administrative law, which does not facilitate citizens' understanding of their rights. We must guarantee citizens access to an open, efficient and independent administration based on a European law of administrative procedure.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution tabled by the JURI Committee on the Regulation for an Open, Effective and Independent EU Administration. I believe that European citizens have the right to expect a high level of transparency, efficiency, speed of implementation and responsiveness from the Union's institutions, bodies and bodies. That is why I voted in favour of the text presented in plenary.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Resolution as its purpose is to ask the Commission to carry out an action plan to propose to Parliament and the Council a regulation of the procedures of the European Union, as well as its administrative function. I am in favour of implementing such improvements in the administration and forcing the Commission to respond to Parliament's demands.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. This proposal is an important step towards better administration and greater transparency in the administration of the EU institutions. That is a positive step, and that is why I support the proposal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, as I did in January 2015 in another Parliament resolution in which we called for the adoption of a Regulation on an open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union, with inaction in response by the EC. In a Union based on the rule of law, it is necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always properly defined, developed and fulfilled. Citizens should be able to expect a high degree of transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and responsiveness of the Union's institutions, bodies and bodies. Citizens also have the right to receive adequate information on the possibility of taking other actions.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the resolution voted on today, the European Parliament called on the Commission to examine a new proposal for a regulation in order to ensure an open, efficient and independent EU administration. I believe that citizens have the right to expect a high level of transparency, speed of implementation and responsiveness from the European institutions. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on an open, efficient and independent administration of the European Union. This Regulation lays down the procedural rules governing the administrative activities of the Union administration. With the development of EU competences, citizens are increasingly confronted with Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, without their procedural rights always being adequately protected. Citizens have the right to expect a high level of transparency, efficiency, rapid handling and prompt response from the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. Citizens also have the right to receive adequate information on the possibility of taking further action on the matter in question. As the Union does not have a single and comprehensive set of codified rules of administrative law, it is therefore difficult for citizens to understand the administrative rights deriveing from Union law. The purpose of this Regulation is therefore to establish a set of procedural rules to be followed by the Union administration when carrying out its administrative activities, so that every EU citizen is orientated in the handling of any administrative matter, is not impeded and the whole process is as transparent and efficient as possible.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The European administration is less robust than the administrations of some cities. Nevertheless, it is extremely important that we constantly streamline its work and save european citizens' money.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Citizens of the European Union are increasingly coming into contact with union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies without their procedural rights always being adequately protected. It is therefore necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always adequately defined and developed and respected.  Citizens have the right to expect from EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies a high degree of transparency, efficiency, swift implementation and readiness to respond. Furthermore, EU citizens have the right to receive adequate information regarding the possibility of taking further steps in this regard, and the existing rules and principles on good governance are not available in one place, but are scattered and can be found in a number of different sources, from primary and secondary law to the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, non-binding law and unilateral obligations of the Eu institutions.  As the rules under EU administrative law are not harmonised, comprehensive and codified, citizens find it difficult to understand their administrative rights under EU law. Consequently, I support this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. With the development of the competences of the European Union, citizens are increasingly coming into contact with the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, and it is necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always adequately defined and developed and respected. Existing rules and principles on good governance are not unified in one place, but can be found in a number of different sources.  Due to the lack of harmonised and comprehensive rules under administrative law, citizens find it difficult to understand their administrative rights under EU law. The Regulation should apply exclusively to the Administration of the Union and not to the administrations of the Member States. The right to good administration requires the Union administration to adopt acts in accordance with administrative procedures ensuring impartiality, eainess and timeliness. I support the proposal for this Regulation, as I believe that citizens have the right to expect from the Union administration a high degree of transparency, efficiency, swift implementation and readiness to respond. An effective Union administration is of great importance and public interest. Properly structured and consistent administrative data support the effective administration and correct enforcement of the right to good administration guaranteed as a general principle of Union law and Article 41 of the EEA. Charter.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution to the oral question on the open, effective and independent administration of the European Union. With this resolution, we call on the European Commission to reconsider the attached proposal for a regulation and to come up with a legislative proposal to include it in its work programme for 2017. We need an administration that will serve our citizens and respect their rights and obligations. Citizens have the right to demand a high level of efficiency, transparency and responsiveness by the Institutions of the European Union and of the authorities and agencies, especially in the light of the falling confidence of citizens in the European Union.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution concerns the strengthening of the citizen's right to transparency, efficiency, rapid implementation and response by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, as it notes that the current range of procedures has gaps and inconsistencies in these procedures.  It also contains a regulation aimed at the proper functioning of the institutions, which they concluded on the recommendation of a group of lawyers.  That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The open, effective and independent administration of the European Union is essential in the public interest, therefore particular attention should be paid to the drafting of corresponding regulations.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal pressures the Commission to come up with a legislative proposal to regulate the administrative procedure of the EU institutions. I see a need to reform the Union’s administrative procedure, as I do not believe that the current framework maximises time and provides sufficient legal certainty for EU citizens when dealing with EU bodies. A large number of European citizens are still not aware of their rights at EU level and do not understand the administration process when dealing with our institutions. Therefore, Parliament is taking this initiative very seriously and I give my full support to an important step towards more efficient administration and transparency.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution to highlight what better administrative support should be. The administration of the Union should adopt the administrative acts within a reasonable time. Slow administration is mismanagement. Any delay in the adoption of an administrative act should be justified and the party to the administrative procedure should be properly informed and given an estimate of the date for the adoption of the administrative act.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Commission to present a draft regulation for an open, efficient and independent administration for the European Union. Over the years, the EU has introduced a large number of sector-specific administrative procedures in the form of binding and non-binding measures without necessarily taking account of the overall coherence of the system. There are gaps and inconsistencies in these procedures, due to their complex diversity, and a set of common administrative-procedure rules now urgently needs to be established at the level of EU institutions, bodies and organs in order to boost legal security, close gaps in the EU legal system and contribute to respect for the rule of law.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Motion for a resolution – I supported the Regulation on the Open, Efficient and Independent Administration of the European Union. The European Union respects the rule of law and it is necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always properly defined and developed and that they are properly respected at all times. The lack of a consistent and non-comprehensive system of codified rules of administrative law makes it difficult for citizens to understand what their administrative rights are. An effective Union administration is crucial for the public interest. The right to good administration requires careful conduct by the Administration of the Union, which obliges the Administration to carefully and impartially identify and review all relevant factual and legal elements of the case at all stages of the procedure, taking into account all relevant interests. The right to good administration imposes an obligation on the Union administration to state clearly the reasons on which its administrative acts are based.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Resolution as its purpose is to ask the Commission to carry out an action plan to propose to Parliament and the Council a regulation of the procedures of the European Union, as well as its administrative function. I am in favour of implementing such improvements in the administration and forcing the Commission to respond to Parliament's demands.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ With the development of the competences of the European Union, citizens are increasingly confronted with the Union’s institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, without always having their procedural rights adequately protected. In a Union under the rule of law it is necessary to ensure that procedural rights and obligations are always adequately defined, developed and complied with. Citizens are entitled to expect a high level of transparency, efficiency, swift execution and responsiveness from the Union’s institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. Citizens are also entitled to receive adequate information regarding possibility to take any further action in the matter. Over the years, the Union has developed an extensive number of sectoral administrative procedures, in the form of both binding provisions and soft law, without necessarily taking into account the overall coherence of the system. This complex variety of procedures has resulted in gaps and inconsistencies in these procedures. To avoid the growing distance between European citizens and its institutions, urgent actions is need to modernise it, make it more friendly and transparent, a better communication campaign is needed in order to inform people of the positive work being done.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. On 15 January 2013, Parliament called, in accordance with Article 225 of the FUE Treaty, for the adoption of a regulation on an open, effective and independent European Union administration, on the basis of Article 298 TFUE. This resolution was voted by an overwhelming majority (572 votes in, 16 against and 12 abstentions).  Parliament's request was not followed by any proposal from the Commission.  The Legal Affairs Committee set up a working group that drafted a concrete suggestion for such a regulation, which was developed and adopted by the Legal Affairs Committee. The European Parliament's resolution calls on the Commission to consider the project and present it with a legislative proposal, to be included in its work programme for 2017. It is necessary for the European Union to have a clear body of EU administrative law rules. This does not prejudge the ENF Group's subsequent position on the substance of a possible legislative proposal by the European Commission. So I'm voting for it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Resolution as its purpose is to ask the Commission to carry out an action plan to propose to Parliament and the Council a regulation of the procedures of the European Union, as well as its administrative function. I am in favour of implementing such improvements in the administration and forcing the Commission to respond to Parliament's demands.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. This represents a cornerstone of Green objectives and priorities. If the Commission will come forward with a proposal on a European Law of Administrative Procedure, as set out by Parliament, the regulation will increase transparency and accessibility, enhance trust and improve the relationship between citizens and the Union’s administration, thereby also reinforcing the legitimacy of the Union.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on an open, efficient and independent European Union administration. The purpose of the regulation is to establish a set of procedural rules, which the Union’s administration should comply with when carrying out its administrative activities. The regulation notes that it is of crucial importance to ensure that, in the Union, procedural rights and obligations are always adequately defined, developed and complied with. I voted in favour because I believe that an efficient Union administration is essential to the public interest.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 On 15 January 2013, Parliament called, in a resolution adopted by an overwhelming majority (572 votes to 16 against and 12 abstentions), the adoption of a regulation on an administration of the European Union open, effective and independent under Article 298 TFEU. The Commission has not taken any action to that effect. The resolution calls on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal, which should be included in its work programme for 2017. We have doubts about what are the administrative rights inherent to citizens or the rights of the Member States of citizens. What are union citizens? Are we also talking about more integration in the field of administration? These doubts open a door to different interpretations. Hence our abstention.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it looks at how we can foster the culture of an open, efficient and independent European administration. Over the years, the complexity of the EU’s administration has increased. New bodies, offices and agencies have been created and the tasks for which the European Union is responsible have also grown. This has meant, too, that citizens and businesses increasingly have become directly involved with the Union’s administration. This happens, for instance, when they are applying for EU funds, or when they lodge complaints against a decision that is unfavourable to them. The regulation would apply only to the administration of the Union’s institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, and not to Member States’ administration. It is crucial to reduce the administrative burden and tackle the negative public image that EU institutions have, in order to reduce the democratic gap that has grown between the EU and its citizens.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution for an open, effective and independent European administration. The fact that the Union does not have a coherent and comprehensive set of codified rules of administrative law makes it difficult for citizens to understand their rights. Not only that: the growing number of citizens facing travel within Member States must comply with often obscure and difficult bureaucratic practices. That is why it is necessary for the European Commission to draw up an action plan to improve and standardise public administration at European level, without prejudice to the specific jurisdiction of the Member States. A first step indicated in the motion for a resolution in this respect may be the certified translation of the various documents relating to the civil status.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report presented and believe that this regulation will contribute to greater openness and efficiency in the governance of the European Union. As the European Union's powers gradually expand, citizens are increasingly coming into contact with the Union institutions, bodies, bodies, agencies and agencies. Citizens have the right, in my view, to expect a high level of transparency, efficiency and rapid settlement from the Union institutions, bodies, bodies, agencies and bodies. The properly structured and uniform administrative procedures guaranteed by this Regulation shall support both effective administration and proper enforcement of the right to good administration, which is guaranteed as a general principle of Union law and within the framework of Article 41 of the Charter. This regulation is therefore the right step towards greater efficiency and transparency of the Institutions of the European Union.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the Resolution on an open, effective and independent administration of the European Union. The European Union does not have a coherent and comprehensive system of codified rules of administrative law, which makes it difficult for citizens to understand their administrative rights under Union law. I believe that, in the light of the principle of legal certainty for citizens and the rule of law, it is necessary to adopt a regulation laying down the procedural rules governing the administrative activities of the Union administration.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – We adopted the first, second, third and, more recently, a fourth railway package. It is high time we understand that it is railway transport that is the future of the transport sector, not only because it is cleaner, greener, safer, cheaper and because it is proven to be the cheapest. I supported this document only because of my desire for development and better railway equipment in order to be competitive with other means of transport. However, we must note that without support for this industry, it could in no way fight the emerging Chinese producers, which enjoy enormous political and financial support.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr In the European railway sector, which combines the production of locomotives and rolling stock, rail, electric process, signalling, telecommunications equipment, etc., 400 000 workers are now employed in this area. The sector is widely represented in both small and medium-sized enterprises and large-scale industry leading companies. It is worth noting that the Union's share of the global rail supply sector is 46%, which makes this sector fundamentally important for the development of the Community economy and other areas. In order to further strengthen the competitiveness of this sector in an increasingly intense environment of international competition, it is necessary to devote all due attention to the promotion of relevant innovation and investment – which in fact we also did in this document – and the same applies to active support and the promotion of a better market environment, both inside and outside the European Union.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm vótáil le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí seo léir taobh amuigh de cheann amháin: is é sin ar mhír 21; leasú 5. Baineann sé le cearta na n-oibrithe agus vótálamar, i bhFine Gael, ar son an leasaithe sin.  Bhí seans agam labhairt ar maidin maidir leis an ábhar seo mar thug an leas-uachtarán Tajani an cead sin dom i ‘bpreabadh na súile’, agus dúras ansin go rabhas i bhfabhar na moltaí seo go léir agus go dtugann sé an-seans don tionscadal seo forbairt. Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid gach seans a thabhairt dó i ngach aon tír chun forbairt agus go háirithe caithfimid cabhair a thabhairt do na fiontair bheaga agus mheánmhéide dul chun cinn a dhéanamh. Molaim an tuarascáil seo.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The railway industry is a key sector in the development of innovative capacities and competitiveness in Europe. Providing forms of intervention and assistance to enterprises could not only promote economic growth, but would also help to develop new strategies for environmental protection and technological development. In this respect, encouraging the digitisation of the sector, through the joint use of the funds allocated for this purpose, and developing a new training and education strategy, could undoubtedly be a good action plan. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because it is not aimed at solving the real problems that have put this important industry in such a complicated situation. The fundamental problem, despite the European authorities pointing to China, is the European Union's trade and competition policy. It is the continuing liberalisation phases of the railway sector and the imposition of strict conditions on public procurement, which expose this sector to international competition rather than putting job creation and growth ahead of competition. Despite including positive references to the participation of trade unions in decision-making and the attempt to propose an industrial policy. The marked lack of reflection on the liberalisation of the sector forces me to vote against a resolution which will not solve the problems of European industry.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. In the face of unfair competition, particularly from Asia, it is essential to further support the steel sector and to better secure European industrial jobs. The resolution proposes concrete measures to improve research and development activities, support SMEs and attract skilled workers to the sector. In addition, we call on the Commission to publish a communication on a coherent industrial policy strategy of the European Union in order to re-industrialize Europe.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report draws attention to a sector that is crucial to the industrial policy of European states. However, its Europeanism prevents a relevant reflection on an industry that is an industry of sovereignty by nature. It calls for more investment in the sector, but does not call into question privatisation and competition, which have precisely the corollary of the decline in investment in the network, as was the case in Great Britain, for example. Moreover, the role of the state is central to exporting these technologies, as in the field of defence industries; if the selling state does not control its equipment, it is not credible. However, the report's response to this is a greater openness of public procurement so that, by reciprocity, others open up theirs to us and do not require on-site manufacturing. We're dreaming! I voted against this report

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy I would like to confirm I voted against this resolution. This resolution asks the Commission to re-evaluate the market definitions and the current set of EU competition rules to take into account the evolution of the global rail supply chain. In my constituency of the North-East the steel sector is in crisis as a result of European Union rules curtailing its ability to compete with China dumping steel on the market.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. Like my colleague Dominique Riquet, I defend the competitiveness of the European rail sector, which is one of the few industrial sectors where Europeans still occupy a dominant position in the world. But it is under serious threat, especially by competitors whose market is locked, sometimes in double turn. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution, in which the EP advocates improving the competitiveness of the European railway supply industry. The European railway supply industry, which is involved in the production of locomotives and rolling stock, track, electrical equipment, signalling and telecommunications equipment, as well as maintenance and part supply services, which includes a large number of SMEs, as well as major industry leaders, employs 400 000 people, invests 2.7% of its annual turnover in research and development and accounts for 46% of the global GTP market. The rail supply industry is one of the most important industries for Europe's competitiveness and innovation capacity. I support the call on the Commission to take measures to ensure that Europe retains a technological and innovative advantage in this sector.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The resolution, which I approved, recalls that the European railway equipment sector, which includes the manufacture of locomotives, rolling stock and tracks, employs 400,000 people and accounts for 46% of the global market. It points out that competitors from third countries, particularly China, pursue aggressive expansion policies and often enjoy strong political and financial support from their home countries where, on the other hand, market access often presents many obstacles for European products. It therefore highlights the need for a level playing field for all in global competition and reciprocal market access in order to prevent the risk of job losses and safeguard European industrial know-how. It also calls for measures to ensure that Europe maintains its lead in technology and innovation in this sector.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The railway industry is an important part of the continent's economy, employment for more than 400 000 people and accounting for 46 % of the world's entire railway industry. This is a capital-intensive sector which is highly dependent on public procurement and is characterised by the obligation to comply with very high safety standards.  The motion for a resolution tabled in Parliament today, and which I supported, stresses the need to take all appropriate measures to protect European know-how, jobs and the global leadership of the sector, through measures to combat unfair competition from third countries. The EU must support its competitiveness by ensuring political and strategic support from the EU institutions for the railway industry. Investment in rail projects must also be relaunched through the use of EFSI, focusing primarily on the maintenance and modernisation of existing railway equipment. The ultimate objective must be to create an industry that can withstand the challenges of the future, maintaining a technological primacy and continuing to foster the commitment of SMEs in the sector.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Resolution, as its purpose is to ask the Commission to carry out an action plan, to propose to Parliament and the Council a regulation of the procedures of the European Union, as well as its administrative function. I am in favour of implementing such improvements in the administration and forcing the Commission to respond to Parliament's demands.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. The railway industry is basic to creating an integrated mobility system, reducing coal consumption in the transport sector and adding efficiency to the European economy. From an industrial perspective, it is a leading sector in the world and with great potential for quality employment generation. The fragmentation of the internal market, unfair competition of some external competitors or the progressive introduction of clauses of origin in contracts in third countries are real obstacles to maintaining and improving our leadership position globally. It is essential to apply the fourth rail package now and rely on the competitiveness and capacity of our industries, as well as modernize business models that do not get the train to take off and capture traffic of people and goods according to its virtues and capabilities.

name: Dominique BILDE
