text: In writing. This report addresses a strategic sector for the Union, and in particular for France, namely the railway industry (Siemens, Alstom ...). The text addresses several positive findings (the need for research and development investments, the importance of the sector, fierce competition and methods for obtaining contracts...), but many points are still negative. The report does not dare to name international adversaries (South Korea, Canada and soon China), laments the lack of opening of foreign public procurement (what about Ukraine which supplied Hyundai in 2012 while it benefits from European funding?) or remains silent on the issue of sanctions against Russia, yet one of the first foreign markets in the sector. Finally, this report provides strong support to the S2R grouping of which Bombardier is a member (the European character is therefore somewhat compromised...).  The Europeanism of the report prevents a thorough reflection on an industry that is an industry of sovereignty. It advocates for more investment in the sector, but does not call into question privatization and competition, which have precisely the corollary of the decline in investment in the network (see the example of the United Kingdom).  Moreover, the role of the state is central and not mentioned.  So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution on the competitiveness of the European railway industry is balanced and acceptable. It is also important for our SMEs operating in third countries to be able to gain greater access to credit in order to ensure their necessary competitiveness in the market, and it is equally important for the EU to strengthen its supervision of non-European investments in the Member States. For all these reasons, I wanted to support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The European rail equipment sector is of strategic importance for industrial growth, employment and innovation and for the transition to sustainable mobility, employing 400,000 workers, investing 2.7% of its annual turnover in R&D and accounting for 46% of the world market.   While the EU maintains a high degree of openness to competition from third countries, there are numerous obstacles in the latter that discriminate against the European rail equipment sector. In addition, some competitors are carrying out an aggressive policy of expansion to other regions of the world with strong political support. Thus, the European rail equipment sector must compete internationally with third-country companies with strong support in the form of state aid, such as favourable export credits. I supported this oral question and the accompanying motion for a Resolution to ask the Commission to make better use of the level playing field within the rail equipment sector and to develop an integrated and coherent industrial policy strategy that highlights the specificity and strategic importance of sectors such as rail equipment.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it is a statement by Parliament on the competitiveness of the European railway supply industry. The European railway supply industry, which is involved in the production of locomotives and rolling stock, track, electrical equipment, signalling and telecommunications equipment, as well as maintenance and part supply services, which includes a large number of SMEs, as well as major industry leaders, employs 400 000 people, invests 2.7% of its annual turnover in research and development and accounts for 46% of the global GTP market. The entire rail sector, which includes operators and infrastructure, employs more than 1 million people directly. indirectly 1.2 million employees. employees; notes that these figures clearly demonstrate the importance of GTP for industrial growth, job creation and innovation, as well as its contribution to the 20% reindustrialisation target. Parliament therefore asks the Commission to make full use of the various EU funding instruments, to examine and use additional sources of funding for Shift2Rail and to seek synergies between different EU funds and private investment. Calls also on the Commission, in this context, to use additional EU funding instruments for rail technologies not classified as Shift2Rail, including through the development of a Shift2Rail pilot system that aligns EU funding with the Structural Funds and other EU innovation funds.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the competitiveness of the European rail industry requires a European training and education strategy linking rail transport companies, research institutes and social partners to jointly examine the skills needed for a sustainable and innovative rail supply industry. In this context, I believe that a feasibility study should be launched on the possible establishment of a European Sectoral Training Council for Railways. It is necessary to urge the Member States and/or relevant regional bodies to establish a framework for the provision of continuous training, in the form of a personal right to training, to ensure that skilled workers can keep up with the growing needs of the sector and adapt to new market conditions or be relocated to another industrial sector in the event of redundancy. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report on the Competitiveness of the European Rail Supply Industry. Due to the increased competition coming from Asia, it has become clear that the European rail supply industry must work together with EU leaders to improve its global competitiveness and ensure fair market conditions for its products, both on the European market and abroad. I believe there is a need to act quickly to strengthen industry, boost research and innovation in rail transport, improve the workforce, strengthen export potential, etc.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The report underlines the importance of this industrial sector in terms of growth drivers and the need to stimulate investment, particularly in research and development.  But its Europeanism prevents a relevant reflection on an industry that is an industry of sovereignty by nature. This report is indeed too oriented on free competition within Europe: - It does not even name the adversaries in the international market (South Korea, Canada) and those that will emerge (China);  - The fact that Ukraine has equipped itself with Hyundai, while the country receives European funds, is not denounced; - It advocates the integration of subcontracting SMEs into intra-European competition, while the organisation in the sector is the only correct answer; - It does not call into question privatisation, which has precisely the corollary of the decline in investment in the network, as in Great Britain for example. Finally, I believe that the role of the state is central to exporting these technologies and that the selling state must order its equipment if it wants to be credible. However, the report naively wants more open public procurement so that, by reciprocity, others will open up theirs to us. So I voted against the resolution.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – On the surface this question appeared to be concerned with improving the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. However, the question fails to deal with the root cause of the problem, which is the continued privatisation agenda of the railway market in EU. The present legal framework prioritises competition and international trade over industrial growth and job creation. Moreover, the oral question is just calling for different forums, strategies, groups and networks to be established and fails to propose any concrete measures to improve the preconditions of the industry, other than new discussion clubs and additional layers of bureaucracy. It was for these reasons that I voted against this motion.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Studies show that interoperability and rail safety is a central element of the sustainable development model for the Europe of the future. Era (European Railway Agency), based in Lille and Valenciennes (France), was established to improve them by means of Regulation (EC) No 881/2004 of 29 April 2004. The Agency shall promote the progressive approximation, registration and monitoring of technical specifications for interoperability (TSI) throughout the European rail system and the development of common safety objectives for European railways. Although ERA does not have autonomous decision-making powers, it helps to draw up proposals for decisions for the European Commission. Regulation (EC) No 1335/2008 of 16 December 2008 assigned new tasks to ERA, which are linked to amendments to the Railway Safety Directives (2004/49/EC) and the interoperability of the rail system (2008/57/EC). Now, with the adoption of the fourth railway package, the ERA's powers of investigation and audit will finally be strengthened in its areas of competence. This will be useful in avoiding having 28 different systems for type-approval of trains: the Agency will act as a one-stop shop responsible for issuing authorisations for vehicles intended for cross-border activities and safety certificates to railway undertakings operating in the different EU states.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report looks at the economic issues surrounding the rail sector and the very strong competition there. However, this report does not sufficiently expose certain shortcomings of countries receiving European funds such as Ukraine, which preferred to equip itself with Hyundai rather than European OEMs. The report also says nothing about the negative consequences of sanctions against Russia, which is a preferred market for the European railway industry. These sanctions, for example, led to the freezing of the LGV Moscow-Kazan project.  Above all, the "Europeanist" tone of this report is problematic in view of the fact that the railway industry is within the sovereign interests of the Member States. For all these reasons, I voted against the motion for a resolution before us.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European rail equipment sector is very important as it contributes to technological advances in favour of a low-carbon mass-use means of displacement. In addition, this sector is made up of a large number of SMEs but also larger companies, which represent a large number of jobs and invest in research and development. It is therefore an important source of technological innovation. However, it is clear that this sector is experiencing difficulties, particularly in terms of international competition from third countries. The resolution calls on the Commission to further mobilise the financial instruments available to this sector, to synergise European funds in the field and to seek other financial resources for the joint venture S2R (Shift2Rail). I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution today to remind the Commission that, in its resolution of 15 January 2013, Parliament called for the adoption of a regulation for an open, effective and independent EU administration. Although the resolution was adopted by an overwhelming majority (572 votes in favour, 16 against, 12 abstentions), Parliament's request was not followed by any action by the Commission. With the development of the European Union's competences, citizens are increasingly confronted directly with the institutions, bodies and bodies of the Union, but all too often they do not receive adequate answers. Over the years, the European Union has developed a large number of sectoral administrative procedures, in the form of binding and non-binding provisions, without necessarily taking into account the overall coherence of the system and the need for transparency, particularly with regard to European citizens. This complex set of different procedures leads to gaps and inconsistencies between the procedures themselves. With today's vote, in essence, we wanted to ask the Commission to propose, in the general interest, a regulation that would make the Administration of the Union more efficient and open. Citizens have the right to expect a high level of transparency, efficiency, speed of implementation and responsiveness from the Union's institutions, bodies and bodies.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ On the surface this question appeared to be concerned with improving the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. However, the question fails to deal with the root cause of the problem, which is the continued privatisation agenda of the railway market in EU. The present legal framework prioritises competition and international trade over industrial growth and job creation. Moreover, the oral question is just calling for different forums, strategies, groups and networks to be established and fails to propose any concrete measures to improve the preconditions of the industry, other than new discussion clubs and additional layers of bureaucracy. It was for these reasons that I voted against this motion.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because it proposes promising measures that help the reform of the rail supply industry – a crucial component of our market. Currently, our rail companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, have to confront very competitive rivals from third countries and are in need of assistance for upgrading. I believe financial and technical support can effectively build a greener and more competitive rail industry, which will definitely boost the development of tourism, transportation and business.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European railway industry employs 400 000 people in Europe. If I am concerned about the slow payment of payments to SMEs in the European railway industry, I would like to point out that Mrs Werner's report calls on the Commission to monitor the correct implementation of the EU late payment directive, and i therefore voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress the specificity and strategic importance of the European railway industry for a European industrial regeneration.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the competitiveness of the European railway supply industry is directly related to the attitude that Europe wants to maintain towards one of its most important industrial sectors. European railways have historically contributed to the development of the continent and their contribution to the modern economy is important. It should also be particularly appreciated that rail travel is less harmful to the environment than the use of other modes of transport, because it entails less average energy consumption per passenger and kilometre, and therefore less greenhouse gas emissions. The effort to improve the railways must therefore be our objective. Although this resolution refers to existing problems facing the industry, its wording does not place sufficient emphasis on workers' rights and in this respect may lead to a further deterioration of these problems. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European railway industry provides more than two million jobs for the citizens of the Union and accounts for almost half of the world market for the railway industry. I believe that we must pay close attention to this area, which I believe is very important for Europe. As it is difficult and expensive for many companies to operate across their national borders due to market fragmentation, I am convinced that the creation of a single European railway area can be the solution to these problems. I also believe that the European Union's funding instruments and the search for private funds should be mobilised so that we can continue to invest in research and development. In this way it is possible to develop railway technologies in the best possible way and maintain the global leadership of the European railway industry. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for a resolution as a whole, and also supported the amendment ‘points out that workers' rights and working conditions are fundamental for the future development of the rail industry’.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I see the need for even better coordination by the Commission of EU financial instruments, other EU funds and private investment, so that the European rail industry can maintain and even further develop its world-leading position. I would particularly like to stress the special position of small and medium-sized enterprises in the railway sector, which make a significant contribution to creating growth and jobs, and which must be given better access to finance.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this resolution as it is not for the EU to tell the UK rail industry what it should do. For example, steel is a major source material for railways, and the EU’s inability to prevent cheap steel being dumped into the EU from China has led to the UK steel industry being decimated and thousands of jobs being lost. The EU clearly does not have a grasp of the business requirements needed to ensure competitiveness, and it should not be telling Member States what to do.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The competitiveness of European industry should be relaunched through the full, effective and uniform implementation of the Regulation on the European rail network for competitive freight transport, which is of benefit to both passengers and industry.  In addition, efforts must be made to remove the main non-tariff barriers that hinder the European railway industry's access to foreign markets, including obstacles to investment, discrimination and a lack of transparency in public procurement procedures.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because it is not aimed at solving the real problems that have put this important industry in such a complicated situation. The fundamental problem, despite the European authorities pointing to China, is the European Union's trade and competition policy. It is the continuing liberalisation phases of the railway sector and the imposition of strict conditions on public procurement, which expose this sector to international competition rather than putting job creation and growth ahead of competition. Despite including positive references to the participation of trade unions in decision-making and the attempt to propose an industrial policy. The marked lack of reflection on the liberalisation of the sector forces me to vote against a resolution which will not solve the problems of European industry.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The railway industry is a strategic sector for European industrial revival. It employs 400 000 people, invests 2.7% of its annual turnover in research and development and accounts for 46 % of the world market in the railway industry. In the light of these figures, I believe, in line with what was adopted in the resolution, that concrete measures and investments can be put in place to achieve the objectives of modal shift to rail transport, both for passengers and for goods, as announced in the 2011 White Paper on transport. Furthermore, in view of the fundamental prerequisites for the competitiveness of the European railway industry, such as the capacity for innovation, the creation of clusters and investment in research and development, I believe that the Commission must take into account, in the near future, the measures and initiatives developed by the European Parliament, and in particular: full and more efficient mobilization of all European financing instruments. , especially for the benefit of SMEs operating in the sector; the establishment of a European forum bringing together companies, start-ups and spin-offs bringing innovative ideas for the rail sector; targeted investments in innovation and digitalisation of rail services, including the integrated electronic ticketing system.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry shows that the rail supply sector is a dominant industry, both in terms of European competitiveness and innovation capacity. It is directly responsible for 1 million jobs and indirectly for 1.2 million jobs in the EU. The resolution underlines that competitors outside the EU, mainly Chinese, are expanding aggressively in Europe and around the world, often with strong political and financial support from their countries of origin. This trend can lead to unfair competition that threatens European jobs, so it is important to ensure a level playing field in global competition.  The European Parliament report adopted today, which I voted in favour of, makes a number of proposals to help and stimulate the competitiveness of the European rail sector. It calls, inter alia, for the rapid introduction of an integrated e-ticketing system in coordination with other modes of transport and other possible services provided by single ticketing service providers, and draws attention to the urgent need to implement modern rail, tram and other rails and necessary accessories in the common European market. It considers that the Commission should consider establishing a Forum at European level that would connect businesses with innovative ideas for the rail sector, in particular digitalisation, in order to share best practices and facilitate the development of partnerships.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The purpose of this ITRE resolution is to draw attention to the situation of the European rail sector. The resolution recalls the strategic importance of the sector for employment growth and innovation. The resolution draws attention to promoting the continued involvement of SMEs in the rail sector, mainly through the Shift2Rail Joint Undertaking, a public-private partnership established under Horizon 2020. The text is linked to the development of state-supported companies (china example) on world markets and gradually also in Europe. Attention is drawn to the possible negative impact of this phenomenon on the European rail industry. The question of recognising China's market economy status is mentioned in the resolution, but without indicating whether MES status should or should not be granted to China. I personally support the provisions of this resolution. I voted yes.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Because, while Malta does not have trains and the manufacturing industry for trains is not a major player in our economy, I still believe that the strength of the European economy as a whole is important to us all as a community, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. As many as 400 000 people are involved in the railway industry in Europe, an industry which covers 46% of the needs of the entire world rail market. However, Europe is in danger of losing market share due to the import of cheap rail supplies from non-European countries such as China and the lack of a coherent trade policy. While the EU market is largely open to competitors from third countries, third countries do not give up barriers that discriminate against the European railway industry, operating unfair competition that puts jobs at risk. With this resolution, we have asked the Commission that future trade agreements and the revision of existing ones should include provisions to improve market access in third countries. It will also be appropriate to develop an industrial policy that promotes sustainable transport, that supports innovation in the rail sector, including small and medium-sized enterprises, and allows the training of specialised staff. I believe, in fact, that these elements, contained in the resolution that I have supported, are essential if the European railway industry is to remain competitive at global level.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution focuses on the European rail industry market and defends the specific nature of the European rail industry by calling for the development of a new innovation programme for the European rail industry. The resolution also stresses the need to develop the right skills for the European rail industry while developing measures to support SMEs in the rail industry. Considering that the sharp and rapid increase in low-cost imports of rail equipment from third countries may constitute unfair competition for European manufacturers, and that it is necessary for the European railway equipment industry to remain competitive in the international market, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The resolution on the competitiveness of the European railway equipment industry calls, in particular, for encouraging collaboration between large companies and SMEs in research projects and for boosting investment in rail projects. This sector employs more than 400,000 people at European level, so I supported this resolution.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report draws attention to a sector at the heart of European states' industrial policy. He calls for more investment in the rail sector without jeopardising privatisation and competition, which has led to a decline in investment in the network, as has been the case in Britain. In addition, the role of the state is crucial in exporting these technologies, particularly in the defence industries. If the selling state does not order its equipment, it cannot be credible. However, the text advocates greater openness of public procurement in the hope that, by reciprocity, others will open up theirs to us. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Railway Materials Sector is of great importance for industrial development, employment and innovation, contributing to the objectives of reindustrialisation and investment in research and development. SMEs in the rail sector must have access to finance and be supported with European funds. Finally, improving the environment of the European market for suppliers and encouraging demand for rail products must be a priority for us.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. The role of the state is central to exporting these technologies, as in the defence industries; if the selling state does not control its equipment, it is not credible. However, the report's response to this is a greater openness of public procurement so that, by reciprocity, others open up theirs to us and do not require on-site manufacturing. Against the resolution and against the oral question.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution addresses the "competitiveness of the European railway equipment industry". It is part of the 4th railway package - which praises and defends. It advocates the path of privatisation of the sector, i.e. strengthening monopolistic control of large multinationals, to the detriment of investment and the public interest. The need for reindustrialisation, which is now being talked about, stems from years of compliance with an agenda of dismantling the industry that was in the public sphere, its privatization, with the obsessive objective of reducing jobs and workers' rights. About this the document says nothing. We propose concrete measures to enhance the railway industry and to look at its revitalization, with an increased public prominence, effectively guaranteeing workers' rights, valuing knowledge and creative work, new methods and technologies in the production chain and involving the definition of strategies according to the specificities, needs and plans of each country. We have made it clear from the amendments we have tabled that there is an alternative path to the one in the resolution. The amendments were rejected by the same amendments that approved the resolution. We voted against it.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as it drives a privatisation agenda.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution because it underlines the importance of the railway industry (IFF) in the process of European reindustrialisation.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the competitiveness of the European railway supply sector. The European railway equipment sector is of great importance for industrial development, employment and innovation, contributing to the objective of reindustrialisation and investment in research and development. SMEs in the rail sector must have access to finance and be supported with European funds. Finally, improving the environment of the European market for suppliers and encouraging demand for rail products must be a priority.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I recognise the importance of the rail supply industry to the UK and I share our Government’s goal of making the UK a leader in railways. We share the commitment to increase our manufacturing and innovation capability to enhance productivity, skills and employment to support UK economic growth. There is much in the resolution that mirrors this focus, but we do not believe that the International Procurement Instrument (IPI) represents the best way to achieve its stated objectives of opening foreign procurement markets to EU bidders. It also carries a significant risk of retaliatory market closures should it ever be used. Conservatives voted in favour of the resolution but continue to oppose the IPI. Paragraph 42 stresses the relevance and the impact that the negotiations on the ‘international public procurement instrument’ and the revision of the regulations on trade defence instruments are having on the European rail supply industry, and calls on the Council and the Commission to take this into consideration and to work closely with the European Parliament to reach a swift agreement on these instruments; and it asks the Commission to take into consideration the impacts which the recognition of market economy status for state-run or other non-market economies could have on the functioning of trade defence instruments and the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The European rail supply industry employs 400 000 people and plays a key role in terms of industrial jobs and growth. We must not allow the rail supply industry to suffer from unfair competition. To secure industrial jobs and to support a sector, which is essential for a shift to sustainable mobility, the EU has to act now from a position of strength. I support this resolution, which proposes concrete measures to improve research and development activities in the sector, to simplify access to markets and finance, to support SMEs and to attract skilled workers to the sector. Moreover, I support the call for the Commission to publish a communication on a coherent EU industrial policy strategy aimed at the re-industrialisation of Europe and outlining its strategy on important industrial sectors, including the rail supply industry.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I believe that the European rail supply sector is of huge importance for industrial growth, job creation and innovation in Europe. The European rail supply sector is of strategic importance in the rebirth of European industry, while the sector must also maintain its global leadership. It includes many SMEs and leading top companies in the sector and employs 400 000 people. Their role in boosting the rail industry is key. It should be highlighted that SMEs should be able to access finance, because this is one of the main challenges they face. The COSME programme and the Structural Funds can help to facilitate access to finance, including in the form of guarantees and capital financing instruments.  At the same time, it would be worth finding alternative sources of funding, such as the SME instrument for horizon 2020. The Commission should ensure that eu financial instruments and resources available to SMEs are used more, and we need to find a way to ensure that SMEs are not dependent on just one company, because it is clear that they are refraining from expansion due to a lack of resources on the one hand and increased risks associated with cross-border activities on the other. To achieve this, we need to create appropriate synergies between funding sources, together with existing support programmes to help SMEs become international.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail industry. As a family politician, I am keen to further promote and strengthen the family-friendly mode of transport by rail, while reducing prices for families. This can also be done across borders through more and better competition.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. "U2012 While it is true that the Resolution has some positive elements—reference to the participation of the rail sector in lowering CO2 emissions or concern for SMEs—it does not go against the sector's liberalisation and deregulation logics. Logics that are the main responsible for the situation in which the European rail equipment sector is located. That is why I voted against the Resolution.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because I found that, unfortunately, the Commission is not acting in a uniform and fair way. We do not have a European Strategy for Industrialisation and Protection of Industrialists, particularly with regard to SMEs, in the context of a global market with often unfair competition because of subsidies granted by third countries to their producers. The European rail equipment industry plays a key role in industrial development and job facilitation, but also in the transition to sustainable mobility in the European area.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. The competitiveness of the European railway equipment industry is increasingly being undermined by increased international competition. Asia is gradually taking over Europe as the main market for rail equipment. However, it is a strategic industry that employs nearly 400,000 people in Europe, is present in all European countries and is made up of a large chain of subcontractors of thousands of specialist suppliers and equipment manufacturers. Demand for such equipment is on the rise at European and global levels, so Europe must take its full place in conquering new markets, whether in America, Africa or the Middle East. It is time for the European Commission to take serious action to enable our industry to be in fair competition at the international level. This must be done quickly if we are to ensure a sustainable future for our industry, in Europe and internationally. Our European response must be twofold: on the one hand, the financing of investments in research and innovation which will constitute the added value of our industry, and on the other hand the use of our trade defence instruments and rules that are not naïve in the awarding of public contracts.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The European rail industry employs 160,000 people in Europe and requires a European strategy to realis the potential for transport development in Europe. It is in this sense that I support this resolution which calls on the Commission to mobilise all available funds to support the railway industry, a strategic sector yet threatened on all sides, including the EFSI, the MIE, or targeted programmes such as COSME.  Without clear and structured support for this industry, it will be difficult to realize the potential for transport development in Europe, even as the regulatory framework is making great strides, with the adoption of the technical component of the 4th rail package in April. The text refers to the next major challenges facing the sector, such as ERTMS or the standardisation of parts, and mentions the problems related to unfair competition in some third countries (notably China).  More than ever, we call on the European Commission to put together a genuine EU industrial strategy, including the railway industry, which is one of the most important and strategic sectors of the Union.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The railway sector overall, including operators and infrastructure, is responsible for more than 1 million direct and 1.2 million indirect jobs in the EU. It is important for European industrial growth, jobs and innovation, and in terms of its contribution to the achievement of the 20% reindustrialisation target. Therefore, in order to boost competiveness, it is highly important to encourage Member States to replace old equipment with modern and sustainable products on a larger scale and to focus on digitalisation in order to increase the performance of rail and to lower its operational costs.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European rail transport industry employs 400 000 workers and covers 46% of the global rail transport industry. The entire rail sector, including operators and infrastructure, directly provides 1 million jobs and indirectly 1.2 million jobs in the European Union. The sector is key to European industrial growth, job creation and innovation, and its development will greatly help to achieve the 20% re-industrialisation target. Railways make a significant contribution to climate change mitigation and to coping with other megatrends such as urbanisation and demographic change. In order to meet the Eu's 2030 climate and energy and decarbonisation targets, it is necessary to move towards rail and other sustainable, energy-efficient, electrified modes of transport. At present, the global competitiveness of the EU rail supplier market is adequate, but in order to ensure that Europe does not lose this position, we need to place greater emphasis on education and research. It is also particularly important to take into account the significant number of small and medium-sized enterprises operating in the industry. These undertakings face significant financial and administrative additional burdens which do not burden their competitors in third countries. We must pay particular attention to their support, in which the European Small Business Act, or even efsi, can play a significant role.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the report since its approach is one-dimensional, setting the framework for full privatisation of the transport sector under reference.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. The European rail supply industry (RSI), which encompasses the manufacture of locomotives and rolling stock as well as track, electrification, signalling and telecommunications equipment, employs 400 000 people directly and is responsible for more than 1 million direct and 1.2 million indirect jobs in the EU. I was pleased that the resolution recognised this as well as the fact that the RSI is a key industry in terms of European jobs in R&D, urging that measures be taken to ensure we maintain a technological and innovative advantage in this sector. I was particularly pleased that it called for European training and for an education strategy bringing together RSI companies, research institutes and the social partners to jointly investigate which skills are needed for a sustainable and innovative RSI so that skills pool will be aligned with growing demand in the sector.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it seeks to strengthen the competitiveness of the industry making it more economically viable.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Written. Today we voted in favour of the resolution on the competitiveness of subcontractors in the rail sector. The resolution highlighted, among other things, the need for future trade agreements and ongoing negotiations with the US, China and Japan not to lead to relocation and deindustrialisation in the EU. This means for us that agreements should be based on free trade, open markets and competition, which is also the basis for europe's economy and rail sector to grow and be competitive in a global market.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal has been needed for quite some time in the European rail supply industry. I support it fully, since the resolution proposes measures to simplify access to markets and finance, support R&D in the sector, and support SMEs in order to engage more workers in the sector.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted for the motion for a resolution submitted after question for oral response B8-0704/2016 in accordance with Article 128(5) of the EIA. Rules of procedure on the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry (2015/2887(RSP)) as it is an extremely important sector that has great importance in the European economy, labour market and has great potential for technological and industrial development.  The EU needs to be serious about protecting and developing this sector, as non-European competition also uses an unfair way of gaining competitive advantages. It is necessary to continue to establish a Single European Railway Area, to lift customs and duty-free barriers, to adopt measures enabling further digitisation in the sector, to apply an integrated e-ticket system, to strengthen the role of the European Railway Agency, to continue standardisation at European level. It is particularly important to connect cross-border business administratively, technically and functionally where this is the case. The Commission should monitor non-European investments in terms of both unfair competition and compliance with European legislation and standards.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report draws attention to a sector that is crucial to the industrial policy of European states. However, its Europeanism prevents a relevant reflection on an industry that is an industry of sovereignty by nature. It calls for more investment in the sector but does not call into question privatisation and competition, which have precisely the corollary of the decline in investment in the network, as was the case in Great Britain, for example. Moreover, the role of the state is central to exporting these technologies, as in the field of defence industries; if the selling state does not control its equipment, it is not credible. However, the report's response to this is a greater openness of public procurement so that, by reciprocity, others open up theirs to us and do not require on-site manufacturing.  So I objected to that.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Like my UKIP colleagues, I voted against this resolution as it is not for the EU to tell the UK rail industry what it should do. For example, steel is a major source material for railways, and the EU’s inability to prevent cheap steel being dumped into the EU from China has led to the UK steel industry being decimated and thousands of jobs being lost. The EU clearly does not have a grasp of the business requirements needed to ensure competitiveness, and it should not be telling Member States what to do.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the competitiveness of the European railway equipment sector. The French railway industry, which employs 21,000 people in our country and ranks third in the world behind China and Germany, is an important issue for our country.  The resolution highlights the specificity and strategic interest of this sector for the re-industrialisation of Europe, and proposes measures to support industry in order to better combat unfair competition from third countries.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution recognises the rail supply industry and its contribution to European competitiveness. Demands are being made on the regulatory framework, research and development and public investment, in order, among other things, to further develop and promote the contribution of rail transport to climate change mitigation. In this regard, the Commission is invited to support the objectives for a sustainable and energy-efficient transfer of passenger and freight transport to rail, as set out in the 2011 White Paper on Transport, through concrete policies and targeted investments. I therefore agree with this motion for a resolution.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it is too free-trade. It opens the European rail sector to Chinese, Korean and Canadian companies at the expense of the interests of the French company Alstom.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The report focuses on a sector that is crucial to the industrial policy of states, which is primarily a sovereign domain. He takes stock of the current situation and makes some honest remarks. It demonstrates the need to strengthen training and qualification in this sector, the toughness of competition to capture new markets and the importance of this industry for growth. However, it ignores many of the challenges facing the sector, such as sanctions against Russia, which are blocking a major market, or fierce global competition from South Korea, Canada and soon China. I voted against it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because it is not aimed at solving the real problems that have put this important industry in such a complicated situation. The fundamental problem, despite the European authorities pointing to China, is the European Union's trade and competition policy. It is the continuing liberalisation phases of the railway sector and the imposition of strict conditions on public procurement, which expose this sector to international competition rather than putting job creation and growth ahead of competition. Despite including positive references to the participation of trade unions in decision-making and the attempt to propose an industrial policy. The marked lack of reflection on the liberalisation of the sector forces me to vote against a resolution which will not solve the problems of European industry.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the call on the Commission to invest money in the railway sector: 'The European Parliament asks the Commission to make full use of the various EU funding instruments, to explore and use other sources of funding for the S2R Joint Undertaking and to seek synergies between the different EU funds'. In my view, the Commission should not meddle in the railway business, and the Czech experience with private carriers shows that the free market without subsidies is also well applied to railways.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European rail supply industry is of strategic importance for industrial growth, employment, innovation and the transition to sustainable development. As europe's rail supply industry is threatened by aggressive competition from third countries, it highlights the need for fair and equal conditions in the global market to eliminate the risk of job losses and protect industrial know-how in Europe. The rail sector employs over 1 million people directly and indirectly 1.2 million, and this clearly indicates the importance of the rail supply industry for the growth of European industry, jobs and innovation, as well as the fact that the sector contributes 20 % to the reindustrialisation target. Research needs to focus on digitalisation, which will increase rail efficiency and reduce their operational costs.  It should also focus on increasing the efficiency of the use of sources and energy to mitigate climate change. Rail transport needs to become more attractive and accepted and infrastructure that is essential for the competitiveness of railways should not be neglected in innovation. This resolution underlines the importance of successfully using the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) as one of the tools for mobilising private capital for the railway sector, so I supported the resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Motion for a Resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail industry for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 9/6/2016, and because this Motion for a Resolution is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution. This report notes fierce competition in the rail sector and calls for increased public investment, particularly in research and development. This report is reprehensible by its unspoken. Firstly, liberalisation policies, promoted by the European Union, are at the root of the erosion of investment in the network. The fiercest competitors, including South Korea, Canada and China, are not named, and no mention is made of sanctions against Russia.  On the proposed solutions, the report is no more satisfactory. Proposals for SMEs are irrelevant. In addition, the support given to the "S2R" grouping ignores the fact that Canadian Bombardier is the main player.  For all these reasons, and because we believe that the railway sector is intrinsically linked to the prerogatives of sovereign states, we cannot support this report.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The European rail equipment sector currently employs 400,000 people. It is therefore an activity that we must take care of, because we are interested in boosting the railway, with interesting advantages for Europe. For this reason, I support the resolution in which parliament is asking for the maintenance of the leadership of the European rail equipment sector at the global level, a new agenda for innovation in the European rail sector, the acquisition of the necessary competences to ensure that the rail equipment sector is prepared for the future, support for SMEs , improving the European market environment for suppliers and promoting demand for railway products, boosting investment in rail projects and improving strategic political support for the sector.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution on strengthening the competitiveness of the European railway supply industry. The resolution draws attention to a number of important problems faced by companies operating in this area. I support the provisions in the resolution on promoting investment in railway projects, increasing support for small and medium-sized enterprises, improving market conditions.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The main purpose of this resolution is to encourage the race forward towards more competition and liberalisation in the rail sector. Continuing the rail dismantling strategy, the text welcomes "the adoption of the technical pillar of the fourth set of railway measures". It even calls for the implementation of "a genuine single market for rail products" through "the removal of the main non-tariff barriers that hinder access to external markets for the sector. The concept of an efficient public service accessible to all users is obviously absent from this text, which seeks only to help private companies to increase their profits in the rail sector. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report draws attention to a sector that is crucial to the industrial policy of European states. However, its ideological Europeanism prevents relevant and lucid reflection. The report calls for investments, but without a concomitant challenge to the privatisation of the sector, which has the direct consequence of the decline in investment, as was the case in Great Britain. In addition, the report makes some staggering conclusions, particularly on the reciprocity of open public procurement. That is why I am voting against the resolution and the oral question.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European railway equipment industry is of strategic importance in contributing to the strengthening of European industry. The rail equipment industry is a key sector for Europe's competitiveness and innovation capacity. It is therefore important to improve support for the sector. The Commission should, as soon as possible, issue a communication on strengthening and supporting the rail equipment industry in a strategy for reindustrialising Europe.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion as competitiveness is essential to Europe’s single market. The motion ensures Europe’s leadership in the rail industry, supports SMEs through investment and the protection of a fair market, and promotes economic growth throughout Europe.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The European rail supply sector is characterised mainly by the production of elements with a lifespan of up to 50 years, a high capital intensity, a strong dependence on public contracts and the need to comply with very high safety standards. In view of the particular contribution of the rail sector, the European Commission must support the objectives of the modal transition to rail passenger and freight transport set out in the 2011 White Paper on Transport with concrete policy steps and targeted investments. The creation of a single European railway area will be crucial for maintaining the global leadership of the European rail supply sector. I consider it essential that the Commission make better use of the European Structural and Investment Funds to support projects in the field of railway research and development at regional level. Greater emphasis must also be placed on the future of the rail supply sector after 2020. In this context, I must point out that teaching suitably selected skills is also a necessary investment in the long-term preservation of the global leadership of the European rail supply sector in the field of technology and in terms of maintaining its innovation capacity. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, intended as input to the Commission’s upcoming strategy on space policy, which is expected in autumn 2016. It aims to ensure that Parliament’s priorities (safeguarding Europe’s leading position in space technologies and services on the global markets, with independent access to space for Europe and a level playing field for the industry) are pursued in the forthcoming Commission document. It highlights, inter alia, the need to focus the new strategy on market uptake of space data and services, so as to maximise socio-economic benefits from the EU’s space programmes; the need to take account of the regional dimension, with support for an increased role for regional and local authorities; and the need to step up awareness-raising efforts in order to promote the potential of European space programmes to the public and private sectors and end users.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy points out that the European rail supply sector employs 400 000 workers, devotes 2.7% of its annual turnover to research and development and covers 46% of the world market. The entire rail sector is directly responsible for 1 million jobs and indirectly 1.2 million jobs in the European Union, indicating the importance of the sector for Industrial Growth, Jobs and Innovation in Europe and its contribution to achieving the 20% reind into industrialisation target. In addition, railways make a significant contribution to climate change mitigation and to coping with other megatrends such as urbanisation and demographic change.  In order to decarbonise transport, there is a obvious need to move towards rail and other sustainable, energy-efficient, electrified modes of transport. Against this basis, the report calls for action at EU level to maintain the international competitiveness and global leadership of the European rail supply sector, to reduce unfair competition in the rail supply sector and to ensure a level playing field in global competition and mutual market access.  I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This report presents positive points such as the importance of this sector in the recovery of growth, the presence of very aggressive competition in obtaining markets, the need to strengthen training and qualification, and the need for investment in research and development. However, the report does not cite the adversaries faced by European railway companies or the fact that this strategic sector for states needs public support, currently limited or banned by the European Union. Moreover, it is not mentioned the very negative impact of the sanctions imposed by the EU on Russia, which is one of the leading markets for the European railway industry. We therefore vote against the resolution and the oral question.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The railway equipment industry is a european industry sector with great weight and enormous potential in terms of economic growth, job creation and investment in research and innovation. Currently, this segment of activity employs around 400 000 people and invests 2.7 % of its annual turnover in development research. However, the sector faces some difficulties that delineating a strategy at European Union level can help to address. In this sense, I am voting in favour, since I consider the delineation of strategic lines at Union level to preserve its leading position on the global stage, to strengthen its focus on innovation, the qualification of the workforce and the improvement of market conditions and competitiveness of enterprises, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, should be central to this sub-sector.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report calls for more investment in the sector but does not call into question privatisation and competition, which have precisely the corollary of the decline in investment in the network, as was the case in Great Britain, for example. Moreover, the role of the state is central to exporting these technologies, as in the field of defence industries; if the selling state does not control its equipment, it is not credible. However, the report's response to this is a greater openness of public procurement so that, by reciprocity, others open up theirs to us and do not require on-site manufacturing. This is absurd and that is why I am voting against the report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which I negotiated as a shadow rapporteur for the EPP Group. This text highlights the specificity, strategic interest and potential that the railway industry has for the re-industrialisation of Europe. It highlights the challenges faced by companies in this sector, which are subject to unfair and aggressive competition from companies whose finances merge with those of their states, such as China. This resolution aims to give SMEs the tools to innovate, export, and participate if they wish in the consolidation of the sector, but also to place the Commission before its responsibilities by asking it to set up a structured and high-level industrial dialogue that brings together economic and political actors.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European railway supply industry (RSI) covers high-speed, conventional and urban passenger and freight trains. It includes the manufacture of locomotives, rolling stock, track, and electrification, signalling and telecommunications equipment, as well as services for maintenance and parts. I voted for this motion for a resolution, which stresses the need to achieve the objective of establishing a single European railway area that is crucial to maintaining the global dominance of the European RSI.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European railway equipment industry comprises the production of locomotives and rolling stock, rails, electrification, signalling and telecommunications equipment, as well as maintenance and supply of spare parts. This industry accounts for 46% of the global rail equipment market, employs 400 000 people, but together with operators and infrastructure provides more than 1 million direct jobs and 1.2 million indirect jobs across the EU. Investment in research and development, innovation capacity, market defragmentation and cluster creation are essential foundations to preserve the international competitiveness of the European rail equipment industry and to contribute to the 20 % reindustrialisation target in the Union. The Commission should consider setting up a forum at European level, which would brought together established or newly established enterprises with innovative ideas for the railway sector, in particular in the field of digitalisation, with a view to exchanging best practices and facilitating partnerships. As s&D coordinator for the ITRE Commission, I draw attention to the importance of manufacturing trains, trams and other modern means of rail transport within the single market, together with all necessary ancillary equipment. This would help to increase the competitiveness of industry and preserve jobs within the Union.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ Stressing the positive impact that the Rail Supply Industry (RSI) has on European growth and climate change, this resolution has my full support. Already the railway sector is the source of 1 million direct and 1.2 million indirect jobs across the European Union. For the sector to continue to generate employment, in the future we need to invest in it by supporting research and developing new innovative technologies that will increase our global competitiveness. Our competitiveness in the RSI is further dependent on access to international markets. EU trade strategy should therefore focus on securing the principle of reciprocity with third countries. Moreover, as called for in the resolution we should be ambitious about the prospect of creating a single European railway network that will increase efficiency, and hence our competition skills, reduce administrative costs and overall drive a shift towards a sustainable and energy-efficient Europe based on a strong railway sector.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of the approved report, I consider it important to swiftly implement the technical pillar of the fourth railway package, which is key to creating a genuine single market for rail products.  It can be noted that greater interoperability and the enhanced role of the European Railway Agency (ERA) will facilitate the harmonisation of the network, thus reducing the cost of developing and approving rolling stock. Similarly, the importance of the political pillar of the fourth railway package should be stressed, which should ensure a fair competitive environment for carriers and, more generally, suppliers.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – On the surface this question appeared to be concerned with improving the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. However, the question fails to deal with the root cause of the problem, which is the continued privatisation agenda of the railway market in EU. The present legal framework prioritises competition and international trade over industrial growth and job creation. Moreover, the oral question is just calling for different forums, strategies, groups and networks to be established and fails to propose any concrete measures to improve the preconditions of the industry, other than new discussion clubs and additional layers of bureaucracy. It was for these reasons that I voted against this motion.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this resolution as it is not for the EU to tell the UK rail industry what it should do. For example, steel is a major source material for railways, and the EU’s inability to prevent cheap steel being dumped into the EU from China has led to the UK steel industry being decimated and thousands of jobs being lost. The EU clearly does not have a grasp of the business requirements needed to ensure competitiveness, and it should not be telling Member States what to do.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Recognising the importance of the European railway industry for employment, innovation and the R&D sector and the contribution it can make to reviving European competitiveness, I would support my group's line on this proposal.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I support this resolution because I consider the lack of available funding to be one of the main challenges for SMEs in the rail supply industry. The COSME programme and structural funds have the potential to deliver greater added value to the programmes they finance, especially when it comes to the involveing of SMEs. Small and medium-sized enterprises in the rail supply industry often depend on one larger company, which often harms them, both due to lack of resources and increased risks associated with cross-border operations, and are often reluctant to expand their business.  I want to stress the need for a holistic, efficient and harmonised application of the Regulation on the European Rail Network for competitive transport of goods. The full application of this Regulation will ultimately benefit both passengers and industry. Increased interoperability of rail transport and a stronger role for the European Railway Agency will facilitate the harmonisation of the rail network, which can significantly reduce the costs of developing, approving rolling stock and rail equipment, all of which are linked to the recently adopted European Rail Traffic Management System.  Also, no less importantly, sufficient human and financial resources need to be made available to the European Railway Agency in order to achieve this new, extended task.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report calls for more investment in the sector but does not call into question privatisation and competition, which have precisely the corollary of the decline in investment in the network, as was the case in Great Britain, for example. Moreover, the role of the state is central to exporting these technologies, as in the field of defence industries; if the selling state does not control its equipment, it is not credible. However, the report's response to this is a greater openness of public procurement so that, by reciprocity, others open up theirs to us and do not require on-site manufacturing. This is absurd and that is why I am voting against the report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's railway supply industry (IFF) is a world leader, accounting for 46% of the global rail industry market. It employs 400 000 people and makes an important contribution to investment in research and innovation. The rail sector as a whole employs over one million workers and 1.2 million in related industries. These figures clearly illustrate the importance of IFF for industrial growth, employment and innovation, including the objective of reindustrialisation of 20% of the European economy. Competitors from third countries, particularly China, are expanding rapidly and aggressively, often with the political and financial support of their home country. It is therefore important for Europe to be able to guarantee fair and equal conditions in global competition, in order to safeguard jobs and industrial know-how. In order to maintain the global dominance of the European IFF, it will be essential to create a single European railway area, to launch innovation programmes, to encourage the formation of local 'clusters', to make the best use of the Structural and Investment Funds, to support SMEs and to boost demand for rail products. In order to make it future-proof, it will also be important to invest in the training of young workers in the sector. This report agrees with this approach, calling on the Commission to commit itself to this, and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The European rail supply industry, which includes the production of locomotives and rolling stock, track-related equipment, electrification, signalling and telecommunications, and parts replacement maintenance and services, which includes many SMEs but also industry leaders, employs 400 000 people, invests 2.7% of its annual turnover in R&D and represents 46% of the global market for the rail supply industry.  In the railway sector in general, including businesses and infrastructure, over 1 million people are directly employed and indirectly 1.2 million. As the world's leading technology and innovation industry, the rail supply industry plays a key role in achieving the Commission's 20% industrialisation target. It is therefore necessary to mobilise various EU funding instruments, explore and take advantage of shift2Rail's additional funding opportunities, advocate synergies between the various EU funds and in relation to private investment.  In addition to investing in innovation, at the same time the maintenance and modernisation of existing railway equipment should not be ignored. I therefore support the adopted text of the resolution and hope for an imminent response from the Commission to the requests made.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Oral question highlights the strategic economic importance of the European rail supply industry, which employs 400,000 Europeans. Railway supply industry growth opportunities are high, resulting in employment and innovation growth and being the best solution for the transition to sustainable mobility. At the moment, competitors from third countries receiving state aid are treating European industry with a sharp expansion of their own. The establishment of a joint shift 2 Rail technology initiative should be accelerated given the pace of development in other countries. I supported the oral question with a view to developing and strengthening europe's rail supply industry.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the modernisation of the European rail supply industry which is integral to increasing the technological standards of the European Union. This is most important as the railway sector accounts for 1 million direct and 1.2 million indirect jobs in the EU. Likewise, this is another step towards achieving the Commission’s 20% industrialisation target. With the passing of this resolution, we can continue these strides towards a competitive Europe whose standards of modernisation match our role in the global market.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Railway Supply Industry (IFF) includes the production of locomotives, rolling stock and tracks, electrification, signalling and telecommunications equipment, as well as maintenance and spare parts services. It employs 400 000 people, invests 2.7 % of its annual turnover in research and development and accounts for 46 % of the world market in the railway industry. More than 1 million direct and 1.2 million indirect jobs depend on the rail sector as a whole, including operators and infrastructure.  The increase in imports of cheap rail supplies (such as engines or rail signals) from non-EU countries such as China is undermining the competitive conditions of European suppliers. Hence the need for a trade strategy that guarantees respect for the principle of reciprocity, particularly in relation to Japan, China and the United States. I voted in favour so that new legislation can enable the EU to respond more quickly and effectively to imports of dumped and subsidised goods, given the possible change, since December 2016, in the management of the EU anti-dumping law for China and the huge 'human costs' to EU workers due to the current crisis in the steel sector.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report, including because, as shadow rapporteur, I recently addressed the issue of regulation in the field of rail locomotive engines. I am therefore aware of the problem where strict European regulation in some cases may jeopardise the competitiveness of our companies in this field.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the competitiveness of the rail equipment sector in Europe. This text highlights the specificity, the strategic interest but also the potential of this sector, in which France ranks third in the world. A central aspect of the text is the strengthening of support for companies in the sector, which employ 400,000 people, in particular to promote innovation and exports.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. With the adoption of the resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail industry, MEPs are sending a clear message to the European Commission for the adoption of an ambitious trade strategy to defend the interests of European industry. With more than 46% of the world market and more than 1.2 million direct and indirect jobs, the European industry is the world leader in rail! However, in the face of globalised competition, the emergence of new global giants and the entry into the internal market of non-European companies, Europe must act to maintain its first place and ensure fair competition. Through this resolution, MEPs call on the Commission to take measures to ensure reciprocal trade so that European companies are not penalised when countries that benefit from the opening up of the internal market enter the market. The resolution also calls on the Commission to take better account of the investment needs in rail infrastructure, which contribute fully and concretely to the challenges of re-industrialisation and the fight against global warming. With this in mind, MEPs want to set up a 'railway forum' to strengthen European investment in the sector in the long term.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. The European rail equipment industry employs 400,000 people, invests 2.7% of its annual turnover in R&D, represents 46% of the global industry market and has a key contribution to mitigating climate change and addressing demographic change. For these reasons, and because it contributes to achieving the 20% reindustrialisation target, the report, which I voted in favour of, asks the Commission to support the objective of a modal shift to rail - both people and goods - through concrete policy measures and selective investments. Many EU companies find it difficult to operate across borders due to market fragmentation at administrative and technical level. In this way, we consider it essential to create a single European railway area, technologically innovative, to maintain the dominant position worldwide. Furthermore, we believe that the Commission should, by December 2016, present a strategy for the aggregation of companies. Finally, we call for a training strategy to ensure a viable long-term rail equipment industry, support for SMEs, improving the market context for suppliers, boosting investment and enhancing competitiveness.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. I voted this morning in favour of Mrs Werner's draft resolution following an oral question from the ITRE Committee on the competitiveness of the European railway equipment sector. Essentially, this resolution aims to draw the Commission's attention to this sector where our leadership (46% of the world market) is now threatened by several factors: weak public order, difficulty in accessing financing, stagnation or even decline in the modal share of rail, competition (sometimes unfair) from third countries, etc. It may not be too late for the future of European rail equipment. The urgency of the situation, however, requires us to act quickly by adopting measures related to financing, research and development, the regulatory framework, training and reciprocity in our trade, with particular attention to SMEs. Let us not spoil the assets of the European railway equipment sector: its environmental performance is excellent, it can rely on a large market and it contributes to mass transport, in the face of increasing mobility needs.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution. The European railway equipment industry is a strategic sector. It employs 400,000 people and accounts for 46% of the global market. However, it should be given the capacity to remain competitive and to protect it from unfair competition from third countries, including China. It is about preserving our jobs and our industry. We call on the Commission to ensure a level playing field, be consistent with the needs of our industry and contain provisions that improve market access, particularly for public procurement. European industry must be able to count on strong political support from the Union.  Furthermore, the resolution sets out other proposals which I strongly support, whether it is a renewal of action for innovation in this sector, more active support for SMEs, or the stimulation of investment. In addition, the Commission needs to re-evaluate current competition rules to enable strategic partnerships and alliances to be established. It is a prerequisite for the emergence of European champions, which are essential for the future both in this sector and in other European industrial sectors.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The European rail equipment industry (IEF) employs 400,000 people, invests 2.7 % of its annual turnover in R&D and represents 46% of the World Market in EFI. The rail sector as a result, including operators and infrastructure, accounts for more than one million direct jobs and 1.2 million indirect jobs in the EU. The importance of the EFI for the growth, employment and innovation of the European industrial sector and its contribution to achieving the 20 % industrialisation target is clear. We also recall the key contribution of the rail sector to mitigating climate change and addressing other major trends such as urbanisation and demographic change. In line with the results of COP 21 and the EU's 2030 climate and energy targets, it is important that the Commission and the Council support the transition to rail transport and other types of electrified, energy-efficient and sustainable transport in order to achieve the objective of decarbonising the transport sector. Concrete steps are needed to preserve the leadership of the European rail equipment industry and boost investment in rail projects

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The European rail equipment sector is of strategic importance for industrial growth, employment and innovation and for the transition to sustainable mobility, employing 400,000 workers, investing 2.7% of its annual turnover in R&D and accounting for 46% of the world market.   While the EU maintains a high degree of openness to competition from third countries, there are numerous obstacles in the latter that discriminate against the European rail equipment sector. In addition, some competitors are carrying out an aggressive policy of expansion to other regions of the world with strong political support.
