Thus, the European rail equipment sector must compete internationally with third-country companies with strong support in the form of state aid, such as favourable export credits. I supported this oral question and the accompanying motion for a Resolution to ask the Commission to make better use of the level playing field within the rail equipment sector and to develop an integrated and coherent industrial policy strategy that highlights the specificity and strategic importance of sectors such as rail equipment.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted a resolution on the competitiveness of the European railway equipment sector. This is an important sector, which still employs 400,000 people and has a key role to play in achieving the Commission's 20% industrialisation target.  For my part, I have always advocated for a strong European industry, which brings jobs and growth. In this sense, I can only welcome the adoption of this resolution, which makes a series of recommendations to improve the competitiveness of this sector. Nevertheless, I would like to express my disappointment at the negative vote on several amendments which I supported which called on 'Member States to reject privatisation and to maintain and strengthen their public rail systems' and which encouraged 'Member States to ensure the participation of regional authorities, social partners and SMEs throughout the process of developing the railway sector'.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Railways remain probably the greenest mode of motor transport and, at the same time, one of the cheapest. Unfortunately, the European railway sector is under enormous competitive pressure from third countries. The question of colleagues was very timely, indeed, how to stimulate the recovery of the European railway sector, how to ensure its competitiveness? One of the measures currently being implemented in my country is the construction of the European standard railway "Via Baltica". This will, of course, create additional demand for both rail services and the rail industry. However, we must also think about measures to encourage businesses to make greater use of the railway. Proposals on this issue have not yet been heard from the Commission.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the competitiveness of the European railway industry.  The rail sector employs 400,000 people in Europe and includes both SMEs and large companies; it invests 2.7% of its annual turnover in research and development and accounts for 46% of the global market.  Its central role in employment is also a key role, as it generates more than one million direct jobs and 1.2 million indirect jobs in the European Union. The Union must act to renew its action in favour of innovation in the sector and it is important to promote the extension of SME activity across borders. It is central to reviving the competitiveness of the European railway equipment industry at a time when it is under pressure from international competition. Thus, we reiterate the importance of ensuring reciprocity of market access and the opening of our partners' public procurements in the context of ongoing trade negotiations and future agreements. At the same time, it is important to continue to fight against all forms of dumping and therefore to modernise our trade defence instruments as soon as possible.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the competitiveness of the European railway industry, which is the basis of the transition to sustainable mobility. The European Union's railway industry is a sector characterised by the strong presence of SMEs. In order for this sector to be competitive, especially in the face of the often unfair competition represented by third countries, investment in innovation must be made. In this respect, the EU has launched a joint technology initiative programme which has encountered many obstacles in the start-up process. The resolution adopted may be a further step in the right direction.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. "U2012 While it is true that the Resolution has some positive elements—reference to the participation of the rail sector in lowering CO2 emissions or concern for SMEs—it does not go against the sector's liberalisation and deregulation logics. Logics that are the main responsible for the situation in which the European rail equipment sector is located. That is why I voted against the Resolution.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. It is important that the rail industry is not squeezed into a crisis due to unfair competition, especially from Asia. That is why we need to secure industrial jobs and support a vulnerable sector. With the agreement, we are introducing a number of measures to ensure that the industry remains competitive, sustainable and future-proof. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European rail supply industry has long faced unfair competition from third-country suppliers. This situation, where a level playing field is not set, threatens jobs in the rail sector in Europe. I therefore supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because it is not aimed at solving the real problems that have put this important industry in such a complicated situation. The fundamental problem, despite the European authorities pointing to China, is the European Union's trade and competition policy. It is the continuing liberalisation phases of the railway sector and the imposition of strict conditions on public procurement, which expose this sector to international competition rather than putting job creation and growth ahead of competition. Despite including positive references to the participation of trade unions in decision-making and the attempt to propose an industrial policy. The marked lack of reflection on the liberalisation of the sector forces me to vote against a resolution which will not solve the problems of European industry.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European railway industry (IFF) is a key sector for the EU's competitiveness and innovation capacity to provide employment for 400 000 employees and some 2.2 million direct and indirect workers if we add up the entire rail sector.  Despite the good environmental performance that the sector is able to offer and the great ability to carry large volumes, there are nevertheless competition problems. Indeed, while the European Union is open to competitors from other countries, the latter have adopted barriers that discriminate against the IFF, in particular China, which is expanding rapidly and aggressively thanks to the political and financial support of its country, thus putting jobs in Europe at risk. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution because it calls for fairer conditions in global competition through reciprocity in market access. We also call on the Commission to work with the rail sector to ensure a more effective use of the European Structural Investment Funds (EIS Funds) and in particular the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), while at the same time seeking to simplify business procedures for SMEs and to remove all tariff and non-tariff barriers.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The railway sector contributes to climate change mitigation and management of other current megatrends, such as urbanisation and demographic change. The rail supply sector is a key industry for Europe's competitiveness and for its innovation capacity. Measures must be taken to ensure that Europe retains a technological and innovative advantage in this sector. I therefore supported this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European rail supply sector employs around 400,000 people and has a number of SMEs connected to it. At present, the sector is under a lot of pressure from foreign companies. I therefore supported Parliament's resolution calling on the Commission to work more vigorously to remove the main non-tariff barriers that prevent the European rail sector from accessing foreign markets. The whole railway sector is of a special nature, mainly due to the fact that it produces elements with a lifespan of up to 50 years, there is a great deal of capital intensity, a strong dependence on public contracts and the need to comply with high safety standards. On the other hand, the European rail supply sector can rely on a number of favourable factors, as it is an environmentally good mode of transport, can rely on a large market and on the ability to facilitate public transport. In the rail supply sector, the EU is very open to competitors from third countries, but third countries have introduced a number of obstacles that put European businesses at a disadvantage. Competitors from third countries, such as China, penetrate quickly and aggressively into Europe and other regions of the world, which often happens with strong political and financial support from their countries. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to guarantee next-generation trade agreements and the revision of existing contracts.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European rail supply industry employs 400 000 workers, invests 2.7% of its annual r&D turnover and accounts for 46% of the global rail supply industry market. The entire rail sector, together with operators and infrastructure, directly creates more than one million jobs in the EU, which is a clear indicator of the importance of the rail supply industry for European industrial growth, jobs and innovation.  Thus, the rail supply industry is essential for Europe's competitiveness, which is why it is necessary to ensure that Europe retains its technological and innovative advantage in this sector. I believe that the European Commission should work with the sector to ensure the best use of the European Structural and Investment Funds, in particular the European Regional Development Fund, and to support research and development projects at regional level. It would also be good to adopt a European training and education strategy liading with railway supply industry companies, research institutions and social partners to jointly examine what skills are needed for a sustainable and innovative rail supply industry.  For this reason, I believe that the oral resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry has good content and, consequently, I voted in favour of it.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 In Europe, railways were born and we must do everything we can to become a leader again in the development and production of modern and safe trainsets and railway infrastructure.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. 'Just over a month ago, we in this Chamber approved by a large majority the technical pillar of the fourth railway package. In doing so, I stressed the importance to our citizens of that regulation and two directives for the creation of a completed railway market. The deepened role of the European Railway Agency (ESB) and the revisions to the interoperability and safety of rail traffic also offer opportunities to our industry.  An open European rail market will strengthen competition between companies active in rolling stock production, electrification, signalling and telecommunications systems. It goes without saying that better performing companies will generate less costs, but I also look forward to the opportunities for innovation that such a large and single market can bring. The current fragmentation, both administratively and technically, mainly hampers many smaller companies and potentially new comers.  If we want our companies in the rail industry to seize these opportunities, it is our job to ensure that the conditions for the proper functioning of this new European market are guaranteed.  The report highlights the appropriate aspects and therefore the N-VA delegation voted in favour of the report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 The European rail supply industry includes the production of locomotives and rolling stock, track-related equipment, electrification, signalling and telecommunications, and parts replacement maintenance and services. This industry includes many SMEs, but also leading companies and employs around 400 000 people.  The European rail supply industry invests 2.7% of its annual turnover in R&D and represents 46% of the global market for the rail supply industry. The rail sector generally employs over 1 million people directly and indirectly 1.2 million. It is therefore clear that the rail supply industry is very important for the growth of European industry, jobs and innovation. The European Union is largely open to competitors from third countries.  However, there are a number of barriers in third countries that discriminate against the European rail supply industry, and competitors from third countries are expanding rapidly and aggressively in Europe and other parts of the world, which can lead to unfair competition that puts jobs in Europe at risk. I support this report, as I believe it is necessary to create a fair and level playing field in global competition and mutual market access in order to eliminate the risk of job losses and protect industrial know-how in Europe.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European rail supply industry, which includes many SMEs, employs 400 000 people. This industry is one of the key to European competitiveness and innovation. Railways are of utmost importance to mitigate climate change, so the transition to railways and other types of sustainable, electrified transport is necessary to achieve the desired decarbonisation of transport.  In order to preserve the dominance of the European rail supply industry globally, a single European railway area needs to be established, as well as modern railways and tramways should be produced. Also, Parliament calls for a European training and education strategy that will unite businesses and other partners from the rail supply industry to jointly define skills for a sustainable and innovative industry. Efforts should be made to promote lifelong learning. I support this proposal for a resolution, as I believe that the guidelines set out in the resolution are well worded and provide better conditions on the European market for suppliers and support for SMEs. I also believe that applying these guidelines would encourage investment in railway projects, which would lead to a strengthening of the global competitiveness of the rail supply industry.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution to the oral question on the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. We need good coordination of european Union financial instruments and funds and private investment by the European Commission. The European rail industry must maintain its leading role in the global market and increase it further. I would particularly like to emphasise the support given to small and medium-sized enterprises in the rail supply industry in the light of gaining access to finance, including in the form of guarantees and capital instruments. I, too, welcome the EFSI, which pays particular attention to SMEs.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The main problem facing the railway industry, which is being silenced in the resolution, is the neoliberal programme it is called upon to implement to strengthen competitiveness and liberalise the market, objectives promoted at the expense of policies for growth, support for the real economy and the creation of new quality jobs.      In the resolution there are problematic negative references which we cannot ignore. For example, the procedures for liberalising the sector, which are promoted in the resolution, are inextricably linked to deindustrialisation, the geographical transfer of productive activity for the benefit of multinationals and the loss of jobs. Liberalisation and privatisation strategies, which are the main factor in the decline of the railway equipment industry in Europe, lead to mass redundancies of workers and the closure of many industrial plants.        Also absent from the resolution are important references that had to be included if the aim was to support the rail industry. For example, there had to be a reference to the need to promote public investment and to use programmes such as Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe in order to finance research in the field of railway technology. It was also necessary to stressed the need to promote measures to facilitate access to finance for MMEs in the railway sector.  That is why we voted against it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Railway Materials Sector is of great importance for industrial development, employment and innovation, contributing to the objectives of reindustrialisation and investment in research and development. SMEs in the rail sector must have access to finance and be supported with European funds. Finally, improving the environment of the European market for suppliers and encouraging demand for rail products must be a priority for us.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The rail sector is one of the main components of the European Union transport system, both in the field of freight and passenger transport. The European railway equipment industry, which ensures the production of rolling stock and necessary devices (locomotives, rails, electrification equipment, signalling and telecommunications) is at the heart of the development and efficiency of the european rail equipment industry, which ensures the production of rolling stock and necessary devices (locomotives, rails, electrification equipment, signalling and telecommunications) for the proper functioning of the entire area in the long term. From this point of view, it can be said that the sector in question is of strategic importance for the European industrial renaissance, in order to achieve the Commission's 20% industrialisation target.  In this context, there is a need to maintain the global competitiveness of the European rail equipment industry, to adopt a renewed EU agenda, but also to invest in acquiring the necessary skills, supporting SMEs and improving the climate in European markets in favour of suppliers and encouraging demand for railway products. Investments in railway projects, both at EU and global level, can support this process, but can only take place under the conditions of stable political support for this sector. I believe that the European rail industry deserves to be supported and, for this reason, I support this resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text and the amendments advocating the defence of public service. The European rail equipment sector, which includes the manufacture of locomotives, rolling stock and track, electrification, signalling and telecommunications equipment, maintenance and spare parts services , and which includes many SMEs as well as large enterprises , employs 400,000 people, invests 2.7% of its annual turnover in research and development and accounts for 46% of the global market. The rail sector as a whole, including operators and infrastructure, generates more than 1 million direct jobs and 1.2 million indirect jobs in the EU. I note that these figures clearly illustrate the importance of this sector for industrial growth, employment and innovation in Europe, as well as its contribution to achieving the 20% re-industrialisation target.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Commission to unveil a coherent strategy as soon as possible on an industrial policy to re-industrialise the European continent. In this resolution we are asking that the EU re-industrialisation strategy should be based on sustainability and energy and resource efficiency and be organised by sector, incorporating strong, vertical industrial production measures within the EU. The rail sector deserves special attention and we call on the Commission to set up a structure to facilitate exchanges between established companies and start-ups in the sector. Finally this text points the finger at unfair practices from international competitors, particularly China.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I supported this resolution because I believe that we must be aware of all the advantages, but also the threats to our economy as a whole, including the rail supply system. In particular, I support the promotion of the inclusion of SMEs in this system, as SMEs are the carriers of the European economy. Therefore, if we want to accelerate the growth of the European economy, it is necessary to provide small and medium-sized enterprises with the maximum number of opportunities for the placement of their products and services.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. The European rail supply industry involves a number of SMEs and industry leaders, employs 400 000 workers, invests 2.7% of its annual r&D turnover and accounts for 46% of the global rail supply industry market. The rail supply industry is essential for Europe's competitiveness and its capacity to innovate. The capacity to innovate, invest in research and development and eliminate market fragmentation is essential to maintain the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. Eu funding instruments need to be fully mobilised and cooperated with the sector to ensure the best use of the European Structural and Investment Funds. For SMEs in the rail supply industry, access to finance is one of the main challenges.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. "U2012 While it is true that the Resolution has some positive elements—reference to the participation of the rail sector in lowering CO2 emissions or concern for SMEs—it does not go against the sector's liberalisation and deregulation logics. Logics that are the main responsible for the situation in which the European rail equipment sector is located. That is why I voted against the Resolution.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The European rail supply industry (RSI), which encompasses the manufacture of locomotives and rolling stock, and track, electrification, signalling and telecommunication equipment, as well as maintenance and parts services, and which includes numerous SMEs, as well as major industrial leaders, employs 400 000 employees, invests 2.7 % of its annual turnover in R&D and accounts for 46 % of the world RSI market. The railway sector overall, including operators and infrastructure, is responsible for more than 1 million direct and 1.2 million indirect jobs in the EU. Recognising the rail supply industry as a key industry for Europe’s competitiveness and capacity for innovation, I urge the EC to take all measures to ensure that Europe maintains a technological and innovative advantage in this sector. Competition rules with regards to China and other emerging actors should be considered. However I also believe that too many internal market physical and regulatory barriers remain in Europe in order to have a single European market in the rail sector. Rail is very far from aviation in this regard.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report draws attention to a sector that is crucial to the industrial policy of European states. However, its Europeanism prevents relevant thinking on a sector that is an industry of sovereignty by nature. It calls for more investment in the sector, but does not call into question privatisation and competition, which have precisely the corollary of the decline in investment in the network, as was the case in Great Britain, for example. Moreover, the role of the state is central to exporting these technologies; as in the defence industries, if the selling state does not control its equipment, it is not credible. However, the report's response to this is a greater openness of public procurement so that, by reciprocity, others open up theirs to us and do not require on-site manufacturing. I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. "U2012 While it is true that the Resolution has some positive elements—reference to the participation of the rail sector in lowering CO2 emissions or concern for SMEs—it does not go against the sector's liberalisation and deregulation logics. Logics that are the main responsible for the situation in which the European rail equipment sector is located. That is why I voted against the Resolution.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ Voted in favour - The rail supply industry is an important EU industrial actor for the transformation towards sustainable mobility and for meeting climate objectives. A coherent European industrial policy based on sustainability and competitiveness of EU manufacturing industry should recognise the importance of this sector and address the needs for: investing in R&D, innovation, developing skills, increasing demand and investment into (sustainable) rail projects, expanding SMEs suppliers’ base, and ensuring manufacturing is maintained in the EU. If the EU rail industry is still a market leader in technology and innovation today and an industry rooted in EU territory, it faces several challenges, including unfair competition on the EU and global markets in the participation of public procurement tenders, in particular from China’s giant state-owned and fully subsidised corporation benefitting from generous export subsidies outside the scope of OECD guidelines. The resolution ask for this purpose that the Commission re-evaluates its market definitions to take the global market into account and enable itself to address the problem posed by mega-mergers in third countries, and, if desired, enable EU companies to make strategic alliances.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. The resolution emphasises the specific nature of this sector, which is characterised in particular by the manufacture of equipment with a lifespan of up to 50 years, high capital intensity, a significant dependence on public procurement and the obligation to comply with very high safety standards. The resolution equally underlines that maintenance and modernisation of existing rail equipment should not be neglected.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it recognises the rail supply industry as a key industry for Europe’s competitiveness and capacity for innovation. It urges that measures be taken to ensure that Europe maintains a technological and innovative advantage in this sector. The resolution also asks the Commission to fully mobilise the various EU funding instruments and to explore and exploit additional sources of financing for Shift2Rail (S2R) and to seek for synergies between different EU funds and with private investments.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution aims to take stock of the competitiveness of the European railway equipment industry.  Not surprisingly, this is an ode to the liberalization and competition of the rail sector.  The goal is clear: to help companies make more profit in this sector. Decidedly, nothing helps. As deaf people ignore the views of European citizens and those who are dedicated to public service, there is no question of promoting an effective public service that is accessible to all users.  Ignoring the damage already perpetrated by successive liberalisations, Parliament, by a very large majority, continues the total liberalisation of rail and the dismantling of public rail services in the name of free and undistorted competition.  The GUE/NGL had tabled several amendments to try to counter this strategy of dismantling the rail. They were all rejected.  Certainly, we do not have the same vision of the public interest in this Parliament. I am opposed to that, once again.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The privatisation processes of EMEF, Empresa de Manutenção de Equipamento Ferroviário, S.A. and CP Carga, Logística e Transportes Ferroviários de Mercadorias, S.A., are an integral part of the liquidation process of the national railway sector and are also part of the privatization process that the Government is launching in the terminal phase of its mandate. The true origin of this process dates back to successive railway packages and successive attempts to impose the liberalisation of the railway sector on the States and peoples of the European Union.  These decisions are in front of the Portuguese Constitution itself and are part of a process that affronts this Constitution in broader terms. It is recalled that the Constitution points, as fundamental economic tasks, to the 'Coexistence of the public sector, the private sector and the cooperative and social sector owned by the means of production' and to 'Public ownership of natural resources and means of production, in accordance with the collective interest'. It is once again confirmed that the European Union is involved in a process of effective destruction of the public sector in order to favour the large private interests.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it recognises the rail supply industry as a key industry for Europe’s competitiveness and capacity for innovation. It urges that measures be taken to ensure that Europe maintains a technological and innovative advantage in this sector. The resolution also asks the Commission to fully mobilise the various EU funding instruments and to explore and exploit additional sources of financing for Shift2Rail (S2R) and to seek for synergies between different EU funds and with private investments.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution for very obvious reasons. As the document states, the rail supply industry (RSI) is not only an important part of the EU economy. It also accounts for 46% of the global RSI market. In addition, it is vital in achieving our COP21 commitments. However, in order to maintain its pole position, this market needs some thorough restructuring. Currently, administrative and technical fragmentation result in serious efficiency losses. Especially to SME’s, this can be problematic. They are an important part of the RSI market and need to remain so in the future. As this resolution points out, we need to defragment the railway market and look for efficiency gains through synergies and increased competitiveness. It calls for a unified EU railway market. In sum, this resolution calls for support to the RSI suppliers, in particular SMEs, through defragmentation of the market. This will attract private investment and finally increase our RSI’s competitiveness in the global theatre.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the competitiveness of the European railway industry, tabled by my colleague from the Socialist and Democratic Group, Martina Werner, met with my vote in favour. Investing in the rail sector today is a necessity from many points of view: we need to protect the one and a half million jobs that this sector generates, guarantee the right to efficient and integrated mobility for European citizens, and meet the challenge of climate change by reducing emissions from means of transport. I particularly welcome the fact that we are aiming for an integrated electronic ticketing system, so as to facilitate the movement of workers and tourists in Europe, and the fact that the rail sector is currently considered to be in a state of shortage of qualified staff, as an opportunity for young people in general in Europe.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Manufacturers of rolling stock and other materials necessary for the construction of railway infrastructure constitute an important part of the economy in all Member States. In many cases, they are extremely innovative companies with many employees. That is why it is so important to create a long-term development strategy for this industry so that it can play an important role in europe's reindustrialisation process.  The favourable economic situation is based in particular on a high level of investment in railway infrastructure, effectively supported by European funds. However, there are already serious risks on the horizon to the sustainability of production and, consequently, to the level of employment in this sector. The pressure on European producers by Asian companies, which receive significant public support and are gaining further foothold in the EU public procurement market thanks to low prices, is a huge challenge. An important challenge will be to change the financing model for investments in the next budgetary perspective, which will undoubtedly lead to a reduction in the amount of funds available to Member States. Investments will need to be more thoughtful, innovation-oriented and profit-making.  I agree with many of the demands made in this report, which diagnose well the challenges facing the rail supply industry. As a representative of the Kuyavia-Pomeranian Voivodeship, I particularly have at my heart the stable future of this sector, an important part of which is bydgoszcz PESA.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European railway industry plays a very important role in achieving the decarbonisation targets of the transport sector. Although it is a sector that still depends to a large extent on public investment, SMEs are central to the supply of railway equipment and technology, which are essential for the modernisation and efficiency of rail passenger and freight transport. However, it is necessary to recognise the danger posed by non-European companies financed by third countries, such as China, and to protect European companies from unfair competition by creating a market with a fair level playing field, preserving European industrial know-how in order to protect existing jobs and create new ones.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the competitiveness of the European railway equipment industry because I agree with the holistic and integrated vision it reflects and the request to the Commission to present a communication on the strategy for the reindustrialisation of Europe. The railway-associated industry is an excellent example of a sector that can and must be supported to adopt a new innovation agenda in industry 4.0. An agenda that combines the development of new products, services, models of organization and skills, involving universities, research centers, reference companies and networks of small and medium enterprises, start ups and spin offs. I support increased political support for the sector, including through its inclusion in the priorities for negotiating international trade treaties, encouraging investment and creating a collaborative context.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the Resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. The rail supply industry is essential for Europe's competitiveness, for mitigating climate change and in responding to other global phenomena such as urbanisation and demographic change. I therefore support the call on the Commission to come up with an EU industrial policy strategy aimed at reindustrialising Europe, based, inter alia, on sustainability, energy efficiency and resource efficiency.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: author. – Mr President, I will speak on behalf of Parliament’s Committee on Civil Liberties Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). Article 218 of the Lisbon Treaty strengthened Parliament’s role in the conclusion of international agreements, generalising the application of the consent procedure and providing that Parliament is to receive enhanced information in the process leading to the conclusion of an agreement. The Framework Agreement on relations between Parliament and the Commission details these provisions in paragraph 23 and 24 and, in particular, in Annex 3, as further confirmed by the rulings of the Court of Justice of the European Union, for example in case C-658/2011, Parliament v. Council. This case law has made clear that Parliament’s right to be informed is not limited to requests for information made just by Parliament, but obliges the other institutions to take the initiative. In September 2014, in the written answers to the questionnaire in the preparation of the hearing on the selection process for Commissioners, Commissioner Avramopoulos referred to his intention to keep the LIBE Committee fully informed on the negotiations on international agreements, according to the Treaty provisions and in line with the Framework Agreement.  The LIBE Committee welcomes the information it has received from the Commission services further to its request. However, we understand that the practical implementation of these Treaty provisions could be further improved, and this on the basis of Article 218(10). So under this framework, in this regard, the LIBE Committee asks the Commission to kindly reply to the following questions.  First, what measures does the Commission intend to take to fully live up to the Treaty provisions and the case law in order to improve the current system of informing Parliament on the negotiations of international agreements, thereby guaranteeing that the required information is automatically transmitted to Parliament in an exhaustive manner and this at all stages of the procedure?  Second, how does the Commission aim to ensure that the regular transmission of all relevant information on negotiations contains, at the minimum, indications as to the third country in question, the type of agreement, the stage of procedure and the relevant documents, such as those mentioned in point 5 of Annex 3 of the Framework Agreement? Is the Commission preparing to set up a permanent mechanism in order to strengthen Parliament’s role in this very crucial and sensitive area?  And lastly, in the particular case of concluded EU readmission agreements, how is the Commission planning to report to the LIBE Committee, which it should do at least twice a year as per the Commission declaration annexed to the European Parliament recommendation on the readmission agreement with Pakistan?

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by expressing my thanks to Ms Metsola and, through you, to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) for having given us the opportunity of this debate to reflect about how the European institutions, and particularly the Commission, can better inform the European Parliament about negotiations for international agreements. As you know, in the context of the new Inter-Institutional Agreement for Better Law-Making, Parliament, the Commission and the Council have made a commitment to meet within six months of the entry into force of the inter-institutional agreement, in order to negotiate improved practical arrangements for cooperation and information sharing. This trilateral approach reflects the fact that the obligation to inform Parliament fully and immediately falls on both the Commission and the Council, in accordance with their institutional roles. For example, it does not fall on the Commission to inform Parliament about decisions taken or texts adopted by Council. But let me reiterate the importance that we, in the Commission, attach to our obligations under the Treaty and to our existing commitment under the framework agreement: we are committed to providing Parliament with full and immediate information at all stages of negotiations for international agreements. The Commission stands by this commitment and monitors its implementation closely. The framework agreement established the practice that information concerning international agreements should, as a general rule, be provided to Parliament through the responsible Parliamentary committee. In line with this sector-specific approach, the Commission has instructed its services to arrange directly with the relevant Parliamentary committees the modalities for the provision of information and documents, to allow for optimal solutions in this area. The Commission believes that our obligations are, generally speaking, well respected and that Commissioners and their services are doing their part to ensure that Parliament is well informed. This includes the provision of confidential information and documents and the specific arrangements set out in the framework agreement. As regards specifically the work of the Civil Liberties Committee, Commission services have established a practice of providing regular updates to the committee on pending international agreement. Commission representatives have always been willing to come and give an update on ongoing international negotiations, either in camera or in a public meeting, as appropriate. Likewise, practical arrangements for informing Parliament about re-admission agreements have so far included regular presentations by senior Commission officials to the Civil Liberties Committee in ordinary meetings. The Commission is ready to provide such information whenever requested, be it in public or, when appropriate, in a restricted meeting. The Commission is also open to discussing with Parliament whether and how practice can be improved. I am looking forward to hearing your concrete proposals, which will fit into the trilateral approach that Parliament, the Council and the Commission, are to start soon.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in 2009 the Lisbon Treaty created the European Parliament we know today, although already since 2006 it had been progressively included in more and more negotiations and consultations on numerous important matters, such as the second Schengen information system for example. The point of retelling these public and well-known facts was simply to point out one rather simple matter: even though over the last decades all of the Union’s institutions have evolved and gained new powers and responsibilities, Parliament has undoubtedly evolved the most. Today it is by right amongst the top four EU institutions in terms of power, the others being the Commission, the Council of Ministers and the European Council. In fact, in a majority of cases when important decisions are concerned, Parliament has to agree to their implementation, not to mention that quite a few of them may get amended in the process as well. In this instance, it specifically applies to the conclusion of international agreements, something that the Lisbon Treaty has brought to the table. Moreover, not only does the Parliament in this respect possess the power of the consent procedure, it also has to be provided with comprehensive information on the process leading to the conclusion of an agreement in question, meaning that, even though Parliament can ask for specific information when such a need arises, it should be given to it of the other involved institutions’ own accord. In other words, I fully support the implementation of additional and the reinforcement of the currently existing measures aimed at a fully functional operation of the system, whose goal is to inform Parliament on the negotiation process of international agreements. It is, of course, fully understandable that, depending on each and every particular case, information may not be fully available for various reasons. However, the points mentioned in the debated oral question should indeed be a bare minimum. The third country in question, for example, the type of agreement discussed, the stage of the procedure and the relevant documents pertaining to the negotiations.  Parliament does not legally have the power of legislative initiative, something that sets it far apart from the national parliaments in our Member States. But then again, the European Union itself is not a federation or a single state, and Parliament is essentially still a consultative assembly. However, it is a consultative assembly with some very advanced powers unlike those of any other similar institutional body around the world, including the ability to ask the Commission to draft the necessary legislation. So, in this respect, Parliament even has a de facto power of legislative initiative. Committee and delegation hearings and non-binding resolutions have an indirect, albeit quite powerful, influence on the Union’s foreign policy. For example: approval of overseas development grants, EU enlargement etc., not to mention the non-binding quotes on new EU treaties, even without possessing the respective veto powers. All of this makes the Parliament an actor to be taken into utmost consideration. To put the overall idea a bit more simply, thanks to the enormous legitimacy gained through European elections directly from the EU citizens themselves, and due to the long-term constant expansions of various powers through the EU treaties, Parliament has the right to be constantly kept in the loop of essentially every EU-level and international development that concerns the European Union , which undoubtedly also includes information provision concerning negotiations on international agreements involving the EU.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – I congratulate the rapporteur first on the initiative and would like to discuss his proposed topics for debate. Thus, the Treaty of Lisbon strengthens Parliament's role in concluding international agreements, ensuring a more general application of Parliament's approval procedures and improved awareness during the process leading to an agreement. This is pursuant to Article 218(10) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  The case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union clearly shows that Parliament's right to be informed is not limited to requests for information made by Parliament, but obliges the institutions to take the initiative. Quite often, however, in practice Parliament's opinion is not taken when concluding international agreements, and this, in our view, by the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists is an outrageous disregard for the rights of the directly elected body, namely Parliament.  The last such case is the agreement with Turkey on migration, with all conditionality of the word "agreement". I am sure that all the colleagues present here today, however numerous, are aware of the facts surrounding this agreement, but I would nevertheless like to reiterate that, according to the official statements on 18 March this year, the members of the European Council and the Republic of Turkey, still the Republic of Turkey, signed a joint declaration on migration cooperation, which is formally a non-binding document , which provides, however, for precise mutual commitments of the parties from a political and budgetary point of view.  Here, the so-called " agreement is that this is a hidden international agreement which, according to Article 218(6) of the Treaty on European Union, should have been concluded only after express approval by the European Parliament. This, honourable Members, means that the draft agreement with Turkey had to be discussed here in this Chamber, to be presented to debates. First, for European representatives to decide whether to have such an agreement and then to discuss the specific texts of this agreement and not to be placed purely and simply as a witness, to a PR action that the European Commission, the Council of Europe and people who are not elected but purport to be European leaders. We are all aware that no such approval for the agreement in question has been granted. None of us have declared, delegated rights to the European Commission and the Council to conclude such PR-ski agreements.  The topic was raised for discussion in the Committee on Legal Affairs by colleagues from another political group, and representatives of the Legal Service of the European Parliament took part in the discussion. They expressed opinions that the agreement concluded, the so-called binding value, but they refuse to express in writing. That's very strange. They say there's an agreement, but it has no legal value, it's some KIND of PR message.  In itself, this claim is outrageous. It is outrageous because it recognises something that for a long time all of us European representatives suspected, namely that the self-proclaimed but unelected leaders of the European Union are doing, to put it mildly, shameful and outrageous deals behind the backs of European taxpayers. They agreed to pay a racketeering ransom of billions of euros - money out of the pocket of every European - to an outspoken dictator, such as Turkish President Erdogan, to save them from what they had done to themselves, namely the huge crisis caused by the immigrant wave invited by German Chancellor Merkel. This shameful and non-European deal with an aggressive, arrogant and dangerous dictator, as the current Turkish President Erdogan is no doubt, is trampling on all the so-called "no-go zones." european values. For us, there is nothing more shameful than talking about freedom of speech and aligning yourself with a dictator, as Erdogan is no doubt, who proves every day in practice, on TV, live, how freedom of speech is crushed, how edits are taken, how media are shut down, how journalists are judged, how to shoot journalists in a courtroom when they, these journalists, reveal a disgusting truth.  In order not to be nude, I will give an example of the attack on the editor of the newspaper "Jumhuriet" – this is a Turkish newspaper, and its editor is the man who revealed the simple, clear and expected of all the fact that the financing, arming, healing, training of Islamic State fighters is on the part of the Republic of Turkey. And that's why he was asked for a life sentence, and then shot at him in the courtroom. Another example – the takeover of the editorial board of Turkey's largest opposition newspaper, "Seman".  I believe that the examples I have set out are an illustrated example of the need for information on such agreements. As a co-legislator, Parliament must be informed of the all details and all stages of the procedures. I call on the Commission to honour its commitments. (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card issue. – Thank you, Mr Dzhambazki, for your question about the blue card. You have just said that there is a declaration from the political leadership of Turkey and the leadership of the European Union, but in reality the signature on the document that is legislative is not, does not exist, is simply a statement, a statement. So, then, what kind of supposedly signed declaration between Turkey and the European Union did you mention in your speech?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – I fully agree with you, dear colleague. That's my question, too. There is no agreement according to what the Legal Service of the European Parliament replied. There's no agreement. It's an application to the media, but there is no agreement that meets the norms, the rules, the international law for the conclusion of an agreement. That's the scandal. I totally agree with you here. (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, my colleague, not to mention the agreement, is this text negotiated between the European Union and Turkey, in your view, just an example of Realpolitik on the part of the European Union, or more than that?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. - That's my opinion, too. In my opinion, what has been reached between the European Council and Turkey cannot be called an agreement. And yes, maybe we can call it "real politics", but in my opinion, forgive me, you may not agree with me, but this is a rather stupid policy, because the European Parliament, the European Council has given way to turkey's real politics. Turkey benefits from this, we lose.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would point out to the Commissioner that more and more citizens are interested in international agreements: from trade to judicial cooperation agreements, to political declarations, and to the negotiations themselves. In my 12 years of working on international trade, I have never seen such active interest. We, the European Parliament, represent the people of Europe, and if we want to serve our citizens well we must be fully informed. Commissioner, the Treaties are very clear in this regard. The European Parliament shall be immediately and fully informed at all stages of international agreements. There are no conditional clauses in that sentence. As the guardian of the Treaties, the Commission must fulfil this requirement. Moreover, the framework agreement sets out clearly how this is to be done: Parliament must be informed by the Commission at the same time as the Council, before a mandate is given, during the negotiation and once an agreement is initialled or signed. Again, the wording in the framework agreement on this point is unconditional. It is a requirement. Yet, to this day, we seem to be treated as a second-class institution vis-à-vis the Council. Commissioner, Parliament must be treated on an equal footing with the Council. There can be no transparency if we learn of items only after the Council has voiced its opinions. The Commission’s agenda must not be set in accordance with the Council’s agenda alone. All that said, Commissioner, my Group also understands that this must be a two-way street: with greater transparency comes greater responsibility. Leaks, lies and mis-information can destroy the work of years in a single day. The European Parliament has rights but also obligations – and that too is clear in the framework agreement. We, as a Parliament, must respect the rules of secrecy of documents in order to preserve our mutual trust with the Commission, and respect their decisions on the level of secrecy attached to negotiation documents. My Group knows that rights come with responsibilities: responsible transparency means respecting the rules of the game. In particular, I would like to congratulate Commissioner Malmström on the excellent job she has done so far to push for, and lead, this transparency initiative in the area of trade. The reason I mention the transparency initiative in the trade sector is because I believe that this model could serve as an inspiration in other domains in which the EU negotiates with third countries. Let me give you another example: the recent deal that the Commission concluded with Turkey on the migration crisis. We all knew that it happened, when it happened and what the key points of it were. But the information was not complete: we were left with a lot of question marks, with information coming instead from the media. So I hope you will treat us as an equal partner in the coming years. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Diane JAMES
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Madam, for a very good presentation and some very laudable words. Your comments on the aspects of this whole debate were very worthwhile to listen to. But this important debate has been scheduled at the very end of this plenary session, here in Strasbourg in June 2016, and we have got less than 25 MEPs here in the Chamber to listen to what we have got to say.  So would you agree with me that we are right to raise the subject, but that in fact the European Council and Commission are not really interested in what we MEPs actually have to say and comment upon?

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: blue-card answer. – I think your question is not connected to what we are actually discussing here. My point here is to ask the Commission to treat this House, the European Parliament – which represents the people of Europe – to treat us on an equal footing, because I want to serve my citizens and in order to do so I need full information, but at the same time as the Council.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, secrecy, opacity, lack of transparency: that is the policy of the European Union's international agreements, because what it wants to hide is the lack of democracy, an imperialist agenda politically and economically. That is why this Parliament has had to battle every document, every note it has drawn from the Commission. For this reason, it has been necessary to use the courts to obtain what the Treaties have: Parliament's automatic and comprehensive access to all relevant information for the negotiations of the International Treaties of the European Union. It is not surprising that this judicialization is necessary: we have become tired in committees of inquiry as in LuxLeaks' of receiving papers with censored content, not to mention the resistance to us being able to know the ATCI documents. Even today, partially, biased and secretly, as if we do not have to answer to the European people what the European Union negotiates on their behalf. We need to learn from leaks and press releases of the European Union's collaboration with Morocco and the colonial exploitation of Western Sahara, the violation of refugee rights in Turkey, the delivery of our data to American agencies and the sale of our agriculture, industry and even labour standards through ACS, AECG or ATCI. The situation is particularly serious because Parliament is the only democratically elected European institution. It is obvious that the Treaties must be opened so that, in the affairs of European foreign policy, which combines neocolonial adventurism, subordination to NATO and service to economic oligopolies, it is Parliament that thinks and decides. But in those respects, such as trade agreements, where the right of consultation and decision is already recognised, how can the Commission justify that its current practices are transparent, if the information is fragmented and collects only the minutes of a party, preventing an overview of what is being negotiated, if it excludes certain committees of Members or uses confidentiality as subterfuge so that access is made only in secret rooms where most of the documents, when they are legible, bear the mark of 'confidential' to prevent the debate from moving to those we represent, which is nothing more than the European people? For us, therefore, the debate on transparency is not a purely technical debate. It is a debate about how the European Union has moved so far from democratic principles that its political activity does not withstand light and stenographers. While denied information, Parliament is turned to the means to ensure that, if there were negotiations, it would be to secure democracy, our social rights, our security, always respecting the popular will. If so, why don't we stay informed? How are we going to believe that geopolitical counterparties are not discussed when it is addressed to the revision of visas and tariffs? How are we going to believe that human rights are not the last of the considerations when discussing migrant and refugee agreements? How do you decide where to send our ships and our weapons to protect multinational interests and not global peace? Who is pushing to make the most of each and every trade agreement born in Brussels, the spearhead of the dismantling of Europe's own social model? Who has the most voice? The employer, her experts? Don't experts have ideology? Or is it that the interests of large countries, including the United States, have more voice than the 751 MEPs in this House in preparing meetings and external lines of action?  If not, do not be afraid, open your doors, your documents, regularly and without cutters, and allow access to parliamentary teams to all, absolutely all the information, although I am afraid that what you will show is the degradation of the European project against the rights of workers and peoples, in the world and in Europe itself.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, as part of the United Kingdom Brexit deliberations three  critical aspects have been highlighted and they are as follows: European Union decision making and the lack of democracy; secondly, the influence and clout of MEPs in European Union decision making; and thirdly European Union scrutiny of its own processes and procedures. How apt it is that this debate brings into sharp focus all three of those!  Now we know that this debate stems from a LIBE question, from the LIBE Committee, and it is essentially a question to the Commission on the right to be informed appropriately when the European Union is negotiating international arrangements and agreements. The question asks whether the Commission will provide, at the very least, indications as to the third country in question, the type of agreement, the stage of the procedure and the relevant documents to Parliament – to this Chamber! It should be of immediate concern to European Union citizens that this is not already the case.  Let me cite the example of my colleague Stuart Agnew who happens also to be an agricultural spokesperson. On Monday 12 October 2015 he viewed the recently published, restricted, agricultural chapter of the trade TTIP document. He had to sign a document stating that he would not disclose what he read, he had to hand over electronic gadgets and cameras, he was only allowed a pen, no paper, he was in a windowless cell and he was issued with special blank paper which could not be photocopied. He was even told that if he disclosed what he had read he would be punished, penalised with a fine and also at the mercy of punishment from Mr Schulz, the President of this Chamber.  If that is what defines the European Union’s definition of transparency and openness on this critical issue of negotiations on international agreements, then quite frankly not only is that a farce, it is unacceptable.  Then we have the case of another MEP, Mr Ming Flanagan. He also visited the TTIP chamber. He also highlighted what was wrong, and he got an email back from Mr Bernd Lange, a fellow MEP, who seem to think ‘that these confidential documents can be consulted on the premises of the European Parliament has been a great achievement for this institution’ and enabled us MEPs to better exert our role of parliamentary scrutiny in negotiations.  Well I do not agree with what Mr. Lange says, and quite frankly for him to even state that when it is quite patently the opposite is just bizarre. Now it is absolutely farcical what we are faced with, but let’s be serious just for a moment. All too often the European Union raises the red flag and condemns secrecy, breaches of openness and transparency elsewhere in the world. Yet here is the European Union saying one thing but adopting the complete opposite in its own backyard, and actually keeping or restricting any information to MEPs. Quite clearly the messages should be from us to the Commission to the Council: Put your own house in order, abide by the transparency that you expect, demand and even dictate from others, but finally restore democracy within this organisation and stop the secrecy and withholding of vital information to which we are entitled, which we are entitled to communicate to our voters , and to which our European Union citizens should be entitled.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you are and I am very concerned about Parliament's information rights by the Commission. The veracity of the information, the cross-checking of the sources are the conditions for an informed judgment. Cross-referencing of sources is absolutely necessary for parliamentary work. In fact, as early as 1986, I had supported the plan of our intelligence officials to set up a school of economic warfare, because war today is often economic and it involves the manipulation of information, and this, when I was in the office of the President of the National Assembly. I also think that the work of parliamentary inquiry is fundamental, because we are constantly trying to manipulate us, to manipulate the representatives of sovereignty. I must tell you, however, that the experience of two years in this Parliament makes me doubt our sincerity in the search for the truth. I am not talking about the Commission, it is under the influence, as the work of our investigative journalists in their book Circus politicus, which has also received the international press prize, has shown. This Commission manipulates us with false information from the propaganda of States, commissioners linked to hidden circles of interest that are not European. This propaganda is shameless, scandalous, conducted by disinformation agencies presented as emanations of civil society or by these secret societies working for foreign lobbies. There is sufficient precision in the investigative work done by journalists. I am talking about our Parliament, how we accept the information given, and also have an intelligence eye on the information that is provided to us. We are quantitatively more than well informed but, qualitatively, are we really informed? I'm asking you the question. Our external services, for example, do not work with sources, do not overlap with the intelligence work done by our states. On the other hand, in France, for example, there is a real work that irrigates the national parliament. There is no such work here. Parliament is the place of amplification of propaganda, of the false voice, so-called official. We write reports, we organize meetings, often in all directions, but in the same tone and with the same people, in the same ideological approach. It is not a scientific approach. Our experts, so-called independents, are chosen from the same mainstream of single thinking formatted in the world of fiction versus reality. In doing so, we distill, under the guise of analysis, propaganda and ideology which, once transformed into decisions, explain the harmfulness of Parliament's action which continues the path of lies.  Let us go back to the Commission, it has always been on the side of the policy of chaos propagated by the United States, and this without acknowledging its mistakes which, even today, the American executive acknowledges.  During the war in Iraq, the Commission, and especially its leader, was the faithful relay, the worst amplifier of the United States, and the saboteur of the peace policy initiated by France and Germany. And on the Parliament side, it was no better. I had met President Brok at the time, at the request of France; he was in favour of this Paris-Berlin-Moscow axis, but American policy was followed by Parliament.  In Libya, the Commission and Parliament applauded the fall of a critical but stable regime. Here too, a dictator, and peace, education, health, exemplary for an African country. Today, 50 dictators, war and chaos... In Syria, the same.  In the Middle East, the Commission and Parliament succeed in the feat of being both hostile to the only democracy in the area - I am talking about Israel - while making sweet eyes at the Gulf States which infuse the poison of radical Islam into our cities. In the Balkans, in Ukraine, in the post-Soviet space, the Commission and this Parliament are still pursuing this same policy and are NATO's faithful allies against the interests of the Member States.  This widening without contours or borders raises walls everywhere instead of building bridges between western and eastern Europe, making our continent, not the tip of Eurasia, but an advanced, instrumentalized and vassalized bridge of America.  The Commission has a policy that is harmful, by its information, to our strategic interests. Its choices have always sought to promote free trade and finance at the expense of long-term development in independent and sovereign strategic investment.  I could cite many more examples, but I will not have the time. I just want to tell you an essential point. Europe political arose during the Muslim invasion. This is the first time in history that we have talked about political Europe.  So, gentlemen, you are in favour today of this Muslim invasion programmed by foreign lobbies, as I have shown by the study that was provided to all parliamentarians, presented this week and which was done by the School of Economic Warfare.  If a political Europe is to survive, it will happen without the Commission, and this Parliament will have to be the emanation of national parliaments.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).)

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: question posed by raising the blue card. - Thank you, colleague, for accepting my question. I'll ask quite simply. If you care so much about information and when you are fighting propaganda so hard, could you tell us what it was like with a €10 million loan to your party, the Front National, because we should also be sure if you speak for your citizens of France or are you acting in russia's mercenary?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: "blue card" answer. My dear colleagues, I will very easily respond. This propaganda has been, in fact, to ensure that all the European banks, all the banks of the European Union to which we have asked for help to finance our election campaigns refuse all our demands, which shows that there is a will to destroy the first opposition party in France today. Unfortunately, we had no alternative but to use abroad; it was Russia, it could have been China or some other external power. What you're denouncing is evidence of manipulation.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will return to the subject. Last June, my PPE colleague Mariya Gabriel initiated a question to the Commission concerning the negotiations on the abolition of the visa requirement for short stays for third states. First of all, I would like to thank Maria Gabriel for this question, because I fully support her and consider her to be very important. After all, in 2014 only 19 of the third countries applied to be added to the list of countries exempt from visa requirements vis-à-vis the European Union. And that number could rise in the future. However, the European Commission, which is responsible for negotiating these agreements, is not alone in monitoring and ultimately approving this process. It is also Parliament that has the power under the Treaty of Lisbon to approve international agreements. And there are several reasons. The main one is the importance of these bilateral agreements and their benefits – strengthening the international market and facilitating investment for both partners. However, we are constantly fighting two procedural problems throughout the process of approving international agreements.  The first is the fact that we Members of the European Parliament have a lack of information on their very content, course and timetable. This is the case for the European Commission, which, however, does not adequately inform the European Parliament. While the European Parliament has the right to obtain information when it requests it. At the same time, however, all other institutions, including the European Commission, have a duty to transmit any information on their own initiative. This is, after all, why Mr Avramopoulos made a commitment to this during public hearings. Unfortunately, after almost two years, I have to say that mutual information does not work. I consider it essential that the European Commission establish a mechanism to ensure the regular transmission of information on ongoing or planned negotiations. We often lack basic information, such as country indication, type of agreement, course of procedure or relevant documents. There is no doubt that, without such data, the European Parliament is unable to strengthen its role in the conclusion of international agreements.  The second problem, Commissioner, which I want to mention here, is the cases of the conclusion of European Union readmission agreements. To this day, there is no system in practice for the European Commission to inform the LIBE Committee of which I am a member of of these agreements in a timely and proper manner. This is despite the fact that this exchange should take place at least twice a year. In my opinion, as in the opinion of my colleagues, the European Commission must address these shortcomings as soon as possible.  Commissioner, it is only through the systematic and more consistent cooperation between the Commission and Parliament that you committed to in your introductory speech that it is possible to reap the benefits that international agreements undoubtedly bring. This is not only because cooperation with third countries is strengthened, but also through benefits for members and citizens of the European Union.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by congratulating the Committee on Civil Liberties Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and its chair, Labour MEP, Claude Moraes, for taking the initiative to raise this important question. But this question goes beyond the concerns of the LIBE Committee, particularly about readmission agreements. As a member of the Committee on International Trade (INTA), I know how crucial access information is. This is a fundamental prerequisite for us to be able to carry out parliamentary scrutiny, which in turn is our main tool to ensure the legitimacy of the EU’s external action and, in particular, its trade policy.  Ultimately, we need to regain the public’s trust, and this starts with upholding the highest level of transparency, not just towards the general public, but also, crucially, towards us as their representatives in the European Parliament. Certainly, as a former trade unionist, I can see – and I think the vast majority of the public would understand – that some discretion is needed in any negotiation, and that it would be detrimental to disclose certain documents when it is clear that such a disclosure could seriously weaken the EU’s negotiating position. But most people would also assume that discretion should not prevent proper parliamentary scrutiny and that MEPs should have access to all confidential information even when the general public does not.  Sadly, this is not the reality today. The frequent complaints raised by MEPs  – and we have heard them today – and national and regional parliamentarians, that they are being kept in the dark when it comes to negotiations on TTIP, TISA or CETA, are not helping to shift the public perception over what is seen as a series of secretive negotiations. This is why we still have a problem with transparency on TTIP, even though in reality the TTIP negotiations are arguably among the most transparent trade negotiations ever conducted, certainly in the case of my Member State and definitely in the case of the EU. Stories in the media about how limited the access granted to MEPs in reading rooms is certainly does not help and I strongly believe that it would be in the interests of everyone to improve the situation. For instance, as the spokesperson on TTIP for my national delegation, I do not have access to consolidated documents or other restricted documents, even in the reading room. The group of MEPs allowed to see these documents, which include our partner countries’ positions, is extremely limited: less than 5% of all MEPs.  This is just one example of how narrowly the Treaty provisions aiming at ensuring the transparency of international agreements have been implemented by the Commission. This minimalistic approach by the Commission stands in stark contrast with European case law, which has always taken a much broader view of what this obligation to inform entails. It is therefore absolutely justified for Parliament to ask the Commission how it intends to fully comply with the Treaty and guarantee a regular and comprehensive flow of information on international agreements in all areas.  This is not to say that the Commission is the only culprit, and I think it is worth mentioning that we have many problems with the Council, and many problems in terms of transparency around the Council. Parliament could also do things better. For instance, MEPs are not allowed to take notes when consulting confidential documents in the reading room as a result of a decision in this House by Parliament’s Bureau. I very much hope that the Commission will seize this initiative as an opportunity to push its transparency agenda further. Transparency is at the heart of Commissioner Malmström’s ambition for EU trade policy in the 21st century, but it is now time to turn those words into concrete action so that we are able to fully fulfil our role, in terms of parliamentary scrutiny, towards the general public and our constituents.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Instead of having to have 27 countries agreeing to everything, to have such TTIP or any of these other treaties, would it not be better if just went ahead and did it ourselves? We could have trade treaties which are more akin to what the British people require and which our economy requires. We would be much better off having Brexit and be able to do these things ourselves. Surely, Madam, you must agree with me?

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: blue-card answer. Well Mr Coburn, I am sure that it will come as absolutely no surprise to you that I do not agree with you. I am campaigning very strongly for Britain to remain inside the EU; and that is primarily because we are stronger negotiating with our partners; we are stronger as one of 28 countries going and negotiating with billion-person countries, trillion-dollar economies around the world. The UK negotiating a deal with China or the US would be effectively accepting the terms of their deal and not pushing our interests. Within the EU, we are able to get a deal which is in the interests of British people and the whole of the European continent.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Mr Avraboule, the initiative of our Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties to put this question highlights the problems of opacity and lack of information that exist during the process of negotiating international treaties on behalf of the Commission and on behalf of the Union. Article 218 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union is clear and there are no misunderstandings, since it explicitly states that the European Parliament is immediately and fully informed at all stages of the negotiation process.
