Unfortunately, the Commission is not meeting this obligation, culminating in the negotiation process of the famous TT IP.  In the case of TTIR, the Commission followed forms of classical secret diplomacy and it was only after the general outcry of public opinion and the reactions of the European Parliament that information on TTI began, but with the eyedropper. It took the intervention of the European Ombudsman, who launched an investigation into the Commission, to commit Mrs. Malmström for transparency and information on TTP. Finally, following the leak of secret documents from the European Union-United States TTIR negotiations, the Commission was forced to change course and Mrs. Malmström made public statements. However, in relation to TTIR, the unacceptable and disparaging procedures for MEPs exist and continue to apply, as they are obliged to read the TTIR negotiating documents in an isolated area without a mobile phone, so as not to photograph the documents, without even paper, without a pencil, so as not to even take notes. In fact, I would like to inform you, Mr. Avramopoule, that the same is not true of the senators of the United States, who have full and unconditional access. At the same time, the assistants of the United States senators and 700 US experts have access to the TTIR documents. They informed us when we visited Washington as an ECR, and I have mentioned them here before, in the European Parliament.  We therefore call for full transparency for TTIR, because, as the leaked documents have shown, this agreement dissolves European agriculture, poses risks to public health by filling the European Union with mutants and supports the action of multinationals against states and small and medium-sized enterprises. Secret Diplomacy of the Metternich type, since the time of the Holy Alliance, is not accepted by the citizens, it is not accepted by the peoples. So transparency everywhere and everything!

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, we need a new interinstitutional agreement. This is absolutely clear to everyone here in this aula, but I also believe in all the institutions of the European Union and all the key people of the European Union. New times, Dear Mr. Commissioner. There are new times when citizens ask us and you for openness, they seek a different administration than the one we were all used to in the earlier decades. We need an open public administration that will allow me MEMBERS and therefore citizens of the European Union to be able to obtain quality, truthful and verified information at any time.  Everything else will not be good for the European Union. If we hide, it won't be good for the European Union. We have a lot of examples of that. I'll take TTIP. We know very well here, in this car, members primarily from the south of the European Union, that we will not vote for TTIP unless producers of agricultural products, protected agricultural products are protected. You, Mr. Commissioner, as a respectable man from Greece, know very well that Greek farmers cannot accept that feta cheese is produced in the United States, just as Italian gorgonzola producers or French roquefort producers cannot do, that I do not now enter into other agricultural products.  That's just one detail of one big treaty. We have a lot of agreements, a lot of details in every agreement and accept that we as Parliament, if nothing else a majority in this Parliament, will be your allies, to be allies with the Council because only in this way, through sincere dialogue between us, will we be able to successfully lead the European Union. Otherwise, it won't be good.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, openness and transparency by governing organisations is critical to voter trust and expectation. There is little or no openness and transparency here in the EU. With regard to international agreements, in the UK TTIP is now a major issue which worries all British citizens, as it will harm our National Health Service, and the National Health Service in Great Britain is the nearest thing to Shinto – it is practically a religion, it is inviolable. To see this treaty, Members this of this honourable House have to go to a windowless dungeon and sign a document that we will not disclose what we have read, and hand over all our electronic equipment, we are not given a pen or paper.  This is the EU’s definition of transparency. This affects our NHS, our agriculture and many other matters. The British members of this Parliament including myself have to sit on their hands while an unelected foreign Commissioner – or Commissar – takes decisions for us. The UK will be much better off creating its own treaties with the rest of the world, rather than having to allow 27 other nations to put their tuppence-worth in as well. It would be much better if we did it ourselves after Brexit. This Parliament thinks consulting documents in a dungeon is a great achievement for the EU. Well I’m sorry, this place looks more and more like the old Supreme Soviet – and it makes it look positively libertarian in comparison.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, the debate, while emotional at times, clearly shows one thing. This is probably the main message to the Commission, which is represented here by the Commissioner, that the European Parliament really wants to be a full-fledged player in the preparation of international agreements with third countries. And it is, in my opinion, right in view of how the legitimacy of the European Parliament has been strengthened since 1979, when Members are elected directly and when we, the MePs, represent 500 million European citizens. The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU has been cited here several times today as a fundamental document of primary law, which clearly states in Article 218 that the European Parliament is immediately and fully informed at all stages of this procedure, i.e. in the preparation of the adoption of Union agreements with third countries. I think, Commissioner, that it is clear from this that this information cannot be done solely on the initiative of Parliament, as you indicated a little in your contribution, because Parliament cannot always know at what stage the Commission's negotiations with a third country are at. It is difficult for us to see the experts and the Commission progressing through the various stages of the negotiations. I think, and in line with the procedure and the view of the European Court of Justice, that you should create some kind of permanent mechanism, after all, you have also already talked here about a permanent information mechanism that would ensure that the European Parliament, namely its competent committee and the members of this committee, is automatically informed and able to comment on this when we get to the next stage of negotiating an international agreement. Of course, the relationship is based on the right to be informed, on the other hand, we should stress here that the European Parliament subsequently gives its consent to the international agreement in question, and if the consent is not to be formal, but to be fully-fledged, if we are talking about the European Parliament as a key institution of the European Union with its legitimacy direct choice, then I think that in the course of the negotiations you should no longer just inform us , but you should also be interested to know what the view of MEPs – at least in the committee – is on the issue, if we agree on which direction the negotiations are going, if we agree at all with a certain type of international agreement. I think that this can prevent a blaming in the European Parliament one day, when there will simply be no agreement on a negotiated agreement, and that is because a majority of Members will not agree with it. So I am very appealing to you to really create a mechanism by which you will not only formally trigger Article 218, but which will really make the European Parliament a partner with the Commission and the Council in negotiating such agreements.  The subject of Turkey has been mentioned several times, and I will not speculate here and debate the degree of bindingness of this political proclamation, but I will be very up to date. Commissioner, there was debate in plenary on Wednesday about the European Commission's efforts to conclude agreements with the nine countries of Africa and the Middle East. I welcome the initiative, but since then I have had many questions in the mail from my constituents in the Czech Republic about what such agreements will look like. Will there also be visa-free travel, which is troubling us in the Czech Republic towards Turkey, or will it not? So, as an MP myself, I feel that citizens are interested in what will be in these agreements. I therefore ask the power, in the interests of the legitimacy of the European Parliament, to give us information in time so that we can vote in good conscience for possible agreements. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – You said you supported agreements with Turkey and other countries. Don't you think these agreements should be discussed here first, in this chamber, before they are voted on before they become agreements? Isn't that the order in the European Parliament's chamber if it is an elected body representing European citizens?

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Colleague, I agree with you, I have also just said that I would like these agreements, which have so far been mentioned in general by the Commission during Wednesday's debate, to take some more concrete form in order to debate them very matter-of-factly here, because I feel that this will be a strong and controversial subject for my constituents in the Czech Republic. So I agree with you.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, international agreements have in recent years become a central topic of debate within European societies. In fact, many European citizens have come to follow and take an interest in the negotiations of these agreements, seeking to inform themselves and know the arguments resolved, the advantages and disadvantages that may be involved. This is especially true for free trade agreements negotiated with third countries. These treaties have polarised the debate among citizens and have fuelled passionate disputes, many of them ideologically very motivated, which is natural and should even merit a positive appreciation. This makes the issue of access to information about the business process in its various stages particularly sensitive. Not by chance, one of the most controversial aspects, as we have seen here today in this debate, on the subject of international agreements, is that of transparency, which is much mentioned, for example, in the case of the discussion on the Transatlantic Treaty, which we are currently negotiating with the United States. In this context, the role of monitoring and scrutinising such agreements by the European Parliament is of great importance. However, the Treaty of Lisbon has not only strengthened these powers of monitoring and supervision, but has established that, in order to be able to perform this function well, Parliament must be duly informed of the progress of negotiations of such agreements. More than that, the Treaty of Lisbon stipulates that the European Parliament's right to information on negotiations is not limited to requests for information submitted by Parliament itself, but must also result from the initiative of other European institutions. That is why the question of institutional mechanisms for transmitting this information is of the utmost importance. And while it has been formalised by LIBE, it also concerns the AFET committee, which focuses on international agreements on the more general dimension of European foreign policy, and the Human Rights Commission, which focuses these agreements on safeguarding and promoting human rights. As president of the Delegation for relations with Mercosur, I have followed and have in mind the need for some degree of confidentiality in the negotiation of trade agreements. Nevertheless, the political action and even some diplomatic action that the European Parliament can take do not commend itself with sporadic information and excessively remote in time. It would therefore be very beneficial for the work, for example, of delegations, this delegation or others, for relations with third countries, in this case with the Mercosur countries, for the negotiators responsible to systematically and in a timely manner provide up-to-date information on the progress of the negotiations on the agreement between the EU and Mercosur, in order to give this concrete example. That's not what's currently going on. Contrary to what is stipulated in the Treaty of Lisbon and the regulated in the framework agreement on relations between the European Parliament and the European Commission, access to information remains dependent on an initiative of the delegation. I believe that the fundamental thing in this case is to ensure that, within the limits of common sense, of course, a regular information flow between the Commission and Parliament on such agreements, whether this is done by establishing a permanent mechanism or on the basis of institutional loyalty and respect for the provisions of the treaties and in the existing interinstitutional agreements.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Seán KELLY
text: blue-card question. – Actually I thought that Mr Assis’s speech was very good and balanced and that is why I am asking him a blue-card question. He was reasonable in regard to the disclosure of information in relation to TTIP, but he said you have to respect a certain amount of confidentiality. So what actually does he really want in terms of disclosure for us, as Members of Parliament, for the NGOs he mentioned, and for the public in general?

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Thank you very much, it is clear that some duty of confidentiality must be respected, it is not possible to negotiate any international treaty, particularly in the commercial component, in the public square. There's no memory that this ever happened. This would make it impossible to approve any treaty. But the truth is that we are living in another time, of greater demand for transparency, and I think, I am referring strictly to the European Parliament, that it is important that there are mechanisms that allow for a more constant and timely transmission of information in the way the negotiation of treaties is evolving. I, as I said, have been following the negotiation of a treaty specifically, which is the Treaty between the European Union and Mercosur, and I see that these mechanisms for the transmission of information need to be improved.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to start by appreciating your remark that there are not 25 of us here, but only 19. This subject is, I think, quite important, but unfortunately it did not attract the attention of even some political factions in this House on Thursday afternoon, which I find rather unfortunate. After all, even Mr Schaffhauser, as I can very well see, did not wait for the Commissioner's reply after his fiery speech, which I do not consider to be respectful or sufficiently respectful of the Commission's position.  However, on the subject itself. I, of course, fully agree with my colleagues that the Treaty of Lisbon constitutions Parliament's position in negotiating international agreements very clearly. I do not think that there is any condition for fulfilling the European Commission's own-initiative obligation, many colleagues have said so here, I will not repeat it.  On the other hand, I must admit that, in the course of negotiating certain international agreements, it is not possible to fully provide all the data, as my colleague Assis has also said, and I agree with his speech. I had the opportunity to speak to an American diplomat, and he smiled very much when he gave his opinion on the Commission's mandate – there is nothing better, he said, than knowing exactly how far the other side can go. Therefore, my position on informing the public about the progress of the negotiations is somewhat reserved, here I would not want to do too much wrong to the Commission. But what's certainly not acceptable is the lack of information about the outcome of the negotiations. There should be absolutely unequivocal full transparency. And I think that the Commission should also add a little in this regard, it should also accept the wording of the Court's judgments, which say ' you must proceed on your own initiative, you cannot wait only for Parliament's requests'.  In this respect, I would like to conclude my speech by asking: How does the Commission wish to respond to these complaints from the Court of Justice? What instruments does it prepare to play actively in its role when these agreements are concluded? I stress that I do not insist on parliament's absolute unconditional information during the negotiations.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, actually I have rather enjoyed this debate, even though there are not many here, but, in some respects, it is the essence of what we are about. It is about how we, the elected representatives and the Commission – called bureaucrats – communicate so that Europe can be better for all its citizens. When this Parliament was first established, I believe it was called a Mickey Mouse parliament, and that is why we have the Mickey Mouse star outside. I am not sure whether that is true or not, but definitely this Parliament initially had no powers, but they have evolved over a period of time. The Lisbon Treaty was very important in that regard – the Lisbon Treaty that took probably 10 years to negotiate and, of course, in my own country, took two referendums to pass. If it was not passed in our country, it could not come into being because it required unanimity.  As a result, there is an onus on us, as legislators because of the powers of codecision, to ensure that the Commission, in particular, is held to account. Over the years, that unfortunately does not seem to have been the position and as a result, sometimes incorrectly, impressions were given, right across Europe through the media, that everything bad was emanating from Brussels. Now you have a potential Brexit which, in many respects, is based on that erroneous assumption, but it was allowed to go unchallenged for years. There was nobody there to put the other side, and Parliament, because it lacked power and lacked information, was not in a position to actually put the other side. Thankfully, that is now beginning to change, hopefully not too late where the United Kingdom is concerned. I particularly welcome the new Commission, under President Juncker, who have made it very clear that they want to be more responsive, they want to cooperate more and they want to work with Parliament. Saying it is one thing, doing it is another and, as people have pointed out, especially I think in relation to Mercosur – Mr Assis referred to it and he was right in that regard – it actually took a debate and a vote here in Parliament to put a halt to some of the unsavoury aspects of that discussion. I think that is a great example of the need, in the interests of the European Union and everybody, for the Commission to constantly inform and to constantly consult Parliament regarding any international agreements. Hopefully that can work out well. TTIP has been mentioned, and actually today was probably the first time I heard a balanced account of the need for publicity, but also disclosure and transparency. Both sides of the House, especially on the left, did acknowledge that you cannot have negotiations in public. After all, you are negotiating with a third country. You can only disclose what they wish to disclose and of course also – and this is very important – what you might start out with as a negotiating position might finish up entirely different when you actually finish the discussions. What would happen in that regard, if every negotiating position was made public, is that the naysayers would have a field day because they would present that as a de facto position, so you could not really have a discussion at all. You would have no discussions and you would have no negotiations, because nobody would want to negotiate with you if you were going to be publishing everything. So I think we are gradually getting the balance right, and hopefully the Commission will do everything they can for more disclosure to inform Parliament constantly so that we can work together so that our citizens are informed that we are here for their good, both the Commission and Parliament.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you very much, Mr. Kelly, for accepting my blue card. I'd like to ask you exactly this at the end of what you were saying about TTIP. Do you agree with me that in fact more public information, more information about TTIP in public, even if it is positions, positions, would be better for the final success of negotiations than this way hidden, even from us MPs, in the complicated process of getting information?

name: Seán KELLY
text: blue-card answer. –That is a very good question and I agree completely. This is the point I was coming to. With Twitter, Facebook, all the TV channels and radio stations now, there is need for proper information and especially when wrong information is given out, we should insist that the correct information is given. In particular we should anticipate matters by actually feeding people with correct information before others actually give them the wrong information, which does huge damage, both to TTIP and many other aspects of the work of the European Union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Commissioner, I thank you for your openness to improving cooperation between the European Commission and the European Parliament. We have repeatedly heard today the demand that the European Parliament be fully and immediately informed of the negotiated agreements, as actually envisaged by the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, and this information is to be provided by the European Commission proactively, not on request. I would agree with the rationale for this request, as presented today by my colleague Jiří Pospisil, who fully captured the situation.  The main point is that the European Parliament has a great responsibility, we vote on some treaties and in some we have the power to consult. And citizens who elect us directly see us as those who have and must fulfill that responsibility. And if we do not want to disappoint them, if we want citizens to respect the decisions of the European Union as a whole, then that decision must be transparent. Commissioner, I would like to tell you that this is not only our request, but you can also see that the European Parliament is also taking more responsibility, and that should be an encouragement for you.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Mr. President, international agreements are a very important instrument of the overall policy of the European Union, because they strengthen economic cooperation, but also strengthen the role of the European Union in the world, in terms of strengthening democracy in the world and affecting crises, especially those that are particularly concerning the European Union. The Impact of the European Union on crises is much less than its economic and financial contribution in various countries, including various international organisations.  On the other hand, the role of the European Parliament is important, as it brings about a stronger democratic process and a stronger involvement of citizens and an understanding of citizens in what the European Parliament and the European institutions are doing, and this certainly increases the quality of international treaties. That is why, I fully support the LIBE Committee's initiative and, in particular, the creation of a permanent mechanism for the involvement of the European Parliament, not only in the adoption, in information, but in the involvement in the whole process, of more active participation in the conclusion of an international treaty. Mr. President, your football team has disintegrated. You have seven deputies here, you can barely put together a handball team without replacements.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to express my thanks to the seven remaining MEPs here, and, of course, to you. I feel very lonely tonight. But this issue is very important and I would like to remind all our colleagues here that at the hearing, a year and a half ago, I committed myself to work in order to enhance and deepen inter-institutional cooperation. I never forget that I am a parliamentarian myself, and the fact that I am from the other side does not mean that I do not share all these views expressed here today. This debate allows the Commission to understand better where Members of this House see the need for improving the information about negotiations for international agreements. First Vice-President Timmermans, as the Commissioner in charge of that, will represent the Commission in order to engage, together with the European Parliament and the Council, in a reflection on how to better implement Parliament’s rights, under the Treaty of course: the right to be fully and immediately informed at all stages of international negotiations.  But let me also remind you that the obligation to inform Parliament on international negotiations falls on both the Commission and the Council. Moreover, we cannot disregard or circumvent the need to protect confidential or classified information related to international obligations or interinstitutional agreements. I would like once again to thank you for your contribution to this debate, and for your attention, and to wish you a nice weekend.
